HEADLINE: Economic Scene;
Getting Prepared For One Germany

BYLINE: By Leonard Silk

 BODY:
MANY people's anxieties these days focus on the political and military dangers of German unification. Memories of the Third Reich do not fade.
But in a world in which economics is a crucial element in national and international power, attention must be paid to the economic consequences of the unified Germany that appears to be emerging, before the rest of the world is ready for it.
West Germany is already the strongest economy in Europe. The prospect of an even greater Germany, with the biggest population, the largest gross national product, the strongest balance of payments and the strongest currency in Europe, strikes other governments, West and East, as too big to swallow. 
Yet, after the pressures unleashed by the economic slide of the Communist bloc and the nationalistic forces released by the peaceful revolution in East Germany, unification looks unstoppable, whether sooner or a bit later. It therefore has become more important than ever for Germany to be closely linked to the European Community and to remain within the only European body in which the United States still plays the leading role, the North Atlantic Treaty Organization.
Chancellor Helmut Kohl of West Germany, caught up this week in the enthusiasm of the crowds in East Germany who chanted ''Deutschland, Deutschland!'' declared, ''My goal, if the hour of history allows it, is the unity of the nation.'' Yet while proclaiming that the two Germanys are on the difficult path to forging a single state, he urged East Germans to take account of the views and interests of their neighbors.
The strongest resistance to a united Germany is likely to come not from President Francois Mitterrand of France or Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher of Britain or President Bush but from the Soviet President, Mikhail S. Gorbachev. He has been declaring that the Soviet Union paid 20 million lives for the current stability of the West.
But must German unification necessarily disrupt stability? ''Much depends on the process of change,'' a leading European specialist, Ivo Lederer of the Stanford Research Institute, said in an interview. ''If other countries criticize or try to impede the process, the Germans are likely to dig in their heels, and nationalism will gain support.'' If the process can be conducted intelligently and slowly, and if the Germans make clear that they intend to remain members of the Western team, he contended, a united Germany could lend economic and political strength to the West.
The main hope for preventing unification pressures from wrecking the European Community and the Atlantic alliance, or from reviving antagonisms between the West and the Soviet Union, would be for West Germany, backed by its allies, to provide economic help to East Germany and other Eastern European states.
Apart from government aid, what is needed is the creation of an environment that will encourage private businesses to invest in the East and ease technology transfer and economic development of those Communist, or formerly Communist, countries willing to cooperate in a new version of the Marshall Plan. That could include the Soviet Union itself. Probably the most important aspect of the Marshall Plan was the thrust it gave to national improvements in organization and productivity, and the revival of business investment and trade.
The forces of a perfervid nationalism of the right were growing again in West Germany even before the revolution in East Germany erupted. Now, with the prospect of reunification nearer, German nationalism has inevitably been given new impetus.
If the East Germans, having lived so long under the yoke of their Communist masters, should freely choose to change their economic and political system, the problem of German unification will in time solve itself. Immediately, however, the issue of national sovereignty could be too menacing for the European Community and other countries to handle. Chancellor Kohl appeared to get it right when he said in Dresden this week, ''With common sense and moderation and a sense for realities, we can reach our goal.''
A critical test will come on May 7, when parliamentary elections will be held in East Germany. If the result should be a mandate for immediate unification, the Western alliance and the detente with the Soviet Union could suffer a serious blow. The United States, now preoccupied with Panama, might not be paying sufficient attention to the heightened German problem.
A healthy economic and political outcome in Europe will primarily be up to the Europeans, and especially to rational and cautious leadership in both East and West Germany. The United States can best back that play by holding to an open trade policy and by working within NATO for a reassessment of the threat from the East and a consequent reduction in military expenditures that would aid economic stability and growth. That would help provide the resources, and the will, for a new Marshall Plan.

HEADLINE: Spending Rises 0.7%; Income Up

BYLINE: AP

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Dec. 21

 BODY:
Consumer spending rebounded in November from a sharp fall in the previous month, while personal incomes increased eight-tenths of 1 percent.
The Commerce Department said today that consumer spending rose at a seasonally adjusted annual rate to $3.54 trillion, a seven-tenths of 1 percent increase that was the steepest gain since a 1 percent jump last March. In October, consumer spending had fallen two-tenths of 1 percent, the first decrease since a one-tenth of 1 percent dip in September 1988 and the largest drop since a 1.4 percent fall in January 1987. 
Analysts said consumer spending continues to be one of the bright spots in a slowing economy.
 
'Consumer Has Not Turned Off'
''It suggests that while we have some weak areas in the economy, particularly in the manufacturing sector, that the consumer has not turned off completely,'' said David Jones, an economist with Aubrey G. Lanston & Company in New York.
But some analysts questioned whether income growth will soon begin to weaken and thus cause a decline in spending.
Consumer spending, which has been a major factor for the economic growth during the first nine months of the year, is watched closely as a barometer of economic health because it accounts for about two-thirds of the nation's economic activity.
The Commerce Department reported last week that retail sales rose eight-tenths of 1 percent in November, a rebound from a 1.3 percent decrease in October. Analysts said it reflected the start of the Christmas buying season the weekend after Thanksgiving.
As measured by the gross national product, the economy grew at a 3 percent rate in the third quarter after gains of 3.7 percent in the first and 2.5 percent in the second, but analysts expect a sharp decline in the three-month period ending Dec. 31.
Mr. Jones said prospects are good for continued consumer spending, ''particularly in nondurables such as apparel, and in the services area because consumers are still basically optimistic and have income growth to support that optimism.''
Personal incomes in November totaled $4.54 trillion at a seasonally adjusted annual rate, following a similar eight-tenths of 1 percent gain, to $4.50 trillion, in October. It was the largest increase since a 1 percent gain last March.
The $26.2 billion increase in personal consumption, which includes everything except interest payments on debt, contrasted to a $6.3 billion decrease in October.
 
Nondurable Purchases Up
Purchases of durable goods - big-ticket items expected to last more than three years - rose $1.9 billion, while purchases of nondurable goods jumped $12.4 billion. Spending on services increased $11.9 billion.
The November report showed that Americans' incomes after taxes rose nine-tenths of 1 percent, up from October's eight-tenths of 1 percent gain.
Americans' savings rate - savings as a percent of disposable income -rose to 6.1 percent, up from October's 5.7 percent rate.
The key component of the income category, wages and salaries, edged up $1.7 billion in November after a $29.4 billion gain in October.
Payrolls at manufacturing companies, hit hardest by the Federal Reserve's high-interest polices, fell $4.9 billion, after an October advance of $6.3 billion.

HEADLINE: Slower Growth Seen In Industrialized World

BYLINE: By STEVEN GREENHOUSE, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: PARIS, Dec. 21

 BODY:
The Organization for Economic Cooperation and Development today projected that growth in the industrial world would slow next year while inflation would inch up slightly.
In its semiannual forecast, the Paris-based group noted that the industrial world had grown at a strong 4 percent pace for more than two years. But it said that growth had started to slow, and would continue slowing next year, because of restrictive economic policies, weakening trade with the third world and a slowdown in investment. 
The O.E.C.D. projected that the United States economy would grow by a modest 2.3 percent next year, compared with the 3 percent rate it expects this year. Last year, the American economy grew by 4.4 percent.
The group said unemployment could stop falling as a result of the slowdown in growth. It prediced that the American jobless rate would rise to 5.4 percent next year from 5.2 percent this year.
The group said inflation in the United States would inch up to 4.4 percent next year, compared with 4.3 percent this year. Although it praised many governments for tightening monetary policies to battle inflation, it predicted that prices would rise by 5 percent or more next year in Canada, Britain and Italy.
 
Price 'Drift' Feared
''Even if inflation has stabilized, and at a lower rate than some observers had feared, it is high enough to be of concern,'' the O.E.C.D. said. Its economists expressed fear that acceptance of a high inflation rate would lead to a ''cumulative upward drift'' in prices.
The O.E.C.D. group projected a worsening, rather than improvement, in trade imbalances among the leading industrial nations. While it saw a slight narrowing of the American trade defcit next year, to $118.1 billion, from $121.5 billion this year, it saw the Japanese and German surpluses widening. It said Japan's trade surplus would rise from $60.8 billion this year to $61.1 billion next year and $68.6 billion in 1991.
As for West Germany, that nation's trade surplus is expected to jump from $60.9 billion this year to $70.8 billion next year and $75.7 billion in 1991.
The organization questioned whether these imbalances were sustainable. Regarding nations with chronic trade deficits, which include the United States, Britain and Spain, it said what was needed was a set of policies that addressed the underlying problems of national savings and competitivess.
Founded in 1960, the O.E.C.D. is an organization of 24 industrial nations that seeks to promote economic growth and cooperation.

HEADLINE: Company News;
Caterpillar's Stock Declines

BYLINE: Reuters

DATELINE: PEORIA, Ill., Dec. 21

 BODY:
Caterpillar Inc.'s stock fell sharply today after the heavy-equipment maker lowered its outlook for the fourth quarter, blaming sluggish economic growth for depressing its sales, especially in the construction industry. 
Caterpillar's stock fell $1.75, to $57.75, in active New York Stock Exchange trading.
The Peoria, Ill., company said its fourth-quarter profit would likely be less than the $1.07 a share reported in the third quarter. In the 1988 fourth quarter, Caterpillar posted earnings of $1.61 a share. Analysts lowered their estimates for this year's final quarter to between 75 and 90 cents a share.
They said the weak sales follow sluggish demand for commercial, industrial and construction equipment, which last year accounted for 29 percent of Caterpillar's sales.

HEADLINE: Stocks Gain; Dow Rises 3.20 Points

BYLINE: By RICHARD D. HYLTON

 BODY:
Stock prices were slightly higher yesterday, as advances of blue chips helped to pull up smaller stocks.
The Dow Jones industrial average edged up 3.20 points, to 2,691.13, as advancing issues on the New York Stock Exchange outstripped declining ones by 932 to 627. Volume was a low 175 million.
''We're really talking about a market that's struggling,'' said Hugh Johnson, chief investment officer of the First Albany Corporation. ''What's happening is there is legitimate concern about the state of the economy.'' 
Mr. Johnson added that the market responded soberly to a move toward lower rates by the Federal Reserve on Wednesday because investors and traders were looking for a stronger action by the central bank.
''We did get a response from the Fed,'' Mr. Johnson said. ''They gave us a modest response to the slowing economic numbers, and I think there is some nervousness that we might not see any more. The consensus on Wall Street is that the Fed has gone as far as it's going for now.''
Among advancing blue chips, I.B.M. was up 1/2, to 95 1/8; American Express 3/8, to 31 5/8; General Electric 1/2, to 62 7/8, and General Motors 7/8, 42 3/8.
 
Disney Regains Ground
The Walt Disney Company, reversing some of the Wednesday's losses, climbed 2 1/4, to 114 1/4. Some analysts called Wednesday's decline, which was attributed to profit taking, excessive.
Technology issues made up some more of the ground they have been losing in recent weeks. Apple Computer was up 1/2, to 36 1/4; Digital Equipment Corp. gained 1/2 to end at 84; Compaq Computer gained 2 to end at 81 7/8, and Intel Corporation moved up 1 7/8, to 33 3/8.
Shares of the Campbell Soup Company rose 2 7/8, to 56 3/4, on more rumors of that the company would be the subject of a buyout because of the liquidation of a Dorrance family trust. Members of the Dorrance family, which founded the company, have maintained, however, that they want the company to remain independent.
Bank of New England slipped 1/4, to 7 1/2, after Duff & Phelps Inc. said it had lowered its ratings of the bank's securities.
Federal National Mortgage Association, known as Fannie Mae, continuing its recent rebound, moved up 1/8, to 34 1/2.
Caterpillar fell 1 7/8, to 57 5/8, after James McGann, an analyst with Drexel Burnham Lambert, lowered his 1989 earnings estimates for the company. Caterpillar announced that fourth-quarter earnings would be below third-quarter levels.
 
Some Utilities Off
The Boston Edison Company lost 1 1/2, to 20 1/8, after announcing write-offs of about $170 million and a dividend cut.
Commonwealth Edison fell 2 5/8, to 36 7/8, after a consumer group asked the Illinois utility regulators to cut the company's rates and refund $270 million plus interest to customers.
Stride-Rite Corporation, which moved up 3 3/8, to 26 7/8, made up some of the ground it lost on Wednesday after it announced estimates of flat fourth-quarter earnings.
The Dow transportation average also moved up, with a strong gain of 6.93 points to end at 1143.67. UAL Corporation, the parent company of United Airlines, gained 1 to end at 158, on continued buyout speculation. Delta Air Lines advanced 1 3/4, to 67 1/4, after announcing that the airline would match the fare cuts by Southwest Airlines earlier this week.
Broader market indexes also made small gains. The Standard & Poor's index of 500 stocks moved up 1.94, to 344.78, while the New York Stock Exchange composite index advanced 0.96, to 190.50.
On the American Stock Exchange the market value index registered a gain of 1.37 to bring it to 369.55.
The Nasdaq composite index gained 4.15 points, to 441.09, with technology issues again leading the list of most actively traded over-the-counter stocks.

HEADLINE: CURRENCY MARKETS;
Moderate Drop for Dollar On Sign of Action By Fed

BYLINE: By The Associated Press

 BODY:
The dollar declined modestly against most major currencies in quiet trading yesterday, tipped lower by renewed anticipation of lower interest rates.
Gold prices also slipped. On the Commodity Exchange in New York, gold for current delivery closed at $411.90 an ounce, down from $413.60 late Wednesday.
Dealers said currency traders shrugged off the United States military action in Panama.
''The market viewed it as a very short-lived situation,'' said Stephen Flanagan, a vice president of foreign exchange at the Manufacturers Hanover Trust Company. ''Interest rates seem to be dominating the market right now.''
On Wednesday, the Federal Reserve appeared to signal an easing of its monetary policy when it added reserves to the banking system. The action helped push down the Federal funds rate, a important barometer of interest rates.
Economists have expected the central bank to ease monetary policy to stimulate the sagging economy. At the same time, a drop in interest rates cuts yields on dollar-denominated investments.
By the end of trading in New York, the dollar had slipped to 143.65 yen, down from 143.93 yen late Wednesday. And a pound cost $1.6145, more expensive than $1.6060 late Wednesday.
Other late dollar rates in New York, compared with late Wednesday's rates, included: 1.7260 West German marks, down from 1.7320; 5.8900 French francs, down from 5.9125; 1.5580 Swiss francs, up from 1.5555; 1,285.50 Italian lire, down from 1,288.50, and 1.1597 Canadian dollars, down from 1.1609.
On the Commodity Exchange, silver for current delivery closed at $5.543 an ounce, down from $5.548 late Wednesday.

HEADLINE: Neighborhoods Santa Has No Trouble Finding

BYLINE: By ANDREW L. YARROW

 BODY:
UNADORNED homes are rare commodities around Christmastime in Bay Ridge, Bensonhurst and Canarsie. With thousands of plastic Santas and snowmen, armies of toy soldiers and multicolored megawatts of lights decorating block upon block of houses and apartment buildings, no one could accuse these Brooklyn neighborhoods of a lack of holiday cheer.
Indeed, no other areas of New York City have such an abundance of private outdoor Christmas lights and decorations as these heavily Italian-American communities. These seasonal displays - which tread a fine line between folk art and festivity -range from simple garlands of lights on a front porch or miniature Nativity scenes to expensive, Disneyesque yards full of animated Santas, elves and reindeer. 
''There's a very innocent, the-more-the-merrier attitude about the lights and plastic decor,'' said Lou Singer, an independent tour guide who is conducting a Christmas Lights bus tour every night through Jan. 4. ''As you go from Canarsie to the Dyker Heights section of Bay Ridge, the economic levels change, as do ideas of what constitutes beauty. Canarsie, which is a working-class area, is heavily plastic and very kitschy. In Bensonhurst, which has a lot of blue-collar and civil-service people, the displays are moderately kitschy, with some clever items. And in Dyker Heights, which is well to do, you really have designer lighting.''
The six-hour tour - which Mr. Singer added five years ago to his already offbeat repertory of guided excursions - seems ideally suited to this 64-year-old raconteur about all things relating to Brooklyn. It begins at 5:30 P.M. at 325 East 41st Street in Manhattan, and proceeds first to Brighton Beach for a pre-lights Russian dinner at Primorski's restaurant. Then, after a quick foray into M & I International Food - a two-story market catering to the area's large Russian emigre population -Mr. Singer guides his mini-bus toward Canarsie.
Just off Rockaway Parkway near Flatlands Avenue, the show begins. Normally nondescript bungalows near Avenues J, K, L and M shimmer with red and white lights, as a melange of religious and secular symbols dot the small front yards. Driving past a house at Flatlands and 93d Street, with an animated Santa and what he called a ''rather big outburst'' of lights, Mr. Singer suggested that ''Con Edison probably gives them a medal.''
The most elaborate display, however, appears as Mr. Singer navigates through blocks of brick row houses and two-family homes in Bensonhurst. Just when it seems as though one had seen every imaginable variation on the Christmas-lights theme, the bus pulls up to the house of the Bruncati and di Martino families on 28th Avenue between Cropsey and Harway Avenues. A series of animated, glass-enclosed dioramas in the yard includes a herd of eight nodding reindeer, a quartet of plastic carolers, a brigade of busy elves, and an upside-down Santa haplessly attempting to descend a too-snug chimney.
''My uncle started it 31 years ago, and it's been getting bigger each year,'' said Joseph di Martino, who spends three months preparing the display each year. ''I've got about $42,000 sitting in the yard. There are 61 figures and 12,000 lightbulbs, and the electric bill for December is about $370. My father says it's gotten out of control, but it's my gift to the neighborhood.''
 
It Seemes to Start With One
Surveying Brooklyn's sparkling displays, Mr. Singer said, ''My guess is that, on a block, one person starts it and the others try to outdo him.''
That certainly seems to be the case in the vicinity of 11th and 12th Avenues, between 79th and 86th Streets, in Dyker Heights. Here, the big brick homes look like over-sized gingerbread houses dripping with lights.
The rather free-form tour concludes with a visit to an Italian pastry shop in Bensonhurst and a late-night stop at the Brooklyn Heights promenade for a view of another forest of lights - the skyline of lower Manhattan.
The tour costs $25, plus $16 for the dinner, which is optional. Up to 29 people can be accommodated. Reservations: (718) 875-9084.

HEADLINE: A vinyl sculpture by Betty Collings at the Bertha Urdang Gallery.Reviews/Art;
Could It Be the 70's Again? An Artist Looks Back.

BYLINE: By ROBERTA SMITH

 BODY:
Betty Collings's new work is a kind of contradiction. Her colorful vinyl sculptures may convey a sense of deja vu - they hark back to Process Art of the early 1970's - and yet many of them hold their own in the present, as a further development of early 70's concerns and ideals.
This quality gives Ms. Collings's show at the Bertha Urdang Gallery, which is her fourth since she started exhibiting here in 1979, a sense of edgy double time. You might want to dismiss it, especially with more than 20 pieces crowded into a gallery that has seen better days as an apartment. But it's not so easy.
Even though the viewer must make a special effort to isolate good work from mediocre, some of these pieces are terrific. The best of them exude a playful devil-may-care spirit - the feeling of abstract toys - that has something in common with the art of Alexander Calder. But they also represent a serious effort to fuse painting with sculpture and to liberate color and form, setting them loose in a world that is at once purely visual and full of suggestions and associations. 
The works on view speak clearly of the early 70's esthetic milieu, and will evoke memories of the efforts from that period of Lynda Benglis, Richard Van Buren and Keith Sonnier, all emerging as artists when Ms. Collings was in graduate school at Ohio State University. It was a moment when many younger artists strove to escape the contraints of traditional painting and sculpture.
New materials and their processes - plastics, resins and vinyls, for example - were frequently called into play. Art objects might be hung on the wall (or from the ceiling, for that matter), but they tended to avoid the flat or rectangular; they might sit on the ground, but they usually did so directly, without benefit of pedestal.
Ascribing to all these principles, Ms. Collings's new work is made of vinyl shaped into big inflatable forms that sit lightly on the floor, hang from the ceiling or, in their most elongated and columnar states, do a bit of both. In fact, all the shapes are distorted columns, mathematically based and related to the helix. Some twist at either end like rams' horns, others bulge unpredictably like eccentric perfume bottles, unfamiliar sea forms or creatures out of Dr. Seuss. Their mathematical aspect has affinities with the art of Ruth Vollmer, whose seemingly organic yet mathematically based sculptures, made mostly in the 1960's, influenced the development of Sol LeWitt, Eva Hesse and Robert Smithson.
In the best pieces, the vinyl is a pale translucent green or pink that has random scars and bubbles like those found in Roman glass. (When Ms. Collings ventures into clear plastic, things get garish.) Their surfaces are gaily - yet, one suspects, systematically - dotted, dashed or daubed with bright acrylic paint. The seams of the vinyl sometimes curl around the form like a spiral, both enhancing the sense of mathematical impetus and creating paths that seem to determine the paint patterns.
Ms. Collings might be described as a second-generation Process Artist who has persisted with ideas brought to prominence, but also largely abandoned, by those more famous than herself. Her art has a deliberateness and a variety that frequently escaped her mentors. In particular, it has a faith in painting and in what the well-laced brush stroke can express that seems more of the 1980's than the 70's.
Whatever seems strange or incomplete about her pieces might be laid, in part, to their being out of fashion; it may be hard for eyes sated on the constant quotations and commentaries of 80's art to even see this work. But as a result, this show provides a valuable articulation of the very things that mitigate against it: the passage of time, the changing of styles and the fading of knowledge concerning work that does not enter the pantheon of recent art. Among many other things, it reminds how quickly one forgets.
Betty Collings's vinyl sculptures remain at the Bertha Urdang Gallery, 23 East 74th Street, through Jan. 6.
 
'Dennis Oppenheim:
The Early Years, 1967-72'
Gordon Matta-Clark: Drawings
 
Holly Solomon Gallery
724 Fifth Avenue (near 57th Street)
Through Dec. 30
This pair of exhibitions provides a true return to the late 1960's and early 70's. The front galleries at Holly Solomon are packed cheek to jowl with Dennis Oppenheim's early pieces, and show an artist equally at ease using his own body to make art or employing a harvesting machine to draw lines in a field of grain.
The best works on view combine texts, photographs and sometimes maps to document Mr. Oppenheim's performance pieces and, in particular, his many ephemeral earth works. In one, the 1968 ''Time Line,'' he traces the boundary line between the United States and Canada on top of the frozen St. John River, which runs between Maine and New Brunswick, making real a line usually most tangible on a map.
In another, he spells the word ''radicality'' in flaming torches placed in the side of a hill. But there are also many drawings for installation pieces and more earth works, two sculptures and two video works. At every turn, the show evokes a period of almost frantic experimentation, when many artists were driven by a strong desire to try almost anything and call it art.
In the back galleries, also hung cheek to jowl, are more than 30 drawings made from 1972 to 1974 by Gordon Matta-Clark, an artist who died of cancer in 1978 at the age of 35. Matta-Clark is best known for turning abandoned houses and buildings into sculpture by cutting out huge portions of their walls and floors.
These drawings - on paper, in frames - are considerably more traditional, but they chart the same energetic imagination. This imagination is expressed in ink, pencil and colored marker, and in motifs that sometimes suggest outlandish flora (and maybe fauna), or that sometimes simply consist of cavorting dotted lines and speeding arrows. The antic, cartoonish flair of the work may in part reflect the influence of the artist's father, the Chilean Surrealist painter Roberto Matta. It unquestionably reflects a talent snuffed out way before its time.
 
Serge Kliaving
Koury-Wingate
578 Broadway (near Prince Street)
Through today
This odd and not entirely satisfying show is the first New York City exhibition for Serge Kliaving, a young French artist of the Conceptual persuasion. Mr. Kliaving seems both suspicious of, yet entranced by, the look of corporate logos, symbols and flags, and uses them to fashion an art that can be both amusing and critical.
To one of the best-known international symbols he adds a visible twist. ''Red Cross Committee'' is a row of 17 brightly beautiful red crosses, painted in acrylic on canvas, that ends subversively - with a quote from the Swiss-French writer Andre Durand about the ''inequality between the one who gives and the one who receives.'' Elsewhere, Mr. Kliaving creates his own logos and the issues to go with them. His ''Save the Martians Campaign'' seems intended to poke fun at environmentalists while also calling attention to the pollution of outer space.
On the visual front, Mr. Kliaving's art has a slightly deprived look that seems deliberate, as if the artist wants it to suggest that it was produced by some ministry of information. This style may have possibilities, but at this point it lacks the sharpness of the artist's ideas.
 
'American Moderns'
Barbara Mathes Gallery
851 Madison Avenue (near 70th
Street)
Through Jan. 23
Gallery group shows abound at this time of year. Some are thematic, some merely advertise the gallery's area of interest, but, with luck, they also present some of its back-room gems. This exhibition achieves the last.
Among its standouts is Arthur Dove's 1926 ''Sea Thunder (Sea Gull Motif),'' one of the best paintings from the artist's 1975 retrospective at the Whitney Museum of American Art. Although one must ignore the burdensome white post-modern frame, the painting is a radiant field, half black, half white, that fuses the gentle undulations of cloud, wave and sea-gull wing while also giving visual form to that aural phenomenon, the echo.
Also noteworthy are three figure drawings from the 1920's by the sculptor Elie Nadelman that give the phrase ''economy of line'' particular truth, and a colorful 1914 pastel by Joseph Stella that attests to the artist's affinity for Futurism.
But the show's high point is a small painting from around 1927 by Helen Torr, the artist who was Dove's second wife. Titled ''Flower Rhythm,'' it is a prismatic abstraction of curving criss-crossing lines and shaded pinks and yellows that appears to be based on the form of a tulip bloom. It is a gem of a back-room gem, one that suggests that the history of American art made before World War II is still not thoroughly known.

HEADLINE: FIGHTING IN PANAMA;
Cities Are Looters' Jungles As Chaos Consumes Panama

BYLINE: By LINDSEY GRUSON, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: PANAMA, Dec. 22

 BODY:
Two days after United States forces invaded the country, Panama appeared close to anarchy as bands of looters and roving gunmen took over and ravaged one neighborhood after another.
Ricardo Arias Calderon, the newly installed junior Vice President in the American-backed government, narrowly escaped assassination this afternoon when shots were fired as he left the National Assembly building, senior aides said.
Mr. Calderon, a Christian Democrat whose election earlier this year was annulled by the regime of Gen. Manuel Antonio Noriega, was not injured. The officials said that the shots were fired from a truck by several men who appeared to be members of a paramilitary group. 
Two bodyguards were slightly injured in the attack, they said.
Looters have swarmed through Panama City's downtown business district, leaving an ankle-deep carpet of glass shards that made many sidewalks all but impassable.
In some areas, hardly a window pane was to be seen as looters ran through the streets searching for remnants overlooked in previous attacks.
''Merry Christmas,'' many of them shouted at passers-by. Some looters chanted ''Viva Panama'' as a convoy of U.S. troops rumbled down the road.
Some store owners took up rifles and stood guard in front of their shops.
Other areas of the capital seemed close to civil war, with supporters and opponents of General Noriega, the deposed strongman, shooting at anyone they suspected of sympathizing with the other side.
An atmosphere of chaos has spread across the isthmus, turning cities into war grounds and provoking sharp criticism of the American invasion, even by opponents of the Noriega regime.
Many of these civilians had previously called for United States military intervention. ''The country is being destroyed to save it,'' said a civil engineer who has long criticized General Noriega and initially supported United States military intervention. ''Washington never thought about the social consequences. This country is deeply scarred.'' American officials said they had dispatched 1,500 military police in an attempt to establish some order in the capital and halt the looting.
But they said that the invasion force was still concentrating on flushing out supporters of General Noriega and seizing their weapons.
''To completely clean out the entire city is going to take months of work,'' said Col. James Snell, a senior American military commander.
The United States sent 2,000 soldiers to Panama today to reinforce its invasion force of 24,000.
Sporadic fighting continued with reports that forces loyal to General Noriega continued to hold some sections of northwestern Panama. Many officers in the Panama Defense Forces were surrendering to United States officials and taking oaths of loyalty to the new Government.
''We want to fight for Endara,'' one officer said, referring to the new President, Guillermo Endara.
 
Fear of Guerrilla War
American troops appear to have seized all of their major military and Government targets. But their failure to prevent hit-and-run raids is threatening to turn the sniping into a full-scale guerrilla war against the American military presence.
Soldiers said that planes approaching the runway at Howard Air Force Base were being fired upon by snipers hiding in the hills. A chartered plane that flew in from Miami this morning with about 200 journalists was hit at least twice.
Late this afternoon, American planes started dropping leaflets in the city encouraging forces loyal to the General to surrender. The papers guaranteed ''safe conduct'' to any United States medical facility, as well as food and shelter, to anyone presenting the leaflet.
''Remember, you need not suffer any longer,'' the pamphlet said.
But the invasion has stirred nationalist feeling among many Panamanians. Although American troops were greeted with cheers in some neighborhoods, criticism of military intervention appears to be growing, even among Panamanians who reject General Noriega's effort to portray himself as a defender of the flag.
 
'I Have My Bags Packed'
''I have my bags packed,'' said a lecturer at the national university who is planning to go to New York or Miami. ''If I was a military man, I'd go to the mountains, not because I support Noriega, but because of the nation. It's like being raped.''
A few Americans who were seized in the initial hours of the invasion were still missing today. American officials declined to discuss their cases for fear of jeopardizing prospects for their release.
The United States troops were still frustrated in pursuing their primary goal, the capture of General Noriega. He was variously rumored to have taken shelter in a sympathetic embassy, to be leading loyal forces from a headquarters in the countryside, or to have fled with a band of loyalists into neighboring Costa Rica. None of those reports could be confirmed.
 
From Allies to Enemies
The invasion, which United States officials acknowledge has run into difficulties, began early Wednesday with a three-pronged attack on major military targets across the country.
The invasion, the largest American combat operation since the end of the Vietnam war, followed two years of worsening relations between the two countries, who were once allies.
The breach widened after the indictment of General Noriega last year on Federal drug trafficking charges. The general has denied the charges, but prosecutors have said their case is strong.
In what was originally planned as a quick and painless campaign to oust General Noriega, Washington imposed diplomatic, economic and military sanctions against Panama. But the effort backfired.
The United States succeeded in isolating the military regime. But its effort wrecked a once-flourishing economy and allowed the general, an acknowledged master of military intelligence, to tighten his grip on power and prepare for American military intervention.

HEADLINE: Upheaval in the East: Moscow;
Soviets Welcome the Uprising Against Ceausescu

BYLINE: By FRANCIS X. CLINES, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: MOSCOW, Dec. 22

 BODY:
The Government today hailed the routing of the Ceausescu regime as ''the will of the Rumanian people'' and expressed its support of Rumanians' demands for democracy.
The Foreign Minister, Eduard A. Shevardnadze, expressed sympathy at the loss of life in the Rumanian uprising and the support of Russians after a meeting with the United States Ambassador, Jack F. Matlock.
Russians sat rapt tonight as the main national news show, Vremya, presented vivid television dispatches from Bucharest showing a huge crowd in the city square celebrating the downfall of the Ceausescu government. By the end of the show, however, fresh dispatches arrived reporting a night attack on the unarmed street crowds by the still resistant security forces of the deposed Rumanian leader. 
The report was some of the most uninhibited allowed thus far by the state-controlled television in its careful coverage of the wave of democratic rebellion that has swept the Soviet Union's Eastern European allies.
 
'Will of the Rumanian People'
President Mikhail S. Gorbachev did not personally comment on the day's events, but he presided over a session of the national congress that expressed sympathy with the Rumanian public's desire for democracy.
''The Soviet Union regards these events as the expression of the will of the Rumanian people, which is working for the renovation of its society on the principles of democracy,'' Mr. Shevardnadze declared in his statement.
''The Soviet people at this important moment for the Rumanian socialist movement express their support to the Rumanian people and sincere sympathy for the loss of human life.''
Nicolae Ceausescu was long at odds with the Kremlin, most recently in defending his hard-line suppression of the Rumanian public as he opposed the democratization changes sweeping through most of the Communist bloc in Eastern Europe. He had led his nation into a maverick position critical of the Soviet Union two decades ago. He supported China during the Chinese-Soviet split and condemned the Soviet-led invasion of Prague in 1968 by Warsaw Pact troops who put down a popular uprising for democracy.
The Kremlin's heightened dislike for Mr. Ceausescu's government was clear for the past two days when Tass, the Soviet press agency, filed dispatches from Bucharest that were notably sympathetic to the crowds of Rumanians.
 
Benefit Seen for Gorbachev
Tass has often been a primary source for the latest news of the uprising. It was quoted with credibility in many Western news accounts as it reported with many bulletins of firsthand information from its Bucharest correspondent on the routing of ''Ceausescu and his clique,'' the ''victory of the Rumanian people in the struggle against dictatorship,'' and, more ominously tonight, the resistance and crowd attacks by Ceausescu's loyalists in the security police.
''The Rumanian people were happy to hear that the Soviet people and peoples' deputies were closely following the developments in Rumania and supporting the Rumaninan people's fight for freedom,'' Tass reported.
Western diplomats said the fall of Mr. Ceausescu regime was of considerable immediate benefit to Mr. Gorbachev.
''This removes an irritant and will leave a more amenable government that will permit better relations,'' said one analyst, who said the sight of the demonstrators in Bucharest would not necessarily compound the slight but growing popular pressure on the Soviet Government to begin yielding to calls for an end to the Communist Party's continuing monopoly on power.
 
Setback for Conservatives
Such a yielding has been one of the characteristic early changes in the collapse of the Eastern European governments. But some analysts insist that Mr. Gorbachev has time to maneuver along the slower pace of democratization that he has set here and that as the originator of the liberalized sense of popular protest that was a factor in the East block governments' collapse, he should be the last to have to face it himself.
''Now the conservatives in the Politburo have one less conservative regime out there to side with when they try to criticize Gorbachev,'' said a Western diplomat, stressing that there still was no sign that the Soviet public was ready to take to the streets to press Mr. Gorbachev for multiparty democratic politics and for improved economic conditions.
This morning, the Soviet Congress of Peoples' Deputies passed a measure expressing its ''great sorrow'' and concern over the deaths reported in the fall of the Rumanian Government.
''We hope that in the nearest future the possibility for peaceful settlement of the existing problems in the spirit of tolerance, humanism and respect to human rights will be found in Rumania,'' the congress declared in the measure, which was passed with 1,809 deputies in favor. There was no immediate explanation why 32 other deputies voted to oppose the statement and 65 abstained.

SECTION: Section 1; Page 10, Column 1; Foreign Desk

LENGTH: 1077 words

HEADLINE: Upheaval in the East: Washington;
Bush Promises to Help If Rumanians Change

BYLINE: By THOMAS L. FRIEDMAN, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Dec. 22

 BODY:
The Bush Administration said today that it was prepared to extend to Rumania the kind of assistance granted to Poland and Hungary if the government that emerges in Bucharest adopts similar political and economic reforms.
President Bush called the ouster of President Nicolae Ceausescu a ''dramatic change.'' And the White House spokesman, Marlin Fitzwater, said:
''Today, Dec. 22, a terrible burden appears to have been lifted from Rumania: the burden of dictatorial rule. The United States shares the rejoicing of the Rumanian people and joins them in their hopes for a peaceful transition toward democracy. We hope the Rumanian Government will now move quickly to respond to the demands of its people for democratic change. If Rumania moves along a path of general democratic reform, the United States pledges its strong support and assistance.'' 
While Mr. Fitzwater declined to elaborate on what form the assistance might take, Administration officials said they were thinking along the lines of the economic aid and incentives granted to Poland and Hungary.
 
A Sense of Powerlessness
The officials conceded, though, that as with the popular uprisings in Poland, Hungary, Czechoslovakia, East Germany and Bulgaria, they were powerless to shape events in Rumania and were watching the uprising unfold there on Cable News Network, much as the rest of the world is.
Not only are they powerless to influence events, officials said, but they think the future in Rumania will not turn out as well as that in neighboring Eastern European countries.
''More than in any other Eastern European country, we are not sure what we will end up with in Rumania,'' a senior Administration official said. ''Ceausescu was a real Stalinist and his family had totally dominated the country, more than any other leader in Eastern Europe. There were no institutions, like the church in East Germany or Solidarity in Poland, where reformists could develop. There was the Ceausescu family and nothing else, and with them gone there is going to be a real power vacuum. You cannot be certain how that vacuum will be filled, at what pace, and by whom.''
 
Concerns About Violence
Administration officials said intelligence reports suggest that there is still a substantial chance of violence among the Rumanians, between rival elements of the army and the security forces, and involving people who want to take revenge on Government forces.
Despite the unpredictability of events in Rumania, the Foreign Ministers of the European Community took immediate action to provide emergency assistance. After a special meeting summoned by the French Foreign Minister, Roland Dumas, the Europeans issued a statement saying: ''So that Rumania can reclaim its destiny, the European Community and its member states solemnly reaffirm their will to give it the immediate aid and cooperation of which the Ceausescu regime has unjustly deprived it.'' Mr. Dumas said later the aid would be given in food.
Administration officials and analysts said the fall of President Ceausescu would affect both American strategic interests in Eastern Europe and American perceptions of the Soviet President, Mikhail S. Gorbachev.
''Now all the dominoes in Eastern Europe have fallen except the big one - the Soviet Union,'' said Michael Mandelbaum, an expert on Eastern Europe at the Council on Foreign Relations. ''This is undoubtedly going to influence the debate in the West about Mikhail Gorbachev. Gorbachev has gotten enormous credibility by allowing and encouraging reform in Eastern Europe, and the more he does that, the less the Soviet Union is regarded as a threat. But the more democratization spreads in Eastern Europe, the more the Soviet Union is going to stand out starkly as the laggard.
''When Gorbachev began, he was doing things that no one in Eastern Europe was doing; now the Eastern Europeans are leaving him in the dust,'' Mr. Mandelbaum went on. ''That is bound to affect the debate about how much we should help Gorbachev.''
 
A Momentum for Change
But at the same time, an Administration official said, the events in Rumania should embolden people advocating reform in the Soviet Union, as opposed to those arguing for a slower pace of change.
''If there is one conclusion that the Soviets should draw from Rumania,'' a senior Administration official said, ''it is that the tide of reform is irresistible. Ceausescu thought he could be different, but the lesson of today is that you cannot hold back the pressure for change. If you try, the costs become too great and those who oppose reform become the chief victims. That is going to create a certain momentum for change in Moscow.''
On the strategic level, the fall of Mr. Ceausescu's government further weakens the Warsaw Pact as a military alliance, some analysts said. It is now virtually inconceivable, Administration officials said, that East Germany, Poland, Hungary, Bulgaria, Czechoslovakia and Rumania would join to pose a military threat to the West. This will only underscore the need, articulated by Secretary of State James A. Baker 3d in his Berlin speech last week, for the North Atlantic Treaty Organization to adopt more political and economic functions if it is to remain a cohesive and relevant alliance in the face of a diminishing Soviet-bloc threat, officials said.
 
'Last of the Dominoes'
''The last of the Warsaw Pact dominoes in Eastern Europe has fallen,'' said Charles Gati, an expert on Eastern Europe at Union College in upstate New York. ''The Warsaw Pact as a united military force is finished. It means that we have to create a new rationale for political cooperation within the Atlantic alliance. Of course, we cannot completely let our guard down. Communism has lost, but democracy has not won yet.''
Asked about the status of the Rumanian Ambassador in Washington, Ion Stoichici, a State Department spokesman, Richard Boucher, said: ''The present Ambassador sort of remains in place until we've received notification from the Rumanian Government that he's been changed and a new person has been appointed.''
About 50 Rumanians, led by Father George Calciu of the Rumanian Faith and Freedom Coalition, demanded that the Rumanian Embassy be turned over to them, but the State Department refused and the building is being guarded by American diplomatic security agents. Rumanian diplomats did not answer the embassy telephone today, and kept the windows curtained.

HEADLINE: Fighting in Panama: Peru;
Protest by Lima Asks U.S. to Halt Anti-Drug Drive

BYLINE: By JAMES BROOKE, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: RIO DE JANEIRO Dec. 22

 BODY:
Protesting American military action in Panama, Peru has requested that the United States suspend its anti-drug operations in Peru's coca-growing areas, an American narcotics official in Lima said today.
The official said the United States was suspending its participation in a $10 million program to eradicate coca bushes in Peru's Upper Huallaga Valley, the source of the raw material for about half of the world's cocaine.
''The Government of Peru has requested that we temporarily suspend all field operations involving use of United States Government equipment and personnel in the Upper Huallaga area until the conflictive situation in Panama is resolved,'' said the American Embassy official, who asked not to be identified.
 
Garcia Won't Attend Summit
The suspension comes after Peru's President, Alan Garcia Perez, protested the American action in Panama by withdrawing his Ambassador in Washington and by canceling his participation in an anti-drug summit with President Bush in Colombia on Feb. 15. 
''How can I meet with a President who has just trampled Latin America?'' Mr. Garcia said to reporters. ''Holding a dialogue with a pistol on the table cannot be tolerated.''
Referring to the American military action in Panama, Mr. Garcia said on Thursday that the United States ''could seek to do the same in Peru if it should think the Government isn't doing enought to fight drug trafficking.''
Later on Thursday, the United States Ambassador, Thomas Quainton, told the Lima newspaper Expresso that officers of the Drug Enforcement Administration remained in the country. ''They are ready to maintain their normal rhythm of operation in the Upper Huallaga,'' Mr. Quainton said, ''but we suppose that we will have to wait for the withdrawal of our troops from Panama.''
In one of the rare street demonstrations against the American military action, hundreds of protesters marched in downtown Lima on Thursday night and burned an American flag in front of the American Embassy.
 
Bolivia Condemns Intervention
In neighboring Bolivia, President Jaime Paz Zamora said today that he condemned the military intervention and demanded the withdrawal of American troops.
Bolivia is a major recipient of American aid in the war on cocaine trafficking, and Mr. Zamora is to attend the summit in Colombia. Today, Bolivia's Foreign Minister, Carlos Iturralde, said the Government was studying a request from Mr. Garcia to boycott the meeting with President Bush.
In Colombia, the country that is to be the host of the Andean drug summit, Julio Londono Paredes, the Foreign Minister, said today, ''No country can assume the right to intervene, directly or indirectly, in another state's affairs, whatever reasons or puposes it may have, much less militarily.''
While most of Latin America's reactions have been limited to diplomatic protest notes, street protests have taken place in Mexico, Cuba and the Dominican Republic as well as Peru.
In Mexico City, about 2,000 people shouting, ''Yankee killers!'' and ''American terrorirsm!'' gathered outside the American Embassy on Thursday night. The demonstrators spattered the Embassy's white marble facade with blue and red paint, the colors of Panama's flag.
In the Dominican Republic, the site of American military intervention in 1965, about 200 protesters picketed the United States Embassy in Santo Domingo.
 
Denunciation From Castro
Officially sanctioned protests took place on Wednesday and Thursday in Cuba, a nation whose Communist Government survived an American-sponsored invasion in 1961.
Today, Cuba's President, Fidel Castro, denounced the American action in Panama as ''in the style of the Nazis and of the fascists.''
Mr. Castro, who disapproves of the democratic opening in Eastern Europe, also complained, ''We haven't heard any of the socialist countries of Europe even talk about the attack on Panama in recent days.''
The Cuban leader, who has provided funds and training for guerrilla groups in Latin America for almost 30 years, predicted, ''If the Panamanian patriots learned the lesson of Nicaragua, of the F.M.L.N. in El Salvador, the United States forces are going to remain mired for who knows how long in this little country.''
''The great army of the great empire is looking stupid,'' Mr. Castro concluded in his first public comment on the American invasion.
 
'IT'S THEIR COUNTRY,' U.S. SAYS
WASHINGTON, Dec. 22 (Special to the New York Times) A State Department official said today that Peru's lack of cooperation left the American Government ''no choice,'' because ''it's their country and it's a joint operation.''
Robert P. Myers, director for program management in the department's narcotics bureau, emphasized that the United States decision to suspend the anti-drug operation was not a retaliatory action but a result of the Peruvian Government's desire not to participate. ''It was not our decision to do this,'' he said.
Administration officials said the summit was still on. ''It would possibly enhance the considerations if they were there,'' Marlin Fitzwater, the White House spokesman, said of the Peruvians on Thursday. ''But we will continue to go ahead and meet.''
Administration officials said the suspension of joint anti-drug activities were not expected to affect economic aid programs to Peru that were not conditioned on the drug effort.

HEADLINE: Atlanta in Contrast: Civil Rights and Racial Hate

BYLINE: By PETER APPLEBOME, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: ATLANTA, Dec. 22

 BODY:
Atlanta likes to call itself the home of Dr. Martin Luther King Jr. and the civil rights movement, but the area surrounding it is home to some of the most prominent white supremacists in the nation.
They and their followers, many of whom have long-running disagreements with the United States Court of Appeals for the 11th Circuit, and some of its rulings on race and school desegregation, are a focus of attention in the investigation of four bombing incidents in the South since last Saturday. Investigators have determined that all four bombs were mailed from northern Georgia, but they stressed that did not mean the assailants live in Georgia.
And although officials insist that the investigation remains open-ended, it is casting attention on a darker side of the Atlanta area, which has often symbolized some of most positive changes in race in America. 
 
Examing Possible Racial Motive
Federal agents are seeking a racial motive in the four bombing incidents, including the explosions that killed a Federal appellate judge and a Savannah lawyer. The other bombs were delivered but removed safely from the offices of the 11th Circuit in Atlanta and the N.A.A.C.P. office in Jacksonville, Fla.
Atlanta had as peaceful an experience with integration as any major city in the South. But the area's history and current politics remain suffused with issues of race. If Atlanta is the home of Dr. King, nearby Stone Mountain was also where the Ku Klux Klan was revived in 1915, and Atlanta became the headquarters of the revived Klan.
Klan marches remain common sideshows in the area, although most activity is outside the city. A Klan telephone line today carried a recorded message urging followers to turn out Jan. 6 at the State Capitol here to protest the holiday honoring Dr. King, who was described with racial slurs and labeled ''Communist scum and sex pervert.''
Some civil rights figures like the Rev. Joseph Lowery, president of the Southern Christian Leadership Conference, say the black gains and prominence in Atlanta may serve as a source of tension and frustration for some whites. Political power in Atlanta, which is now 70 percent black, is dominated by blacks like Mayor Andrew Young and Mayor-elect Maynard Jackson.
But Dr. Lowery and others say the hate groups remain fringe movements with no more influence in the Atlanta area than anywhere else.
 
'Just a Matter of Population'
''If there are more of them here, it's because there are more people here,'' said Stuart Lewengrub, southeast director of the Anti-Defamation League of B'nai B'rith. ''It's just a matter of population. This is the population hub of the South, so it's the hub of some of the bad things in the South as well as the good.''
Much of the ire of white supremacists is directed at the Federal judiciary in general and the 11th Circuit in particular. The court has ruled on several cases involving the Klan and prominent white supremacists like J. B. Stoner, who lives near Atlanta, and Roger Handley, an Alabama Ku Klux Klan leader. It has ruled on desegration cases in Jacksonville and Savannah as well as DeKalb County near Atlanta.
The issues have touched a raw nerve with hate groups.
For example, a message left on the answering machine of Daniel Carver, Georgia Grand Dragon of the Invisible Empire Knights of the Ku Klux Klan, in September and taped by the Southern Poverty Law Center of Montgomery, Ala., extolled a planned ''whites only'' demonstration in Jasper, Ga., with a barrage of racial slurs. The message concluded: ''White people are sick and tired of their schools being destroyed. Children can't possibly concentrate on getting an education. Their main goal is just making it through the day without being attacked by a savage nigger.''
A Klan newspaper, The Cross and the Sword, in 1987 ran an item on a civil rights case involving Mr. Handley, lambasting a ruling by what it referred to as ''the Jew-controlled 11th Circuit Court of Appeals.''
 
Violent Rhetoric Is a Staple
And in their rhetoric, at least, white supremecists have long threatened violent action.
In a speech at an annual Labor Day Klan rally in Stone Mountain near Atlanta in 1985 another white supremacist leader, Frank Shirley, said, ''It's always refreshing to see more cases of white vigilantes.'' He added: ''Death to the race mixers. They have whirled down the gauntlet at our feet.''
The speech, tape-recorded by law enforcement officials and obtained by the Southern Povery Law Center, concludes: ''When the hour of retribution strikes, there will be 10 million dead ones in America.''
The leading white supremacists in Georgia remain fringe figures, most of them in suburbs or small towns outside Atlanta, with little influence on mainstream life. Among them are Mr. Stoner, who was convicted in 1980 of a 1958 bombing incident in Birmingham, and his longtime associate, Ed Fields, who publishes a newsletter called The Truth at Last. Prominent Klansmen, several of whom received a $940,000 judgment for attacking civil rights marchers that was upheld by the 11th Circuit, include Mr. Carver and Dave Holland, who called his Southern White Knights of the Ku Klux Klan ''the most militant white racist Klan organization in the country.''
But officials of the Federal Bureau of Investigation have not said if they have any suspects in the bombings, and past and current Klan members deny they or their associates were involved.
 
Klan Leader Denies Bombings
''There are two different mentalities in the Klan,'' said Edward Stephens, a former Grand Dragon of the Invisible Empire Knights of the Ku Klux Klan in Georgia. ''The one type that might have enough sense to know how to make such a thing as a bomb have better things to do with their time. The different class, the unemployed street bums, the bad apples in the Klan, don't have enough intelligence to know how to deliver such a bomb.''
He said he had not been contacted by the F.B.I. but would be glad to answer any questions and added that he could understand frustration with the 11th Circuit.
''I hate to see what happened to the judge and all that but the 11th Circuit with the lawsuit we had really distorted the law,'' he said. ''They were just so biased and liberal about it. A majority of it is dominated by extreme liberals.''
Officials familiar with Klan activity in Georgia said such a high level of violence would be uncharacteristic. The state has several Klan organizations, many of which have splintered from one another. Some speculated that if white supremacists are involved, they might not be involved with high-profile white supremacist activities or traditional groups like the Klan.

HEADLINE: Bitter Coal Strike May Be at End, but Ripples From Dispute Are Widely Felt

BYLINE: By MICHAEL deCOURCY HINDS

 BODY:
Children of striking coal miners might not get the Barbie dolls and Nintendo games they asked for this Christmas, but officials on both sides said yesterday that after nine months of a bitter labor dispute, the miners might soon have a contract.
Negotiators, who have been meeting around the clock since Wednesday, continued intense talks yesterday in Washington, and the Department of Labor three times said an announcement was imminent.
Spokesmen for the participants would only say that a news conference would be held concerning important developments. Although the Labor Department canceled each announcement it scheduled, officials from both sides who were not in the meetings said last night that they were ready for an announcement at any time.
On one side is one of the fastest declining unions in the nation, the United Mine Workers of America, which was founded 99 years ago and had a half million active members in 1946. Today, after decades of mechanization and a spurt in nonunion mining, the union has 63,000 working members who mine only a third of the nation's coal. 
If the miners lose the strike, their leaders say it would wipe out the union, bring chaos to the coal industry and ultimately leave 125,000 retired miners and their beneficiaries without health benefits.
On the other side is the Pittston Coal Group, the nation's 17th largest producer. Before the strike it was considered modestly profitable, but said it needed concessions on health benefits to remain competitive.
If the company cannot obtain the concessions, Wall Street analysts say Pittston would probably stop mining coal or sell its coal operations. Spending Millions Because of a Strike The strike has hit both sides hard.
Pittston hired replacements for striking workers and has restored production to almost what it was before the walkout. But the company says it spent $20 million on security and fenced-in trailer parks for the new workers. Analysts estimate the company has lost more than $60 million on the strike, a figure some anaylsts say would take decades to recoup with concessions.
The union has been depleting its $90 million strike fund with $225 weekly strike pay for its members. It faces more than $64 million in fines imposed for members' acts of violence, civil disobedience and destruction of Pittston property. The Russell County Circuit Court in Lebanon, Va., established an escalating scale for the fines, and each strike-related traffic violation now costs the union $500,000.
The issue of paying the soaring cost of health benefits is the most important one for union labor today, said Morton Bahr, president of the Communications Workers of America. This month his union ended a strike against Nynex after the company withdrew its demand that workers pay a greater share of health-care costs.
National union leaders say the outcome of the Pittston strike will set the tone for collective bargaining in the 1990's, but at a Christmas party in southwest Virginia this week, the concerns were much more immediate.
''When you look at the kids' eyes, you can see all the worry the strike puts on the family and this community,'' said Rickey E. Blaylock, a former professional wrestler (''The Mountain Mauler'') and a local official of the United Mine Workers of America. He wore a Santa's suit on Sunday in the shell of a former supermarket here and, at the end of a day filled with 2,000 wishes, his voice wavered.
Children listing what they wanted for Christmas said their biggest hopes were for dolls, electronic video games, and a union contract for their fathers.
Miners, dressed in the striker's belligerent uniform of military camouflage fatigues, spoke in interviews of being arrested without cause, of walking picket lines in 3-degree weather and of making sacrifices to get by on strike pay of $225 a week.
They talked of battling a conglomerate corporation that wants to take away health benefits and job security that their fathers and grandfathers fought for 40 years ago. They said the union and their lives would be wrecked if they do not win the strike.
Wildcat strikes this summer, involving 45,000 miners, or 5 of every 7 union coal miners in the country, have underscored the high emotions of the union members. On a community level, the strike has ruined businesses, impoverished families, turned neighbor against neighbor and local police against state police.
A mediator, William J. Usery Jr., Secretary of Labor under President Gerald R. Ford, was appointed by the Bush Administration in November to try to resolve the deadlock. Union Tactics Lead to Arrests Civil disobedience and passive resistance have been the union's primary tools in the strike. The State Police in Virginia have made 2,886 arrests for actions like impeding the movement of Pittston coal trucks and occupying a company coal preparation plant for four days. Pittstson hired new workers for 25 mines and plants in Virginia and West Virginia but closed indefinitly three plants in Kentucky.
Although many demonstrations took place around the headquarters of the company's coal operations in Lebanon, Va., others were held in Greenwich, Conn., where The Pittston Company, the coal group's parent company, is based. Other Pittston subsidiaries are Burlington Air Express, Brink's Inc., and Brinks Home Security.
Some say the Virginia state police have overreacted. Avery W. Phipps, sheriff of Dickenson County, Va., complained in a letter to Gov. Gerald L. Baliles in August that the state police were enforcing ''martial law'' and treating strikers in ways that the ''Humane Society would not tolerate in treatment of animals.'' The State Police investigated his complaint and found it unfounded.
Other critics pointed to the example of Sister Bernadette Kenny, a 50-year-old Catholic nun, who was arrested by a Federal marshal for driving her mobile health clinic too slowly in front of a coal truck last July. She said she was handcuffed for two hours and jailed for six hours before being released on a $10,000 bond. Federal charges were dismissed in September when the driver of the coal truck testified on her behalf.
Violence has frequently erupted, resulting in 3,000 broken winshields, burned vehicles, assaults, cut power lines, dynamite explosions and 211 felony arrests in Virginia alone. In mid-December, someone dressed in camouflage fired a shotgun at a Pittston truck, blew out the windshield and wounded the driver.
Hate and desperation are palpable in mining communities of Southwest Virginia, even 1,200 feet underground where temporary replacement workers are mining coal from the Jawbone Seam at Pittston's McClure Mine No. 1 near Clinchco, Va. ''My next-door neighbor calls me a scab and the union people tried to burn my house down,'' said a young miner eating his lunch in the near darkness of the mine.
The miner said he has to endure the harrassment to support his family. He earns $15 an hour, several times his pay at a landscaping company before joining Pittston last summer. He said he had been a union member for six years, but like a dozen other replacement workers interviewed, he had a raft of complaints about the union.
The most frequent complaints were that union leaders called strikes for the slightest infraction of complex work rules and that it was impossible for a young miner to get a union job because there were thousands of laid-off miners who are older, had ve more seniority and would get first crack.
''I got to make a living, too,'' said David G. Dupont, another replacement worker and a former union member who had been unable to find a union job since 1984. Since then he has been unemployed or worked minimum wage jobs. ''My family comes first; it's every man for himself now.'' Rallying Cause For Faltering Movement The strike comes at a time when the labor movement is in worse shape than it was in the 1920's, said Richard B. Freeman, a professor of economics at Harvard and director of labor studies at the National Bureau of Economic Research, a private research organization.
He said that union labor has fallen from a high point of 40 percent of the private work force in the mid-1950's to 12 percent today, and he estimated that union labor will fall to 5 percent of the private work force by the the year 2000. ''If the only way we can compete is by reducing the living standards of our blue collar citizens, that is nothing any of us can be proud of,'' Professor Freeman said.
The strike has also become a rallying cause. ''This strike is important for the morale of the labor movement,'' said Douglas A. Fraser, former president of the United Automobile Workers and now a professor of labor studies at Wayne State University.
Richard L. Trumka, president of the miners union, has rallied the public and unions behind his cause by couching the economic issues in moral terms and by playing up the importance of complete health care coverage for people who work in one of the nation's most dangerous occupations.
Government statistics indicate that there are about 55 deaths and 10,000 to 16,000 injuries each year as a result of explosions, cave-ins and other mine accidents. In addition, 4,000 miners die each year from lung diseases that result from inhaling dust from coal and other minerals.
''This strike is about health benefits that the company says it can afford to pay,'' Mr. Trumka said, during a break from the bargaining table in Arlington, Va. ''But the company would rather walk away from commitments it made over the past 30 to 40 years.'' Agreement on Benefits: The Background Every national contract since 1950 has required companies to provide complete health coverage to miners as well as to retired miners, disabled miners and their widows and orphans. John L. Lewis, then the union president, negotiated this landmark contract in exchange for allowing coal operators to introduce mechanized equipment that would ultimately eliminate 300,000 jobs.
Under the agreement, companies pay for their own employee benefits and make contributions to a multi-employer fund that provides benefits for retirees, no matter which company had employed them last. The union subsequently amended this agreement and now permits companies to pay retirement benefits directly to their employees who retired after 1976. But another fund, supported by company contributions, was established for miners who retired after 1976 from companies that went out of business.
The pension funds have done well, but the benefit funds have a deficit of more than $60 million, which is increasing at the rate of $6 million a month. Last year, companies were asked to contribute $1.92 per employee an hour worked; now that contribution has increased to $2.94.
Pittston has balked at these rising costs and a union contract that it says stifles productivity. ''Any number of industry experts will tell you that the U.M.W.A. mines impose a cost penalty ranging from $3 to $6 a ton over nonunion competition,'' said Michael E. Odom, president of Pittston Coal Group. ''The U.M.W.A. medical plan is a runaway program and it has to be adapted to the real world. The U.M.W.A. contract imposes archaic, inefficient practices and impediments. We have got to reduce our overall costs by improving productivity.''
In 1987, Pittston withdrew from the Bituminous Coal Operators Association, the bargaining organization for unionized companies, and rejected the contract that covered the period from 1988 to 1993.
Pittston then offered its miners a contract with a wage increase of 90 cents an hour over three years, an increase that was slightly larger than one in the national contract and one that would bring the average weekly paycheck to $634. The company contract would have reduced medical benefits from 100 percent coverage to 80 percent coverage and the number of paid holidays and sick days from 45 to 35 for an employee who has been with the company for 15 years.
The contract also would have given the company wide flexibility in scheduling shifts, including new night shifts on Sunday, and would have permitted the company to have nonunion contractors take over many union jobs involving the repair of equipment, transportation of coal, construction of mining facilities, maintenance of idled mines and laboratory work.
The union worked without a contract for 14 months and then went on strike April 5, 1989. In July, the National Labor Relations Board issued a complaint against the company charging it with unfair labor practices involving its failure to bargain, unlawful discharge of workers and unilateral implementation of contract provisions. As a result of the complaint, which will have a hearing next year, the company cannot permanently replace its striking workers and must restore jobs to the strikers after the dispute is settled. 'A Dead Limb On a Tree' The Rev. Harry P. Whitaker, pastor of the Straight Holler Free Will Baptist Church in Dante, Va., and a miner who retired from Pittston after 31 years, said he has complained about Pittston's actions on national television, radio and at a Pittston shareholder meeting. ''Pittston promised me that if I worked for them for 20 years, they would take care of my health for life,'' he said, as he leaned on a cane at a recent union rally in Castlewood, Va.
''But now they say, 'Harry Whitaker, you ain't working for us any more. You got black lung. You can't sleep at night. You got a bad heart. Your hips are crushed. You can't walk good. You're like a dead limb on a tree. You're not bringing in any fruit any more. We're breaking our promise to pay your medical bills.''
Mr. Whitaker said he had to tap his $402-a-month pension from Pittston to cover medical costs, like doctor's visits, that Pittston's new benefit plan did not cover.
Competitors are just as angry as the retirees. ''Pittston is simply trying to dump its unfunded employee liabilities on the rest of the industry and it's very devastating on us,'' said Robert E. Murray, president and chief executive officer of The Ohio Valley Coal Company, a privately owned company in Alledonia, Ohio.
Mr. Odom, Pittston's president, said, ''The funds are insolvent because the U.M.W.A. has priced itself out of business and there are fewer companies left to pay the benefits.''
No matter how the strike is resolved, labor specialists say that it has built a new grass-roots movement by attracting the support of a thousand unions, religious organizations, clergy members and community groups.
''If we are unsuccessful after this super effort,'' said Mr. Trumka, the union president, ''what does that say about the state of collective bargaining?''
