HEADLINE: Fire Director, Budget Chief Are Selected

BYLINE: By TODD S. PURDUM

 BODY:
Filling the post that he has called his top priority, Mayor-elect David N. Dinkins yesterday named the executive director of the state's Financial Control Board, Philip R. Michael, as his Budget Director. Mr. Dinkins also named a career firefighter, Carlos M. Rivera, to be Fire Commissioner.
The appointment of Mr. Michael, a former City Finance Commissioner who, as head of the control board since last year has been responsible for monitoring the city's budget, seems intended to reassure business leaders that Mr. Dinkins is prepared to weather uncertain fiscal times.
Mr. Rivera, a member of the Fire Department for 31 years and its Chief of Operations since October, would become the first Hispanic commissioner in the department's 124-year history. Chief Rivera would also help round out the ''gorgeous mosaic'' the Mayor-elect uses as a metaphor for the city and his administration, even as he faces stiff pressure from supporters to name additional Hispanic appointees. 
 
'Vigilance Over the Bottom Line'
At a news conference announcing the appointments, which brought to 11 the number of posts he has filled, Mr. Dinkins said the naming of Mr. Michael ''should send a strong signal to the business community, to the city's bondholders and to the taxpayers that we will not relax our vigilance over the bottom line, even in difficult times.''
Stanley Hill, head of District Council 37 of the American Federation of State, County and Municipal Employees, the largest city employees' union, said that he was disappointed at the choice and that he had called Mr. Dinkins to express concern about the union's past differences with Mr. Michael when he was Finance Commisssioner. ''But David assured me we would have effective communications,'' said Mr. Hill, a major supporter of Mr. Dinkins.
Nine days before he is to be sworn in, Mr. Dinkins has yet to fill critical positions like labor relations director, head of the City Planning Commission, health commissioner and human resources administrator. Mr. Dinkins said yesterday that he was satisfied with the pace and that taking care to fill posts with the right people was ''time well spent.''
Like Mr. Dinkins's appointee as First Deputy Mayor, Norman Steisel, Mr. Michael is a veteran of the Koch administration who has since worked elsewhere, most recently at the control board. The board was established in the fiscal crisis in the mid-70's. At that time it had binding powers over the city's fiscal affairs, but now performs oversight and advisory functions.
Mr. Michael said he would stress increased productivity by the municipal work force as a way to help solve impending budget gaps.
''The Mayor-elect has impressed upon me that he believes that productivity is a key element, real productivity that will go a long way toward solving the budget problem, and I concur,'' Mr. Michael said. He cited improving vehicle management, using additional one-officer patrol cars and reducing the managers in some agencies as possible options.
 
'Reordering of Priorities'
''I think there are many agency heads, when they understand the budget requirements that are going to be placed upon them, who will use their creativity to develop even further productivity goals,'' he said.
Mr. Michael and Mr. Dinkins acknowledged that productivity gains alone would probably not be enough to keep the budget balanced or afford new programs in the face of faltering tax revenues and virtually no growth in the economy.
''There's no doubt there's going to be some reordering of priorities,'' Mr. Michael said. ''And everybody can't have everything.'' He said that he did not believe a tax increase was ''a necessary element to balancing the budget,'' but that it could not be ruled out.
Later, Mr. Steisel said the incoming adminstration was committed to reviewing ideas for increased productivity, even those, like one-officer patrol cars, that have been considered for years without being adopted.
''Some of the ideas have been out there and been discussed and been abandoned because they weren't timely,'' Mr. Steisel said. ''Some of those have to be looked at. The environment may be different, and we may want to pursue those. Some were abandoned because we didn't have imaginative management. All of that has to be reassessed in the climate of a new administration.''
 
Trying to Help Morale
Mr. Michael praised the professional staff at the budget office and said he hoped many of them would stay on. He will take office Jan. 1, replacing Paul Dickstein, who plans to leave for the private sector.
For his part, Chief Rivera said he would work to increase morale in the department, which suffered during feuds with Mayor Edward I. Koch over salaries and the closing of firehouses in the last two years. Chief Rivera said he would work to make sure safety was not jeopardized by adopting a ruling that the city won this week that allows it to use four-person pumpers instead of five-person crews.
The Chief said he did not envision using four-person crews on ladder trucks that perform high-rise rescues. ''I don't think that's a viable option,'' he said. ''We have certain standards to maintain.''
Chief Rivera sidestepped questions on whether firefighters should have a wider role in rescues and emergencies, work that is dominated in New York as in no other city by the police and that has been the subject of intense feuding in recent years.
Officials in the Koch administration proposed shifting added responsibility to the Fire Deparment, but were overruled by the Mayor, who sided with the police. Aides to Mr. Dinkins, including his new Police Commissioner, Lee P. Brown, have said they will re-examine the issue.
Asked for his personal opinion on whether firefighters could handle emergency work as well as the police, Chief Rivera said that he was ''a bit prejudiced,'' but that he thought they could. ''We can go from a water leak to a collapse to a plane crash,'' he said. ''And we respond quickly, and we're very aggressive on the scene.''

HEADLINE: As Deficit Threatens, City Hall Budget Watchdog Becomes Master

BYLINE: By RICHARD LEVINE

 BODY:
No one can say Philip R. Michael, who was named yesterday as New York City's next budget director, does not know what he is getting himself into.
Just Thursday the New York State Financial Control Board, which Mr. Michael now serves as executive director, issued a report that began, ''By now it has become abundantly clear: The 10-year boom in the city's economy that preceded the October 1987 stock market crash, and that greatly stimulated tax revenue growth, has been replaced by a disconcerting stagnation.''
That stagnation will be Mr. Michael's to cope with as he endeavors to keep the city's $26.5 billion budget balanced at a time when new resources are scarce and ills like homelessness, drug abuse and AIDS abound. The Koch administration estimates that Mr. Michael will face a budget deficit of $395 million for the fiscal year that begins in July, but others have warned that the gap could grow to several times that figure. And there may be more problems with this year's budget as well: A report from the State Comptroller's office yesterday warned of a potential gap of $185 million, although that was disputed by the departing budget director, Paul Dickstein. 
In selecting Mr. Michael for the $110,000-a-year post as Director of the city's Office of Management and Budget, Mayor-elect David N. Dinkins chose a former city finance commissioner and current fiscal monitor, whose agency was established during the crisis of the mid-1970's and has the authority to step in and control spending if the city finishes the fiscal year with a $100 million deficit.
 
Background as Tax Collector
Raymond D. Horton, president of the Citizens Budget Commission, an independent group that analyzes the city's finances, praised Mr. Michael, saying his background at the Finance Department, which collects the city's taxes, had given him a sure sense of the sometimes perplexing flow of revenues. Mr. Horton also said that while Mr. Michael was at the Financial Control Board he focused on the growth of the city work force. ''That's the thing that drives the budget,'' Mr. Horton added.
The control board's latest report, in fact, noted that even with a midyear hiring freeze, the city-financed work force grew 2.1 percent in fiscal 1989, to 219,000, which was 30 percent more than the force on the payroll in 1981.
In a telephone interview yesterday, Mr. Michael said he would ''seriously consider recommending to the Mayor no growth in the work force.''
At the news conference at which his appointment was announced, Mr. Michael also spoke of increasing the efficiency of municipal government, saying he would examine the possibility of police patrol cars with a single officer, among other ideas. ''The Mayor has impressed upon me that he believes that productivity is a key element, real productivity that will go a long way toward solving the budget problem, and I concur,'' Mr. Michael said, as Mr. Dinkins stood by his side.
 
Philosophy and Crime
Philip Roy Michael was born on Aug. 5, 1940 in San Francisco and attended the University of California at Berkeley, earning a bachelor's degree in philosophy in 1962 and a law degree in 1965. That year he moved to Washington to become a trial attorney in the United State Justice Department's Organized Crime and Racketeering Section.
In 1972 he joined the New York City Police Department as the deputy commissioner for trials. When Mayor Edward I. Koch was elected in 1978, Mr. Michael was appointed First Deputy Commissioner of the Department of Investigation and, in 1980, Finance Commissioner.
He left the city government in 1984, joining Merrill Lynch & Company as an investment banker before becoming general counsel to Sanus Health Systems, a health maintenance organization, in 1986. He joined the Financial Control Board in January 1989.
''He's obviously bright, he knows the territory and I think they found a good man for the job,'' said Mr. Dickstein of his successor.
 
Rohatyn Happy, Union Is Not
Felix G. Rohatyn, chairman of the Municipal Assistance Corporation, called Mr. Michael ''thoroughly professional and thoroughly knowledgable.''
But Stanley Hill, head of District Council 37 of the American Federation of State, County and Municipal Employees, said he was disappointed with the choice of Mr. Michael, with whom Mr. Hill said labor leaders had had ''communications problems'' and difficulties ''working out labor-management problems'' while Mr. Michael was Finance Commissioner.
But Mr. Hill said he had been reassured by Mr. Dinkins that ''we would have effective communications.''
Mr. Michael lives in the Riverdale section of the Bronx with his wife, Jean, and their three children. He said he runs ''maybe 15 miles'' and plays in several pickup basketball games a week.
But he may not have much time for that for a while. The city's financial plan, which updates the current budget and estimates revenues and expenses for the next four years, is due on Feb. 1.

COMPANIES

Heating oil prices have surged and spot shortages have occurred in recent days. Experts fear continued cold weather could bring more widespread shortages. Several companies are rationing sales to dealers, and governors have sought delivery curbs. [37.]

Keating Jr., the former California savings and loan executive, and Senator Alfonse M. D'Amato of New York, whose role in Federal housing projects has been questioned. [16.]

Federal Reserve policy makers decided not to change monetary policy at their late fall meeting but left open the possibility of lower interest rates if economic events dictated, minutes of the session show. [38.]
 
The lagging Christmas shopping season picked up new life in its final week, with a potential bonus due on Sunday, an extra shopping day this year. But retailers see only limited sales gains for the season, which has been plagued by bitterly cold weather. [39.]

HEADLINE: Orders Up Strong 5.1% For Durables

BYLINE: Reuters

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Dec. 22

 BODY:
Bolstered by a surge in demand for aircraft and parts, orders for durable goods rose by a surprisingly strong 5.1 percent in November.
The Commerce Department said today that orders for durable goods increased to a seasonally adjusted $130.7 billion last month. Orders had dropped by seven-tenths of 1 percent in October and 1.2 percent in September. 
Aircraft orders accounted for about 40 percent of the November increase, but there were also smaller increases across several other broad categories of goods. The overall 5.1 percent rise in durables orders was the largest monthly increase since a 7.4 percent gain in December 1988, department officials said.
 
Shipments and Backlogs Up
Economists said the durable goods report, showing gains not only in orders but also in shipments and backlogs, might ease some concern about a weakening manufacturing sector.
Even excluding military orders, durable goods orders were up 4.2 percent after a rise of one-tenth of 1 percent in October. Orders for goods outside the transportation sector rose by 3.1 percent in November after falling by 1.7 percent in October.
''This confirms our belief that the fourth-quarter weakness should be temporary,'' said David Wyss, chief economist with DRI/McGraw Hill Inc. in Lexington, Mass. ''It should be bouncing back up in the first half.''
Durable goods, which are built to last three or more years, are a key part of the nation's manufacturing sector, and orders for the big-ticket items are closely watched as an indicator of the economy's health.
The United States Chamber of Commerce, representing many major manufacturing companies, said the orders rise was a delayed reaction to falling interest rates since June. ''This good news is an early Christmas present for the Fed, which has come under increasing criticism that its high interest rate policy will lead to a recession,'' said William MacReynolds, the business association's forecasting director.
Mr. Wyss of DRI/McGraw Hill also said the report should take some pressure off the Federal Reserve. ''This certainly suggests less reason to worry about a recession than some of the Fed governors, particularly Mrs. Seger, seem to think and thus less reason to ease,'' he added. A Fed governor, Martha Seger, said recently that she was worried about the possibility of a recession.
 
Unfilled Orders Increase
In today's report, the Commerce Department said that shipments of durable goods rose by 1.5 percent after October's 2 percent fall. Unfilled orders, a gauge of future activity, rose by 1.5 percent after an October gain of five-tenths of 1 percent. It was the largest one-month increase in the orders backlog since a 1.8 percent increase last December and reflected more orders for aircraft and parts.
Orders for military capital goods rose by 15.6 percent in November after a 9.1 percent drop in October. Nonmilitary capital goods, spurred by transportation orders, rose by 8.3 percent after a 1.8 percent increase in October.
Among other sectors, electrical machinery orders rose by 7.9 percent in November after a 3.6 percent October fall, while non-electrical machinery orders went up by 6.6 percent after a 4.7 percent October decline.
Primary metals orders rose by 1.7 percent in November after falling by 3.4 percent in October.

HEADLINE: Patents;
American Inventors Gained in '89

BYLINE: By Edmund L. Andrews

DATELINE: WASHINGTON

 BODY:
IN a reversal of a 26-year decline, American inventors this year obtained a larger share of the patents issued in the United States than they did in 1988.
This week, the Patent and Trademark Office reported that inventors based in the United States obtained 54,762 patents, or 53.3 percent of the total, a rise of six-tenths of 1 percent, in the fiscal year ended Sept. 30.
Although the improvement in share was small, the increase in the total number of patents awarded was large - 102,712 this year, compared with 83,584 in 1988. Inventors living in the United States obtained almost 24 percent more patents this year than last, coming far closer than usual to matching their Japanese counterparts, who obtained 26 percent more patents in 1989. 
Since 1963, foreign inventors, led by the Japanese, have obtained a growing share of total American patents in all but two years. In the 1988 fiscal year, the foreign share reached a high of 47.3 percent, with one-fifth of the patents going to Japanese.
The most recent tally shows that Hitachi Ltd. of Japan heads the top 10 companies obtaining patents in the United States and that only two American companies are on the list - the International Business Machines Corporation and the General Electric Company. The decline of American companies from the list has frequently been cited as evidence of the erosion of the nation's technological prowess.
The sharp increase in the number of patents issued reflects both a rise in the number of applications submitted and a campaign by the patent office to process applications more quickly.
Experts were encouraged by the numbers but were also cautious. ''It's interesting, but it would be nice to see two years in a row,'' said Edwin Mansfield, director of the Center for Economics and Technology at the University of Pennsylvania.

HEADLINE: Your Money;
Strategies to Pare Tax Bill for 1989

BYLINE: By Jan M. Rosen

 BODY:
MOST people who take an evening to go over their finances will find they can pare their 1989 tax bills, but they must act in the coming week.
The primary areas of opportunity involve charitable contributions and state and local taxes. For people with self-employment income, a Keogh retirement savings plan offers tax deferment, and for those who can take miscellaneous itemized deductions, there may be ways to increase them.
Of course, for some people it will be advantageous to delay any tax savings until 1990. These include people who may move from 28 percent this year to 33 percent next year, or from 15 percent to 28 percent, and those who are subject to the alternative minimum tax bracket of 21 percent this year but are likely to be subject to a regular 28 percent bracket next year. 
Also, some people remain convinced that Congress will raise tax rates, making deductions worth more in future years.
''My own feeling is that they will not rise,'' said Terence E. Kelly, a tax partner with BDO Seidman in Grand Rapids, Mich. He cited the anticipated ''peace dividend'' from the sweeping change in Eastern Europe, which many expect to lead to a reduction of military outlays; a slowdown in the economy, which would be worsened by a tax increase, and the final phase-out of deductions for personal interest and certain passive losses in 1990, which will result in higher collections.
''However,'' Mr. Kelly said, ''I have some clients who believe rates will rise,'' possibly to 33 percent or 35 percent, and possibly as a trade-off for restoring preferential treatment to long-term capital gains.
For those who want to ease the 1989 tax bite and who itemize deductions, here are the main areas of opportunity:
CHARITABLE GIVING: Gifts of cash, property and securities that are given to eligible charities like churches, synagogues, educational institutions, hospitals and other recognized charities, are deductible.
For those not subject to the alternative minimum tax, it is beneficial to give appreciated securities, rather than cash, because the donor can deduct the fair market value of the securities without having to pay a tax on the capital gain. Substantial gifts of property must be appraised.
The gift must be made in the calendar year 1989, so tax professionals advise clients making large donations to make sure they have evidence that they met the deadline. Send a check by certified mail with a receipt, have the bank certify the check, use a credit card or, to be sure a stock certificate is endorsed in 1989, visit the broker, they advise. If the charity does not receive or record the contribution until 1990, that is all right as long as the donor has evidence of making it before the end of 1989.
STATE AND LOCAL TAXES: Quarterly payments of estimated income taxes are due Jan. 16, Mr. Kelly noted, but those who make them in December can deduct them on their 1989 Federal returns. Similarly, real estate taxes that are paid before the end of the year can be deducted on 1989 returns.
MISCELLANEOUS ITEMIZED DEDUCTIONS: Generally only those expenses that exceed 2 percent of adjusted gross income can be deducted. Still, people who pay large dues to trade unions or professional organizations or who have large business expenses not reimbursed by their employers may qualify for the deduction. If so, they may want to bolster it by paying 1989 bills in December instead of January or entertaining clients and charging it to a credit card this week.
Included in this category are the cost of certain business and professional publications, but multi-year subscriptions cannot be prepaid; tax, investment and financial-planning fees; 80 percent of the cost of certain business meal and entertainment expenses, and rental fees for safe deposit boxes.
KEOGH PLANS: People who have income from self-employment are eligible for these tax-deferred retirement savings accounts. This includes freelance income or income from directors' fees, even for people who also have income from an employer.
Julian Block, a tax lawyer in Larchmont, N.Y., notes that unlike individual retirement accounts, Keogh plans must be established by the end of the year, but they do not have to be financed until the due date of the tax return. He advises those pressed for cash to open an account and contribute more next year.
Turning to another area of tax planning, Mr. Block said relatively affluent individuals often give cash to family members or friends because gifts of up to $10,000 to each recipient ($20,000 from a couple) are not subject to gift taxes.
Grandparents, for example, may help grandchildren with their education expenses. But, Mr. Block warns, here the I.R.S. will not buy the line ''the check is in the mail.'' It has to have cleared the donor's account in 1989 to count this year. So anyone making a gift this week should go to the bank and have the check certified, Mr. Block said.

HEADLINE: Fed Voted for No Change In Policy at Nov. 14 Meeting

BYLINE: AP

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Dec. 22

 BODY:
Federal Reserve policy makers decided not to change monetary policy at their late fall meeting but left open the possibility of lower interest rates if economic events dictated, according to minutes of the session released today.
''While current indicators of economic activity suggested a somewhat weaker expansion, most of the members agreed that a steady policy course was desirable at this point, especially in light of the stimulus provided by recent easing actions,'' said the minutes of the Nov. 14 meeting of the Federal Open Market Committee.
Most of the policy makers agreed, however, that ''some further easing might be needed if the incoming information on business activity suggested more softening than most members currently expected.'' 
 
First Drop Since Nov. 7
The Fed permitted short-term interest rates to drop a quarter of a percentage point earlier this week, to 8.25 percent. It was the first decrease since Nov. 7, when the central bank also permitted the Federal funds rate to decline a quarter of a percentage point.
Manipulation of this rate, the interest rate that banks charge each other for overnight loans, is the primary lever the Fed uses to control short-term interest rates. It has used this lever several times since last June, when it began relaxing its grip on credit that was aimed at slowing inflation. 10-to-1 Vote by Panel The initial decision to keep the Fed's policy unchanged was reached on a 10-to-1 vote of the market committee, which is made up of Fed governors in Washington and five of the 12 Fed regional bank presidents.
Martha Seger, a Fed governor, cast the dissenting vote, contending that a further easing was needed in view of persisting weakness in the manufacturing sector, particularly automobiles, and a likely softening in construction and capital spending.
The committee met again last Monday and Tuesday, but minutes of that meeting will not be released until next month. The committee gathers in secret eight times a year to formulate monetary policy and confers by telephone as needed.

HEADLINE: Japan Economic Growth

BYLINE: Reuters

DATELINE: TOKYO, Dec. 22

 BODY:
The Japanese Government today forecast that the country's economic expansion would slow next year but would still be one of the fastest growing of the major industrial nations. The economy is expected to grow 4 percent in the 1991 fiscal year, which begins next April 1, down from the 4.6 percent estimated for the current year. The projected rate would outpace the estimated growth for the United States and West Germany. Japan has also projected a $78 billion trade surplus for 1990-91, down from an estimated $81 billion this year.

HEADLINE: CURRENCY MARKETS;
Dollar Ends Sharply Lower; Gold Moves Higher in U.S.

BYLINE: By The Associated Press

 BODY:
The dollar tumbled yesterday in abbreviated pre-Christmas trading, weighed down by continuing demand for the West German mark and expectations that interest rates are headed lower in the United States.
Gold prices rose in New York after turning in a mixed performance overseas. On New York's Commodity Exchange, gold for current delivery rose $1.30 an ounce, to $413.20. 
Traders said the dollar was little affected by the continuing United States intervention in Panama and the fall yesterday of Nicolae Ceausescu, the longtime Rumanian leader.
The currency markets finished the trading day at around midday, several hours earlier than normal, as traders got a head start on the three-day holiday weekend.
The underlying factors that have affected the dollar in the last few days - a weakening United States economy and the expectation that interest rates are headed lower - continued to depress the currency, traders said. Falling interest rates hurt the dollar by cutting yields foreigners can get on dollar-denominated investments.
In Europe, dealers said that the dollar was hurt by the strength of the mark. As the dollar fell below the 1.7250-mark level, they said, dealers who had instructions from some customers to sell dollars at that level began executing those orders. In New York, the dollar fell to 1.7070 marks, from 1.7260.
In Tokyo, the dollar fell 0.10 Japanese yen to close at 143.67 yen. Later, in London, the dollar was quoted at 143.05 yen. In New York, the dollar fell to 142.35 yen, from 143.65 yen late Thursday.
The dollar also fell against the British pound. In London, the pound rose to $1.6205, from $1.6125 late Thursday. It rose to $1.62425 in New York, from $1.6145 late Thursday.
Selected dollar rates in New York, compared with late rates Thursday, included: 1.5490 Swiss francs, down from 1.5580; 5.8345 French francs, down from 5.8910; 1,277.75 Italian lire, down from 1,285.50, and 1.1592 Canadian dollars, down from 1.1597.

HEADLINE: Boston Mayor's Ulster Project

BYLINE: AP

DATELINE: BOSTON, Dec. 22

 BODY:
A nonprofit group founded by the Mayor of Boston and a Northern Ireland political leader will build a $100 million shopping center in the economically depressed city of Londonderry in Northern Ireland.
Ground-breaking will begin next fall on the 300,000-square-foot complex, which is expected to provide about 1,400 jobs in office, service and construction, Mayor Raymond Flynn said Thursday. The shopping center is expected to open in 1992 and will double the retail space in the city, he said.
 
He said it was the largest
American investment ever in Northern Ireland.
The project stems from Boston Ireland Ventures, a nonprofit group founded in 1987 by Mr. Flynn and the Northern Irish political leader John Hume. Mr. Hume is leader of the Social Democratic and Labor Party, representing moderate Roman Catholics.
Londonderry, the second-largest city in Northern Ireland, is one of the poorest areas in the country, with an unemployment rate in some sections at 45 percent.
After 18 months of negotiations with the British Government, which rules Northern Ireland, the O'Connell Development Company, based in Quincy, Mass., agreed to build the complex.

HEADLINE: Opening Way for Aid, Poland Agrees to Economic Change

BYLINE: By MALCOLM W. BROWNE, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: McMURDO STATION, Antarctica

 BODY:
A new wind is blowing through America's remote outposts in Antarctica: a not entirely welcome impetus toward healthier bodies and tidier habits.
''I'd say what's happening here is that the damn yuppies are trying to make the ice respectable,'' a veteran Antarctic construction engineer observed. ''It's as silly as whitewashing the rocks around a command post in the middle of a war.''
In the last week swarms of National Science Foundation employees, contractors and Navy men and women were spread over the barren hills of McMurdo Station and environs, picking up cigarette butts, soda cans and other litter, some of it decades old. Neither the renowned English explorer Robert Falcon Scott nor his successors who have used this coastal site since the turn of the century appear to have regarded neatness as the greatest virtue. 
But now, partly because of pressure from Greenpeace and other conservationist groups, the watchword is ''environment''; he or she who willfully dirties Antarctica is made to feel guilty. Foolish as it may seem to longtime Antarctic workers to return garbage and chemicals to the United States, everyone appears to be cooperating. Not to do so is to invite dismissal from one's job and the ice.
 
'It's Time to Change'
A lesser burden of guilt is also heaped upon the slothful.
''Here we have an American base - McMurdo Station - side by side with a New Zealand facility - Scott Base,'' a Navy medical corpsman said. ''The Kiwis eat the same food we do, but at the end of a winter season, our triglycerides and low-density lipoproteins are far higher than theirs. We've tested them.
''The reason,'' he continued, ''is that we spend our time 'vegging out' indoors, while they're out on cross-country skis or jogging. It's time to change our flabby ways.''
McMurdo's four bars, serving a summer population of about 1,200, are still crowded to capacity every night until closing at 11 P.M., but now there are aerobics classes each morning. A full-size bowling alley is in constant use, and a few hardy people jog the gravel road up and down long, steep hills leading to Scott Base, two miles away, even when the temperature dips far below zero.
Bulletin boards around the compound's dormitories and common buildings advertise community projects that include meetings of the local chapter of Alcoholics Anonymous, chili cook-offs, square dances, science lectures and hikes to nearby beauty spots.
 
Reminders of Danger
The homespun tone of some of these activities might make it appear that Antarctica had become as tame as the ordinary world. But there are constant reminders that it is as much a killer as it was when men first set foot here a century ago. In the space of one week this month, two ski-equipped transport planes suffered minor crashes, and a helicopter was briefly stuck near the active crater of Mount Erebus volcano.
No one was hurt in any of these incidents, but many of the buildings and sites in the McMurdo area are named for men killed in a long stream of accidents.
Even officially approved activities can be deadly. One of the more potentially hazardous trips favored by hikers and cross-country skiers is to a landmark called Castle Rock. This stony peak, about eight miles from McMurdo, is reached by ascending a steep, snow-covered glacier, along which trail guides have marked a safe route. From Castle Rock, the view of Ross Island, McMurdo Sound and the shimmering white and blue Royal Society Mountains 70 miles away has captivated every traveler since Captain Scott himself.
 
Follow the Flags
The hiker can avoid trouble on the way to Castle Rock by following the bamboo poles and green flags that mark the trail, provided a sudden blizzard does not obscure the flags and disorient him. But three years ago a group of skiers tried a shortcut, and two of them died at the bottom of a crevasse.
Another of McMurdo Sound's scenic attractions - the labyrinthine ice caves that pock its icebound coast - was placed off limits this year. An unusual warm spell that drove temperatures well above freezing ''rotted'' the ice caves, making them liable to collapse. Antarcticans were deprived of the eerie blue luminescence in the caves caused by sunlight penetrating the ice walls.
 
Small Pleasures
To an outsider, the ban on travel to the ice caves might seem a trivial loss, but the small pleasures afforded by Antarctica's usually hostile environment mean a great deal to residents.
When there is nothing to do outdoors, men and women fall back on the reading and video-cassette libraries. They socialize over long, large meals in the galley; check the Navy-run shop that sells souvenirs, cigarettes and shaving equipment; visit the combination barber and beauty parlor, or sleep.
In the blazing 24-hour-a-day sunlight of midsummer, sleep often comes slowly late at night. Even at 4 A.M. a few insomniacs are usually prowling the dusty streets of ''Mac Town,'' admiring the mountains and savoring the crisp sting of the air.
 
Life in the Dome
Americans should spend more time taking the air, says Dr. John T. Lynch, science director of South Pole Station. Most of the living space at the South Pole, including the dining room, pool room, library, bar and other rooms, are housed in oversize orange meat lockers mounted on stilts under an enormous dome above the two-mile-thick ice sheet. The box-like buildings under the dome have no windows, since their only view would be of the gloomy half-light of the dome's interior.
''It turns people into what we call dome slugs,'' Dr. Lynch said. ''There are South Pole residents who never step outside for days on end. It's unhealthy. People think and work better when they're in direct touch with their environment. I would hope a future South Pole Station would allow its inhabitants more sense of belonging to this harsh place, and not allow them to forget where they are.'' Not everyone shares his views. ''Don't you kid yourself about all this fragile environment stuff,'' said a contractor. ''Antarctica is a monster that'll kill you the first chance it gets. I like working here, but if I couldn't shut out old White Mama a lot of the time, I'd go nuts.''

GRAPHIC: In Antarctica, environmentalists hope to compel scientists, known for their tendency to litter, to tidy up. At South Pole Station, above, most residents spend so much time indoors they feel little kinship with the land. (NYT/Malcolm Browne)

HEADLINE: China's Lonely Press Tries to Look the Other Way

BYLINE: By STEVEN ERLANGER, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: BEIJING, Dec. 22

 BODY:
Fearful of reviving its own domestic opposition, the Chinese leadership has kept much of the extraordinary change in Eastern Europe out of the press.
Diplomatically, China has distanced itself from much of Eastern Europe while drawing closer to Rumania. The popular upheaval that has continued in Rumania, despite the sort of crackdown the Chinese carried out in June, remains unreported in the domestic Chinese press. It was, however, mentioned briefly in the English-language China Daily, intended for foreigners.
Chinese students and intellectuals with access to short-wave radios have been getting news about Eastern Europe from the Voice of America and the British Broadcasting Corporation. The Beijing authorities have jammed both services' Mandarin-language broadcasts with uneven efficiency, but not their English-language transmissions. 
''It seems the dialectic of history is with us,'' said a professor at an elite university here, barely suppressing a smile. ''Of course we are encouraged by the changes in Eastern Europe, especially the students. But anyone old enough to have been through the Cultural Revolution knows that China presents a different set of problems.''
 
Deep Roots
Prime among them, he said, is the deeply rooted nature of the Communist Party here, which made the revolution and constructed the patterns of power. Unlike Communist leaderships in Eastern Europe, the leadership here did not arrive in the baggage train of the Soviet Army. And unlike Communist regimes in the Soviet bloc, the Communist system here was not laid upon a functioning Westernized society like a thin layer of asphalt.
The Communist Parties in China, Vietnam and Cuba - all of which have resisted the political tide that seems to flow, however uncontrolled, from Moscow - are associated with larger historical accomplishments like decolonization, national liberation, literacy and better food distribution.
In China, which remains a peasant-dominated state, the general level of education is far lower than in Eastern Europe. And here, too, there are no independent organizations like the Roman Catholic Church in Poland and the Lutheran Church in East Germany around which an opposition can form.
 
Differences With Moscow
While the policies of President Mikhail S. Gorbachev of the Soviet Union have been an inspiration to many dissidents in Eastern Europe, China and the Soviet Union haven't seen eye to eye on very much for the last 30 years or so. Even many Chinese opposed to the leadership here still speak with contempt about Soviet society, politics, culture and technology. This is, after all, a country that has dropped the Volga for the Toyota as fast as it could afford to.
Still, the Chinese leadership has taken great pains to try to limit the infectious nature of change in Eastern Europe. In recent weeks, daily coverage of events there has been limited to a few terse reports in the party newspaper, People's Daily. Beijing radio and television have followed suit with limited items at the end of broadcasts.
Even these reports carefully skip over the popular nature of the protests in Eastern Europe. Changes that are mentioned are described as a result of leadership decisions, not public pressure. Chinese news organizations have also tried to emphasize those shifts as designed to ''perfect socialism'' or insure ''stability and unity,'' a common theme in internal Chinese reporting.
 
No Mention of Corruption
In the sparse coverage of East Germany, for instance, there has been no mention of the corruption charges against the former leadership. In the popular protests here in May and June that were finally crushed by the Chinese Army, a central complaint of the demonstrators was the issue of nepotism and corruption among party leaders and their families.
Press organizations here have also quoted some statements by Eastern European leaders criticizing Western ''manipulation'' and ''interference into internal affairs,'' another popular theme here, as the campaign against American ''meddling'' and what the Chinese call the ''capitalist strategy of peaceful evolution against socialist countries'' continues in full swing.
For example, late last month, People's Daily and the official New China News Agency gave prominence to a report in the official Rumanian party paper, Scinteia, of an ''imperialist offensive'' against socialism. They also highlighted a declaration from the Czechoslovak Defense Ministry that said the Czechoslovak Army supported the party and opposed any ''anarchy fanned by the internal and external antisocialist forces.''
 
Focus on 'Turmoil'
There has also been a series of small reports emphasizing ''turmoil'' in Eastern Europe or the potential for it as the result of domestic change. On Wednesday, for example, the press agency issued a four-paragraph item about a warning strike for higher wages by Hungarian train drivers. It quoted Prime Minister Miklos Nemeth as saying that Hungary would collapse if ''all social strata go on strike in this time of widespread domestic difficulties in the economy.''
At the same time, Western diplomats say, the Chinese leadership has been distancing itself from much of Eastern Europe, keeping correct but cool relations, following standard protocol, with the new regimes in Eastern Europe. The exception has been Rumania, which under President Nicolae Ceausescu kept warm relations with Beijing throughout the Chinese-Soviet split. Ties have become even closer, as they have with North Korea and Cuba.
 
Visit to Rumania
In late November, Qiao Shi, a member of the standing committee of the Chinese Politburo, visited Rumania. In a meeting with Mr. Ceausescu on Nov. 21, reported by the press agency, Mr. Qiao said he was ''deeply impressed by the powerful leadership of the party'' and the ''political ideological work prevalent in the whole party and people.''
On Nov. 18, People's Daily published a lengthy interview with Mr. Ceausescu, who said he ''treasures'' his ties with China and that in a ''rather complicated'' world situation, ''it is all the more necessary to increase cooperation between Communist parties and socialist countries.''
A message from the Chinese to mark the end of the recent Rumanian party congress called for ''militant unity'' between the two parties on the basis of ''revolutionary friendship.''
In the weekly Foreign Ministry briefing on Thursday, the ministry spokesman, Jin Guihua, was asked if China would support Rumania's move to crush ''counterrevolutionary'' demonstrations as the Rumanians had supported China in June. But the spokesman was clearly not going to be drawn into such parallels. He simply said that China did not approve of any country interfering in the internal affairs of another - the same phrase China used today to condemn American military action in Panama - and said, ''We believe that Rumania can properly deal with its own affairs.''
 
A Party Meeting
A Chinese party member said a high-level party meeting was held last week to discuss Eastern Europe, in an effort to enable party organizers to brief their units. The party member said the changes in Eastern Europe were attributed to three factors: the influence of Mr. Gorbachev, who was said to have been described in unflattering terms; the presence in Eastern Europe of ''uneradicated bourgeois and social democratic elements,'' and ''the interference in internal affairs'' by capitalist countries, in particular the United States.
China, the party member said, was described as being a bastion of Communism in the world and one of its firmest defenders. With developments in Rumania, China's position seems that much lonelier today.
On Wednesday, the Chinese party General Secretary, Jiang Zemin, spoke at a conference for party officials. In his speech, reported by the official press agency, he said that stability and economic progress were China's main tasks and required adherence to its policy of openness to the outside world.
 
Hopes for Continued Friendship
BEIJING, Dec. 23 (Reuters) -China's Foreign Ministry said today that it hopes to remain friends with Rumania and, in a report from Bucharest, the official New China News Agency adopted a tone that was mildly supportive of Nicolae Ceausescu without endorsing him personally.
The ministry comment was the first official reaction to developments in Rumania since Mr. Ceausescu fled Bucharest on Friday and army units sided with pro-democracy demonstrators to fight die-hard loyalists.

HEADLINE: Upheaval in the East: Dispatches;
New Candor in the Coverage in Rumania and East Germany

BYLINE: Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Dec. 23

 BODY:
The Rumanian press has begun reporting events with a candor unthinkable before the ouster of Nicolae Ceausescu, Following are excerpts from the Rumanian press agency Agerpres and Rumanian, East German and Hungarian broadcasts as monitored and translated by the United States Government's Foreign Broadcast Information Service.
 
A National Front
 
Rumanian radio domestic service - Ion Iliescu, in a live studio appearance, begins to read a communique from the Council of National Salvation. Iliescu says that the overthrow of the Ceausescu regime is the result of the heroic struggle of all the people, of all nationalities, particularly the youth, and will open a new page in Rumania's political and economic history. He says it was decided to set up a National Salvation Front, supporting the army, to restore democracy and freedom. The Government and the State Council have been dismissed. All state power has been assumed by the National Salvation Front, to which the army will subordinate itself. Local councils of the National Salvation Front, he says, are to be set up in all counties to insure public transportation, public supplies, and a normal development of activities. 
Iliescu says it is proposed:
* To abandon the leading role of a single party and adopt a pluralist system.
* To separate various state powers.
* That the country be called Rumania in the future.
* To form a committee to draft a new constitution.
* To restructure agriculture, helping smallholders, eliminating ideological dogmas.
* To observe the rights of national minorities.
* To reorganize all trade activity.
* To direct the entire foreign policy to united Europe.
* To observe commitments with the Warsaw Pact.
* To observe human rights.
* To restore civilian rule.
Iliescu says the new Salvation Council is a provisional structure.
This is the mandate he received, Iliescu concludes. The reading of the communique concludes. The national anthem is sung.
 
An Appeal to Builders
 
Rumanian Radio domestic service - We appeal to builders on work sites, the nearest one is on Stirbei Voda Street. In order to preserve health, all physicians should come to their offices.
At last moment, piece of news which fills our hearts with joy and we hope it will make you happy, too, esteemed listeners: The tanks of the Ministry of National Defense have arrived to defend the building of the radio station in Nufebilor Street 22-64. The Rumanian Army is up to expectations as it has been during these days of difficult trial for the Rumanian nation.

At this moment we have received wondrous proof from our colleagues in Timisoara; here is radio free Timisoara.
We are broadcasting after 5 years of silence from the hero city, free Timisoara.

All those arrested during the (inaudible) rose up against tyranny and to the collective of the National Theater for their support. The Rumanian people have won. We have in our hands the first leaflet published in Timisoura today entitled: The Tyranny Has Fallen.

The Hungarian press agency, MTI - The Hungarian Ministry of Defense has made public the text of the telephone call which Minister of Defense Ferend Rarpati placed on Friday to Lieut. Gen. Nicolae Eftimescu, first deputy of the chief of staff of the Rumanian Army. . . .

HEADLINE: Upheaval in the East: The Experts' View;
Outlook Is Uncertain for Rumanian Democracy and Economic Improvement

BYLINE: By ERIC PACE

 BODY:
Experts on Rumania and international relations agree that the army will continue to play a crucial role as popular unrest propels the country toward change, but they give differing appraisals of the prospects for democracy and improvement in the economy.
Reacting to the uprising against President Nicolae Ceausescu, Ken Jowitt, a professor of political science at the University of California at Berkeley, said on Friday, ''The army obviously will play a critical role in eliminating whatever opposition from Ceausescu forces may exist and will undoubtedly provide part of the new leadership.''
Professor Jowitt said a post-Ceausescu Government would provide the nation with an entirely fresh start.
 
'Clean Sweep' for Rumania
''Assuming civil war does not break out, I believe that there will be clean sweep, both politically and economically, for at least two reasons,'' he said. ''The first is the widespread rage against the Communist Party of Rumania that permeates the entire population. The second is the example of what is happening'' elsewhere in Eastern Europe. 
He also said Rumanians in the near future will more likely follow ''the more radical Hungarian, rather than the more limited Bulgarian, reform process.''
Professor Jowitt, whose scholarly concerns include all Communist governments, is the author of the 1971 book ''Revolutionary Breakthroughs and National Development in Rumania'' and the editor of the 1978 book ''Social Change in Rumania 1860-1940.'' He speaks Rumanian and has visited Rumania repeatedly over the years.
''What we have to look for now is Rumania's ability to take advantage of the fact that it has no foreign debt, unlike other reforming East European regimes,'' Professor Jowitt said. ''And it also possesses what is potentially a very rich agriculture.''
 
'Really a Disaster'
But Norman Manea, a Rumanian dissident writer who is an International Fellow at Bard College in Annandale-on-Hudson, said, ''Rumania now needs much wealth from the Western countries, because the situation there is really a disaster,'' as far as the economy is concerned.
He said Rumanians ''need the basic elementary needs of sustenance.''
Throughout the 1980's, President Ceausescu pursued a harsh austerity program to eliminate the country's foreign debt, which once stood at $11 billion. The measures included widespread cutbacks in electrical power and heating for homes and industries and a basic disregard for consumer needs.
Joseph Rothschild, a professor of Political Science at Columbia University and a specialist in East Central Europe, took a gloomy view of the prospects for democracy in Rumania, which with 23 million people is the third most populous country in the Soviet bloc after the Soviet Union and Poland.
''I don't expect much,'' he said Friday. ''This is not a country with a democratic tradition which the Communists had suppressed. It is a country that has never had a democratic tradition.''
 
'Potentially Fairly Rich Country'
Appraising the economy, he said: ''Rumania is a potentially fairly rich country. There is a lot of resources under the ground and a significantly trained and economically hardworking and indeed even talented population, so I think the economy can probably do far better than it's done in the last decade'' under the Ceausescu regime.
The post-Ceausescu leadership, he predicted, ''won't be so obsessed by Ceausescu's concern to pay off all foreign debts.''
He predicted that a new government would ''pursue a quite nationalistic line vis-a-vis the Soviets'' and that Rumania would now try to reclaim - or at least to call for the return - of Moldavia, which is now part of the Soviet Union but was formerly a province of Rumania.
J. Michael Montias, an expert on Eastern European economics at Yale University who visited Rumania earlier this month, said: ''The Rumanians are a very talented people. Their elites, while they have been very subservient to the regime, have within them a real potential for improving the Rumanian economy and moving to a more humane political system.''
 
Not a 'Backward Balkan Nation'
Rumania should not be treated ''just as a backward Balkan nation,'' he said.
''They have a history that suggests that democracy is not to be ruled out at all as a possible path of political development,'' he said. ''So I'm not at all unhopeful that if - as the Russians would say - the constellation of forces is right, that Rumania could move toward democracy and toward something like a market economy.''
But Sam Beck, an anthropologist at Cornell who has done research inside Rumania, said that ''for the country to re-establish itself economically, the workers are going to have to have confidence in whatever new government emerges'' if the country's productive capacity is to be expanded.
''What it means is that the Rumanian people as a whole are once again being put into the position of having to sacrifice for the good of the state,'' he said. Mr. Beck added that economic stabilization would be particularly difficult given the current upheaval and the hardships of winter.
But Mr. Beck did see some optimistic signs. ''It's significant that the army did apparently join the populace as a whole and in at least some instances refused to follow the instructions of the security apparatus,'' he said. ''It renews one's confidence in the ability of oppressed people to resist even the kinds of disciplinary mechanisms that can be employed by the military arm of the state apparatus.''
 
'Threshold of Tolerance'
In Washington, former Secretary of State Alexander M. Haig said the ''student-led uprising has now apparently garnered the support of the military so that in the near term, in the final analysis, the military will be instrumental in the future government.''
He also observed that the army's ''threshold of tolerance was exceeded by the brutality of the events in recent days, and that provides a basis for optimism about the future.''
As to the prospects for a post-Ceausescu civilian leadership in Rumania, Mr. Haig, a former supreme Allied commander in Europe, said, ''It's classic in such situations that party moderates will be probably in the first wave of government authority.''
In the economic realm, he said, the only way the country can go now is up. ''Rumania has historically been capable of exports to the West and to the United States,'' he said, ''and therefore, after a period of transition, and given the dire straits of the ecnomy today, it can do nothing but improve.''
Mr. Haig, who was Secretary of State under President Reagan, is the president of Worldwide Associates, an international marketing, merchant-banking and real estate company, and is writing a book on the history of the Cold War.

HEADLINE: Upheaval in the East: Emigres;
From Abroad, Uncertainty And Grieving

BYLINE: By DONATELLA LORCH

 BODY:
Mujur Stancu held a candle and wept yesterday as he sang and prayed in St. Dimitru's Church for the thousands of his countrymen who have been killed in Rumania this week.
About 100 Rumanian-Americans crammed into the one-room Rumanian Orthodox church, smoky with incense, on Manhattan's Upper West Side. Most of them had come to exchange news from Romania - death and perhaps, fledgling democracy - and to discuss what they could do to help relatives and friends there.
Before the Rev. Dimitru Sasu began his simple memorial prayer, the atmosphere was feverish as men and women gathered under the gilded wood paintings of saints and martyrs to speak of revolution, relatives and the fate of President Nicolae Ceausescu. 
''I haven't slept in two days,'' said Mr. Stancu, who is worried about his mother and sister in Bucharest. ''No one knows what is going on. It takes three to four hours to get a phone line to Romania.'' #50,000 Rumanians in U.S.
About 50,000 Rumanians live in the United States, the vast majority having immigrated after World War II, said Vasile Ciobanu, the president of Rumania 21, an organization for exiles. He estimated that 30,000 live in the New York area.
They are loosely organized, with most of them maintaining only individual ties with their homeland. The events this week in Romania, however, are drawing these emigres together and forging a new sense of solidarity.
Mr. Ciobanu was urging Rumanians at the church to return to their homeland and fight. The only consensus at the church, however, was to see Mr. Ceaucescu's dictatorship replaced by democracy, free elections and a market economy.
News of the capture of Mr. Ceausescu, who ruled Rumania for more than a quarter of a century before he was ousted Friday, was greeted with hugs and tears of joy.
 
Anxiety About Violence
But many were anxious about the mounting death toll. Fierce fighting between the army and pro-Ceaucescu security police has claimed hundreds of lives nationwide in the last two days.
Some of the people at St. Dimitru's were dressed in mink coats, others in tattered leather jackets and jeans. But all who gathered in the church seemed to agree that Mr Ceaucescu was a criminal and should be tried for murder.
Their main concern, however, was helping their countrymen. Some of the young men said they wanted to return to fight, and one said he wished the United States would dispatch troops, as it did this week to Panama.
Father Sasu has established a Rumanian Aid Fund to collect money and to send blood supplies, clothes and food.
''I called Bucharest at 3 A.M.,'' Father Sasu said. ''People are saying that it is worse than World War II.''
 
Supplies Are Running Low
The priest said that his niece, a doctor in Timisoara, had been bathing patients with her hands and water because soap and other supplies were unavailable.
He said it was taking about three hours to get a phone line to Rumania, so he had received only sporadic news. But Father Sasu said he had received phone calls from doctors throughout the United States who wanted to go to Rumania to assist in the medical emergency.
Donna Manea, who lives in Jackson Heights in Queens, said her mother had been fired upon in the streets of Bucharest.
But Mrs. Manea was exultant when she spoke of the new provisional Government formed in Bucharest.
''I have a such a feeling of elation,'' said Mrs. Manea, 40 years old, who arrived in New York a year ago. ''Yesterday my mother could speak freely on the phone for the first time. Sometimes, I feel guilty that I am here.''
 
Need for Blood Donations
Father Sasu told the congregation that he had heard reports that the blood bank in Bucharest had been destroyed by ''terrorists,'' and he asked for donations so that fresh supplies could be sent.
Almost all of the people who gathered at the church had heard that the water supply in Timisoara had been contaminated, and that residents had been advised to be careful in choosing what they drank.
Hogea Vladian, 37 years old, an artist from New Jersey, said he was skeptical about the Rumanian-American community's ability to organize.
''Everyone has different ways of arranging things, and that's exactly what is going on in Bucharest,'' he said.
He said that he would like to return to his country, but that he was frustrated by the lack of organization. ''It's anarchy over there, he said.''

HEADLINE: New Bush Budget Will Stick To Themes From Campaign

BYLINE: By DAVID E. ROSENBAUM, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Dec. 23

 BODY:
Sticking to the themes he developed in his election campaign last year, President Bush will emphasize in his budget message to Congress next month new proposals to encourage personal saving and modest spending increases for drug control, education, science, research and the environment, Administration officials said.
And in keeping with his campaign pledges, Mr. Bush will propose no broad additional taxes. But he plans to call for raising a small amount of money with new taxes that he calls ''user fees,''
He also plans to modify slightly his proposal that was blocked by Congress this year to cut the capital gains tax rate and to recommend a new long-term, tax-free savings account.
The President will assert that the lower capital gains tax and the new savings account are essential aspects of the Government's strategy to increase personal savings that can be used for long-term investment. 
 
Budget Message on Jan. 22
Mr. Bush is still tying up loose ends of the budget, which he is to submit to Congress on Jan. 22, and some Cabinet members and agency heads say they still do not know how much they will have to spend in the fiscal year 1991, which begins next Oct. 1. The basic themes of the Bush proposals were gleaned from interviews with White House officials as well as others.
Mr. Bush will stress, they said, that the $6 billion to $8 billion in cuts that he plans to propose for the military need to be used entirely for deficit reduction, not for new domestic spending. He will call for a spending freeze in most domestic programs and will propose no expensive initiatives.
Overall, the budget is expected to call for spending only slightly more than the $1.1 trillion in the current budget, and to project a deficit just below the $64 billion limit set by the budget-balancing law. The Administration estimates that without any cuts in spending or increases in revenue, the deficit for the fiscal year 1991 would be $105 billion.
The Administration's budget will provide a framework for Congress, but from recent experience the specific elements of the final budget Congress approves will bear only the vaguest resemblance to those the President submits.
Here, based on interviews with many officials, are the budget proposals in various areas:
MILITARY. Mr. Bush is expected to ask Congress to approve $295 billion in budget authority for the Pentagon and to propose actual spending of $292 billion. Budget authority is the amount of money Congress approves in a particular year; at the Pentagon the money is often spent over several years.
Those figures are slightly above the $291.2 billion in budget authority and $288.4 in spending in this year's budget. But they are 2 percent to 3 percent below the amount needed to keep pace with inflation and thus, in the odd way budgets are calculated, are counted as a cut of $6 billion to $8 billion.
HEALTH. The President will propose limiting health spending to $5.5 billion below what would be necessary to keep up with inflation, the largest budget reduction outside the military. Hospital reimbursement rates and payments to some physicians under Medicare would be lowered, and Federal money for medical education and capital improvements for urban hospitals would be reduced.
Spending for alcohol and drug abuse would increase slightly, to $2.5 billion, but financing of AIDS research would not be increased. The Food and Drug Administration would be allowed to spend slightly more than this year.
TAXES. To gain more political support for his capital gains proposal, Mr. Bush plans to recommend lowering the tax rate not only for profits from the sale of securities but also those from the sale of real estate, timber and most other assets. His capital gains proposal this year was limited to securities like stocks and bonds. Capital gains are now taxed at the same rate as other income, 28 percent for the wealthiest taxpayers but as high as 33 percent for others. Mr. Bush would reduce the rate to below 20 percent.
The new savings plan would let couples make contributions of about $5,000 a year to a special account, and interest and dividends would be exempt from taxation if the deposits were left in the account for at least 10 years.
The budget will also propose raising $2.5 billion in additional taxes by requiring all state and local government employees to pay the Medicare payroll tax now required of all other workers. Some of those workers are now exempt from the health insurance tax.
Mr. Bush will ask Congress to approve several small new taxes - user fees. For example, he will suggest a sales tax on pleasure boats, recreational vehicles and some camping equipment, with the money to be used for various environmental and recreational programs. Additional fees will also be proposed for processing certain Government forms. Congress has rejected several user fees that former President Ronald Reagan, as well as Mr. Bush, proposed over the last several years.
ENVIRONMENT. In the 1988 campaign Mr. Bush pledged to be the environment President, and his budget message will highlight the environment, showing, for the first time, a tally of all Federal environmental programs. The budget will include a substantial increase in the operating budget of the Environmental Protection Agency, which is about $2 billion this year. Much of the additional money will be earmarked for research on toxic substances, global warming, acid rain and pollution control. More money will also be allotted for enforcement programs.The budget will also include more money for cleaning up pollution at nuclear weapons plants and for acquiring, operating and maintaining national parks.
EDUCATION. As a candidate, Mr. Bush also pledged strong support for education. This year he proposed small amounts of money to reward successful schools, recognize superior teachers and otherwise improve education. These proposals were rejected by Congress, which preferred to place the limited resources on compensatory education programs for poor children.
The President is expected to resubmit the proposals that failed this year and to recommend additional support for health and nutrition for preschool children as well as an expansion of the preschool program Head Start.
DRUG CONTROL. He will call for more money for prison construction, law enforcement and intelligence operations related to the use and trafficking of illegal drugs. He wants a larger allocation for the Border Patrol and more military and economic assistance to Colombia, Peru and Bolivia, the sources of much of the cocaine in the United States.
SCIENCE AND RESEARCH. Mr. Bush will stress applied research to improve the competitive position of American industry internationally. He will call for an increase in the budget of the National Science Foundation, and will seek additional money for developing hardware for a space station, to be completed late in the 1990's.
BUDGET PROCEDURES. Mr.. Bush will suggest that the budget-balancing law be modified so that spending added after the start of a fiscal year would make it more difficult to reach the law's deficit target in the next year. And he will ask for increased authority to block spending approved by Congress that he does not favor.

SECTION: Section 1; Part 1, Page 19, Column 1; National Desk

HEADLINE: AIDS Strategy for Addicts Is Faulted

BYLINE: By GINA KOLATA

 BODY:
Scores of programs that provide clean needles or bleach to drug addicts to prevent transmission of the AIDS virus may fail because they overlook other routes of infection, according to new research and the observations of other experts.
The findings are causing a rethinking of a critical AIDS prevention strategy among the group in which the AIDS virus is spreading most rapidly. Already half of the intravenous drug users in New York are thought to be infected, and many are so frightened of getting AIDS that they are accepting bleach kits to disinfect their needles and syringes.
But the researchers report that even the addicts who try to protect themselves by using bleach risk infection by sharing the water supply they use for rinsing their syringes, and then using that same water to liquefy their drugs for injection.
The addicts also share other paraphernalia that could be contaminated with the virus. But some experts say that even though they are now recognizing the importance of giving the addicts more than bleach, it is politically difficult to give out drug paraphernalia. 
 
Only Half the Message
''It certainly becomes more controversial to give out things that are used in the act of injection,'' said Dr. Don Des Jarlais, director of research at Beth Israel Medical Center's chemical dependency institute in New York.
The Federal Centers for Disease Control reports that of the 113,211 Americans diagnosed as having AIDS, 23,722 used intravenous drugs. An estimated 100,000 intravenous drug users in New York City have the AIDS virus, according to a report by the National AIDS Commission. It can take a decade before an infected person develops AIDS.
Most AIDS education programs, some experts say, are giving addicts only half the message they need to protect themselves against the virus. In most of more than 100 local programs in American cities, addicts are advised to avoid infection with the AIDS virus by using condoms in sex and bleaching needles and syringes.
These programs usually send workers out to take bleach and condoms directly to addicts. A handful of such programs, including one in New York City, also distribute clean needles and syringes.
''We've focused all of our efforts on needles and syringes,'' said Dr. Stephen Koester, an ethnographer with the University of Colorado's Addiction Research and Treatment Services. ''It was not until we really watched people shoot drugs that we came to realize that there is more high-risk behavior than simply sharing needles and syringes.''
 
Peril of Sharing the Water
Dr. Koester said he became aware of the risks that addicts take when he visited their hangouts in Denver and watched what intravenous drug use actually involves. He found, he said, that water is scarce in ''shooting galleries,'' which are often in abandoned buildings.
Seventy-five percent of the 104 addicts he questioned said they shared water, usually rinsing their syringes in it after they injected themselves and before they cleaned the needle and syringe with bleach. Another addict would then use some of that water to liquify heroin, cocaine or other drug before injecting it.
''We have walked into shooting galleries and seen water that was actually pink with addicts' blood,'' Dr. Koester said.
He taped an interview with a heroin user who said: ''Some people shoot dope quicker and faster than others. So, while somebody is rinsing their syringe out in a cup of water, another person is pulling water out to put into their spoon to cook their dope in.''
 
An Economic Necessity
Dr. Koester also found that 85 percent of the addicts in his study shared a spoon or bottle-cap ''cooker'' to mix cocaine, heroin, methamphetamine or other intravenous drugs. It is a ritual meant to conserve the precious drugs. ''Sharing as camaraderie is a myth,'' Dr. Koester said. ''It's an economic necessity.''
First, a group of users will pool their powdered drug and mix it together. Then they will put a cotton filter in the cap to screen undissolved particles that could clog the needle. They siphon up all of the solution into a single syringe and measure how much each user can have.
Then they squirt the solution back out into the spoon and each person puts his or her needle in the cotton and draws up a share of the drug solution. Frequently, to get the last drops of drug out, a user will wait until everyone has drawn off some, and then that user will add a little water to the filter, swish it around and inject the water.
Dr. Des Jarlais also found that the vast majority of New York addicts share cookers. And he has found that addicts who shared cookers were more likely to have AIDS virus infections than were addicts who did not share cookers but otherwise behaved similarly to the sharers.
 
The Ones Who Didn't Know
Intravenous drug users sometimes bleed profusely trying to find a vein. ''They take a rag and wipe the blood up,'' said Yolanda Serrano, executive director of Adapt, the Association for Drug Abuse Prevention and Treatment in New York.
Dr. Koester said that when he told addicts that by sharing water, spoons and filters they risked getting the virus even if they cleaned their needles and syringes with bleach, most were shocked. ''People in the streets say, 'Oh my God, I didn't know you could get it this way,' '' he said.
The majority of addicts who have been questioned said they thought bleach or a clean needle and syringe were enough.
Dr. Barry S. Brown, chief of the community research branch at the National Institute on Drug Abuse in Rockville, Md., conceded that he had thought it would be enough to give out clean needles and that addicts would know how to protect themselves. ''I was really surprised,'' he said. He added that he recently instructed the institute's 41 programs in 45 cities to at least distribute clean water with the bleach and to tell addicts not to share drug paraphernalia.
Dr. Brown said he thought addicts would know they were taking risks by sharing water and paraphernalia. ''You would think there would have been some generalization,'' he said, ''but unfortunately there hasn't been.''
Dr. T. Stephen Jones, a medical epidemiologist at the Centers for Disease Control in Atlanta, keeps track of the agency's efforts to prevent AIDS virus infections among addicts. He said that although the centers have not asked that addicts be given anything beyond bleach and condoms more aggressive efforts are ''something we're considering.''
 
A Clash of Terminologies
Dr. Jones said in particular that although he had ''never heard of anyone giving out water,'' such a program ''would be a good idea.'' The centers finance prevention efforts in 27 metropolitan areas.
Dr. Reyes Ramos, an ethnographer with the University of Illinois in Chicago who works with addicts in El Paso said: ''A lot of the literature talks about high-risk behavior and needle sharing as if addicts have the same terminology as the researchers. By being out there, I've learned that isn't the case.''
Virologists say they have not established just how infectious bloody water, used cotton drug filters, or shared spoons or bottle caps might be if one of a group of addicts was infected with the AIDS virus. Dr. Charles Schable, chief of the serology section at the Centers for Disease Control, said, ''Any time you are transferring body fluids, that would be a potential concern.''
Dr. Koester said his group is now handing out not just bleach but also bottles of water and a piece of cotton to use as a filter when they counsel addicts.
 
Trying to Reach the Addict
Dr. Reyes has recently started handing out water along with bleach and instructing addicts on the dangers of sharing. ''We haven't gotten to the point where we can say that we have organized them to protect themselves, but we are working toward it,'' he said.
Ms. Serrano goes one step further. ''We give them everything,'' she said. ''We give them a one-ounce bottle of bleach. We give them a one-ounce bottle of water. We give them cotton. We give them a cooker. We give them an alcohol swab, and we give them bandages.''
She said many of the addicts her group has counseled have said they are changing their ways. But, she said, with just 13 workers, Adapt has been able to reach relatively few of New York's drug users. ''Bleach is not enough,'' she said. ''Only a small group know that. Most still need to be reached.''

CORRECTION-DATE: December 28, 1989, Thursday, Late Edition - Final

 CORRECTION:
An article on Sunday about programs to prevent transmission of the AIDS virus by drug addicts referred incorrectly to one at the community research branch of the National Institute on Drug Abuse. It provides bleach to clean needles, but does not give out needles.
