HEADLINE: Cold Wave Testing Natural Gas System

BYLINE: By THOMAS C. HAYES, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: DALLAS, Dec. 23

 BODY:
With bitter arctic cold sweeping across much of the nation, dozens of utilities and large industrial customers are scrambling to secure enough energy to avoid shortages and plant shutdowns.
The cold wave is the first major test of the ability of the pipeline system to meet the heaviest demand for natural gas since the Reagan Administration deregulated prices five years ago.
''Right now it is doing well,'' said Michael German, senior vice president of the American Gas Association, an industry trade group. ''The issue is how long the system can maintain record deliverabilities.'' 
 
Operating at Capacity
Natural gas pipelines have been operating at full capacity for more than a week, and dozens of steel mills and automobile and chemical plants in many parts of the Midwest and Northeast have been forced to switch to fuel oil, propane and other power sources.
Analysts said these and other industrial users represented about a third of all gas-shipment orders. Because they can burn other fuels, their supply contracts allow the pipeline companies to shut off supplies to them when cold waves cause a surge in demand. These interruptible contracts have lower rates.
''There has been no curtailment of firm customers by major pipelines, and we don't expect it for the holidays,'' said R. Skip Horvath, an official of the Interstate Gas Association of America, a trade group in Washington representing large pipeline companies. He was referring to customers, including millions of homeowners, who rely solely on natural gas for heating.
The National Weather Service says this month could be the coldest December of the century; the average temperature nationwide was 18 percent below normal through Dec. 16.
 
Busy Month for Pipelines
Pipeline companies say gas shipments, running 30 percent above normal levels, could set a monthly record. The American Gas Association said the highest monthly volume was 2.4 trillion cubic feet in January 1979. Mr. German estimated that shipments this month would range from 2.3 trillion to 2.5 trillion cubic feet.
Industry analysts and pipeline executives said the record cold wave would probably put an end to the surplus of natural gas that gave consumers an upper hand and kept prices depressed over the last four years. It could also stimulate pipeline construction even beyond the $10 billion worth now on the drawing boards, the analysts said.
Prices have soared as natural gas inventories, at a record high in mid-November, slipped below their normal early-winter level.
Sub-zero temperatures are forecast for northern Texas and Oklahoma this weekend.. That would freeze water vapor in hundreds of wells, temporarily cutting gas production.
 
Shortages: Real and Feared
Energy analysts say that if bitterly cold weather again moves south to the Gulf of Mexico for periods of a week or more in coming months, shortages and serious power curtailments for much of the nation may be unavoidable. Scattered shortages of propane and home heating oil were reported last week, especially in the Northeast.
''Even if we have normal weather in January, February and March, we're going to be on the ropes because of the storage runoffs that are occuring now,'' said John E. Olson, a natural-gas analyst with the First Boston Corporation in Houston.
In recent days a number of utilities, industrial users and other large gas consumers have signed or entered negotiations for long-term supply contracts. Many of them were influenced by reports that public gas utilities were offering more than $3 per thousand cubic feet in the spot market, and finding few takers, to keep up with soaring demand. A month ago prices were in the $1.70 range.
The spot market, which deals in natural gas for shipment in 30 days or less, has grown to account for about 75 percent of orders taken by pipeline companies since price controls ended.
 
Placing Their Orders
Sharply depleted gas inventories will keep prices from plunging in the spring when pipeline companies place orders with producers to rebuild their stocks. Prices paid to producers in recent years have ranged from $1.30 per thousand cubic feet in slack periods of spring and fall to about $2 in January, typically the month of peak demand.
A shift to longer contracts and higher prices, if it is sustained, should give producers incentive to raise their drilling budgets, industry officials said.
''This winter of 1989-90 is going to be a watershed'' for the industry, said Thomas A. Petrie, managing director of Petrie, Parkman & Company, an energy investment firm in Denver.
Rising natural gas consumption in recent years had already caused many large independent gas producers, including Burlington Resources, Enron Oil and Gas, Anadarko Petroleum and Union Texas Petroleum, to increase their drilling budgets for 1990.
With economic factors pointing toward rising prices, ''the incentive to drill is increasing,'' said David N. Fleischer, an analyst with Prudential-Bache Securities Inc.
Theodore R. Eck, Amoco Inc.'s chief economist, said drilling activity would rise sharply if gas prices averaged near $2.50 per thousand cubic foot in the coming years.
 
A Cleaner Fuel
For the first eight months of this year natural gas consumption was up 14 percent over the comparable period of 1986, according to the Energy Information Administration. Growth is expected to outpace other fuels, in part because natural gas is one of the least-polluting fossil fuels.
Many analysts said 30-day contracts now being negotiated would range from $2.40 to $2.60 per thousand cubic feet in January, compared with an average of about $1.70 in November and $1.90 in December. With the squeeze on inventories, natural gas prices should move into a higher trading range in 1990.
''Prices won't be as important'' to pipeline executives in the weeks ahead as they search for new gas supplies this winter, said Charles M. Oglesby, executive vice president of the Coastal Natural Gas Group, operator of the nation's fourth largest pipeline system.
He said pipelines near the Gulf Coast would not wait until spring to rebuild their storage reserves if temperatures moderate and prices ease in the coming weeks.

HEADLINE: J. L. Harrisingh Wed in Brooklyn To Miss Bertrand

 BODY:
Judith Ann Bertrand and John Lawrence Harrisingh, assistant corporation counsels for the city of New York, were married yesterday in the Harriet Packer Chapel at the Packer Collegiate Institute in Brooklyn. The ceremony was performed by the Rev. Dr. Donald Roberts, a Presbyterian minister. 
The bride is the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Orlando S. Bertrand Jr. of Brooklyn. The bridegroom is the son of Mr. and Mrs. Lawrence B. Harrisingh of New Rochelle, N.Y.
Mrs. Harrisingh, 25 years old, graduated from Packer and Wellesley College and received a J.D. degree from the University of Chicago. Her father retired as the payroll director of the New York City Law Department. Her mother, Winifred Bertrand, is the chief claims representative in health claims for the Guardian insurance company in New York.
The bride is the granddaughter of Dr. and Mrs. Bertrand of Atlantic Highlands, N.J., and Port Charlotte, Fla., and Mrs. Fitzgerald Blackman of Brooklyn and the late Mr. Blackman, who was the Mayor of Port of Spain, Trinidad, from 1970 to 1974.
Mr. Harrisingh, 25, graduated cum laude from Howard University and received a J.D. degree from Fordham University. His mother, Elaine Harrisingh, is a lawyer in New Rochelle. His father retired as an economist with Amax Inc., a Greenwich, Conn., concern that mines and distributes aluminum, gold, coal and other minerals. The bridegroom is a grandson of the late Scovel Richardson of New Rochelle, a judge of the United States Court of International Trade in New York and a chairman of the Howard University trustees.

HEADLINE: THE YEAR'S BEST;
MORE/On Art

BYLINE: By Michael Brenson

 BODY:
The texture of a season is defined as much by the atmosphere around main events as by the events themselves, as much by the huge and ever-changing cast as by current art stars. Here are a few snapshots from a very personal album.
When you arrive at a large international group exhibition of contemporary art a few days before the opening, there is invariably chaos. You assume that somehow the art will be installed on time, and it usually is. But if you had arrived in Brazil a few days before the opening of the recent SAO PAULO BIENAL and seen all the empty galleries and unloaded crates, you probably would have said to yourself, ''Not this time.'' But the art did get installed and the exhibition did open on schedule. And if some work was uncrated and the varnish on the benches was wet, there was still a sense of triumph. There always is. The first time I saw ''BRAQUE AND PICASSO: PIONEERING CUBISM'' at the Museum of Modern Art was the weekend before the opening when there was no one in the galleries and there were no labels on the walls and the only sound was the stopping and starting of the motorized chair of William Rubin, who, like other curators, depends upon a wheelchair to soften the ordeal of a formidable installation. That day I could not speak about what I had seen. For the first time an exhibition had left me mute. There is one ''Braque and Picasso'' exhibition that depends upon contemplation, but there is also another that depends upon crowds. Between them is a gap that is almost impossible to chart. Anyone visiting the VELAZQUEZ show at the Metropolitan Museum of Art is likely to be struck not only by the paintings but also by the number of viewers standing in the center of the galleries looking confused or lost. What they expect is clearly not what they find. Perhaps the promise of something called ''great art'' is such that the art cannot possibly deliver. Perhaps promising a blockbuster and delivering a small, coherent, scholarly exhibition will generate a frustration that no museum wants.
Here are some New York highlights outside the spotlight. BETYE SAAR'S ''MOJOTECH,'' at the Studio Museum in Harlem, a pointed and poetic meditation on tribal and technological magic . . . With its economy and eloquence, HOUSTON CONWILL'S ''POETS RISE,'' at the new Social Security headquarters in South Jamaica, Queens, may be the best public sculpture installed in New York City this year . . . Of the myriad works inspired by love and knowledge of nature, few have been more surprising and moving than the sculptures of GIUSEPPE PENONE at the Marian Goodman Gallery (through Dec. 30) . . . JONATHAN SILVER's installation of syncretic, allegorical figures at the Sculpture Center put off some people but touched others in ways that not much contemporary art can . . . ''MASTERPIECES OF MING AND QING PAINTING FROM THE FORBIDDEN CITY,'' at the Metropolitan Museum, demonstrated that Chinese painting is so fundamental that eventually just about everyone is going to have to think about it who cares deeply about art. In any album, there are snapshots of people: Barbara Kruger, walking through the galleries of the Pompidou Center in Paris prior to the opening of the ''Magiciens de la Terre,'' weary from installing her own work but with an eagerness and curiosity that should have been the spirit of that failed show . . . Janice Biala, the feisty and articulate octagenarian painter in Paris who bears in her manner and words the memory of a vanishing and irreplaceable Europe.

LENGTH: 2188 words

HEADLINE: THE YEAR'S BEST: FILM VIEW;
New and Original Were the Hallmarks

BYLINE: By Vincent Canby

 BODY:
THIS WAS THE YEAR OF MONEY.
It wouldn't stop talking. Japanese interests bought Columbia Pictures and then paid an emperor's ransom to Warner Brothers to obtain the release of Jon Peters and Peter Guber, the producers of ''Batman,'' to run their new toy.
''Batman,'' which reportedly cost $50 million to produce, went on to make the sort of profits only Steven Spielberg dreams of, after receiving reviews so reverent that they read like the fashion-show coverage of the emperor's new wardrobe.
Some stars were asking (and receiving) $10 million or more per picture, which was the total budget of the average movie in the not too distant past. 
A couple of years ago, Cineplex Odeon, the high-flying Canadian exhibition company now facing financial problems, outraged the public (and Mayor Edward I. Koch) when it raised first-run ticket prices in Manhattan to $7. This year the price went up to $7.50. Nobody uttered a word.
It used to be said that you can't take it with you. This new rapacity suggests that a way has been found. It is no coincidence that this year, as last, all but one of the movies on the top-10 list are based on original screenplays, that is, on material initially conceived of as film material. In each case the result is a work that could not exist in another form without serious alteration of identity.
These are films that enlarge the possibilities of cinema by celebrating what would appear (to playwrights, novelists and short story writers) to be the limitations of the screen. Each in its own way defines the medium. It may also be heartening that four of the top 10 also mark the feature-film debuts of their directors. It's not too much to expect that additional good work will follow. In alphabetical order, the 10-best films of 1989 are: ''Chocolat,'' directed by Claire Denis (her first feature) and written (in French) by Miss Denis and Jean-Pol Fargeau. A limited but no less perceptive and evocative recollection of life in Cameroon when it was a French colony in the 1950's, as recalled today by the the daughter of a white French district officer.
The semi-autobiographical film is about the intense but mostly unspoken friendship of a lonely little French girl named France (Cecile Ducasse) and the elegant black house''boy,'' Protee (Isaach de Bankole), the would-be warrior who acts as her de facto nanny. As the elder France (Mireille Perrier) remembers the events of one hot summer, she comes to understand something of the forces that led inexorably to the violent end of trust. Everything that happens is vivid and clear and subject to the kind of speculation that rewards as it tantalizes.
''Chocolat'' is beautifully acted and shot with the kind of clarity that is the cinema equivalent to spare, carefully measured prose.
''Crimes and Misdemeanors,'' written and directed by Woody Allen. Mr. Allen's most successful ''serious'' film is also his most seriously funny comedy, a big, multicharacter piece about how some members of today's upper middle class (in this case Jewish) society might not only get away with murder, but also get away guilt-free.
''Crimes and Misdemeanors'' dramatizes the rootlessness that haunts its characters, played to perfection by Martin Landau, Anjelica Huston, Mia Farrow, Jerry Orbach, Claire Bloom, Joanna Gleason, Sam Waterston and Martin Bergmann. It's a toss-up as to whom steals the show: Alan Alda, as a successful, incredibly self-assured television producer, or Mr. Allen, as a dedicated producer of documentaries that tend to be honored only at obscure film festivals abroad.
''Do the Right Thing,'' written and directed by Spike Lee. With his third feature film, Mr. Lee comes into his own as director of distinctive style, capacity and passion. Set in Brooklyn, in one block of Bedford-Stuyvesant on the hottest day of the summer, the film chronicles the events leading up to a vicious race riot.
The movie is big, colorful, tumultuous and sorrowful. Its resolution continues to shock and disturb long after one leaves the theater. There is, however, no doubt about the mastery of the man who wrote, directed and stars in it. The excellent cast also includes Danny Aiello, Ossie Davis, Ruby Dee, Richard Edson, John Turturro, Giancarlo Esposito, Bill Nunn and the exuberant Rosie Perez.
''Enemies, a Love Story,'' directed by Paul Mazursky and written by Roger L. Simon and Mr. Mazursky, based on the novel by Isaac Bashevis Singer. Nothing Mr. Mazursky has done before has the wit, wisdom and complexity that are evident in ''Enemies, a Love Story,'' the director's finest film to date. Perhaps Mr. Singer is the collaborator for whom he has always been searching.
Set in New York City (mostly Coney Island and the Bronx) in 1949, the film embraces not only the Holocaust, which is tricky material for the maker of fiction, but also the entire Jewish experience. It's about the earnest, feckless Herman (Ron Silver), a Polish Jewish emigre who survived the war hidden in a hayloft, tended by his former housemaid Yadwiga (Margaret Sophie Stein), a Gentile whom he has since married out of gratitude. Unknown to Yadwiga, Herman maintains another household in the Bronx where he lives with the exotic Masha (Lena Olin), a survivor of the death camps who knows all about the Brooklyn wife but makes allowances.
The menage is further complicated by the arrival of Tamara (Anjelica Huston), the Polish wife Herman thought had died in the camps with their children. ''I'm dead,'' Tamara says cheerfully when she arrives at Herman's Brooklyn apartment.
Though Herman is a very peculiar and particular character, he is also - without meaning to be - Everyman. He is a wonderfully hopeful, forlorn fellow whose existence is a bedroom farce played in three-quarter time. ''Enemies'' is funny and sad and, by being utterly specific, mysterious. The performances are among the year's best.
''High Hopes,'' written and directed by Mike Leigh. The subject of this brilliant satire is life in Margaret Thatcher's England as seen from the vantage point of the underemployed and ever-skeptical. The characters include Cyril, a bearded young man who refuses to cooperate with the System and thus works as a messenger; and Shirley, the loving, wise young woman with whom he lives. There are also Cyril's despairing old mum, his wildly ambitious, nouveau riche sister, her gross husband and random Thatcher types, whose scenes are as comic as anything in a political revue.
Mr. Leigh's films are the result of long weeks of rehearsals, during which actors are encouraged to improvise. This may be one of the reasons for the extraordinary spontaneity that lights up ''High Hopes,'' which veers from sober drama to comedy to outright farce without missing a beat.
''Little Vera,'' directed by Vasily Pichul and written (in Russian) by Maryia Khmelik. The unexpected frankness of ''Little Vera'' was so newsworthy that it almost overshadowed the quality of the film itself. This is an exuberant kitchen-sink comedy about a pretty, bored, heavily made-up teen-ager, Vera (Natalya Negoda), who drifts into marriage with a young student who is probably going to make her life miserable.
''Little Vera,'' set in and around an unnamed port city, makes no attempt to see the bright side of the dreary lives of Vera, her exhausted mother, her alcoholic father and her brother, a doctor who lives in Moscow and seems to be well on his way to becoming a pompous bore. Mr. Pichul regards his characters with sympathy, but imposes no hopes on them. The tone is cool. The warmth, of which there is plenty, comes from the humanity of the characters and the actors who play them, especially Miss Negoda. ''Mystery Train,'' written and directed by Jim Jarmusch. Mr. Jarmusch's third released feature is his chef d'oeuvre. The comedy is a three-part fable set in a Memphis, Tenn., where Elvis Presley is still big business. Elvis's ghost also haunts every room of the Arcade Hotel, the seedy establishment that is the film's principal setting.
Mr. Jarmusch's sense of humor illuminates even the most somber settings and most dimwitted characters. It locates the order in a universe that is otherwise beyond comprehension. ''Mystery Train'' is light as a feather. It is also eccentric, original and has the kick of a controlled substance. The great color photography is by Robby Muller.
''Roger & Me,'' written and directed by Michael Moore. This feature-length documentary (Mr. Moore's first film), is one man's blisteringly funny attack on the giant General Motors Corporation, which Mr. Moore holds to account for its treatment of long-time employes in Flint, Mich. The film documents the sad economic state of Flint after the closing of various G. M. operations. Since the film's showing at the New York Film Festival, Mr. Moore has been criticized for the loose way in which he has played around with historical sequence to make his case against the company. This isn't a nice thing to do, and , perhaps Roger Smith, the chairman of G. M., has a right to be offended. However, Mr. Moore might argue, throwing thousands of workers out of their jobs wasn't exactly admirable either.
''Roger & Me'' is clearly one man's biased commentary, the sort of flagrant, opinionated, freewheeling journalism that means to be offensive on behalf of people who have no voice in things. It is personal journalism of a highly original, satiric and colorful order, quite unlike the work of any other documentary film maker at work today.
''Sex, Lies and Videotape,'' written and directed by Steven Soderbergh. Mr. Soderbergh's first feature is a small, stunningly controlled comedy about love, marriage, sex and idle philandering.
At the center is Graham, a romantic if impotent young man who can only relate to women whom he tapes on his camcorder as they talk about their sexual fantasies. There is also John, who is having a torrid affair with Cynthia, the sister of his wife, Ann. Do you follow? Mr. Soderbergh's film makes these relationships completely clear, as well as very funny and rueful. Relationships aren't easy, especially when, as in our society, they are virtually all one talks about.
''Sex, Lies, etc.'' is a remarkable achievement for young Mr. Soderbergh and his principal actors, James Spader, Andie MacDowell, Peter Gallagher and Laura San Giacomo.
''True Love,'' directed by Nancy Savoca and written by Miss Savoca and Richard Guay. An astonishingly fine first film, ''True Love'' is set in the same Bronx that gave us Paddy Chayefsky's ''Marty'' 30-odd years ago. Miss Savoca follows the preparations leading up to the marriage of two good-looking, lower-middle-class Italian-Americans who may well be ruing the day two years later.
The uproariously comic surface of the movie never obscures the probably bleak future awaiting the betrothed pair. Yet the film also seems to understand that this future will somehow be weathered in the same way the pair survive the chaos of their wedding. The film has been written, directed and acted with breathtaking skill. The cast members to remember include Annabella Sciorra (the bride) and Ron Eldard (the groom). The runners-up, in no particular order of importance: Jim Sheridan's ''My Left Foot,'' with Daniel Day-Lewis's extraordinary performance as Christy Brown, the physically disabled, Dublin-born painter and writer; Brian De Palma's ''Casualties of War,'' with Sean Penn and Michael J. Fox, about a Vietnam soldier who blows the whistle on his comrades after they rape and murder a Vietnamese peasant woman; Oliver Stone's ''Born on the Fourth of July,'' based on Ron Kovic's memoir about a radicalized Vietnam vet, played by Tom Cruise in one of the year's most moving performances.
Also, Edward Zwick's ''Glory,'' written by Kevin Jarre, a big, brightly colored, pageantlike account of the heroism of an all-black Union regiment in the Civil War, with Matthew Broderick, Denzel Washington and Morgan Freeman, among others; ''Driving Miss Daisy,'' Bruce Beresford's appreciative screen adaptation of Alfred Uhry's Pulitzer Prize-winning play, with Jessica Tandy and Morgan Freeman.
Also Juzo Itami's ''Taxing Woman's Return,'' in which the most humane and satiric of Japanese directors studies a Japan that is turning to bogus religious cults and Swiss bank accounts; Claude Chabrol's chilly, aggrieved ''Story of Women,'' based on the true story of a rather commonplace, opportunistic young woman (Isabelle Huppert) who finds her calling as an abortionist during World War II and is guillotined more for political than moral reasons.
Also ''Henry V,'' a tough, vivid, pocket-sized screen version of the Shakespeare play, adapted and directed by Kenneth Branagh, who also plays the title role with great efficiency; Gus Van Sant Jr.'s ''Drugstore Cowboy,'' in which Matt Dillon gives a mini-bravura performance as a small-time Portland (Ore.) thief and junkie; and Danny DeVito's ''War of the Roses,'' with super performances by Kathleen Turner and Michael Douglas, a hilariously nasty comedy that is the flip side to all movies in which lovers live happily ever after.

GRAPHIC: Andie MacDowell in Steven Soderbergh's stunningly controlled comedy ''Sex, Lies and Videotape,'' Martin Landau in Woody Allen's ''Crimes and Misdemeanors,'' Mr. Allen's most seriously funny comedy, and Annabella Sciorra and Ron Eldard in Nancy Savoca's astonishingly fine ''True Love''; Cecile Ducasse in Claire Denis's perceptive and evocative ''Chocolat, '' Youki Kudoh and Masatoshi Nagase in Jim Jarmusch's ''Mystery Train, '' a film with the kick of a controlled substance, and Natalya Negoda in Vasily Pichul's ''Little Vera,'' an exuberant kitchen-sink comedy (Biran Hammill); Philip Davis and Ruth Sheen in Mike Leigh's brilliant satire ''High Hopes,'' Spike Lee and Danny Aiello in Mr. Lee's tumultuous and sorrowful ''Do the Right Thing'' and Michael Moore in his blisteringly funny ''

HEADLINE: BROADWAY BUSINESS;
The Sound of Synthetic Music

 BODY:
To the Editor:
Peter Passell's article on the economics of the theater business discusses efforts to reduce some ticket prices (or fatten profits) by cutting labor costs. Falsely claiming that musicians' work rules are ''from the Middle Ages'' and that they deter the use of new technology, Mr. Passell reports ''some accounts'' that ''a few musicians playing synthesizers could now do the work of an entire orchestra.''
In fact, undeterred by our union's work rules, three synthesists in Broadway's current incarnation of ''Sweeney Todd'' are now gamely trying to emulate its original 25-musician orchestration. Most listeners, including your own reviewer, have found the synthetic sound to be inferior. It is only partially true that ''these machines can duplicate the sound of most conventional instruments with uncanny accuracy.'' They can imitate the sounds of single instruments, one note at a time, fairly well. But they are no match for living musicians who are experts at phrasing, the art of connecting one note to another to make an expressive musical statement. And the machines can't begin to generate the excitement that an ensemble of talented musicians, interacting with each other, with the performers on stage and with the audience, can bring to a theatrical production. 
Our labor agreement's requirements for minimum numbers of musicians, varying according to the sizes of theaters, is not ''featherbedding.'' Even with synthesizers, several recent productions have seen fit to employ larger orchestras than required. Most people know that large orchestras produce greater richness annd variety of sound than small ones. Except for your reporter, a few accountants and an insensitive minority of Broadway managers, nearly everyone agrees that our work rules are reasonable - that's why they're still in the agreement, which is renegotiated every three years.
Did you know that the entire cost of the whole orchestra in ''Jerome Robbins's Broadway'' (one of the shows using more musicians than required) is less than $3.50 per ticket? Let's face it, even if no musicians were employed, audiences would still have to fork over more than $56.50 a seat. The Times and theatrical managements should look elsewhere for meaningful savings.
 
JOHN GLASEL
 New York
 
The writer is president of Local 802 of the Associated Musicians of Greater New York, American Federation of Musicians, AFL-CIO.

HEADLINE: CLASS IN MOVIES;
Mirroring Small-Town Life

 BODY:
To the Editor:
Janet Maslin makes a thought-provoking point when she writes that the avoidance of class issues causes American films to ''feel hollow'' [''Class Consciousness: The Pros and Cons,'' Nov. 26.]. But when she criticizes the characters in ''Steel Magnolias'' for looking and sounding alike despite their diverse backgrounds, I think she ignores one of the realities of small-town life.
As someone who has lived in a rural village, a medium-sized city and the New York metropolitan area, I can report that class distinctions are often less pronounced in very small towns, where people of varying backgrounds and economic circumstances frequently live in the same neighborhood and attend the same church - as the characters in the film do.
It's quite possible, I suspect, for a group of small-town Southern women who gather in the same place over a period of years to become fast friends, and grow to sound alike. And, considering that their meeting place is a beauty salon, they might look somewhat alike, too.
 
MICHAEL GATES
 Jersey City, N.J.

HEADLINE: THE YEAR'S BEST: ARCHITECTURE VIEW;
Pei, Prince Charles - and Skyscrapers Everywhere

BYLINE: By Paul Goldberger

 BODY:
IN ARCHITECTURE, THIS WAS SURE-ly the year of I. M. Pei: not a new face, to be sure, but an omnipresent one. In Paris, Mr. Pei's glass pyramid in the court of the Louvre, the object of bitter controversy for years, opened in April to an almost entirely positive reaction. Those who had always thought a crystal pyramid was the right idea for a new entrance and virtual logo for the Louvre rejoiced in self-satisfaction that the 72-year-old Mr. Pei had maneuvered his way through the political thicket so skillfully; the doubters generally came around, moved by the extraordinary beauty of Mr. Pei's exquisitely crafted object and by the extent to which it did allow the older buildings of the Louvre to maintain their integrity. In the end, the quibbles were minor: the way the three little pyramids placed beside the main one trivialized the composition, for example, or the way the staircase was detailed - hardly enough to deny the success of the project as an example of what Mr. Pei does best, which is to create a true civic monumentality in the modernist mode. And that is what the architect did as well in his second major public building to be finished last year, the Morton H. Meyerson Symphony Center in Dallas. Opened in September, the Meyerson could be called a grand concert hall in the new style: it aspires to the luxury and monumentality of the great classical halls, but the architecture is mainly Mr. Pei's modernist geometries. Its swooping shapes of glass and limestone are a bit too abstract on the outside, but inside, the auditorium, which has somewhat of the air of Viennese modernism to it, is warm and pleasing.
Mr. Pei also saw the completion this year of the headquarters for Creative Artists Agency in Beverly Hills, a tiny modernist gem, barely bigger than the houses of certain Hollywood moguls, but more sleek and self-assured than a dozen of them put together. And in Hong Kong, the architect's Bank of China, the tallest building on that explosive skyline, and perhaps his most important skyscraper ever, was finished. But it was also a year for Mr. Pei's longtime design partners, Henry I. Cobb and James Ingo Freed: for the first time, they got their names on the door as the title of the Pei firm was switched on Sept. 1 from I. M. Pei & Partners to Pei Cobb Freed & Partners. Mr. Freed's powerful and complex design for the Holocaust Museum to be built in Washington, which was made public last year, underscored the breadth of design strength that exists within this architectural office.
If I. M. Pei seemed the most attention-getting practicing architect in 1989, surely Prince Charles was the layman who loomed largest over the architectural profession. His criticisms of modernism, which began with a speech in 1984 attacking a proposed addition to the National Gallery in London, reached a fever pitch in 1989 with the publication of his book ''A Vision of Britain'' and the mounting of an exhibition presenting the Prince's views at the Victoria and Albert Museum in London. The Prince is now Britain's architect-in-chief in all but official title, as developers have begun to feel it necessary to seek his approval for major projects, and his views seem to have become more and more rear-guard as time has gone on. The Prince's dislike of modern architecture in Britain is not hard to understand - most of it is awful - but his rhetoric seems more likely to encourage sweet and sentimental little classical buildings than the more civilized and urbane modern buildings that are urgently needed.
What does it mean that I. M. Pei, the pre-eminent modernist, and Prince Charles, the ever-more-dogged classicist, together dominated the architectural picture in 1989? Maybe that celebrity, diplomacy and a self-assured, aristocratic bearing count for as much as any ideological position, since if Mr. Pei and the Prince share anything, it is that both are famous, both are good with words and both are as suave as the day is long. What it really tells us, of course, is that the public is not so determined to live only in the world of cozy classical buildings envisioned by the Prince - that under the right circumstances, when modern buildings can be made to possess both the sensuality and the civic grandeur of great classical ones, the public likes them just fine. Many buildings of the past year had nothing to do with either Mr. Pei or the Prince, of course. Among the most memorable were the Canadian Center for Architecture in Montreal, by Peter Rose, and the Wexner Center for the Arts at Ohio State University in Columbus, by Peter Eisenman and Richard Trott. The two buildings make a striking juxtaposition: both cultural institutions, both their architects' first major public buildings, they could not be more different in terms of the design philosophies they represent. The Canadian Center is a subtle and complex essay in stone, metal and wood, a museum and library that beautifully integrates classicism and modernism, and in many ways evokes the spirit of Louis Kahn in its determination to imbue us with a sense of architecture's basics without literally copying from history. It is a building that embodies the very best possibilities of this moment, and it marked an auspicious debut for Peter Rose, who must now be considered among the figures to be reckoned with in North American architecture.
The Wexner Center is a building that seems at once trendier - it is the major American monument in the style of clashing angles called deconstructivism - and more old-fashioned. Designed by Peter Eisenman, a renowned theorist who has at last begun to build actively, it is a building that is intended by its architect to be disquieting, but is in fact less shocking and awkward than the rhetoric surrounding it would have us believe. This building will not be an easy place in which to display art, but many of its interior spaces, as well as the vast gridlike arcade outside it, are powerful architectural experiences. But in its insistent belief that modernity still possesses the ability to throw us out of equilibrium, the real message the building sends is one of nostalgia for the idea of the avant-garde.
It is paradoxical that the year that gave us the Canadian Center for Architecture also saw a threat to the masterpiece by Louis Kahn that in many ways influenced it, the Kimbell Museum in Fort Worth. Last summer the Kimbell announced plans to expand Kahn's 18-year-old building by adding new sections imitative of the original design, in effect turning the building into an architectural version of a stretch limousine. The design, by Romaldo Giurgola, provoked an outcry; 1990 will see whether the Kimbell goes ahead, or decides that it can respect this great building better by leaving it be.
Otherwise, it was a year of more and more skyscrapers everywhere, from the outtowns, those suburban clusters of high-rises beside the interstates, to the downtowns. Stylistically there is a bit more calmness to the major buildings finished in the last year: structures like the NBC and A.T.& T. buildings in Chicago, both by Adrian Smith of Skidmore, Owings & Merrill; the Norwest Center in Minneapolis by Cesar Pelli; 1675 Broadway and 114 East 47th Street in New York by Fox & Fowle, and World Wide Plaza in New York by David Childs of Skidmore, Owings & Merrill all suggest a comfortable but not slavish historicism. These are all buildings that echo the spirit of the towers of the 1920's and 1930's, but they wear their nostalgia gently, and do not copy the past too literally. So, too, with one of the more promising skyscraper designs to be announced in the last year, the proposed new tower for Rockefeller Center in Manhattan by William Pedersen of Kohn Pedersen Fox. In all these projects there is a sense of responsible urbanism, a belief that the tower is part of a larger urban fabric and not a prima donna object in itself - and if there is any accomplishment in the last year, it is the willingness of architects to tone down just a tiny bit the egos that have so dominated design in the last decade. Not a lot, mind you, but a little. A sorry exception is the new design unveiled in late summer for the proposed 42d Street Redevelopment Project in Manhattan, by John Burgee Architects with Philip Johnson; these four towers, controversial since they were first announced in 1981, have now been redesigned as monoliths of deconstructivism, perhaps the neatest marriage of trendiness and gigantism in memory. The buildings are much too big, as they were in 1981; switching architectural style without changing anything else does nothing to address the underlying problems in this project and, indeed, has the sorry effect of enhancing the sense that architecture is merely a matter of fashion - if the style looks tired, don't worry, it can be changed in an instant.
As a new city administration prepares to take office, to be led by a Mayor who has been at least slightly more skeptical of large-scale development than his predecessor, the outlook for the Times Square project is uncertain, even though all official approvals have been obtained. But architecture enters the 1990's with both a weakened economy and a strengthened sense of social responsibility, making the mega-projects of the last few years more than a little problematic. There is more talk of turning architects' talents once again to housing, to schools, to public places. Not the least of the achievements in New York in the last year has been the completion of a major chunk of the city's $5.1 billion housing program, which calls for the renovation or construction of 286,000 housing units for people of low to moderate incomes by 1998, as well as the completion of the prototype for a series of transitional residences for the homeless, designed for the city by Skidmore, Owings & Merrill. The gradual shift in priorities as we move to a new year, and a new decade, would surely have pleased three of architecture's leading lights who died in 1989: Edgar Kaufmann Jr., the architectural historian who helped inspire his family's house, Fallingwater, by Frank Lloyd Wright, and later turned it into a public museum; Percival Goodman, the architect and teacher who specialized in synagogues but for generations was an outspoken advocate of good planning in New York; and Hassan Fathy, the Egyptian architect who engaged in a lifelong struggle to prove that the traditional vernacular architecture of the Middle East was not incompatible with the need to provide adequate housing for a contemporary society. Different men all; what they shared was a love of architecture and a belief that it could enrich the fabric of life.

HEADLINE: PROSPECTS;
Setting High Tech Free

BYLINE: By JOEL KURTZMAN

 BODY:
Earlier this month U S West Inc. made a successful bid to lay a fiber-optics network in the Soviet Union. Last week, the Commerce Department indicated it would allow the deal to go through. The decision could signal a willingness by the United States to ease restrictions on high-tech exports. These exports are currently limited by the Coordinating Committee on Multilateral Export Controls, called Cocom, which includes 17 Western countries. Will Cocom change its rules? Four experts discuss its future.
 
Donald M. Kendall
Chairman of the executive committee, Pepsico Inc. 
The Cocom list of restricted technology exports has been expanded beyond our ability to watch it. In the past the list has been very restrictive. When Richard Perle was Assistant Secretary of Defense the list was ridiculous. He even stopped the building of a combine plant on the basis that it could be used to make armored cars.
The list should be confined to something that can be maintained. What we need to do is get together some people from industry and the military and start at ground zero. Cocom should only limit leading-edge technology. Because of our balance of trade problems we have to get aggressive about selling overseas.
 
Roger W. Robinson Jr.
President, R.W.R. Inc., and former senior director for international economic affairs, National Security Council.
Western export controls have been greatly exaggerated as a constraint on the normal conduct of East-West trade. The Cocom regime remains crucial to maintaining the West's qualitative edge in military technology over the Soviet Union's quantitative advantage. Neither Soviet economic nor political reforms are yet irreversible and both espionage and technology theft are on the rise. Despite the best intentions of reformers in Eastern Europe, Moscow still possesses formidable leverage through Warsaw Pact membership, control over energy supplies and as a market for Eastern Europe's exports. An across-the-board exemption which significantly expands East European access to militarily relevant Western technology is therefore premature.
 
Arthur Hartman
Senior consultant, Apco Associates, and former ambassador to the Soviet Union.
Changes in Cocom have been long overdue. The procedure has to be simplified and brought up to date. Over the last four years there has been a reduction in the list of restricted items and a change from restricting individual items to restricting specific systems and processes. Most joint ventures themselves don't require very high technology. But what happens is that now even simple technologies are hooked up with computers and that limits them.
But Cocom isn't really holding up trade. Lack of foreign exchange on the Soviet Union's part and an inability to make decisions and plan what they want is what's holding up trade with the Soviet Union.
 
Ed Hewett
Senior fellow, the Brookings Institution.
I don't think the overall impact of Cocom is that important. A lot of Soviet factories are museum pieces. It would be a boon for them just to have 1970's technology. And that is what Soviet factories will want once they are decentralized to the point that they are paying for the technology they want to import.
But one area where Cocom is significant is with Soviet defense companies that want to enter into joint ventures with Western companies. These companies are looking for partners in manufacturing. They are the best companies in the Soviet Union. They know quality but they have high production costs. With the right manufacturing partners they could do much better. By restricting joint ventures, Cocom ultimately will limit the flow of new Soviet technology back to the United States.
My guess is we'll see the Cocom list of restricted exports shrink when Commerce Secretary Mosbacher gets out in front on the issue.

HEADLINE: BUSINESS FORUM: THE COST OF CAPITAL;
How to Make Raising Money Cheaper

BYLINE: By WILLIAM FARLEY; William Farley is chairman and chief executive of Farley Industries.

 BODY:
THE acceleration of Japanese purchases of American corporate icons like Rockefeller Center, Columbia Pictures and CBS Records should come as no surprise, given the huge advantage that the Japanese enjoy in capital costs. Recent studies have found that America's capital is between 2 1/2 and 4 times as expensive as Japan's. Inexpensive capital has given the Japanese a booming manufacturing sector and ample cash with which to purchase foreign assets.
Why is Japan's capital so much cheaper? According to George Hatsopoulos, an expert on the cost of capital, the differential results from three factors:
First, Japanese companies are able to obtain more of their financing in low-cost debt or debt-like instruments, while the structure of the American financial system dictates that American companies rely on expensive equity financing. Japanese debt-to-equity ratios are roughly 3-to-1, while ours are 1-to-3. 
Second, the Japanese save more than three times as much of their incomes as Americans, thereby creating a greater pool of capital for investment within their country.
Third, tax policy in Japan helps reduce the cost of capital by encouraging savings and investment.
The general perception about Japan's advantage in the cost of capital is that it is the result of interest rate subsidies. But subsidies are not as critical as the differences in debt-equity ratios. Tradition in the United States require that balance sheets be heavily weighted toward equity and that corporations be debt-adverse. In Japan, debt and debt-like instruments are common. It is becoming increasingly clear that in the 1990's, American companies will be reducing their debt while they increase their reliance on equity financing.
The problem with America's reliance on equity financing is that it is extremely expensive. It is expensive because entrepreneurs must give away a piece of the company.
Here is a very simplified example of how costly equity financing can be, particularly for a rapidly growing company. Let's assume that you have a venture for which you need to obtain $5 million in start-up capital. Let's also say you believe that in 10 years the company will be worth $100 million.
If you can borrow the money from a commercial bank at 10 percent interest, over 10 years you will pay $5 million in interest. If you can sell high-yield bonds at say 15 percent, you will pay $7.5 million in interest over 10 years. But if you had to give up a modest 25 percent in equity to get that $5 million - and if you pay no dividends - you will end up giving up $20 million in value. Even though this is a simplistic example, which does not account for inflation, it is clear that debt is much cheaper.
The implications of the cost-of-capital differentials are scary. Hindered by the high cost of capital, American business cannot afford to reinvest as much as the Japanese or invest in high-risk endeavors that can create enormous leaps in technology.
The cost-of-capital problem is a major threat to America's economic future. If today's politicians do not act to lower the cost of equity capital, they risk stalling the economy. Their short-sighted tax and spending policies helped put us at a competitive disadvantage. The tax changes from 1981 to 1986 increased our capital costs by as much as 90 percent, according to a June 1990 special report from the American Council for Capital Formation.
ALTHOUGH the 1986 tax revision package made some progress toward the elimination of incentives for over-consumption, it did not take the steps necessary to stimulate savings and investment. On balance, we still have a tax system that does not promote economic growth.
For individuals, we can restore preferential treatment of capital gains, reduce the limitations on individual retirement accounts and move toward consumption-based taxes. For business, dividend deductibility would slice into Japan's capital cost advantage, because it would make equity more like debt.
American politicians must stop treating the symptoms of the high cost of capital and start treating the disease. Their predilection for short-term solutions has only made our long-term economic problems worse. Growing Japanese ownership of American assets can be stopped by legislative actions. But these legislative actions should be aimed at lowering the cost of capital and restoring America's competitiveness. America does not have to have more expensive capital than Japan. The slogan of one Japanese car manufacturer is ''inexpensive and built to stay that way.'' That applies to Japan's capital as well. America's capital is expensive and unless Congress takes steps to lower capital costs by reducing the budget deficit and increasing incentives for savings and investment, it will stay that way. If we reduce the cost of capital, we can keep America American.

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

SECTION: Section 3; Page 2, Column 3; Financial Desk

LENGTH: 790 words

HEADLINE: BUSINESS FORUM: THE COST OF CAPITAL;
Don't Give Up on Junk Bonds

BYLINE: By GLENN YAGO; Glenn Yago is director of the economic research bureau at the W. Averill Harriman School of management at State University of New York.

 BODY:
RECENTLY, I participated on a panel with leaders of the House and Senate to discuss mechanisms for increasing investment in distressed communities. None of the communities or minority businesses we discussed were investment grade. Rather, they were completely unbankable, and most credit analyses by rating agencies would classify them as ''junk'' investments.
Nevertheless, warm from the witch hunt against Michael Milken and studying further capital market regulations that will limit capital access, the Congressional panel members reveled in sucker-punching the junk-bond market for its 3 percent decline for the quarter. 
Yet, what the panel didn't know is that in the context of American financial history, junk bonds are nothing new. High-yielding financial innovations started with the Republic. As business historian Robert Sobel of Hofstra University has documented, the earliest junk bond was issued by Alexander Hamilton to refinance the costs of the Revolutionary War. Zero-coupon bonds, convertible bonds and other hybrid instruments financed the railroads, the development of the Western states and the growth of the oil industry at the turn of the century. This was long before they financed the RJR Nabisco deal. Before Carl C. Icahn and his purchase of T.W.A., secured equipment trust bonds helped diversify freight and passenger railroads and build public utilities. Preferred stocks were popular among new industrial issues at the turn of the century. Simple and straight debt that yielded high interest rates financed the acquisition of U.S. Steel by J. P. Morgan and the restructuring of Goodyear Tire and Rubber by Dillon Read in 1921.
The risk of default among high-yield companies has been widely exaggerated. Failure rates of high-yield issuers and leveraged buyouts and their spinoffs are remarkably less than for American businesses as a whole. Even one widely quoted study that claims a 34 percent default rate for new high-yield issuers translates into a modest 2.8 percent annual average default rate if the time horizon is extended over a period of 12 years. This study identified only 78 defaults out of a universe of 1,500. Yet, despite these defaults, those 1,500 issuers provided investors with an average positive return of 8.5 percent annually, a rate which over the same period compared favorably with Treasuries or high-grade corporate bonds.
Companies that have issued high-yield securities create jobs at four times the average rate for all companies. They experience a one-third greater growth in productivity, 50 percent higher growth in sales and about three times faster growth in capital spending.
The empirical evidence for leveraged buyouts - financing which depends only in part (15-25 percent) on high-yield securities - is similar. In what has come to be known as the decade of restructuring, the 1980's saw a takeovers, leveraged buyouts, divestitures and spinoffs financed through new financial technologies.
Through such recapitalizations, companies have consolidated excess capacity in various industries and enabled a number of low-margin, low-market-share operations to consolidate into higher-margin, higher-market-share businesses. The sale or spinoff of unrelated businesses has been part of this restructuring process.
According to our studies, restructured companies reverse declines in sales, productivity and capital spending. They are less likely to close and thereby cause less job loss. The productivity of factories owned by companies with leveraged buyouts runs about 14 percent higher than factories in companies without leveraged buyouts. The productivity advantage is closer to 20 percent in factories with high management and employee ownership participation, as new owners realize they must focus their business on projects with a high promise of success.
AS junk grew, so did the value of the underlying equity in company financial structures. John Pound, a researcher at Harvard University, found that high-yield issuers generally increased cash flow, earnings, dividend payments, sales and capital spending at a rate that was greater than the expectations at the time of issue. Price-earnings ratios approximately doubled on average, and price/cash-flow multiples increased by about 10 percent after the debt placement.
At its best, the high-yield market reintegrated management and owners, investment and control, and promoted lower capital costs through new institutional arrangements that should be furthered in the 1990's. By shifting the focus from passive to active investors, the high-yield market accomplished what legislators now seek to inhibit - the development of financial institutions and markets that could keep economic growth alive.

SECTION: Section 3; Page 12, Column 4; Financial Desk

LENGTH: 220 words

HEADLINE: Fixing the Dollar

 BODY:
To the Editor:
In ''The Floating Dollar Needs an Anchor'' (Business Forum, Nov. 19), David Ranson states that the dollar is an unstable unit and does not inspire confidence. I could not agree more. His suggestion to fix the value of the dollar to a set basket of commodities deserves serious consideration by the Congress, particularly now when inflation, an ever-present threat, can cause the dollar to depreciate.
As far back as 1937, no less an expert than Benjamin Graham, one of America's most highly respected authorities in the field of investing, advocated securing the currency with approximately 20 basic commodities which would be stored at suitable locations throughout the nation. The value of the underlying commodities would protect the currency against wide variations in value and, at the same time, stabilize the prices of the commodities.
The Senate seemed to agree. In March 1937 the chamber passed the Crop Insurance Bill, under which such stored commodities would be covered by all-risk insurance provided by a Government agency. The bill was introduced in the House and favorably reported by the Committee on Agriculture, but was not acted upon prior to adjournment.
Now is the time for this proposition to be submitted to the legislators anew.
 
ROBERT HEILBRUNN
 New York, Nov. 19

LENGTH: 185 words

HEADLINE: Fixing the Dollar

 BODY:
To the Editor:
It seems incomprehensible that learned economists would advocate gold as a cure for inflation. (''Conduct a Test of a Gold Standard,''
 
Business Forum, Nov. 19.) 
Gold is basically an index of anxiety with little other use. Since the start of civilization the entire world has produced less than 3 billion ounces, a minuscule amount when compared to other metals. Seven percent has had industrial application, 16 percent wound up in jewelry.
The vast majority of gold is produced by South Africa and Russia. It would be obvious exegesis to delineate the horrific state of those two countries' economies and the value of their currencies.
The No. 1 factor in this country's fight against inflation is productivity. Japan, with sparse natural resources, has concentrated on productivity with obvious results. Wake up, America!
 
HERBERT BARCHOFF
 New York, Nov. 22
 
The writer was one of the founders of the American Copper Council and has served on the President's Council of Economic Advisers and as adviser to the Senate Banking and Currency Committee on Foreign Trade.

SECTION: Section 4; Page 6, Column 1; Week in Review Desk

LENGTH: 625 words

HEADLINE: PORTRAIT OF THE 1980's;
Back in 1979, The Word Was Malaise

BYLINE: By GEORGE JOHNSON

 BODY:
THE 1970's were not all bad by any means. But by the time 1979 was entering its final weeks, feelings of gloom were so heavy that even some of President Carter's detractors had to admit he had a point: the country was suffering from a bad case of malaise. Sometimes it seemed that the decade would never end.
For those looking ahead to the 1980's, it was hard to be optimistic. People were predicting rising oil prices, more inflation and an escalating cold war. Howard J. Ruff's ''How to Prosper During the Coming Bad Years'' spent most of 1979 on the best-seller lists. The best-selling nonfiction book of the decade was the evangelist Hal Lindsey's apocalyptic ''Late, Great Planet Earth.'' 
''For the better part of the past two years nobody has been safe from the divinations of the new decade,'' Lewis H. Lapham complained in Harper's Magazine. ''Almost without exception, the seers who look into the abyss of the 1980's predict catastrophes appropriate to the fears of the audience they have been paid to inform and alarm.''
But it was not only the professional prognosticators who were worried. By the end of December, the hostages were in their second month of captivity in the American embassy in Teheran. To America's eyes, Iran itself was being held hostage to Islamic fundamentalism, a force that seemed ready to engulf the Middle East. The Soviets began airlifting troops into Afghanistan, ostensibly to suppress an Islamic revolt. So much for detente. With Soviet expansionism unleashed again, any hopes that the Senate would ratify the SALT II accord faded toward nothingness. Mutual stockpiles of nuclear weapons seemed as permanent as the Berlin wall.
Back home, a different kind of nuclear fear hung in the air from the Three Mile Island accident that spring. Millions of television viewers who had watched the chillingly technical descriptions of what they feared would be a meltdown - the China Syndrome they had seen at the movies - were suddenly very sure that they didn't want nuclear power. But the options looked just as bleak. With soaring oil prices and fears of another OPEC squeeze, the White House was talking about a 50-cent-a-gallon gasoline tax for 1980 and an emergency rationing plan. With hopes blackened by double-digit inflation and crushing interest rates, Paul A. Volcker, the new Federal Reserve chairman, said the country would just have to get used to a lower standard of living.
With America's own fundamentalist revolt stirring, political commentators foresaw the rise of a conservative Christian voting bloc -good news to the rekindled presidential hopes of Ronald Reagan. Demographers were predicting that as the baby boom aged, the country would be dominated by a new conservatism, trying to hold onto a way of life that seemed to be slipping away.
While it was hard to hold out much hope for political or ecological harmony, technology seemed unstoppable. Jimmy Carter called for a national solar energy policy and synthetic fuels. In a report on the coming 1980's, U.S. News & World Report made this prediction: ''Parked in the typical family's garage in 1989 will be a small, two-seater electric car for commuting and a diesel van for weekends and vacations.''
Ten years ago, in a 1970's retrospective, a writer for The Week in Review predicted that by 1989 ''smart telephones will switch calls to wherever the subscriber is, and televisions will hang on the walls like pictures. Automobiles will be programmed to avoid skids and collisions.'' Nearly everybody believed that the space shuttle would make flights into orbit almost as routine as air travel.
Viewed from its beginning, a decade can seem like an endless expanse; then, 10 years later, it turns out to be finite after all.

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

The New York Times

PUB-DATE: December 24, 1989

SECTION: Section 4; Page 7, Column 1; Week in Review Desk

LENGTH: 619 words

HEADLINE: PORTRAIT OF THE 1980's;
Trivial Pursuits And Huge Thoughts

 BODY:
Like any other decade, this one got a reputation as trivial in the arts-and-literature department. In films, Americans wanted things kept light. At the same time, they bought books about chaos, the decline of their nation and the closing of their mind. 
 
Best Sellers
The best-seller lists of the decade were dominated by the usual celebrity biographies, horror and espionage tales, exercise manuals, guides to making love and money, inspirational stories about animals and political memoirs. But bookstore windows were occasionally graced by best-sellers that helped shape what people talked and thought about, books that everybody had to know about and maybe even read.
At the beginning of the decade, Norman Cousins's Anatomy of an Illness celebrated the healing powers of the spirit and holistic medicine. Hopes that all the world would enter a New Age of enlightenment were reflected in futuristic tracts like Alvin Toffler's Third Wave and John Naisbitt's Megatrends. According to other books, the salvation would be laissez-faire economics: Free to Choose, by Milton and Rose Friedman, and Wealth and Poverty by George Gilder.
This was the decade when business magnates and corporate raiders became stars. Along with Iacocca and Trump were attacks on business and finance: Greed and Glory on Wall Street (Ken Auletta), The Reckoning (David Halberstam).
Journalists became historians and covered events as ancient as The Trial of Socrates (I. F. Stone) and as recent as The Path to Power, the first volume of Robert A. Caro's biography of Lyndon Johnson. In A Bright Shining Lie, Neil Sheehan showed how one corrupt military leader personified the contradictions of Vietnam.
The historian Paul Kennedy's Rise and Fall of the Great Powers warned that for centuries superpowers have run through predictable cycles of domination and decline. In The March of Folly, Barbara Tuchman showed how shortsighted leaders keep marching their countries to ruin's brink.
Books seeking to explain the mysteries of science were especially popular: Tracy Kidder's Soul of a New Machine, Stephen W. Hawking's Brief History of Time, James Gleick's Chaos. The physicist Richard P. Feynman wrote two surprising best-sellers, with the help of his friend Ralph Leighton: ''Surely You're Joking, Mr. Feynman'' and ''What Do You Care What Other People Think?'' In The Man Who Mistook His Wife For A Hat, the neurologist Oliver Sacks told readers true stories of brains gone haywire. In Under the Eye of the Clock, a young quadriplegic poet named Christopher Nolan, who learned to type with a unicorn stick attached to his forehead, told what it is like to navigate through life with a damaged nervous system.
A few novelists managed to tap the intellectual currents of the decade and produce fiction popular enough to be sold in grocery stores. Umberto Eco drew on semiotics and medieval theology for The Name of the Rose. John Updike filled the pages of Roger's Version with modern religious controversies, physics and computer science.
Toward the end of the decade, books titillated readers with warnings that civilization was breaking down: Tom Wolfe in his novel The Bonfire of the Vanities, Allan Bloom in his treatise The Closing of the American Mind. In Cultural Literacy, E. D. Hirsch Jr. provided a list of facts he thought Americans should know - and probably didn't. To John Allen Paulos the problem was not only illiteracy but Innumeracy.
One best-seller owed its success not to its content but to what it symbolized. People all over the world bought Salman Rushdie's Satanic Verses to show dictators and bookstore chains that readers won't stay silent when a writer is condemned to death for his prose.
