HEADLINE: Future Health: How Much Care?

BYLINE: By Charles E. Rosenberg; Charles E. Rosenberg is the author of ''The Care of Strangers: The Rise of America's Hospital System.''

 BODY:

WHAT KIND OF LIFE
The Limits of Medical Progress.
By Daniel Callahan.
318 pp. New York: Simon & Schuster. $19.95.
THESE are the best of times for American health care; they are also the worst of times. Most of us will live to attain the biblical threescore and ten; many of us will avoid the pain and incapacity that would have beset the long-lived a century ago. Medicine's technological capacity has never been more impressive, and our society has shown itself willing to pay ever increasing amounts for the promise of health and long life. No other industrialized society allocates so much of its gross national product to health. Yet we Americans feel cheated, dissatisfied with many aspects of a system that has promised so much. Certainly we are unwilling, and perhaps we are unable, to bear its ever more burdensome cost. There is a broad consensus that something should and must be changed. 
With this consensus has come a steadily intensifying debate. And no voice has been more eloquent in this discussion than that of Daniel Callahan. His controversial book of 1987, ''Setting Limits: Medical Goals in an Aging Society,'' suggested that we look critically at the economic costs and the diminished quality of the lives of those who were being sustained by medicine's life-extending tools. The limits built into the human body, he argued, provided natural, and thus ultimately necessary, policy limits. Not everything that might be done should be done.
Mr. Callahan's new book, ''What Kind of Life,'' builds on these themes and presents them in a more systematic and inclusive form. The problem with our health care system, Mr. Callahan argues, lies ultimately in the realm of values, not in the realm of economics or management. We have become the victims of our own goals and achievements - victims of our faith in medicine as ever progressive technology, of our political attachment to individual choice and, finally, of our unwillingness to set limits. As long as these values pervade our culture and define our expectations, he argues, no amount of bureaucratic manipulation or procedural cost-cutting will bring lasting or meaningful reform. Such meliorist measures, without a change of values, can provide no more than temporary, symptomatic relief. Mr. Callahan's is a fundamentally cultural and, in a sense, moral view. Budget debates, he believes, are not simply arenas for negotiating interests, but occasions for articulating widely accepted values.
He advocates a rather different configuration of values as a prerequisite to a more rational and humane health care system. We must, he says, accept the reality of disease and the immanence of death in every human body; medicine cannot ultimately master nature. Moreover, we Americans must learn to see health as a communal good, not an individual good, for social choices affect us all. By keeping people alive on respirators while allowing education and preventive medicine to stagnate, we are deciding, whether consciously or not, what kind of society we will have.
Mr. Callahan's position points toward a number of practical conclusions. First, he argues that centralized planning and control are indispensable to reform. And second, he advocates a set of categorical rules that would define limits in particular clinical interactions - for instance, a rule that would deny renal dialysis or organ transplants to patients above a certain age. Inevitably such policies would mean the acceptance of scarcity and - though we might not want to call it that - rationing. Mr. Callahan even provides a specific set of priorities to order debate and policy making. Our top priorities, he says, should be preventive medicine and the needs of groups at particular risk - for instance, prenatal care for the poor - while our lowest priority should be high-cost interventions in marginal cases - say, 18-ounce babies ''or ninety-five-year-old patients suffering from multi-organ failure, or the quadriplegic teenage victims of auto accidents.'' Every American should have the right to humane care, not cure.
Most of these ideas would find widespread approval in health planning circles and, in fact, they already have. But Mr. Callahan writes for a much broader audience and does so with elegance and lucidity; he excels at describing present irrationalities and in underscoring the benefits anticipated in his new model health care system. This book will be a much discussed and influential contribution to an already vigorous debate.
But it is not without flaws. Perhaps most significant is the author's unwillingness to engage with our political system. He urges us to seek a collective good that transcends the interest-defined politics that normally and incrementally forge policy. Unfortunately, his book does not tell us how we are to achieve this laudable goal. Defining a common good is a political as well as a moral and cognitive problem. To draft a blueprint for reform, one must focus on the process by which values are articulated into specific interests and how they are perceived by individuals in their various social positions.
Our contemporary sense of crisis has, in fact, emerged not from rational discussion of an ideal medical system but from the contradictions deeply embedded within our present system. Even as people admire life-extending technologies, for instance, they voice their fears of the very same technologies and complain of spiraling costs. Moreover, expectations and policy decisions create interests, de facto political realities. When Medicare was established in 1965, it created a powerful political force - a bloc of morally entitled and economically interested voters. Similarly, when employers began routinely paying for health insurance in the 1940's and 1950's, they unwittingly contributed to the current economic crisis in health care and thus to the growing corporate advocacy for some national health insurance scheme.
No analysis that skirts these concrete issues can provide a compelling plan for social action. Mr. Callahan is effective in telling us where we should go, but not in providing a road map pointing out the most effective route. In the absence of such analysis, he asks us, in effect, to simply say no to our culture's faith in progress, to its worship of individual choice and to its habitual unwillingness to accept limits.
Mr. Callahan's cultural view raises another difficulty. If our values are as deeply embedded as he thinks, then the possibility for social reform seems limited. Mr. Callahan's emphasis on the primacy of values fits uneasily in a book that advocates rapid social change. Fundamental values are just that: fundamental, whether they relate to political choice or medicine. Many of Mr. Callahan's criticisms have been made for at least a half-century by socially minded physicians and prescient planners, but they have had little effect in moderating the trend toward an ever more costly, inhumane, and disproportionate emphasis on acute and intrusive care.
Nonetheless, these are the criticisms of a reader in general sympathy with Mr. Callahan's goals. Our health care system will certainly change during the coming generation, and, I hope, in many of the directions so passionately advocated in this book.
 
DRAWING THE LINE
Daniel Callahan, the author of ''What Kind of Life: The Limits of Medical Progress,'' describes himself freely as a philosopher - but one whose attentions tend toward the practical.
''Toward the end of the 1960's I got very interested in medical ethics - an area that was developing very rapidly and presenting our society with some historic problems,'' Mr. Callahan said, explaining his preoccupation with medicine and society in a telephone interview from Denver, where he was delivering a lecture.
In 1969 Mr. Callahan was a founder of the Hastings Center, a research institute whose role, he said, is to ''systematically explore questions of medical ethics.'' He relishes debate - something his new book, which questions ''moral assumptions'' built into our health care system, is likely to generate in quantity.
To those who would label meanspirited his book's argument for limiting society's support of more and ever more medical care, Mr. Callahan has a ready response.
''In many cities in this country we have wonderfully equipped neonatal intensive care units right down the street from terribly equipped schools,'' he said. ''We have to examine how money might be spent for the greater number of people.''
Mr. Callahan is acutely aware - and seemingly untroubled - that he will come under attack for advocating such positions as an arbitrary cut-off weight of 500 grams (slightly less than 18 ounces) below which, he believes, hospitals should not make costly and uncertain attempts to save newborn babies.
''Does it make sense,'' he asked, ''to devote such a tremendous quantity of resources to saving smaller and smaller babies, and then thrust them into a society that is characterized by second- and third-rate schools?''
He added: ''We have skewed things too much toward health care as opposed to housing, education and other things. Medical care cannot be allowed to trump everything else.'' - HOWARD W. FRENCH

HEADLINE: Trees Don't Vote

BYLINE: By Elio Gaspari; Elio Gaspari is a correspondent for Veja, a Brazilian weekly news magazine.

 BODY:

THE FATE OF THE FOREST
Developers, Destroyers and Defenders of the Amazon.
By Susanna Hecht and Alexander Cockburn.
Illustrated. 266 pp. New York: Verso. $24.95.
FOR the past few years, much of the worldwide debate about global warming has centered on the devastation of the tropical forest of the Amazon. Already 10 percent of the forest has been destroyed, and its burning is now responsible for 10 percent of the world's carbon dioxide production. ''The Fate of the Forest'' is a journey into this devastation, the most senseless ecological disaster of our time. Written by Susanna Hecht, a botanist and ecologist at the University of California, Los Angeles, who has lived in the Amazon, and Alexander Cockburn, a British journalist who has been hailed by The Times Literary Supplement of London as ''probably the most gifted polemicist writing in English today,'' the book is not just about the forest itself but also about the greed of its destroyers and the fierce struggle of its supporters. 
To their credit, Ms. Hecht and Mr. Cockburn do not share the romantic and pastoral view held by the sort of ecological groups that defend trees more ardently than the human beings who starve under them. Nor do they take the paternalistic stand of the industrialized nations that, having burned their own forests, now think Brazil incapable of caring for the Amazon without some kind of international tutelage. ''The forest's fate,'' write the authors, ''will depend on the vision and the political sagacity of the people who live in it.''
Without a doubt ''The Fate of the Forest'' is ambitious. It begins with the history of the Amazon - told with a few exaggerations - and includes a full and rather boring chapter on the intricate geography of the region. Then it offers a balanced description of the mechanism by which the delicate ecological equilibrium of the forest is being undone.
''The Fate of the Forest,'' however, is primarily about the people who have left their marks on the Amazon. It leads the reader through a grandiose cast of characters - from American tycoons like Henry Ford in the 1930's and Daniel K. Ludwig in the 70's and 80's, who saw their expensive projects buried by the forest, to more modest actors such as the rubber tappers' union leader Chico Mendes, who lost his life a year ago while fighting the economic exploitation of the region and its people.
Rightly, Ms. Hecht and Mr. Cockburn take straight aim at the culpable - the Brazilian elite. But in launching most of their attacks at the Brazilian military rather than the business elite, Ms. Hecht and Mr. Cockburn miss the mark. In Brazilian history, the destruction of the Amazon has gone on regardless of whether the military has been in power or not.
The authors argue that the devastation of the tropical forest is a direct consequence of a geopolitical vision conceived by the Brazilian military - more specifically, by Gen. Golbery do Couto e Silva, who was the power behind three of the five generals who ruled Brazil from 1964 to 1985. It's true that the military did authorize depredations in the area. But the real force behind the destruction was and is found in the Brazilian business community, particularly the sector involved in the development of cattle ranching.
In an effort to make connections that justify their scenario, Ms. Hecht and Mr. Cockburn practice what could be called ''orthopedic journalism'' - forcing facts into postures that suit their theories. For instance, the devastation of the Amazon forest, contrary to the authors' theory, continued after the military left power in 1985, so Ms. Hecht and Mr. Cockburn conveniently define the civilian government of President Jose Sarney as a ''nominal democracy,'' implying that it is a mere embellishment of the military. Wrong. Mr. Sarney's presidency is corrupt and incompetent, true. But it also represents the longest period of public liberties in Brazilian history.
The authors also play fast and loose with the life of General Golbery, who lost his position in the Government in 1981. Golbery opposed some of the madder schemes for the Amazon, including the construction of a road, called the Perimetral Norte, that would have led nowhere. Since then, a derivative of this corrupt project, called the Calha Norte, has been started, and the authors contend wrongly that the General's ''shadow hangs over'' it. Golbery liked being perceived as a mysterious figure, and things were attributed to him whether he did them or not. But the authors of ''The Fate of the Forest'' have embroidered his biography a bit too much. He never fought in World War II - in either France or Italy - as they would have it, and when he actually landed in Naples the war was over.
Other statements in the book are exaggerated or superficial, and still others lack adequate documentation. One cannot say that in 1492 there were 6 million to 12 million Indians living in the Amazon basin, or that ''it is likely'' that the figure may have been as high as 15 million, when a book cited in the bibliography refers to only five million Indians. Mistakes permeate all four centuries covered by the book. Even the current United States Ambassador to Brasilia, Richard Melton, is wrongly called Richard Murphy.
Some errors in ''The Fate of the Forest'' derive from poor investigative reporting. Nonetheless, the authors are not intellectually dishonest. At a time when the international press and television praise Chico Mendes as a kind of Albert Schweitzer of the tropical forest, Ms. Hecht and Mr. Cockburn make it clear that his career as an environmentalist ''cannot be divorced from his active life as an extremely radical political militant.'' I suspect that the Hollywood producers who are now scurrying to turn Mendes's life into a multimillion-dollar script might feel uncomfortable when they learn about his past allegiance to the Communist Party of Brazil - an organization aligned ideologically with Stalinist Albania.
Unfortunately, ''The Fate of the Forest'' resembles some trees of the dying forest. It is impressive and colorful, but the roots are planted in barren soil.

SECTION: Section 7; Page 24, Column 1; Book Review Desk

LENGTH: 845 words

HEADLINE: The Hills Were Alive With the Sound of Tummling

BYLINE: By Joe Cohen; Joe Cohen, a staff reporter at Variety, has covered the Catskills for more than 40 years.

 BODY:

A SUMMER WORLD
The Attempt to Build a Jewish Eden in the Catskills, From the Days of the Ghetto to the Rise and Decline of the Borscht Belt.
By Stefan Kanfer.
Illustrated. 333 pp. New York:
Farrar, Straus & Giroux. $22.95.
COMICS used to describe Route 17, which took Jewish vacationers to the Catskills resorts, as starting on Manhattan's Lower East Side and ending in the mountains. In his well-researched and highly readable history of the Borscht Belt, ''A Summer World,'' Stefan Kanfer traces Route 17 even further. For him, the highway started more than two centuries ago in Europe before reaching the Lower East Side. 
Mr. Kanfer, a contributing editor at Time magazine, notes that the first record of a Jew in the Catskills is a 1773 reference to ''Jacob the Jew,'' an early settler among the Dutch burghers. He follows the glories of the area through its heyday to what he calls its decline.
The major factors in the creation of the Catskills as a summer resort were the unrestricted waves of immigration from Germany, Russia and Poland in the 19th century. America was the destination for five million Jews, many of whom settled on the Lower East Side while longing for relief from the squalor both in their homes and in the sweatshops where they toiled.
Some managed to escape to the mountains, where they bought small farms. But farming was not their forte, and soon the farms became boarding houses, then inns and bungalow colonies for visitors from the city.
The guests, however, insisted on entertainment from the Catskills bonifaces, and by the 1920's, Mr. Kanfer shows, what started as an extra added attraction had become a major undertaking. Waiters and busboys were pressed into service as tummlers (the comedians and would-be comedians who were so important to the emergence of a Catskills brand of comedy), while the social directors became impresarios. Waitresses were transformed into script girls who went to Broadway shows and copied the routines of leading comics (and sometimes full plays), which were later presented in shorter form by the staffers. Mr. Kanfer explains that the practice ultimately had to be stopped when one stenographer was caught transcribing an entire edition of George White's Scandals.
Among the social directors were Moss Hart, the future playwright, and Don Hartman, soon to be head of Paramount Pictures. The tummlers came in with names such as David Daniel Kaminsky, Aaron Chwatt, Jacob Pincus Perelmuth, Morris Miller, Eugene Klass, Joseph Levitch, Milton Berlinger, Joseph Gottlieb and Murray Janofsky, and emerged as Danny Kaye, Red Buttons, Jan Peerce, Robert Merrill, Gene Barry, Jerry Lewis, Milton Berle, Joey Bishop and Jan Murray.
The comedian Joey Adams, who wrote a book on the Borscht Belt, is frequently mentioned in ''A Summer World,'' but Mr. Kanfer does not tell Mr. Adams's story of his own name change. Some years after getting his start in the mountains, he confessed to having been born Abramowitz and changing his name to Adams when he went into show business. While on a club date in Boston he was approached by Wendell Adams, a member of the fine old New England family, who jokingly inquired if they might be related. ''I don't know,'' Joey replied. ''What was your name before you changed it?'' The queen of the mountains was the soft-spoken and regal Jennie Grossinger, and she is featured throughout Mr. Kanfer's book. Her parents, Selig and Malke Grossinger, had purchased a small plot of land before World War I with a down payment of $450. In the years to follow, Jennie became the region's best-known hostess, her hotel the most imitated.
One of the imitators was Arthur Winarick, the bald manufacturer of Jeris hair tonic and the owner of the Concord. After hearing that Grossinger's had an 18-hole golf course, Mr. Kanfer relates, Winarick wanted to build a 50-hole course. He ultimately contented himself with three courses, two with 18 holes and one with nine.
IN recent years, television and increased competition for vacationers have proved serious threats to the region, and recession fears hit hard when Grossinger's was sold in 1985 for conversion to condominiums and ski houses. Other hotels followed, through either Chapter 11 or direct sale, while some of those that are still in business are now places where religious cultists frolic. Still, resorts such as the Concord continue to be vacation spots, holding out hope for preservation of the area.
In telling the story of the Catskills, Mr. Kanfer has tied together history, religion and show business into an entertaining compendium. But despite his book's subtitle, he need not worry about the area's decline. The Catskills innkeepers are a resourceful group. Years ago when they were in trouble, they drummed up fall and winter weekday business with conventions and trade shows. Today, they hope that the New York State Legislature will grant them casino gambling. If the lawmakers comply, there will unquestionably be many more chapters to be written on the history of the Borscht Belt.

GRAPHIC: Guests play ''Simon Says'' at Grossinger's (The New York Times/Suzanne DeChillo)

SECTION: Section 10; Page 1, Column 2; Real Estate Desk

LENGTH: 2754 words

HEADLINE: Office Construction in the Doldrums

BYLINE: By THOMAS J. LUECK

 BODY:
THE New York region's commercial real estate developers, whose teeming construction sites and vastly profitable office ventures became a symbol of the go-go 80's, are entering the new decade with sharply reduced plans and protracted construction schedules.
Analysts say the shift comes at time when work remains in progress on dozens of new office towers in midtown Manhattan, along New Jersey's Hudson River waterfront and elsewhere. But, they say, it will become much clearer by the end next year, when work on several Manhattan buildings will have been completed and hardly any new buildings will be breaking ground.
Elsewhere in New York City, and in northern New Jersey, Westchester and Fairfield Counties and Long Island, building activity also will trail off, but less rapidly than in Manhattan.
The slowdown is less severe than in Texas, Arizona, Florida and some other parts of the Sun Belt, where hyperactive real estate investment and a boom-and-bust economy are taking most of the blame for the nation's most expensive bailout of the thrift institutions that make development loans. So much office space is vacant in some Sun Belt cities that little new construction is expected for years. 
The experts doubt that such a serious glut will develop in the New York region because employment remains robust in most of its office-using industries and the rapid falloff in new construction will prevent overbuilding from reaching much more serious levels.
Indeed, at a time when large blocks of new space have been coming on the market, particularly in West Midtown, law firms, advertising agencies, foreign banks and other large companies have been signing on for them. Leases were signed in the this year for 24.2 million square throughout Manhattan, 3.3 more than in 1988, according to Julien J. Studley Inc., a real estate brokerage that analyzes leasing at new and old buildings alike.
The firm said more than three times the amount of office space was leased in New York City this year than in any other American city.
But the high leasing levels have not kept office vacancy rates from reaching their highest point in over a decade - nearly 14 percent, and climbing, in midtown Manhattan, 13 percent in lower Manhattan and over 20 percent in some suburbs. Many executives worry how long it will take to fill the existing buildings and all but dismiss the need for more construction soon.
A Japanese company that has already provided $200 million in construction financing for a half-complete 50-story Manhattan office tower petitioned the courts in mid-December to force the project into bankruptcy. The building, Americas Tower, on Avenue of the Americas between 45th and 46th Streets, is one of more than a half-dozen new midtown office buildings whose developers are engaged in a bruising competition for large corporate tenants. Although the court denied the petition of the Japanese company, KG Land New York Corporation, its partner, New York Land Company, said it had solicited bids for a new partner or source of financing.
And while it is worrying some New York City developers, uncertainty over office demand is causing even more concern in the suburbs. In another December court action, the Resolution Trust Corporation, the Federal agency formed in August to oversee thrifts taken over in the Government's rescue program, seized City Federal Savings Bank, New Jersey's largest savings institution.
City Federal is the second-largest lender taken over, behind Gibraltar Savings of Los Angeles. The bank said its problems were largely confined to nonperforming construction loans made to builders of condominiums and other residential properties in New Jersey, Florida and Texas, but its portfolio also included some loans to commercial developers in New Jersey who, although current in their accounts, were experiencing extreme difficulting attracting tenants.
''THE problems in the suburbs are much worse than in the city,'' said Rosemary Scanlon, chief economist for the Port Authority of New York and New Jersey, which monitors economic conditions throughout the New York region.
She said the difficulties of suburban developers are particularly severe because most started work on office projects on speculation. Now, she added, with a surplus of space, the problem is aggravated by an acute shortage of workers that is discouraging companies from moving to the new offices.
In a region that has gone through sharp, unpredictable economic swings, sometimes leaving it with shortages of office space in periods of sudden expansion, experts offer little consensus about how steep the current decline will be or how long it will last. Some warn of deep trouble.
''The picture is frightening,'' said James P. Stuckey, president of New York City's Public Development Corporation since 1985, who leaves office with the inauguration of David Dinkins as Mayor next week. He added that the midtown vacancy rate could go above 20 percent - its highest level in memory - if all the corporate tenants known to be planning to leave the neighborhood do so and few new tenants are signed on over the next year.
Real estate executives maintain that the problem lies less in a spurt of new construction than in broader regional economic shifts.
For more than a decade, office-using industries have led the region's economic expansion. Dozens of corporations moved their headquarters to campuslike suburban installations in the 70's, banks and securities firms had a voracious demand for offices near Wall Street in the early 80's and advertising firms, entertainment companies and law firms have more recently beaten a broad path to midtown Manhattan.
But now, with deep and continuing employment cuts at Manhattan's banks and securities firms, hostile takeovers and management restructuring programs that have eroded employment in the suburban corporate centers and generally bleak forecasts of economic growth in the region, few corporate pace setters are in view.
''The region's economy is changing and nobody knows how it is going to turn out,'' said Richard Rosan, senior vice president for new development of Silverstein Properties, a major commerical developer in New York City and New Jersey. ''We just can't see where the growth is coming.''
In one analysis, the Edward S. Gordon Company, a brokerage, found that midtown construction will decline sharply in the next 18 months. It forecast that only one 225,000-square-foot office building, less than a quarter the size of many of the city's office towers, will be completed in the midtown market in 1991.
That level of completions would be the lowest since 1960, the first year in the brokerage's study. In contrast, the company said, eight midtown office buildings will be completed in 1990, seven were completed in 1989 and six were completed in 1988, adding at least 3.5 million square feet of new midtown space in each of those years.
Office construction in lower Manhattan is, for the moment, a dead issue, according to the brokerage. It said that no new office buildings were completed this year and that none would be in 1990 or 1991. In the mid-80's, the study showed, an annual average of over 3 million square feet was added on Wall Street and elsewhere in lower Manhattan.
Suburban construction is slowing, but far from coming to a halt. An analysis by Cushman & Wakefield, the national real estate brokerage, found that 5.7 million square feet of office space was completed this year in the corporate centers of northern New Jersey, including the Hudson River waterfront, Morris County, along Route I-78 and elsewhere in the northern third of the state. That was slightly more than half the amount added in 1988, and the concern said even fewer new offices are now under construction.
On Long Island, it said 1.1 million square feet was added this year, half the amount of 1988, but it said that 2.1 million square feet is now under construction. In Fairfield County, Conn., it said, 1.6 million square feet was completed this year, down from 2 million in 1988, and only 695,000 square feet of new space is under construction.
The study found a more dramatic slowdown in Westchester County, where only 342,000 square feet was completed this year, compared to 1.8 million in 1988. It said 619,000 square feet is now under construction.
Experts say the reduced levels of construction are a result of an economic cycle that brought rapid job growth and expanding space needs for most of the last decade but has left the entire New York region bracing for little overall growth in the early 90's, and employment cuts in some industries.
One that is likely to weather the downturn with few job losses is the construction industry itself, which is in high demand in huge, long-term projects to rebuild the region's roads, bridges, airports and mass-transit systems. Billions of dollars have been budgeted for the work by New York City, the states, the Port Authority and other agencies.
Samuel H. Ehrenhalt, New York Regional Commission of the Federal Bureau of Labor Statistics, said 162,000 are currently employed in construction jobs in the region, a 3 percent increase over 1988. The number of construction workers has increased gradually in each year since 1984, the Federal agency said.
NOR are the region's developers and commercial landlords without large, highly profitable corporate tenants to court. Some of the towers completed over the last two years have been quickly filled.
''I am not at all pessimistic,'' said William Zeckendorf Jr., one of New York City's most active developers, who this year completed Worldwide Plaza, a complex of offices, condominiums and retail space that covers a midtown Manhattan block bounded by Eighth and Ninth Avenues and 49th and 50th Streets.
Although many of Mr. Zeckendorf's condominiums remain unsold, the office space in the complex is more than 90 percent leased, with the biggest amounts occupied by Cravath, Swaine & Moore, a law firm, and Ogilvy & Mather and NW Ayer, both advertising agencies, which took partial equity in the complex and signed on long before it was complete. Many large corporations seeking new space because their leases are coming up for renewal and they need more modern quarters for their computers remain in the market, he added.
Another developer, Lewis Rudin, has leased out 30 floors at 1675 Broadway, a 35-story office building he completed at Broadway and 52d Street this year. He said several tenants have expressed interest in floors that remain vacant. ''We've been so successful it's dull,'' he said.
And along the Hudson River waterfront in Jersey City, the Limited Ltd., a national retailer, has signed on for nearly a third of the space in the Newport Office Tower, a 1.1 million-square-foot building being put up by Melvin Simon Associations, an Indianapolis developer, in the Newport complex of apartments, offices and a shopping mall. The building is expected to be completed in the fall of 1991.
Elsewhere in the real estate industry, executives are abuzz with conjecture that several companies will commit themselves to large new blocks of space soon.
Chemical Bank, which earlier in the year withdrew from negotiations to move its headquarters to one of the office towers planned in the redevelopment of Times Square, is widely reported to be considering moving part of its operations to the Meadowlands area of New Jersey or one of the new office towers in midtown, while also negotiating a new lease at its current headquarters at 277 Park Avenue, at 48th Street.
The News America Corporation, the publishing company controlled by Rupert Murdoch, is rumored to be negotiating for a large complex of offices at 1575 Broadway, a new office tower just off 47th Street.
And the Sony Corporation, the Japanese conglomerate that over the last two years acquired Columbia Pictures and CBS Records, is thought to be considering consolidating its New York operations at the Americas Tower. Real estate executives said privately last week that they would not be surprised if Sony replaced KG Land in extending financing for the project, while taking space in the building as well.
In all, industry experts said, that large blocks of offices, totaling 5 million square feet, are being sought by corporate tenants in New York City and are likely to be leased in the first three months of 1990.
''There is a lot of leasing going on and a lot of people still in the market,'' said Raymond O'Keefe, senior vice president of Cushman & Wakefield.
STILL, experts said a surge in leasing activity would have been expected even in a period of economic strain because of the vast amount of new space built in the last three years. Most of the Manhattan construction was prompted by city incentives, extended to developers who laid their foundations in West Midtown by May 1988, that permitted buildings larger than would otherwise have been allowed.
A result, some say, will be little more than a high-stakes game of musical chairs in which several large corporations move to new offices but leave large vacancies behind.
''There are diminishing expectations all over the place,'' said Maurice Solomon, manager of the midtown office of Julien J. Studley. To attract tenants, he said, developers have been offering incentives that would not have been considered in the mid-80's, including six-month rent abatements and large packages of interior improvements tailored to the needs of individual office users.
And while bleak economic forecasts are making the developers less ambitious, well-organized community resistance to large-scale development is slowing the process, particularly in New York City. Major, widely publicized projects that have been planned for years remain blocked by litigation.
One is Columbus Center, a proposed complex of offices, condominiums and stores on the Columbus Circle site now occupied by the New York Coliseum. Its developer, Boston Properties, which has faced vocal community opposition and several suits since it was selected for the project in 1985, has gone through three alterations of its plan, finally winning the endorsement of some its most powerful opponents - including Mayor-elect Dinkins and Manhattan Borough President-elect Ruth Messinger - in late 1988.
But fresh suits filed in September say the project would violate air-quality standards, and those actions are pending.
Morri Berman, the attorney for Boston Properties, owned by Mortimer Zuckerman, the publisher of U.S. News and World Report, said the developer expects the project to go forward. But he declined to predict when the legal challenges would be resolved other than to say the developer hoped to break ground before the end of 1990.
The delay of Columbus Center is a sensitive matter at City Hall because the site is to be sold by the city, with the proceeds used for subway improvements and to pay other city bills. The administration of Mayor Edward I. Koch had planned to budget $247 million of the proceeds for the current fiscal year.
Another long-delayed commercial venture that is critically important at City Hall is the proposed redevelopment of Times Square, first planned in 1983. The project is to include four office towers of 32 to 57 stories, a hotel, a merchandise market and the renovation of historic 42d Street theaters that are now pornographic and action movie houses.
Dozens of suits have been filed to block the project, which can proceed only if New York State's Urban Development Corporation condemns existing Times Square properties. Many of the suits contend that businesses would be improperly displaced, the planned office towers are too large and bulky and the developer, a partnership of George Klein, a large New York City builder, and the Prudential Insurance Company of America, had been given unnecessarily lucrative financial incentives to build in an area that would eventually be redeveloped anyway.
A redesigned plan for the office towers was released by the developrs in August. Since then, state officials said, all the suits that had been on appeal have been thrown out of court or withdrawn. But two new suits have been filed, which could delay condemnation and redevelopment further.
Larry Joseph, a spokesman for the Urban Development Corporation, said that the agency's lawyers hope the remaining litigation will be resolved by March and that condemnation and demolition of the existing Times Square buildings will begin by the end of 1990.

HEADLINE: Stewart Looks Past Oakland's Shadows

BYLINE: By MICHAEL MARTINEZ

DATELINE: OAKLAND, Calif.

 BODY:
THE day is still not over, but shadows and the temperature have begun to fall quickly as Dave Stewart drives slowly down Center Street, turns left onto 15th and then finally pulls to a stop at Cypress Avenue. There are old, tired houses to his right and to his left, a barricade of yellow police tape in front of him and then a strange wide expanse of leveled earth beyond that, as if a bulldozer had suddenly pushed everything aside.
Stewart surveys all of this, points toward a winding piece of concrete that looks like part of a freeway on-ramp and then shakes his head.
''It's all gone,'' he said in the cool afternoon air. ''The whole thing. Gone.'' 
For nearly two miles stretching east, there is little but rubble where the two-tiered Interstate 880 once stood. But staring down at him, its shadow growing longer as the sun drops, is the only thing remaining: a massive slab of the fallen freeway resting limply against an upright section of the structure, a reminder of what used to be and what had happened to change it.
More than two months have passed since the Oct. 17 earthquake rattled northern California and sent the World Series into a 10-day holding pattern. But the memories are still strong for those who live in the Bay Area, including Stewart, the Oakland Athletics pitcher.
In baseball history, Stewart will always be recalled as the pivotal performer in the A's four-game sweep of the San Francisco Giants, the winner of the first and fourth games and the most valuable player of the Series. In reality, he was one of the players affected most by the quake's resounding destruction, his nights spent driving to the Cypress structure to watch rescuers pull bodies from the rubble.
Stewart still does not know what caused him to lay awake, then inexplicably visit the freeway site in the nights that followed the tremor. But he knows that it was his city that buckled, that few could feel the sense of loss and concern that he did.
''I'm born here; I'm raised here,'' he said one day last week. ''That's the difference. I wouldn't expect a player born in Mobile, Ala., and playing in Oakland to care as much as I do. Part of my character comes from this city. It's my roots.''
So as Oakland continues to rebuild, Stewart watches with special interest. He points to buildings ruined by the earthquake but also drives through areas that signal a rejuvenation of the city of more than 300,000: Jack London Square, the downtown area along Broadway, and old Oakland, where Victorian houses are being carefully restored.
The double-decker 880 freeway was a part of Oakland, too, carrying commuters north and south in almost constant congestion. Stewart rode it to the Oakland Coliseum in the summer's early afternoons, then rode it home at night.
''My sister was supposed to be coming to the ball game at that time,'' he said, remembering the moment the earthquake struck, 5:04 P.M. Pacific time, about a half hour before the first pitch of Game 3. ''I had no clue what happened to her because there was no phone communication. If she'd been on time, she would have been a part of that damage. But she hadn't even left the house at 5 o'clock.''
Perhaps it was his familiarity with the devastated area - the fact he drove regularly on I-880, or the fact he spent idle hours in the neighborhood as a youth - that drew Stewart to Cypress Avenue for several nights afterward.
''I still don't have the slightest idea,'' he said. ''People have told me they think it was the security of knowing that people were out there working to get others out. I don't know.''
Stewart is more certain of his need to play a role in Oakland's revival. He willingly attends business functions that go toward helping the redevelopment of the community, he serves on the board of directors for the Oakland Boys Club and he speaks on behalf of the local Just Say No campaign against drugs. Equally important, he spends one week in early January calling more than a dozen schools throughout the Bay Area and addressing the drug problem with students.
Stewart, who is 32 years old, said he has become keenly aware of Oakland's problem because, in part, it contrasts his own memories as a youngster, days when there were alternatives to crime and drugs.
''You see the amount of athletes to come out of this area, and you know it's because there were a lot of recreation and park facilities,'' he said. ''Now you take it 15, 20 years later, and there aren't as many opportunities for kids to develop. I built my self-esteem on the baseball fields. They don't have that anymore, and so they look to other avenues.
''Drugs aren't new; they've been here a long time. But people see them as a way to make money, and so they start selling marijuana in high school, then go on to bigger things.''
In Stewart's mind, the best way to solve the dilemma is to bring back playgrounds, programs and positive alternatives.
In a significant way, Stewart has become Oakland's own ambassador. His pitching brings him notoriety, his community work satisfies a need to give back.
He might be the city's best-known resident, even though he spends part of the winter in the southern California town of Claremont, east of Los Angeles. In his car, motoring through the suburbs and then back into downtown, strangers recognize Stewart and honk. He always waves back. ''A lot of people identify with me,'' he said. ''Being from Oakland, the comment that's made most often by people is that they appreciate what I'm doing for the community. They know I'm trying to do something about things, not just making my money and getting out.''
About money: Stewart, despite three consecutive 20-victory seasons with the A's, suddenly ranks as a baseball pauper, his $1.075 million salary running far behind the contracts signed recently by Mark Langston, Mark Davis, Robin Yount and his own teammate Rickey Henderson.
But Stewart, who has one year remaining on his current pact, is in early negotiations with the A's on a two-year extension that could pay him $7 million.
''For me,'' he said, ''it's not a question of making more money. It's a matter of being recognized as the best. If I have to make more money than Mark Langston to be recognized as the best, then that's what I'll have to do.''
There has always seemed to be a shortage of recognition for the right-hander, who has never won the Cy Young Award and whose accomplishment in the post-season - becoming the first pitcher to go 2-0 in the league championship series and 2-0 in the World Series - was largely overlooked.
''Nobody talks about it,'' he said of his 4-0 streak, which gave him 25 victories for the season, ''but then it might be just another part of my career. I've gotten used to it.
''Yes, I've won 20 three times, but it's been my misfortune that somebody else has pitched as well or better and won the Cy Young. All I can do is pitch consistently. That's the thing people respect. Dependability. That's the best I can ask of myself.''
In Oakland, Stewart has been undeniably dependable. Now, when he looks at the streets, he sees a part of himself.
''Heck, I grew up here,'' he said. ''This city isn't any different from any other city. There's drugs and crime, and people talk about wanting to move out, but I'm not that way. It's a good place to live. It's my home.''

HEADLINE: Baseball Notebook;
Whatever the Sport, Bo Jackson Makes Contact

BYLINE: By MURRAY CHASS

 BODY:
FOOTBALL, which Bo Jackson will play at Giants Stadium today, is a contact sport. So is baseball, which Jackson also plays. While Jackson has shown improvement in avoiding contact in football this year, he has displayed improvement in making contact in baseball.
Entering the Los Angeles Raiders' game against the Giants, Jackson needs 85 yards to become a 1,000-yard rusher. His 915 yards -in only 10 games - has already easily exceeded his 1988 total of 580 yards, and the total computes to a 5.6-yards-per-carry average compared with 4.3 last season. 
Playing for the Kansas City Royals, Jackson did not make contact 172 times, making him the most prolific batter at striking out in 1989. But his ratio of one strikeout every 2.99 times at bat was virtually the same as his 1988 ratio of 3.01.
In his other 343 times at bat, though, Jackson compiled a .385 average, giving him the third-best contact average in the majors among the 42 players who struck out 100 or more times. Will Clark of San Francisco had the highest contact average, .404, and Rolando Roomes of Cincinnati was just one point ahead of Jackson at .386. (To figure contact average, subtract strikeouts from times at bat and divide hits by that number; 400 times up with 100 strikeouts and 100 hits yields a .250 batting average, but a .333 contact average.) Jackson had the greatest difference between batting average (.256) and contact average (129 points). Roomes had the second greatest spread (123 points).
Jackson, a consistent 100-plus strikeout batter, has been among the top 10 hitters in contact average in each of his three full seasons. In 1987, he batted .391 when he hit the ball and last year batted .369. Both times he was seventh.
In 1987, Jack Clark had the highest contact average, .429, but last year Andres Galarraga finished at .404, the same as Will Clark this year. Galarraga and Jack Clark each produced a .355 contact average this year and tied for ninth. In between Jackson and those two were Eric Davis .376, Danny Tartabull .371, Kevin Mitchell and Howard Johnson .369, and Mickey Tettleton .361.
Not everyone who strikes out 100 or more times has a better-than-.300 contact average. Five of this year's group of 42 didn't make it to that level: Lloyd Moseby .277, Darryl Strawberry .288, Joe Carter .293, and Tom Brunansky and Cory Snyder .296.
Rob Deer of Milwaukee, who had a .210 batting average and a .318 contact average, had the worst strikeout ratio, one for every 2.95 times at bat. Jackson was next at 2.99 and was followed by Jack Clark 3.14, Roomes 3.15 and Pete Incaviglia 3.33.
Roomes, a Cincinnati outfielder, could be a strikeout force to be reckoned with. He played in only 107 games as a 27-year-old rookie this year, but his strikeout ratio was not an accident because he brought impressive credentials with him.
Roomes, who grew up in Rockaway Park, Queens, led three different minor leagues in strikeouts, including two in a row, the Eastern League and the American Association, in 1987 and '88. Furthermore, in his 10 years as a professional player, he has averaged one strikeout every 2.87 times at bat.
 
A Fuming Steinbrenner?
George Steinbrenner, the Yankees' owner, can't be pleased with the Mets' acquisition of Alejandro Pena from the Los Angeles Dodgers.
When Pena was a free agent last year, Steinbrenner wanted him badly for the Yankees' bullpen. Pena was prepared to join the Yankees until the Dodgers stunned him with a two-year, $2.15 million offer. Steinbrenner was so outraged that he stopped talking, at least temporarily, to Pena's agent, Tom Reich, with whom he always had had a solid relationship.
Now, one year later, Pena will come to New York, but not to pitch for the Yankees.
 
Cerone's Word Power
Rick Cerone, on the other hand, will come back to New York to catch for the Yankees for a third time, proving that the best way to deal with the owner is to curse at him in a roomful of people. That's what Cerone did in the Yankees' clubhouse after a game in the 1981 division playoff.
When Cerone signed up for his second term, in 1987, he started out by calling Steinbrenner to ask for an invitation to spring training, no contract necessary. But the owner gave him a $250,000 contract.
Now Cerone has a two-year, $1.4 million contract with the Yankees. It happens to be the most lucrative contract per year that he has ever had. He signed a four-year, $2.4 million contract with the Yankees before the 1983 season.
Two things to be said for Cerone: he is one of the tougher catchers in the majors and last season he had the second best runs-batted-in ratio among catchers. He drove in 48 runs in 296 times at bat, or one every 6.2. Carlton Fisk was the only one who was proportionately more productive, driving in 68 runs in 375 times at bat, or one every 5.5.
 
A Fair Chance for Samuel
When the Dodgers acquired Juan Samuel to play center field, some defensive-minded people wondered if the Dodgers had seen Samuel play center for the Mets. Fred Claire, the Los Angeles general manager, said they had, but they are confident Samuel will improve and play adequate defense.
''He's a great athlete,'' said Claire. ''He has the speed and the ability. I don't think he had a fair opportunity. We go into it thinking he can play center.''
But can the Dodgers be confident about an offensive comeback by Samuel? It has been two years since he was the catalyst the Mets expected him to be when they got him from Philadelphia. In 1988, Samuel dropped 29 points in average (.272 to .243), 16 home runs (28 to 12) and 33 runs batted in (100 to 67). This past season he continued his skid, batting .235, hitting 11 home runs and knocking in 48 runs.
 
The Bashing Continues
Poor Calvin Griffith. The former owner of the Minnesota Twins has been out of baseball for five years, but he is still being bashed for his penurious economic practices.
Some years ago, when the owners were discussing revenue sharing among the clubs, with the larger-market teams helping their smaller-market brethren, George Steinbrenner expressed his opposition by saying, ''Let me run the Twins instead of Calvin Griffith and I'll accept revenue sharing.''
More recently, the subject of revenue sharing between owners and players came up, and Donald Fehr, the players' labor leader, said: ''If you want to have revenue sharing, you can't have any more Calvin Griffiths running baseball teams because Calvin Griffith doesn't produce revenue. The players cannot be in the position of being stuck with bad management.
''We all know that some baseball teams are very good marketers and some stink. When markets set salaries, the ones that don't do so well nevertheless have to meet market standards. When you go to revenue sharing, if Calvin Griffith is running a team, not only does he depress salaries on his team but he also depresses salaries of the other 25.''

HEADLINE: Question of the Week;
Will East German Athletes Continue to Dominate?

 BODY:
rrConsidering their small population, the East Germans have performed an athletic miracle through individual and organized effort, and that is to be lauded without cynicism. Yet, the same mind-set in their political system has caused all the discontent that has so rapidly risen to the surface this year. The control that glorifies a few hundred athletes and instills pride in the nation leaves millions more suffering politically, economically, socially, artistically, in short, in every outlet of human expression.
Capitalism is replete with disillusioning waste and excess, yet athletes and exemplars from other disciplined professions succeed in systems such as America's when their desire truly comes from within.
East Germans loosened from the reins of their state, who realize such personal inspiration, will continue to find ways to dominate on an individual basis, even with less help from Big Brother.
 
LOUIS ALTMAN
South Fallsburg, N.Y.

HEADLINE: Bethlehem Township;
Residents and Quarry Are at Loggerheads Over Blast Effects

BYLINE: By NOAM COHEN

DATELINE: BETHLEHEM TOWNSHIP

 BODY:
WHEN chunks of granite from a nearby quarry tumbled into his backyard last spring, Gus Dobes of Bethlehem Township complained to the state. Months earlier, when he and his neighbors noticed that their houses were shaking more than usual from the quarry's blasts, he signed a petition that was also sent to the state.
Now that Mr. Dobes has lost at least an acre of his backyard to a 60-foot-deep chasm that he thinks was created by unsafe mining by the owners of the Pattenburg Quarry, he has opted for a different strategy. ''I think I will have the lawyer do the talking,'' he said. For Mr. Dobes, who has lived for 20 years in the same house, which is roughly 400 feet from the quarry, the story is pretty simple: a crack in the road outside his door in late October, a blast of dynamite in the quarry in early November and then, 20 minutes later, a 250-foot-long landslide that swallowed some of his land.
Mr. Dobes's neighbor, the Pattenburg Quarry, has a different explanation. ''I think it was bad timing,'' said Michael A. Gianetti Jr., the quarry's operations manager. 
The ground above the quarry, Mr. Gianetti said, was weakened by a poorly designed drainage system, saturating the land and jeopardizing the road's structure. ''We could have stopped blasting for years, and when it fell they would have still blamed us,'' he said.
Geologists disagree about the cause of the landslide, which occurred 400 feet from the quarry through a road that winds above the outdoor mine. The quarry's engineers say a joint between two rocks gave way because of the weight of water-soaked land. Township officials say the slide is down toward the quarry, an indication, they say, that the mine blasts somehow jeopardized the structure of the rocks around the quarry.
The landslide will most likely permanently close Bellwood Farm Road, a thoroughfare in this small community, and no doubt will spawn years of costly litigation against the quarry by Mr. Dobes and the township. Lawyers for the township say they may also sue the state, which has the power to forbid blasting, for permitting the Pattenburg Quarry to continue its mining.
The landslide and the different explanations for its cause also illustrate the simmering feud between many of 3,400 residents of the township and the quarry's new owners.
The conflict dates to the time two years ago when the Gianettis bought the quarry, and when, shortly afterward, the township passed a regulation that would have all but ended stone excavation within the township.
The fact that the new owners replaced an old township family that had mined there for six decades has not made negotiations between the two sides any easier.
But more than the quarry's ownership has changed in the half century of mining in this township, which is situated in central New Jersey, just off Interstate 78 and close to the Pennsylvania border. Bethlehem, once primarily agricultural, is now also residential, increasing public exposure to the mine.
Many in the township say they are concerned by what will happen to the area once the quarry has been exhausted - 15 years from now, according to recent estimates.
In a nearby township, Bernardsville, town administrators seized on a similar change of quarry ownership to pass regulations that banned mining there. The law has been upheld by a local court and is now being appealed by the mine's owners, who contend that they have had millions of dollars in stone reserves taken from them without just cause.
''Years ago, if this had happened you would make an agreement with the farmer next door and that would be the end of it,'' said Anthony Figel, the Pattenburg Quarry's engineer. Mr. Figel said neighbors who complained about blasts from the mine were ''like people who move next to an airport and complain about the noise of the planes.''
In mid-October, people first noticed that there were two pronounced cracks in Bellwood Farm Road, prompting township officials to close the route, which had been regularly used by school buses. Neighbors immediately suspected that the quarry, an 86-acre complex just off a highway, might be to blame.
The quarry, which alone spans 40 acres, holds granite that is used to make the crushed-stone base for roadbeds. The rest of the land houses a rock-crushing machine that can pulverize up to 1,200 tons of rock a day.
After the cracks first developed, the quarry stopped blasting for a week to allow the township to test the road's safety, Mr. Figel said, although the crusher continued to operate. In that time, Mr. Figel said, the township ''didn't do anything.''
''It's almost like they sat back and waited for this to happen so they could pounce on us,'' he said.
But the township called the state and asked a team of experts from the Labor Department's Division on Mine Safety to examine the road. The state conducted its tests and determined that the road would not be imperiled if the quarry blasted within legal limits.
The next day the Township Committee passed a resolution asking the quarry to hold off blasting for a week.
At noon a day later, dynamite blasted the quarry's northwest face. Half an hour later, witnesses say, the landslide began. ''It's an amazing thing to see trees 50 feet high slip to the left,'' said Robert L. Alexander, a lawyer for the township who saw the landslide. ''It would take a fool to watch this blast take place and the landslide and not see the connection.''
The landslide's effects can be seen inside the quarry as well. Boulders weighing about 30,000 tons were dislodged by the blast, about six times more than usual, in a potentially dangerous avalanche, Mr. Gianetti said. The quarry operators say that the collapse within the quarry is evidence that the problem is based outside the quarry and that perhaps it was an abandoned mine shaft, maybe a sinkhole. In their thinking, the avalanche is damage against the quarry committed by a careless township that failed to check the safety of land where it built a road.
The quarry is under a recent court order that forbids blasting but allows the crushing, loading and transportation of rock.
Many in the town think that shutting down a road used by more than just the quarry's neighbors might be the incident they need to tightly regulate the quarry, or even shut it down.
At a town meeting about the landslide attended by about 80 people last month, resident after resident asked that tight limits be placed on the quarry. So much so that Rita Regimbal, an associate of Mr. Alexander, at one point had to urge restraint, for financial reasons. ''We don't want to just put them out of business for the sake of putting them out of business, despite what many individuals here might feel,'' said. ''We want them to only do what can be done in absolute safety.''
The quarry thinks the episode is based on an irrational fear and hatred of quarries. ''We think this whole thing is a witch hunt and a vendetta,'' Mr. Gianetti said.
The owners of the quarry fear for its own economic welfare and that of the state. ''The quarries are getting beat in this state,'' Mr. Figel said. ''If it keeps up in New Jersey, you are going to be importing stones.''
Mr. Dobes said that he planned to remain in his home, but that he feared for the future. The foundation of his house already has two cracks, he said, and he continually reassures himself that the landslide has not grown any bigger.
''I go over and look every day to see what's happening,'' he said.

LENGTH: 919 words

HEADLINE: ART;
'Cartoons Come to Paterson'

BYLINE: By VIVIEN RAYNOR

DATELINE: PATERSON

 BODY:
SINCE a fire in its administrative quarters last year, the Paterson Museum has been rather subdued - not that it is ever very active. This ''warehouse'' of local history in the Rogers Building, which was once an assembly plant for locomotives, is the centerpiece of the Great Falls Historic District. Yet it seems to be awaiting the arrival of the cultural renaissance that was announced way back in the 1970's.
Perhaps it was never meant to be. Paterson was founded as an industrial city, reportedly the first in the country, and it remains that, notwithstanding the departure of the silk and engineering industries that made it famous. Come 1992, it will be 200 years since the Society for Establishing Useful Manufactures decided to erect the first mills (for spinning and weaving cotton) and houses (fewer than a dozen) and harness the power of the falls. 
It was here that Samuel Colt established his first ''gun mill'' (1836), that his cousin, Christopher, started the silk industry (1839) and that John Philip Holland designed and launched, in the Passaic River, his first submarine (1878). Paterson was immortalized in the late 1950's by William Carlos Williams's giant poem of the same name, and the city, with its ramshackle wood houses and telephone poles groaning under swags of wire, has the look of a Ben Shahn painting. Nevertheless, its distant past is the more marketable today. With a collection of minerals, close to a quarter of a million photographs documenting the city's development, industrial relics and the like, the museum has the makings for educational shows and, on occasion, has used them. But low funds and perhaps low morale, too, have kept it from realizing its potential. Nowhere is this more apparent than in the art exhibitions, including the current ''Cartoons Come to Paterson.''
The curators imported for the occasion are Jose Delbo and Hy Eisman, authors of, respectively, ''The Transformers'' and ''The Katzenjammer Kids.'' Between them, they have come up with about 70 colleagues, a quarter of them born in New Jersey or living there, and twice that number of works. Some drawings are originals displayed in glass cases, but most are reproductions attached to boards under plastic.
Visitors had better be well versed in strip cartoons and the comic groups Marvel and DC; beginners, late starters and those who have lost traction in the field need not apply.
Cartoons have been the entertainment of millions for most of the 20th century, but only in the post-Pop era have they been elevated to the status of art - much to their detriment. The Museum of Cartoon Art, in Rye Brook, N.Y., is a mine of syndicated fun (it was founded by Mort Walker, whose ''Beetle Bailey'' figures in this show). But its atmosphere is that of a ''serious'' museum. Unfortunately, comics don't lend themselves to the system devised for processing high art, nor should they try, if only because the originality that is so prized in the upper strata counts for little in the cartoon world.
Most people know that ''Peanuts'' is Charles Schulz's baby and ''B.C.'' Johnny Hart's. But ''Batman'' - does he belong to Bob Kane, who invented him, or to the artists who draw him, Mr. Delbo and Tex Blaisdell among them? It is the same with ''Superman,'' who is represented here by Alex Saviuk and Bob Oksner but is the 1930's creation of Siegel and Schuster. ''Concessions'' to draw characters of this stature are awarded by the publishers, along with strict rules for drawing them.
There are personages like Conan the Barbarian, who started life as the hero of a paperback series, and Mr. Delbo's own Transformers, who were originally robot toys. This information was supplied by Mr. Delbo, not the biographies, which, written mainly by the artists themselves, tend to be irritatingly informative about wives (without whom) and children but facetiously offhand about accomplishments. As already indicated, it is a take-it-or-leave-it show.
Walt Kelly's ''Pogo'' is present; so is Andy Kubert's ''Brave and Bold.'' Virgil Partch's Surrealist man is bending over to retrieve a gun that a flirtatious woman has dropped instead of a handkerchief. A cartoonist in The New Yorker style, Don Orehek is represented by a drawing of whale watchers sighting their quarry as it spouts medical debris.
Dennis Corrigan aspires to high art with Surrealist images beautifully drawn in pencil. ''Kitty Litter'' features a car full of joy-riding cats with a tom at the wheel, discarding trash over the side. In ''Three Men Carrying a Grudge,'' the figures are dressed in 18th- , 19th- and 20th-century costumes while in their collective hands is the beetle from, seemingly, Kafka's ''Metamorphosis.''
There are children's book illustrations by Harry Devlin, notably one of figures skulking by the light of a yellow moon toward an obviously haunted house.There are also political cartoons on the order of Don Evers's, one of which shows Uncle Sam getting his outstretched hand eaten away by acid rain. At the other extreme are frames from a Disney feature and a Howdy Doody image by Milt Neill, together with Charlie McGill's cartoon-poster of the Spinks-Tyson fight.
Under its acting director, Giacomo de Stefano, the museum is hanging in there. But it plainly needs help from Conan, the Hulk or even Prince Valiant, and a grant from Daddy Warbucks wouldn't come amiss. The show is on view through Jan. 27, from 10 A.M. to 4 P.M. Tuesday through Friday and 12:30 P.M. to 4:30 P.M. Saturday and Sunday.

HEADLINE: NEW JERSEY OPINION;
Too Much For a Commuter

BYLINE: By Eric L. Muller; Eric L. Muller lives in Highland Park.

 BODY:
TO the world, Mikhail Gorbachev is the man who has rekindled nearly dead hopes for world peace. He is the man who has thrown open the shutters on the long-sealed window of Soviet history. He is a prince of light emerged from an empire of darkness. He is also the man who keeps me from reaching the second section of the newspaper by the Rahway station.
For years, my morning train ride to Manhattan was comfortably predictable. After settling into my window seat in New Brunswick, I would open the paper, turn to the weather map and scrutinize the progress of fronts and storms across the nation. This would take me to Edison. I would flip back to the front page for a scan of the headlines. The Metuchen and Metropark stations would pass by as I skimmed through the front section. 
By Rahway, I would be well into the second section, sometimes even as far as the obituaries. The Newark station would find me in the sports section, or perhaps the movie reviews on a Friday. As the train rolled to a stop in Penn Station, my paper would be neatly folded and tucked into the outside pocket of my shoulder bag.
Measuring my morning ride by my progress through the newspaper was easy in the good old days of Brezhnev, Andropov and Chernenko. Back then, a quick glance at a headline would tell me whether an article was for reading or for skipping. I knew I could automatically skip any article about missiles, Poland, shake-ups in the Soviet Politburo, arms negotiations or economic policy in the Soviet bloc. Only the headlines changed from day to day; the stories seemed to stay exactly the same.
In these days of glasnost and perestroika, no article may safely be skipped. Even the most mundane of articles contains some revelation, new proposal or startling innovation. One day President Gorbachev unilaterally removes every weapon but popguns and slingshots from Eastern Europe. The next day he sacks the entire Politburo and replaces it with the board of directors of I.B.M. A few days later he issues an edict declaring ''Iacocca'' to be required reading for all Soviet schoolchildren, then rushes off to sit in on keyboards at a Rolling Stones concert in Gorky Park.
It is the recent spate of stories like these that has slowed my reading to a snail's pace and confined me to the front section of the paper for the duration of my trip. While I struggle toward the editorial page, fellow commuters breeze through ''Finnegans Wake.'' Under Brezhnev, I considered moving closer to New York City to cut down on my commuting time; under Mr. Gorbachev, I am looking for housing at the end of the line.
My inability to make a real dent in the morning paper is not just frustrating; it is scary. If I am having trouble making it through one section, then the folks at the White House and the State Department must be absolutely drowning in the flood of articles, position papers, briefings, field reports, press releases and communiques that Mr. Gorbachev has unleashed.
President Bush has been faulted for reacting too slowly to change in the Warsaw Pact nations, but my guess is that he is actually responding to events as soon as he finds out about them. If his Presidency is anything like my morning commuting, he and his staff are understandably a bit behind in their reading.
Mr. Gorbachev's news offensive is clearly his strategy for world domination, and it is working. His plan is to keep the news coming fast and furious until we are several weeks behind in our reading. He will then announce the annexation of Western Europe and North America. By the time we actually learn of his action, three or four weeks later, we will already be the newest Soviet republic. Nikita Khrushchev may have threatened to bury us, but Mr. Gorbachev is actually doing it. He is burying us in newsprint.
The Bush Administration must take a hard line against the Gorbachev strategy. The President should ask our NATO allies to impose a complete ban on any news story with a dateline of Moscow, Warsaw, Budapest, Prague or East Berlin. He should then call for a series of news reduction talks aimed at bringing to manageable and verifiable levels the number of daily press releases, press conferences and photo opportunities to which each superpower is entitled. Only with a News Reduction Treaty in place can President Bush assure the American people that we will not fall victim to the Gorbachev media assault.
It is also the only way I will ever again reach the second section by the Rahway station.

LENGTH: 1379 words

HEADLINE: ABOUT NEW JERSEY

BYLINE: By Anthony DePalma

 BODY:
THE leader of the Broad Street Gang in Newark died a few weeks ago, and this hardhearted city wept.
His gang doesn't do much bragging, but it has left its mark on the street whose name it bears as well as in the city's far weedy corners and stifling apartments where hope is as rare as gold.
His gang is small, only six members, and they hang out on or just near Broad Street. It is the nonprofit community groups in Newark who named them, knowing that they can be tough and that unless you've got them on your side, you're in trouble.
The gang consists of Prudential Insurance, Public Service Electric and Gas, First Fidelity Bank, New Jersey Bell, Blue Cross/Blue Shield and Mutual Benefit Life, where its leader, Robert V. Van Fossan, worked until he died on Oct. 29. 
Every city has its own corporate good citizens, the companies that make the biggest single contributions to the local United Way and send someone to Chamber of Commerce meetings. They might put up a billboard at Christmas.
But here, where the poverty and the problems are on a scale that is out of the ordinary, the big companies have acted in an extraordinary way. For the people who run Newark, and those in the nonprofit organizations that try to make it livable, the Broad Street Gang has become a benevolent, sometimes frugal, sometimes generous partner that is essential to almost any project.
And usually out front with the money, or the support, or the personal physical presence that could lend legitimacy to an organization or its mission, was Mr. Van Fossan, known to many by his street name, Van.
It was Van who in the dark days of the 1970's promised that Newark could be better even though it looked hopeless. He led the way to restore Newark's neglected Symphony Hall. He was chairman of Renaissance Newark, the group that pushes the city's revival. Mutual Benefit's meeting rooms became ad hoc council chambers where ideas about fixing Newark's problems were aired and bold plans for the future were made. When the $30 million Performing Arts Center was on the ropes, it was Van who brought in a private investor, Raymond Chambers, and had Mutual put up half the letter of credit to get the project going.
It was also Van who set the tone for the gang over the last decade, taking the lead on many projects, cajoling his counterparts in the other headquarters to do more than they perhaps were inclined to do.
Now that he is gone, there's suddenly some doubt about what will happen in Newark. ''The Broad Street Gang just ain't what it used to be,'' said Richard W. Roper, director of the program for New Jersey affairs at Princeton's Woodrow Wilson School for Public and International Affairs and someone who lived and worked in Newark for years. ''Van's role in keeping corporate responsibility high on the agenda of the companies was critical. He was the glue that held the corporate actors in place in support of Newark's revitalization. Now that he's gone, I'm at a loss to identify his successor.''
The gang may not be what it used to be, but it is not coming apart. Everett Shaw, Newark's deputy mayor for development as well as the president of Renaissance Newark, has worked in other cities, but he believes that the gang probably contributes more money and energy, on the basis of each one of Newark's 315,000 residents, than any other corporate community in the country.
''Our corporate C.E.O.'s are more sensitive, more aware of what it takes to turn urban centers around that in any other place,'' Mr. Shaw said.
Corporations don't make contributions for purely altruistic reasons. For them it's a form of marketing, and they often select the projects they will support according to the type of image they want to put forward. They tend to be fairly conservative in their mission, which makes the projects they back most likely to succeed. The gang doesn't like to take big risks.
Neither do other companies elsewhere. But a few things set Newark apart. For one, its rock-bottom poverty and negative image present problems that often outstrip its comparatively minor size. Similiarly, the size of some of its big corporate leaders, particularly Prudential, the largest insurance company in the world, far exceeds what might be expected in a city with wooden letters identifying City Hall.
Their recognition of the size of the problems they confront might have helped persuade the corporations that their abilities to accomplish anything in Newark were limited if they acted on their own. Recently, they have joined with Mayor Sharpe James's administration in many initiatives, forging in the process a relationship other communities could envy.
''It's one thing to give money,'' Mayor James said one day recently when he attended a public ceremony at Penn Station wearing a maroon tie imprinted with the Gibraltar symbol of Prudential, ''but to give money and be active in partnership with the city and with community groups is symbolic of their committment to Newark and to the people of the city.''
That may be, but the money itself is substantial. Mutual Benefit's annual giving exceeds $2 million in Newark. Prudential tops $2.8 million. First Fidelity won't say. The other three are regulated and that puts limits on how much they can give, but even here it runs into hundreds of thousands.
What may be more important, though, is the broader involvement, the tangible presence of the gang members that provides the support holding many projects together. For instance, 100 Blue Cross employees now meet every other week with Newark schoolchildren enrolled in a program that guarantees them college scholarships if they finish school. Eventually, Blue Cross will be meeting with 400 children on a regular basis. By 1991, Mutual Benefit may tie some part of employees' bonuses to their voluntary service to community.
Public Service's decision to build a gleaming new headquarters just off Broad Street in 1981 was seen as a symbolic reaffirmation in Newark's future. The building's embracing front plaza, where concerts are held weekly in summer, and where the Puerto Rican Festival and the African Festival were staged, had become a focus of the new Newark.
First Fidelity has lent money to developers putting up stores and housing throughout the city. New Jersey Bell was recently honored by the White House for its James Street tutorial program, in which every Tuesday 60 Bell employees work with third- and fourth-grade pupils.
Prudential, because of its sheer size and wealth, has been able to finance dozens of organizations and projects. Its employees get involved in the Boys Club and the Community Food Bank. And - some say this is most significant - its investment in the five-building Gateway office complex near Penn Station forms the core of Newark's economic recuperation.
The city's nonprofit organizations often find themselves making the trek down Broad Street, financing proposal in hand. ''They set the tone on policy and programs,'' said Lorna K. Johnson, president of the Urban League of Essex County, an established, old organization that runs a large work training program and other activities in Newark. Ms. Johnson, who is leaving her position at the end of the year, said the gang's support was crucial to the survival of programs like hers, which receives more than $100,000 from the gang.
The Broad Street Gang was feeling pretty good about itself, finally seeing some of its investments pay off in the form of a stronger, brighter Newark. Now that Van is gone, the gang will continue to play a crucial role, but nobody expects it to be quite the same.
The men in charge of the other corporations all are involved in the community, but not in the way Van was. Robert C. Winters, the chairman of Prudential, has the most visible spot in the gang, but his interests are more on a national level than the company's front yard. Mr. Van Fossan's successor at Mutual Benefit, Henry Kates, has agreed to fill Van's positions as president of the Newark Chamber of Commerce and head of Symphony Hall. But even he concedes that it would be difficult for anyone to fill Van's shoes.
''Leaders tend to emerge rather than declare themselves,'' Mr. Kates said. ''I think all of us are looking to see where we can fill the void.''
