LENGTH: 2347 words

HEADLINE: Crystalline Ice Fantasies In Frozen Manchuria

BYLINE: By MOANA TREGASKIS; MOANA TREGASKIS is a writer who lives in Honolulu.

 BODY:
FAR north of China's Great Wall, a city of crystalline sculptured ice emitting colored light transforms long frozen winters into a fantasyland. The annual Ice Lantern Festival in Harbin, capital of the northeastern border province of Heilungkiang and once a city of many Russians, celebrates the lunar new year like no other place in China.
While the rest of the country frolics with paper lanterns, Harbin's vast Zhaolin Park is transformed into a city carved of ice. From Jan. 1 through the end of February, fanciful creatures and giant animals inhabit a world of icy palaces and tall pagodas, snowy flowers, pavilions and frozen tableaus from Chinese legends. In daylight the scene takes on a silvery cast. At night it blossoms in rainbows of light that blaze from inside the sculptures. The peacock struts his multicolored tail, a volcano erupts with red light, the stout-hearted climb a bluish replica of an ice-covered Great Wall, and children scramble up the tail of an elephant to slide down its icy trunk. 
Ice sculpture is a part of life in the Harbin (Harb-EEN), the industrial city and river port about 800 miles northeast of Beijing. Here, in the region still known as Manchuria, the largest Russian settlement outside Russia was established after World War I, and some of the city's architecture still reflects that time. Later, Harbin had one of the largest European populations in the Far East, until the Communists took over after World War II. And on a visit there last winter - before the harsh crackdown on pro-deomcracy demonstrators in Beijing and other cities - I noticed among the ice sculptures, along with other foreign themes, an exhibit inspired by Disney and a carved dolphin representing Alaska.
Throughout the city ice-covered pandas, prancing horses and tigers and creations of frozen falling water adorn traffic circles and the entryways of hotels and government buildings. In midwinter days that peak around zero degrees Fahrenheit, the high energy level of the Harbinese is noticeable, and perhaps it can be attributed to food portions fit for a giant, or to the fact that all buldings are superbly heated. Temperatures can sink to minus 20 at night yet no one seems to mind. The Harbinese leave their television sets and do what northerners everywhere do in winter - put on another layer. They stroll about eating ice cream clutched in mittened hands. They claim it melts too fast in the summer.
Reminiscent of a misty Oriental painting, a deceptively pleasing lavender pall hangs over city and countryside. Rather than bits of delicate cloud, the haze is a false curtain of polluting smoke from industrial coal and heating wood fires. ''Black snow,'' said a visitor from Pennsylvania sweeping up a handful. ''Just like Pittsburgh when I was a kid.'' The ice carvings are swept clean daily of snowfall and pollution.
A bustling city of some three million, Harbin is an exception in a land crammed with ancient sites. Until the turn of the century a mere village whose name meant ''where the fishing nets are dried,'' its character was forever altered by Russians and by Japanese. Russian architecture, especially old Orthodox churches and the railroad station, brought fame and the sobriquet, Moscow of the East. Japanese warlords imposed the birth of Harbin's thriving heavy industry.
The history of Heilungkiang plays a major role in the clamorous events of 20th-century China. In 1896 Russia negotiated a contract to build a railroad to Vladivostok through the province that has developed since into the Texas of China. (The nation's largest oilfields begin 62 miles northwest of Harbin. In 1914, following an agreement that extended Russian rights along the rail line to Britain as well, several European countries and the United States signed up for equal privileges, sending a swarm of foreign entrepreneurs to Harbin and turning it into an international city. In 1917 White Russian refugees surged into Harbin, which grew into alarge Russian settlement. Then in February 1932 Japanese troops occupied the city, renaming the province Manchukuo.
Throughout World War II, under the oppressive rule of Japan's Manchuria-based Kwantung army, the heavy industrial trend was begun with forced production in a province rich in coal and other largely untapped resources. The Soviet Army took back Harbin in 1945 and withdrew when Chinese troops were installed by agreement.
THE Russians are long gone from Harbin, leaving onion-domed churches and little trellised street kiosks that perk up the drab square buildings of newer vintage. The most interesting aspect of the provincial museum, built in 1923 as the commercial center, is outside, where symmetrical domes and spires rise at each end. The immense railroad station, built when the Russians projected a great northern transport hub in Harbin, is no longer large enough.
In the Daolichu district not far from Zhaolin Park, the skyline is studded with cupolas, spires and scalloped turrets. St. Sophia's Church is a fine example, its great onion bulb a tinge of old Moscow. While numerous churches were ravaged during the Chinese Cultural Revolution in the late 1960's and turned into warehouses, several remain. In the Nangang district the vaulted Orthodox church (Church of China Eastern Orthodox) is always open, and elderly devotees come and go. Services are conducted in Russian. The church was reopened in 1984. Nearby, the Gothic Church of the Christian religion (Lutheran), built in 1911, is locked except Sundays. Services are conducted in Chinese; the church was reopened in 1980.
The deep frozen Songari River is the soul of the Ice Lantern Festival. Winding through the northern part of the city, it provides the building blocks. Work begins in late November when metal stakes are driven into the ice. By hook, crane and truck, ice blocks are moved to the park where carpenters using electric saws slice them into smaller chunks. The last three weeks of December are a flurry of carving as more than 2,000 artisans and electricians leave factory jobs to apply skills and fancy to the ice.
By Jan. 1 the entrance walk is lined with birds and animals on pedestals, leading to an icy cauldron with leaping red streamers simulating the Olympic torch. Pathways with whimsical creatures and ice railings curve toward a transparent Moorish palace with colored lights, a multilevel pagoda with 10 100-foot-tall pavonine spires, ice bridges and gardens, a frozen onion-domed church, or a glowing ice rink for dancing. Chinese and Western music hoots from speakers while frolicking lighted deer and rabbits, penguins, dragons and a phoenix accompany Snow White and the Seven Dwarfs.
Beyond a tall gateway of horseshoe-shaped ice blocks on the high road, the Sungari River turns into a huge playground. At an ice-walled slide that shoots down the steep bank, revelers sit on woven mats or stand in street shoes for careening descents to the frozen water. A bone-chilling wind accompanies merrymakers who hire ice boats to sail the wide river, or one-horse gigs mounted on sleds and decorated with colored streamers. Throughout the winter members of a little troupe of outdoor sports fanatics named the Harbin Penguins jump into the frigid water to swim where the three-foot-thick ice has been hacked away.
The festival, first held in 1963 in the tottering days of economic recovery from the Great Leap Forward, collided with the Cultural Revolution but restarted in 1978 and has been picking up size each year. International competition in ice carving began three years ago and in the winter of 1989, France took the gold. Circling a nearly full-scale Arc de Triomphe, shiny transparent sculptures included a glistening Liberte (first prize), a great fat sumo wrestler (third prize, Japan) and a fighting Australian kangaroo. Harbinese clustered at Alaska's entry, a totem-style dolphin with a placard in Chinese describing the Aleutian fairy tale of the dolphin god.
It's a sure bet that a visit to Harbin will include too much food. Winter meals are piled on platters in at least seven courses. The Chinese dishes are sour, mildly hot, fresh, salty and substantial; some are crisp and many are oily. Western fare has a bit of old Russia clinging to it, especially in pastries and braised dishes. The Harbinese favor sausage snacks - white-meat and red sausages are popular, stuffed in wheat buns, with pancake or steamed bread, or sauerkraut noodles. In street markets, fresh vegetables from southern provinces are kept under heavy quilts to prevent freezing. About the city, streamer flags on single poles announce restaurants - red for local, blue for Mongolian food and neither very clean. In addition to beef and mutton, pork is abundant. It is said that all leftovers go to the pigs and I believe it - the porkers wandering around country villages are enormous. Group travelers can arrange for a banquet serving the so-called four dainties of Harbin: stewed bear's paw, one of the oldest delicacies in Chinese recipes; braised moose's snout in brown sauce; fei-long (grouse) soup, and white houtou mushrooms served with shredded chicken.
Dancing is another diversion on winter nights. To Chinese popular music performed by a six-piece band and solist, throngs of dancers swirl around ballroom floors in a smooth adagio-like step. Western cassettes blast during the intervals when the dance floor takes on the look of a crowd of beginners trying to learn unrestrained disco movements. For an entrance fee of 6 yuan (50 cents), whether the music is live or canned, everyone dances (usually 200 to 300) - couples, men and men, women and women, threesomes and singles. (The regulars' boots were stashed neatly under tables.) There are about 20 dance halls in Harbin.
During Harbin's winter, Manchurians offer advisories on keeping warm outdoors. We wore the recommended down clothing, played amid frozen creations and always remembered the final admonition: after staying out for some time, don't drink hot water until your teeth get warm.
 
PLANNING A TRIP TO HARBIN
 
Getting There
Air China (formerly C.A.A.C.) operates many domestic flights to Harbin: from Beijing, Changchun, Shanghai, Shenyang and Guangzhou (Canton). Travelers can reach Harbin by rail from any province. The Chinese say that travel on the Trans-Siberian Railroad offers better service on the run from China to the Soviet Union, with Chinese staff, than in the other direction with Russian personnel.
Travel in China is controlled by China International Travel Service (C.I.T.S.), the government wing concerned with all foreign visitors. It provides English-speaking guides and has the final say in hotel choice. The best prices are in packages from travel agents specializing in mainland travel; they have Beijing branch offices. There are agencies in Hong Kong that arrange personalized itineraries and simplify the sometimes difficult visa procedures. They have a wide knowledge of hotels and arrange everything in 24 hours. An all-inclusive week in the north is about $1500 round trip from Hong Kong. One experienced agency is Lap Ming International Travel Service, East Ocean Center, 98 Granville Road, T.S.T. Kowloon, Hong Kong; telephone, 3-723-8803.
 
Currency and Customs
China's two-tier money system is confusing. Renminbi (R.M.B.) is People's Money and foreign exchange certificates (F.E.C.'s) are Tourist Money, both issued in denominations of yuan (pronounced wan). In exchange for cash or traveler's checks from international banks, visitors receive exchange certificates; a dollar equals about 3.71 yuan. Tourists must pay for purchases in F.E.C.'s; if you want to buy something at a street market, you'll have a small amount of R.M.B. Stay clear of the black market in currency; the penalties are stiff.
 
Where to Stay
Harbin is oriented to international trade and there is no shortage of hotels; reservations required. While cleanliness standards are not up to those in the United States , the hotels are are adequate, with restaurants and shops and English-speaking staff. Good are the Swan Hotel (Tian E Fandian), which was crammed with Russian buyers attending a trade fair when we stayed there (73 Zhongsang Road; telephone, 54041); and the Guoji Fandian (International Hotel, 124 Dazhi Street; 31441). Doubles with baths and TV from about $20.
Top of the line is the new wing of the Friendship Hotel. Full of marble, it is considered the best in Harbin. Doubles with baths and TV from $21 (57 Youyi Road; 47132). Opened this year, the new Milky Way Hotel charges from $21 for doubles with baths and TV.
 
Other Advice
Practical winter clothing is essential; fancy dress unnecessary. Take a down jacket, lined boots, warm slacks, a cap with earflaps, sweater, mittens and silk longjohns, which can be bought cheaply in China (though not in extra-large sizes). Women need warm slacks; a skirt or dress should be worn only indoors and not in transit.
The common cold with lingering cough is a hazard of China travel in any season. Known as Peking throat and caused by pollution, it happens anywhere, anytime. Take your own remedies and prescription drugs. Drink only boiled water (tea) or bottled liquids. No special innoculations are necessary for China, but a gamma-globulin shot to prevent hepatitis is recommended.
 
Dining and Shopping
Unless you have an iron stomach, hotel dining rooms are the safest bet, as well as restaurants recommended by C.I.T.S. It is said that Huamei in Zhongyang Street is the best in Harbin for Russian food. When you go to outside restaurants, don't plan on using the toilet facilities - they are not clean and flushes seldom work. Street markets are everywhere in the city, as well as two large department stores crammed with merchandise and always crowded. The Friendship Store, on the top floor of the Second Department Store, offers curios and toys. The Xiangyang Fur Store has a large selection of leather and fur, with coats of fox, squirrel or sable from $67; quality is mediocre. - M. T.

HEADLINE: FIGHTING IN PANAMA;
Noriega's Move Meets Approval At White House

BYLINE: By MAUREEN DOWD, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Dec. 24

 BODY:
The White House expressed satisfaction tonight that Gen. Manuel Antonio Noriega was ''under the control of diplomatic authorities.''
The Bush Administration seemed pleased even though it was not clear whether the general would be turned over to United States or Panamanian authorities for trial, or if a deal might be worked out that would free him to live in another country, possibly Spain or Cuba. In Panama, Panamanian and foreign officials said General Noriega had expressed a preference to live in either of those places.
''His reign of terror is over,'' said President Bush's spokesman, Marlin Fitzwater, who was alone in his press office in a deserted White House.
Mr. Fitzwater said the United States ''will continue to pursue avenues for bringing General Noriega, now located, to justice.'' He said the President ''is gratified that General Noriega has been located.'' 
Mr. Bush, who went to the Pentagon this morning for a briefing on the fifth day of military operations in Panama, was told the news late this afternoon at the Presidential retreat at Camp David, where he is celebrating the Christmas holiday with his family. He was told at about 4 P.M. by his national security adviser, Brent Scowcroft, Mr. Fitzwater said.
The Bush Administration had said that one of its major objectives in sending United States troops to Panama was to apprehend General Noriega and bring him to justice. Tonight's announcement that the general had turned himself in to the Vatican envoy in Panama fell short of that goal.
But the White House said it was pleased with the surprise development because, as one Administration official put it, ''We know where he is, he's totally separated from the rest of society and he can no longer be a rallying point for his forces.''
It could not be learned in Washington whether an agreement had been reached beforehand among General Noriega, the new Panamanian Government and the Papal Nuncio.
Many critics had complained last week that if General Noriega was not captured, Mr. Bush's decision to send American troops to Panama would be viewed as less than a clear success.
 
Restoring Law and Order
But the White House immediately began to contend tonight that all of its major objectives had been realized. Mr. Fitzwater said General Noriega's decision would help the United States in its efforts to restore stability to Panama City and to set up the Government of President Guillermo Endara.
''As we work to help return law and order to Panama City, and as the Government of President Endara begins its work, the demise of General Noriega sends a strong signal that freedom and democracy in Panama are now on the rise,'' Mr. Fitzwater said.
Although the Bush Administration said Wednesday morning that the apprehension of General Noriega was one of the four principal objectives of the American invasion, senior officials spent the last several days preparing the public for the possibility that the general would not be captured.
Defense Secretary Dick Cheney said this morning on the ABC News program ''This Week'' that the capture of General Noriega would be ''the icing on the cake,'' suggesting that the mission would be successful even without apprehending the general because ''any ability by him to control the situation in Panama is gone.''
Mr. Cheney left for Panama later today - before the news that General Noriega was turning himself over to the Vatican representative - to meet with American troops and review the situation.
Over the years, the Reagan and Bush Administrations tried a variety of diplomatic and economic means to try to oust the Panamanian military leader.
Recalling the diplomatic efforts, one Administration official said tonight that the Government ''had shown flexibility about Noriega in the past, and we will probably be willing to show flexibility in the future.''
According to international law, diplomatic missions are safe havens for those seeking asylum. American military forces had surrounded the Cuban and Nicaraguan Embassies in Panama City to prevent General Noriega from taking asylum there. But they apparently were not monitoring the Papal Nuncio's office in Panama City, because the general was reported to have driven up in a private car and walked in alone, after calling first.
After General Noriega's turned himself in, however, the Papal Nuncio's residence in the Paitilla district of Panama City was surrounded by about 200 American soldiers and three tanks.
Administration officials were aware of the paradox of the situation.
Last week, worried that the wily general was still on the loose, they tried to blacken his reputation by revealing the cache of strange items found at his headquarters and portraying him as a ''narco-terrorist'' under the sway of the occult, cocaine and pornography.
 
A Different Image
By turning himself in alone on Christmas Eve to Pope John Paul II's representative, Msgr. Jose Sebastian Laboa, the general presented a different image as he turned from a fugitive to a man seeking political asylum.
A Justice Department spokeswoman, Deborah Burstion-Wade, said she was not sure of General Noriega's status under the protection of the Vatican envoy.
''Although events are unclear at this point, we still remain very interested in bringing him to the United States to stand trial,'' she said. She added that she did not know whether any Justice Department attorneys were on hand in Panama to formulate a request for extradition.
Raymond Takiff, a Miami lawyer on General Noriega's defense team in the United States, told Reuters tonight that he had learned that a mob was on its way to the building where Mr. Noriega had sought asylum. ''We're afraid they're going to hang him,'' he told the news agency, adding that he was surprised that General Noriega had turned himself in to the Papal Nuncio and that the general was not taking advice from his American lawyers.
 
No Decision on Extradition
Defense Secretary Cheney had suggested for the first time on television this morning that even if caught, the general might not be brought back to the United States. ''If he were to be captured in Panama and arrested, then I suppose we'd have to sit down at that point and decide whether he was going to be brought back to the United States, extradicted if you will, or whether he would be prosecuted in Panama.''
General Noriega's supporters have pointed out that it would be embarrassing for the United States to bring to trial the Panamanian who worked for the Central Intelligence Agency through several Administrations, because he might try to use classified documents in his defense.
Washington insiders warned last week that it could be risky for Mr. Bush, who was head of the C.I.A. when General Noriega was still associated with it, if the general was captured alive and returned to justice in the United States.
The Panamanian threatened Mr. Bush during the 1988 campaign, saying he had damaging information about the Vice President's role in the Iran-contra scandal, an assertion that Mr. Bush hotly denied.
''The worst thing for George Bush would be Noriega on trial up here filling in embarrassing blanks,'' Kevin Phillips, a conservative analyst, said.
 
'Many Secret Skeletons'
William Schneider, an analyst at the American Enterprise Institute, agreed. ''I'm not convinced this Administration really wants Noriega to go on trial,'' he said. ''Noriega worked with the C.I.A. and claims to know a great many secret skeletons that are buried close to George Bush. A protracted Noriega trial would be a real horror for this Administration.''
Before General Noriega's decision to turn himself in was announced, Mr. Bush attended a Pentagon briefing on Panama and said afterward that he believed that American troops had achieved ''a real turnaround'' in ending the chaos that had reigned since the United States had invaded early Wednesday morning.
Evidence that General Noriega's action came as a surprise to the President was reflected in Mr. Bush's remarks after the briefing. Asked when American troops might be able to capture the general, the President replied, ''If I knew that, why both of us would be a lot smarter.''
Mr. Bush said then that his military advisers had told him that ''the emphasis now is on cleaning up the last parts of resistance, seeing that civilian government take over, tranquillity in the city and then moving on food and medicine.''

HEADLINE: Upheaval in the East: Moscow;
Soviet TV View: Ceausescu [Equals] Stalin

BYLINE: By FRANCIS X. CLINES, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: MOSCOW, Dec. 24

 BODY:
A Soviet television news program tonight celebrated the fall of Nicolae Ceausescu in Rumania by comparing him to two former Soviet leaders, Stalin as a despotic abuser of his own people and Brezhnev as a nepotistic corrupter of his Government.
The news program, ''Seven Days,'' presented a seven-minute opening dispatch that brought the nation up to date on the third day of the military struggle for Rumania. It also offered a brief biography of Mr. Ceausescu that noted that his final speech included a promise that Rumania's living standards would soon improve. 
''It was too late,'' the narrator said, as the film and commentary depicted the Rumanian leader's flight, the fall of his Government and the aftermath, in which various democratic improvements have been promised.
The news program was noteworthy both for its terms of reference to two Soviet leaders and for a following report that summarized a state of general economic crisis in East Germany, Czechoslovakia and Bulgaria.
The program's reference points seemed particularly tailored to the Soviet public's anxieties, since economic hardship remains the dominant issue in the nation, overshadowing even the continuing democratic revolt in East Europe.
The comparison of Mr. Ceausescu with Stalin and Brezhnev was offered in dramatic tones by a narrator who said that news reports from Rumania indicated that 324 members of the Ceausescu family had been found living luxuriously by dint of their patronage jobs on the Government payroll.
''In repressing his people, he may have lagged behind our Stalin, but he nevertheless worked hard at it,'' the narrator said of Mr. Ceausescu.
Of immediate interest to Soviet officials was that Ion Iliescu, the spokesman for the Rumanian National Salvation Front, the new interim governing panel in Bucharest, has known President Mikhail S. Gorbachev since they were university students together 35 years ago.
During the day, Mr. Gorbachev again brought the National Congress up to date on the news from Bucharest, noting that fighting was continuing but that events seemed to favor the eventual success of the popular revolt against the Ceausescu Government.
Mr. Gorbachev continued to make a point of ruling out suggestions from the United States Government and elsewhere that military intervention by the Soviet Union might be in order. The Soviet leader noted that while some members of the new provisional governing panel in Rumania had been asking for foreign military help, the Chief of Staff of the Rumanian Army had said no such aid was needed.
President Gorbachev continued to treat the upheavals in the Eastern bloc as a trend that has his approval. He did not address the question of whether the uprisings in Eastern capitals might inspire greater protest in the Soviet Union over the undelivered economic promises of his perestroika program.
Thus far they have not. In a sudden change of plans that seems designed to ease discontent, Mr. Gorbachev recently revamped his economic program away from his long-sought renewal of basic industry toward a short-term improvement in the nation's abysmal consumer economy.
Various critics have since warned that this is a repetition of the 70-year pattern of Communist economic failure. But Government officials say they are embarking on radical economic reform aimed at achieving Soviet success in the world economy.

GRAPHIC: Rumanians celebrating yesterday outside the captured Communist Party headquarters in Bucharest. (Reuters)

HEADLINE: Upheaval in the East: The New Leaders;
Bucharest Government Has Yet to Take Shape

BYLINE: Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Dec. 24

 BODY:
Little is known in the United States about the members of the Council of National Salvation, the group trying to organize a government in Rumania following the fall of President Nicolae Ceausescu, State Department analysts said today.
Though the names of several committee members have come to public attention, Steve Kane, a member of the State Department's task force dealing with the events in Rumania, emphasized that the council has neither defined its leadership structure nor named individuals to top posts, including chairman or head of government.
On Friday, the council did announce the formation of a provisional government to run the country and prepare for elections in the spring.
In contrast to the anonymity surrounding most council members, a considerable amount is circulating about two prominent members, Ion Iliescu and Corneliu Manescu. 
Mr. Iliescu, an ousted member of the Central Committee of the Communist Party who announced the arrest of Mr. Ceausescu, has emerged as the principal spokesman for the new council and is believed to be a contender for the position of head of state. He is a former Rumanian Foreign Minister who was placed under house arrest in March for co-signing a letter urging Mr. Ceausescu to abandon his cult of personality or to resign.
The other Rumanians believed to be playing a leading role in the council, according to State Department analysts and other experts on the region, are:
SILVIU BRUCAN - A former Rumanian Ambassador to the United States who served as a senior editor of the Communist Party newspaper, Mr. Brucan worked with Mr. Manescu to form the council, Rumanian television reports say.
In March, Mr. Brucan was one of the former officials of the Government and party who sent the open letter to Mr. Ceausescu, accusing him of destroying Rumania's economy and terrorizing the population by abusing the secret police. All of the former officials were put under police guard.
Mr. Brucan had been placed under house arrest two years ago for telling Western correspondents that the Communist leadership had lost touch with the workers and had become their exploiters.
''I was a fishbone in their throat,'' he told a friend in Washington last year. ''They couldn't swallow me and they couldn't spit me out.''
GEN. NICOLAE MILITARU - The committee announced Saturday night that General Militaru, an army officer who was demoted by President Ceausescu, would be its Defense Minister.
Besides former officials, the committee includes these noted poets and writers:
DOINA CORNEA - Considered one of Rumania's most outspoken dissidents, Miss Cornea, a writer, has been under virtual house arrest for more than a year.
''The Rumanian people - you too, I think - are at a crossroads,'' Miss Cornea wrote to President Ceausescu in April. ''This exhausting rule you impose on us, against the fiber of our being - constitutional, morale and biological - is becoming even more unbearable.''
MIRCEA DINESCU - Mr. Dinescu, a poet, stood with Mr. Manescu on Friday after the takeover of the Rumanian television studios in Bucharest. He was thrown out of the Communist Party in March because of his contact with foreigners and was dismissed in the spring from the magazine Rumania Literara.
Mr. Dinescu told the Rumanian writers union in the summer that he had been placed under house arrest in a rural town because he had given an interview to the French newspaper Liberation. Since April, he said, he had been under 24-hour surveillance.
ANNA BLANDIANA - An intellectual and outspoken critic of Mr. Ceausescu, Miss Blandiana has published a number of poems and short stories in which she described the somber atmosphere of daily life in Rumania.
Several times during the last few years, Miss Blandiana defied orders from the Government that she discontinue her writing, said a former high-ranking official in the Rumanian intelligence service.
AUREL DRAGOSCH MUNTEANU - Mr. Munteanu, the former editor in chief of a literary magazine, recently sent a series of letters to Mr. Ceausescu, criticizing his political and economic programs.
The secret police, in response to Mr. Munteanu's criticism, interrogated and beat him on several occasions, the former intelligence official said.

GRAPHIC: A civilian ducking gunfire during heavy fighting yesterday in Bucharest. Across the street was the body of a slain soldier. (Reuters)

HEADLINE: Hispanic Population Suffering Along With Massachusetts Economy

BYLINE: By CONSTANCE L. HAYS, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: BOSTON, Dec. 22

 BODY:
For the estimated 300,000 Hispanic residents of Massachusetts, many of whom remained mired in poverty in the years when the state's economy flourished, the outlook as the economy stagnates is especially bleak.
By most social and financial measures no other ethnic group faces as many problems.
''I don't think anyone in the Hispanic community has had the illusion that we've been in good times,'' said State Representative Nelson A. Merced, who last year became the first Hispanic lawmaker elected to the legislature here. ''And I think they're going to get worse. Clearly, the state is not going to have the resources to deal with some of these problems.'' 
Statistics compiled in a recent study by the Boston Foundation, a private nonprofit group that does research on social issues, show that the poverty rate rose for Hispanic families between 1980 and this year, while the rate of black families and white families in poverty declined.
The Hispanic dropout rate from Boston public schools is 53.8 percent, the highest of any group. Unemployment is running at about 50 percent among Hispanics workers statewide, higher than for any other ethnic group. The rate of underweight babies born to Puerto Ricans is almost twice that of whites in Massachusetts, and a Hispanic woman is 10 times as likely to have AIDS as a white woman.
Comparisons like those are repeated across New England and the country, said Frank Bonilla, the director of the Center for Puerto Rican Studies at Hunter College in New York. ''It's a feature of recovery as much as stagnation, and that's what is so alarming,'' he said.
 
Few Agencies Address Problems
Although the Hispanic population in Massachusetts grew from about 1,200 in 1960 to about 150,000 to 1980, and has doubled in the last nine years, there are few agencies in the state that address those citizens' specific problems. Many Hispanic residents here speak only Spanish and others are subjected to job discrimination even when they are proficient in English. The agencies that do exist to help them have had to struggle for money and predict that the waiting lists for their classes in job skills and English will grow even longer as state money is squeezed from their budgets.
''We're in the middle of making some very, very difficult decisions about cutting back on programs, when obviously there are great needs,'' said Frieda Garcia, executive director of the United South End Settlements, a social service agency in Boston's Roxbury section. Her budget had to be reduced to $2.4 million for next year from $2.7 million this year, largely because of state budget cuts.
Massachusetts is experiencing the worst deficit in its history this year. The total deficit is about $1.2 billion, and to comply with the state's balanced-budget law, legislators are making deep cuts in spending and are talking about raising taxes. A state program for immigrants called Gateway Cities was cut to $2 million this year from $11 million two years ago, and then the $2 million was withheld.
But many experts say Hispanic residents have not relied heavily on such services, partly out of apprehension about Government programs and partly from ignorance about their existence. As a result, gauging the depth of their needs is difficult because little data have been collected. At least 55 percent of all Hispanic residents of the state are Puerto Rican, with a large proportion of Dominicans as well. In recent years, many people from Peru, El Salvador, Guatemala and other Latin American countries have arrived. It is not clear how many are illegal aliens.
''The awareness of the problems is very new, but it's not that people in the community haven't been talking about them,'' said Miren Uriarte, the director of the Mauricio Gaston Institute for Latino Community Development and Public Policy, established earlier this month at the University of Massachusetts. ''It's that other people didn't listen. Now the population is getting large and the problems remain unattended, and something needs to happen.''
 
Few Jobs Offer Growth
Complicating the problems facing Hispanic residents is the Massachusetts economy's emphasis on service jobs, rather than manufacturing, said Jaime Talero, the executive director of Oficina Hispana, a nonprofit advocacy agency in Boston. Even in the years when the economy was flourishing, the percentage of Boston's Hispanic families headed by a single parent rose from 74 percent to 78.7 percent between 1980 and this year, a study released earlier this month by the Boston Foundation showed. A survey of other major American cities by the same group found poverty declined slightly for Hispanic single-parent families, from 70.1 percent in 1980 to 68.9 percent in 1987.
''The structure of employment in Massachusetts is becoming increasingly stratified,'' Mr. Talero said. ''People come here for jobs, and they see that yes, there are a lot of jobs, but no, they're not for Hispanics.''
While other immigrants, pulled themselves up from poverty by starting out on factory floors and working their way up to positions as foremen and managers, Hispanic immigrants have arrived at a time when jobs affording that opportunity are few and far between.
The jobs they can find, Mr. Talero said, are ''low-level, very low-paying jobs.''
''The building cleaning and maintenance industry is dominated by Hispanics,'' he said. ''If you enter into that kind of cleaning job, it doesn't prepare you for anything else. If you start in a cleaning job, that's where you'll stay.''
Discrimination creates further obstacles, many advocates and experts say. ''There is a lot of discrimination when you try to enter the work force, and then a lot of discrimination that obstructs the upward mobility of Latinos,'' said Millie Rivas, assistant director of the Gandara Mental Health Center in Springfield. ''When they quote the unemployment rate, those are the ones who have solicited work. There's a much larger group that has just given up.''
 
Job Searches Can Last a Year
The center tries to find jobs for people in its substance-abuse treatment program, but the barriers mean that people often try to find jobs for a year before succeeding, ''unless it's auto mechanics or janitorial services or kitchen work,'' Ms. Rivas said.
Another source of problems is that Hispanic residents rely on public education, which has not responded fully to specific needs, other advocates said. Dropout rates are high, and even the students who graduate often find they are not prepared for the job market.
''We have identified in Boston more than 20 schools that have at least 50 students who are Hispanic, but no bilingual staff,'' said Javier Colon, a lawyer at Multicultural Education, Training and Advocacy Inc. in Somerville. ''The whole affirmative action program has not worked for Hispanics in the school system. There has not been any substantial increase in Hispanics at the teaching or administrative levels.''
Bilingual-education programs do exist across the state, but most of them try to phase the children out by the third grade. Then the children suffer from a lack of sensitivity to their culture and many later drop out, Mr. Colon said. A dropout prevention program initiated by his group and Hispanic parents lists among its ''Common Sense Tips'' things like: ''Learn how to pronounce students' names correctly first and last. Make the effort to call students by their names.''
With this kind of program, advocates for Hispanic residents of the state are trying to have a voice in the systems they rely on. In the heavily Hispanic town of Chelsea, just outside Boston, the first Hispanic citizen ever was elected to the school committee this fall.
It is a slow process, said Mr. Merced, the state representative. His first term, he said, has felt like ''I'm riding a horse and we're going in different directions.''

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

COUNTRY: UNITED STATES (97%); 

STATE: MASSACHUSETTS, USA (97%); NEW YORK, USA (79%); NORTHEAST USA (79%);

HEADLINE: On the Frigid Great Lakes, Ore Shippers Rush to Beat the Ice

BYLINE: By WILLIAM E. SCHMIDT, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: ESCANABA, Mich., Dec. 21

 BODY:
Running full speed through the black Lake Michigan night, the Joseph L. Block was 20 miles offshore and inbound for Escanaba when her searchlights picked out the front edge of the ice, a jagged sheet nearly a foot thick, smooth and hard as steel.
On the bridge of the ore carrier, Capt. Duane Carlton braced and ordered engines to half, as the 728-foot Block, wreathed in clouds of mist rising off the nearly frozen lake, nudged through the slabs of floe ice.
Suddenly, there was a deep metallic groan, and the entire boat shuddered as her rounded prow smashed into the ice. The Block hesitated and then churned slowly forward, the huge plates of ice creaking and snapping as Captain Carlton pushed the carrier's 7,000-horsepower engines to full.
On the lake, the temperature was nearly 8 degrees below zero, with a 20-mile-an-hour wind whipping snow across the ice. In the brittle darkness ahead, between the Block and the Escanaba harbor light, two other freighters were already stuck in the ice, trapped by what weather forecasters and lake shippers have described as the earliest and hardest winter on the Great Lakes since 1976. 
 
Trying to Beat the Ice
Even before the brutal cold of this week, when record-breaking temperatures stayed well below zero for nearly two full days all across the region, carriers on the Great Lakes have been hurrying to beat the ice, which has seized harbors and shipping channels in conditions like those of mid-January.
''It's a race with winter,'' said Dan Cornillie, the manager of fleet operations for the Inland Steel Company, which operates the Joseph S. Block and two other vessels that ship iron ore pellets to their Indiana steel mills from mines in Minnesota and the Upper Peninsula of Michigan. Conditions permitting, he hopes to squeeze in three more runs before the ice makes it impossible.
For steel makers like Inland, these late season runs are vital. Ships like the Block carry as much as 33,000 tons of iron ore, which is piled in huge mountains beside their steel plants, to keep blast furnaces running until spring, when the ore boats are able to get back on the lakes.
While the Block made harbor late Wednesday night, the ice slowed her considerably, adding four hours to what is normally a 21-hour run to Escanaba from Indiana Harbor, near Chicago. But her sister ship, the Wilfred Sykes, was not as fortunate; the 678-foot ore boat spent 13 hours locked in the ice off Escanaba, before a tug boat could reach her and break her loose.
Even the behemoth Columbia Star, which, at 1,000 feet, is nearly 40 feet longer than the Queen Elizabeth 2, was a prisoner of the weather. Outbound from Escanaba and fully loaded with ore, it took her nearly eight hours on Wednesday to make barely four miles in the ice.
 
Moving Ore by Rail
George J. Ryan, the president of the Lake Carriers' Association, said the early winter will force carriers to leave an estimated 1.6 million tons of ore and other materials on docks. It will either have to be moved by rail, at much higher costs, or left there until the ice breaks up in the spring.
''What is happening out there boggles the mind,'' said Mr. Ryan, who said carriers are pushing to move as much of the material as possible before ice locks them out entirely. ''We have not seen a winter like this in a long time.''
Because of extreme cold and channels clogged with ice, the Soo Locks at Sault Ste. Marie, Mich., which carry vessels between Lake Superior and the lower lakes, will shut down at midnight Wednesday, one of the earliest closings in recent years.
''Basically, every place is frozen up, and a lot sooner than anyone expected,'' said Lieut. Bruce Toney, the operations duty office for the Ninth United States Coast Guard District in Cleveland, which oversees the Great Lakes.
Ice floes and windrows, ridges of ice formed where floe ice smashed together, have clogged shipping lanes from the St. Lawrence Seaway in upstate New York to Milwaukee Harbor on Lake Michigan.
The worst conditions are on Lake Superior, where some vessels that arrived in Duluth this week decided to lay over there for the winter, rather than risk a run back toward the Soo Locks.
 
Some Areas Covered in Ice
Some areas, like Green Bay in Wisconsin and Saginaw Bay in Michigan, are completely covered with ice, and Coast Guard vessels are helping commercial tugs free freighters locked in harbors.
Ordinarily, the shipping season on the Great Lakes runs from mid-March until early or mid-January. Before the onset of bitter winter weather, shippers were headed for one of their most successful years since the recession of the early 1980's.
The vitality of the big lake boats is a direct measure of the state of the Midwestern industrial economy. Although lake boats also carry coal, cement, grain and other bulk materials, the major commodity is taconite, the pellets of iron ore and limestone used by the steel mills of Detroit, Cleveland and northwest Indiana.
As the steel industry has increased production in recent years, the demand for taconite has grown as well, and vessels that were once mothballed have been brought back into service. Mr. Ryan said about 60 vessels were sailing the Great Lakes this December, more than twice the number in 1984.
Carriers complain that Coast Guard resources have not been adequate in the Great Lakes to keep open critical shipping lanes. Part of the problem is that the cutter Mackinaw, a 290-foot 10,000-horsepower Polar class icebreaker, is in the yards for repair and remodeling, and will not be available until spring.
Although many of the ore carriers, which are larger than most ocean-going ships, are able to push through the ice, they are slowed to two or three miles an hour, as against their normal cruising speed of about 15 miles an hour.
 
'Cutting Through Velcro'
''It's a little bit like cutting through Velcro,'' said Lieut. Pat Dietrich, the operations duty officer with the Coast Guard Group Milwaukee, which oversees ice operations on Lake Michigan. ''You can move, but not very easily.'' With a crew of 27, the Joseph L. Block left her berth at Inland Steel late Tuesday, delayed nearly six hours because cold had fouled the machinery used to unload the taconite pellets away from the boat. Almost as soon as she passed the breakwater, the boat ran into ice, although much of it was just a thin glaze on the top of the waters off Chicago.
As the Block churned forward at full speed, the ice made a kind of tinkling sound, like the breaking of crystal, as it was pushed aside by the blunt bow.
Spray off the lake had already draped the decks and masts with a coating of ice, five inches thick in places and twisted into surreal sculpture by the wind. First Mate Tom Martineau estimated there was 350 tons of ice dragging on the ship.
To reduce further ice buildup, and stay out of the wind, the Block hugged the Lake Michigan shoreline, keeping four to five miles off as she pressed northward. At Rock Island Passage, she headed northwest into Green Bay, on the final sprint into Escanaba, and immediately ran on to the thick sheet ice.
On the bridge, Captain Carlton and Mr. Martineau played searchlights over the seascape, boring through the night to find the chalky tracks gouged in the ice by the passage earier of other boats. While the carrier's two diesel locomotive engines were running at full power, the Block made barely eight miles an hour, or just more than half its cruising speed of 14.5 miles an hour.
Down below, crew members wondered if the boat would make port in Escanaba before the local taverns closed at 1:30 A.M. ''I could use a highball,'' said Patrick LaFreniere, a sailor who began working the lake boats in 1952. ''But I'm going to tell the bartender that I don't want any ice. I've seen enough ice the last week.''

HEADLINE: Call Sugar Complaints Just Sour Grapes

 BODY:
To the Editor:
In ''Uncle Sugar, Uncle Milk'' (editorial, Dec. 12), you uncritically accept candy industry complaints about sugar policy. What's worse, you assume that candy manufacturers are reliable spokesmen for consumer concerns. 
You state that United States candy makers pay twice the world price for the sugar and corn sweeteners in candy canes. In fact, the corn syrup used is selling at less than the world price of sugar.
A more serious error is the assertion that jacked-up sugar prices cost United States consumers $3 billion a year. That assumes lower sugar costs get passed through to consumers.
Most sugar is consumed in processed foods. In a typical candy bar the sugar costs just over a penny. If sugar were free, would manufacturers sell candy bars for 44 cents? Processors like the candy companies typically do not pass along savings on sweeteners to the consumer - a fact readily demonstrated in Department of Agriculture statistics.
In 1980, there was no sugar program and consumers paid 43 cents a pound for sugar. Today, consumers pay about 40 cents a pound. If sugar prices had simply kept pace with inflation, the price would be more than 61 cents a pound.
But major sugar-using processors, among the most profitable companies and industries in the United States, are beefing about sugar prices. Where's the beef?
 
ROBERT C. LIEBENOW
President, Corn Refiners Association
 Washington, Dec. 12, 1989

HEADLINE: ESSAY;
More Lying In State

BYLINE: By William Safire

DATELINE: WASHINGTON

 BODY:
My first inkling that untruthfulness had become tolerable in the Bush Administration came when I inquired why no high-level official was being sent by the U.S. to the Sakharov funeral.
The Vice President was prepared to go; the Secretary of State was already in Europe; yet Mr. Bush chose to send only our resident envoy. A spokesman explained to me - on background - that the Sakharov family wanted it that way.
That was patently untrue; Yelena Bonner would hardly ask that we not make a fuss over her dead husband lest a major expression of respect embarrass Mr. Gorbachev. Mr. Bush chose to downplay our concern for human rights; just as troubling was a decision to fake the reason. 
The next evidence was Secretary of State Baker's volunteered remark, on live television Dec. 10, that since the massacre at Tiananmen Square the recent Scowcroft-Eagleburger trip to China was ''the first time we've had high-level United States officials go to the People's Republic of China.''
A week later, when CNN disclosed that Mr. Scowcroft had been dispatched to Beijing secretly only a few weeks after the massacre, we learned that Mr. Baker's assertion had been untrue - not an inaccuracy or a misstatement, but a statement made with intent to mislead.
Why did this experienced Washington hand so cavalierly jeopardize faith in the State Department's good word? The answer he gave yesterday was ''I was trying to protect the confidentiality of a classified Presidential mission.'' If he did mislead Americans, he added winningly, ''I only misled them for seven days.''
That's not the way it works in the real world of protecting secrets. With a life in danger - as when a hostage has a gun to his head - a lie is morally defensible. But government officials have no business lying about the public's business, even in the name of national security. Instead, they have the obligation to refrain from saying all they know.
The duty to conceal embraces no right to lie. In prospective military strikes, a zipped lip is respected. In economic affairs, if any Treasury Secretary is asked to confirm rumors about a devaluation planned for the next day, he is obligated to keep his mouth shut lest speculators profit at taxpayers' expense.
The proper answer is not merely a refusal to answer, which seems to confirm, but an aggressive ''What kind of dumb question is that? You know we never discuss such things.''
James Baker has long had the rules of media engagement pasted in his hymnbook. In this China-trip case, he foolishly sought to avoid political embarrassment by pretending the President did not break his word about eschewing high-level exchanges with Chinese leaders.
Maybe he thought nobody would find out about the first trip six months ago, a gamble that obviously failed to get results; the Secretary now knows he blundered like the rankest amateur. ''I could simply have no-commented,'' he finally admitted in Haigspeak, ''which is what I should have done.''
George Bush compounded the erosion of trust by getting tricky about the word ''exchange.'' Asked inaccurately if he had not pledged no contact with Beijing, he pounced on a narrow interpretation of his word: ''I said no exchange,'' he replied triumphantly, as if his dispatching of an envoy halfway around the world escaped the meaning of exchange.
That's like the President saying he had spoken to us with his fingers crossed. Churchill used to say, ''Nothing rankles like a trick''; Mr. Baker and Mr. Bush have confused the need to keep one's mouth shut about diplomatic initiatives with the inclination to mislead to cover up embarrassments; the first protects secrets, the second subverts Presidencies.
White House aides expect the departures from truth on China to be redeemed by free passage to the dissidents Fang Lizhi and wife and the unjamming of V.O.A. (both already negotiated), as well as amnesty for all nonviolent demonstrators (a sticking point). After aggressive acquiescence in secret produces results, Mr. Bush believes his finger-crossing will be forgiven. He is mistaken; a reputation for duplicity clings.
This poetic justice just in: ''Essay'' has learned secondhand that Secretary Baker has been telling selected pundits and reporters - off the record - that he opposed the Scowcroft trips. Ironically, of all the Bush men involved in the kowtowing to Deng, it is James Baker - in publicly defending what he privately whispers he opposed - whose credibility has been most besplattered and whose reputation for shrewdness has been most muddied.

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

TYPE: Op-ed

HEADLINE: 2 Peaceful Magazines Wage War in Vermont

BYLINE: Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: BRISTOL, Vt., Dec. 20

 BODY:
There are, predictably, trees dressed in brilliant displays of fall foliage on the covers of both magazines. Inside, the pages of both are filled with soothing editorial and pictorial tributes to the beauty of Vermont.
Outside the covers, however, a snappish dispute between the editor of Vermont Life, a state-owned magazine, and the publisher of Vermont Magazine, a private publication, has become contentious enough that both the Secretary of Development and the Attorney General have stepped in to referee.
The war of words began after David Sleeper, publisher of the two-issue-old Vermont Magazine, asked the Vermont Agency of Development and Community Affairs, which is publisher of Vermont Life, to allow him to rent the magazine's subscription list, arguing that it is a public document. 
His request prompted Thomas Slayton, editor of Vermont Life, to say, ''It suggests to me they're getting little desperate,'' a remark that infuriated Mr. Sleeper.
 
Remark Upsets Publisher
''What disturbed me was a member of the development agency making idle and damaging speculation about our financial condition,'' Mr. Sleeper said. ''Soon after his comments appeared, we heard from several of our advertisers asking if it were true. In fact, we're in great shape.''
But Mr. Slayton said the remark about Mr. Sleeper was meant to be ''more a statement about his behavior than about the financial health of his magazine,'' adding, ''I obviously have no knowledge of his finances.''
By the standards of most media empires, this dispute has to be rated the Battle of the Midgets. Vermont Life, one of the grande dames of state-owned magazines, was first published in 1946. It now has a circulation of 110,000; 80 percent of its 90,000 subscribers live out of state.
In recent years because of rising production and mailing costs, Vermont Life has been losing money, provoking debate among members of the advisory board over whether the magazine should accept advertising.
In the early years, the quarterly magazine took an overtly come-hither promotional stance, designed to lure businesses and homeowners to an underdeveloped state. Although that message has shifted as the state's economic circumstances have improved, the pages, for the most part, remain dedicated to the scenic glory of Vermont: cows grazing on hillsides, white church spires rising above snow-covered villages.
Vermont Magazine, the bimonthly newcomer, paired its premier issue with a marketing campaign that included distributing 10,000 free copies at country inns, in addition to the 35,000 copies it sold to subscribers and on newstands.
Like Vermont Life, Vermont Magazine is primarily circulated out of state; also like Vermont Life, it devotes much of its space to Morgan horses, tips on where to ski and profiles of local craftsmen. Still, Mr. Sleeper believes that his editorial mission differs in one very significant way.
''We're different because we are independent of state government,'' he said. ''We can make independent judgments; there is no topic we shy away from. We can do political profiles, we can talk about where state programs have failed, and the only people we report to is ourselves and our readers.''
Mindful of that difference and convinced that he is not a direct competitor of Vermont Life, Mr. Sleeper professes not to be dismayed that he has failed three times to get his rival's subscription list. The most recent rejection came this fall, from Jeffrey Francis, the new Secretary of Development, with a supporting ruling from the Attorney General's office.
''We're already renting a million names a year,'' Mr. Sleeper said. ''Frankly, we're not convinced that the Vermont Life list would be all that useful to us. A lot of those names are in far-flung places like Arizona. It just isn't that big a deal.''
Mr. Slayton said he, too, was ready to bury the hatchet. ''I don't quarrel well,'' he said. ''Besides it's not a good thing for two magazines promoting sweetness and light in Vermont to be fighting with each other.''

HEADLINE: Illegal Salvadorans Fight Poverty, Winter and Fear on L.I.

BYLINE: By SARAH LYALL

DATELINE: HEMPSTEAD, L.I., Dec. 24

 BODY:
Living 10 to 12 in a house, working as landscapers, dishwashers and maids, tens of thousands of Salvadorans are struggling to survive on Long Island, having traded the violence of their homeland for the uncertainty of life as undocumented aliens.
Estimates of the number of Salvadorans living on Long Island range from 60,000 to more than 80,000, giving the area one of the largest Salvadoran populations in the country after California, Texas and Washington, D.C. Social workers and others say the influx has created an underground of illegal workers who snap up unskilled service jobs for little pay.
At the same time, the wave of people arriving without money or work is straining the communities in which they settle. Increasing numbers of Salvadorans are homeless, walking the streets of several towns or huddling in makeshift lean-tos in wooded areas. And, social workers say, more and Salvadorans are becoming alcoholics as their hope turns to despair. 
This winter, as a new wave of Salvadorans arrives after the most recent round of violence in their homeland, joining Guatemalans, Nicaraguans and other Central Americans who have settled here, the Federal Immigration and Naturalization Service has begun a quiet crackdown on undocumented aliens and the people who hire them. #26 Job Seekers Arrested In September, the immigration service arrested and began deportation proceedings against 26 Salvadorans looking for day jobs in front of a delicatessen in Glen Cove. Recently, church workers and Salvadorans say, immigration officials have raided several factories and arrested workers.
Glen Cove is considering an ordinance that would make it a crime for illegal aliens to solicit work on the streets of the city. ''They're taking jobs away from people who are documented in this town, and they're not paying taxes,'' said Jeanne Henderson, a spokeswoman for Glen Cove. ''It's just not the American way.''
In 1979, the Salvadoran community on Long Island was relatively small, said Kenneth Lederer, the executive director of the Central American Refugee Center, a legal advocacy group. But since 1982 or so, the numbers have been rising steadily. In the last year, Mr. Lederer said, ''we've seen a steady increase that reflects the increase in fighting in El Salvador.''
The immigrants arrive almost daily, often after a long journey to reach the United States border and then a trip by bus or air to Long Island. They come to Long Island because they know or have heard of others who live here.
The Salvadorans tend to settle in more urban areas, in places with a Spanish-speaking population or near transportation hubs, where trains and buses make it easier to travel for work. There are more than a dozen areas on Long Island, mostly in Nassau County, where several thousand Salvadoran immigrants are living. In some areas, there are Salvadoran grocery stores; in Hempstead village, there are half a dozen Salvadoran restaurants.
 
Many From Rural Provinces
In some parts of Westbury, Hempstead and Glen Cove, where most of the Salvadorans live, there are large pockets of people from the eastern, more rural, provinces of El Salvador. Many people came from the same two towns - Poloros and Concepcion de Oriente, both in La Union. Many cannot read or write, even in Spanish.
Many Salvadorans, like Juan Carlos Murillo, say they fled their country because the political situation became intolerable.
Mr. Murillo, who is 22 years old, said that when he was a university student in 1985, the Salvadoran Government tried to force him to join the army. He avoided it after his family paid a $300 bribe - far more than a month's salary - but he was warned that the next time, he would have to enlist.
Mr. Murillo said his family's small store to the north of San Salvador was destroyed in the recent fighting, and they have nothing. ''They are hoping I will help out,'' he said, ''but it's hard.'' Mr. Murillo worked as a landscaper this summer and fall, earning $40 a day for up to 10 hours of work, but the season is over, and now he is unemployed. ''I'm trying to get a job,'' he said. ''Anything is welcome.''
Mr. Murillo is relatively lucky. He lives with about 15 others in a group home in Nassau County for Salvadorans, one of several set up by the Interfaith Nutrition Network. This season, a Christmas tree full of lights and ornamental animals and a sign saying ''Peace'' adorns the house. But others are not so fortunate. In an area where high prices are driving even middle-income people away, housing is harder still for people who have nothing. Many Salvadorans live in temporary group homes; many carve out tiny sections of apartments shared by a dozen or more people. Increasingly, there are homeless Salvadorans.
''By and large, they're living in houses and apartments that are vastly overcrowded,'' Mr. Lederer said. Sometimes, he said, people take turns in the same bed, each renting an eight-hour shift.
 
Sleeping on Church Steps
Church workers and people who run group homes say they try never to turn anyone away. But a new influx of people, with more expected because of recent surges of violence, is straining their resources.
''We've had people sleeping outside on the steps at times,'' said Josephine Miscioscia, the parish outreach director at St. Patrick's Roman Catholic Church in Glen Cove. ''We've had people sleeping in vans that have been parked nearby.
Sister Joan Staudohar, who runs a home for Salvadoran women and their children in Nassau County, said it was always filled to capacity. ''Just last week I had four calls to take a woman and child,'' she said.
Many Salvadorans interviewed said that all they wanted was a job. But most of them arrived after 1982 - too late to qualify for amnesty under the 1986 immigration law -and it is illegal for anyone to hire them. And work is harder to come by. Jobs are becoming scarcer as more people come in, and employers are wary of hiring undocumented people.
 
Jobs and Law Both Tighten
''The market has tightened,'' Ms. Miscioscia said. ''The immigration law against people hiring has become quite strict, and the more people come, the more saturated is the market for unskilled jobs.''
Mateo Gomez, who left San Salvador two years ago, when he was 22, and now works for Sanctuary, the support network for refugees, said: ''There are a lot of people coming to Long Island, and everyone's competing for a job. It's much harder.''
Those Salvadorans who do work invariably get temporary jobs: in factories, landscaping concerns, fast-food restaurants and people's houses, cleaning or caring for children. They get the jobs through referrals and, sometimes, through soliciting on the street.
''They've been advantageous to the local community,'' said Steven Valli, the human services coordinator for the Church of St. Brigid in Westbury. ''If the Salvadorans were not in Glen Cove, grass would not get cut, buildings would not get built and houses would not get cleaned.''
 
I.N.S. Raids Sidewalk
Every morning in Glen Cove last summer and fall, as many as 100 Salvadorans gathered in front of a delicatessen on Cedar Swamp Road to solicit day jobs as landscapers. After some of the storekeepers on the street complained, the Mayor of Glen Cove, Donald DeRiggi, telephoned the Immigration and Naturalization Service, which arrested 27 of the men on the sidewalk. They were released pending deportation proceedings against 26 of them.
The Mayor then proposed an ordinance that would make it illegal for five or more people to gather on a street to seek employment. When people objected by saying it violated the right to free assembly, he proposed another ordinance, which would prohibit undocumented aliens from soliciting employment on Glen Cove's streets.
There is no vote scheduled on the ordinance, said Ms. Henderson, the city's spokeswoman, adding that the debate itself seems to have put an end to the Salvadorans' visibility in the city. ''Just the threat of an ordinance moved the beehive somewhere else,'' she said.
 
Documentation Not Likely
''I sympathize totally with why they're here,'' she added. They're running from a terrible situation. But they're going to have to be documented like everyone else.''
But, Salvadorans say, it is unlikely that most of them will get documentation. Yanira Lopez, co-director of the Long Island chapter of the Central American Refugees Committee, said that because the United States treats most Salvadorans as economic refugees, not political refugees. only about one in a hundred are eventually granted political asylum.
Mrs. Lopez, who said she left her home in San Salvador when the Government began killing and arresting members of her church group, said: ''It's almost every single family who has lost someone or who has had someone jailed. People say that if you stay, you'll be killed.''
Speaking of the immigration service, Mr. Gomez said: ''The I.N.S. has closed the door on the Salvadoran people. We're not recognized, we can't get medical care, we can't go to school, we can't get a work permit, and it's very hard to get a job.''
Because they are undocumented, the Salvadorans are not entitled to social services, other than emergency medical care, and some are afraid to go even for that. The network of church and religious groups, around which many of the Salvadorans' lives revolve, try to fill in the gaps.
 
Escaping Both Armies
Like many churches in areas with a high concentration of Salvadoran and other Central Americans, Our Lady of Loretto Roman Catholic Church in Hempstead helps with food, clothing, counseling and classes in English. Every Sunday, the pastor, the Rev. James K. Bogert, presides over the largest Spanish-speaking mass in Nassau County, with more than 1,000 people attending.
Father Bogert said that despite the difficulties of life here, many Salvadorans feel that they had no choice. ''Most are single young men who come to escape being drafted into the Army or by the guerrillas, and they clearly feel that they're coming to something better,'' he said.
Mrs. Lopez said: ''The difference is that here, you know your life is safe. It's not that this is the best place for us. It's that if we stayed in Salvador, we could be dead.''

HEADLINE: At B. Altman, Christmas but No Santa

BYLINE: By NICK RAVO

 BODY:
Santa Claus skipped over the B. Altman and Company department store in midtown Manhattan yesterday. In fact, he did not appear once during the entire Christmas shopping season. He had been cut from the budget.
''This totally ruined my Christmas,'' said Periwinkle Sedigh, 24 years old, a cosmetics saleswoman from Bayside, Queens. ''I thought there would at least be a Santa here.'' 
Such gloom could be found throughout the 124-year-old department store, which for the last month has been holding a going-out-of-business sale, prompted by a Federal Bankruptcy Court decision last fall.
And because of austerity measures enacted by the court-appointed liquidators, this last Christmas at B. Altman will probably be remembered as the Christmas without a Santa, as well as the Christmas without a Christmas party, a Christmas bonus or Christmas music.
 
'Maybe a Funeral March'
''I don't want to hear Christmas carols now - it wouldn't be appropriate,'' said Brian Rice, a merchandise manager at the store. ''Maybe a funeral march instead.''
After weeks of reduced prices, much of the store's merchandise had disappeared by yesterday. Some floors were virtually vacant except for naked clothes racks and empty glass cases. Other areas had goods, like bathroom scales and sheets, scattered on the floor as if the area had been ransacked.
And throughout the store, signs were posted everywhere. They stated the obvious: ''Going Out of Business'' or ''Closing Our Doors Forever.''
The store did retain its famous winter window displays, but they did little to bring holiday cheer to the store's 500 employees, many of whom said they felt tradition-bound to work on Christmas Eve. #46 Years on the Job ''This is the worst thing that has ever happened to me,'' said Ruth Fleischer, a clerk in the store's silverware department who has worked for the company for 46 years.
''The fact that a lot of these people are going on unemployment - that's sad,'' said Philip Weber, 55, of Dobbs Ferry, who works in the store's estate-jewelry department.
The 13-story landmark building, at Madison Avenue and 34th Street, is expected to close late next week. Five of B. Altman's six stores in the New York region will also close.
''It's very upsetting,'' said Edward A. Granito, 57, a furniture manager from Whitestone, Queens, who has worked for the company for 39 years in Manhasset, L.I., and in Manhattan. ''It's really awful to see a store go down like this.''
 
Laughing Over Its Demise
''I came in today on my day off just so I could say I spent the last Christmas Eve,'' he added. ''I've spent every Christmas Eve here.''
Not everyone, however, was mourning the store's passing. One person was actually laughing over its demise. ''It feels wonderful,'' said William C. Muncy of BCF Inc. ''I'm the liquidator.''
Many customers also seemed oblivious to the employees' sentiments. They were too busy scavenging. ''I'm here for specials, but it seems like they are all gone,'' said Gina Dorantes, 22, a medical assistant from Jackson Heights, Queens, who bought an $85 blanket for about $50.
''I'm looking for a blender,'' said Anthony Pietropinto, 51, a psychologist from Greenwich Village. ''It's hard to find.''
 
Gentility and Conservatism
Founded by Benjamin Altman, a merchandiser, philanthropist and art collector, the store has long had a reputation for gentility and conservatism. B. Altman officials would not say on what day the sale would end, but they indicated that it probably would be on Saturday.
But the store might be left open for employees for a few more days. A public auction for many of the store's most expensive items - like pianos and paintings - will be in January.
One of the store's most popular attractions, its restaurant, Charleston Gardens, closed two days ago. ''My mother used to take me to lunch there,'' said Mr. Weber.
''Everyone is a little sad and nostalgic,'' said Adriana A. Kyzyk, 27, a sales manager. ''This store goes back to the days of the carriage trade and old New York.'' #1700 People Unemployed And, as might be expected under the conditions, complaints about service were common. ''These are people who, in some cases, after 30 or 40 years are losing their jobs,'' said Bernice Berman, an assistant store manager. ''So they're not in the best Christmas spirit.''
In the last few days, some employees have been entertaining themselves by circulating two poems that vent their ire at the L. J. Hooker Corporation, which bought the department store chain in 1985.
Many of them suspect that B. Altman, which has a debt of more than $15 million, was forced into bankruptcy because of a leveraged buyout gone awry. The closings are expected to leave more than 1,700 people unemployed nationwide.
One poem, written by the men's department manager, Jim Gettens, begins:
 
''It's a sad time for all as we play our last show,
And our last ''Altman's Christmas'' seems so full of woe.
The management's changed now, they're all so aloof
Just ask for assistance if you need any proof!
And it ends with:
 
''It's funny but Christmas just won't be the same.
It's only a store but what a proud name.
The years that we spent here will all be remembered.
The friends we have made; the people we've tendered.
To all who have made it so nice to have worked here,
This verse just says THANK YOU and gives you three CHEERS!
Be proud of the parts you all had to play
And try to forget the abominable way
That B. Altman's was forced to fade out of sight!
''Happy Christmas to all, and to all a good night.''

HEADLINE: Board of Estimate Approves Fordham Plan to Sell Site at Lincoln Center

BYLINE: By ARNOLD H. LUBASCH

 BODY:
A plan for Fordham University to sell part of its Lincoln Center campus to a commercial housing developer has been approved by New York City's Board of Estimate.
Before voting on Thursday night, the board heard Fordham officials stress their view that selling the site to the developer for $16.5 million was essential to obtain money so the university could build affordable housing for students.
Several community representatives opposed the sale, contending that it would bring more congestion into the area and would violate Lincoln Center's original urban renewal plan, which allowed Fordham to obtain the site in the first place. 
Fordham's president, the Rev. Joseph A. O'Hare, headed the university officials who urged the board to allow the sale to proceed by changing the urban renewal restrictions on commercial construction. He said that the restrictions were supposed to continue until 1997, that they were never meant to be permanent and that the university merely proposed ''accelerating the time period.''
 
Affordable Student Housing Urged
''We recognize the concerns of the community,'' he said, noting that the developer's plan has been modified, reducing the size of the apartment building to be constructed and increasing the open space adjoining it. He said the lack of affordable housing for students in New York City ''justifies the lifting of these restrictions.''
Among those opposing the Fordham proposal were Ruth W. Messinger, who represents the West Side in the City Council and is to become the Borough President of Manhattan, and Assemblyman Jerrold Nadler of Manhattan.
Ms. Messinger said she supported Community Board 7, which opposed the proposal. She said that she understood Fordham's position that the university needs to meet the residential needs of students, but that ''serious studies'' were needed on the best ways to proceed.
Mr. Nadler, saying the proposal ''abrogates the intent'' of the urban renewal plan, said he found it ''distressing'' to finance a dormitory by building luxury housing on a site from which low-income tenants had been evicted to make room for an educational institution. #41-Story Apartment Tower Under the urban renewal plan for Lincoln Center, most of the two blocks at the southern side of the site was set aside for Fordham, which bought the land and built academic buildings there. Fordham recently applied for permission to alter the original plan's restrictions so that it can sell a small portion of the site to the developer.
The developer, the Carol Management Corporation, will be permitted to build a 41-story apartment tower on the southeast corner of the intersection of Amsterdam Avenue and West 62d Street, near another apartment building that it recently built.
The city's Planning Commission has approved the proposal for the new apartment building. But Community Board 7 has voted overwhelmingly against it, noting that the original urban renewal plan for Lincoln Center limits construction to institutions until 1997.
Fordham has said it will use the money primarily to build a 20-story college residence on the southwestern part of its Lincoln Center campus.
