HEADLINE: BUISNESS DIGEST

 BODY:

International
Japan will give tax credits to companies that import more machinery, computers, automobiles and other manufactured goods, under a plan agreed upon by Japanese officials. The agreement is a reversal of Japan's post-World War II industrial strategy. Japan estimates the credit is likely to increase imports by $3 billion or so, a fraction of the country's $48 billion merchandise trade surplus with the U.S. and $78 billion surplus with the world. In Washington, a U.S. trade official said the tax credits were welcome but did not address underlying problems in Japanese trade policies. [Page 37.] 
Economic growth may elude villages on China's coast. In the country's economic retrenchment, imposed after the political upheaval and bloodshed of May and June, the coastal regions stand to lose the most. [38.]
 
Companies
An explosion at an Exxon refinery near Baton Rouge set parts of the plant on fire, killed one person and injured others. The refinery is the nation's second largest and produces more than 600,000 barrels a day of refined petroleum products. [16.]
Brutal competition among toy makers has resulted in a difficult time for Fisher-Price, which recently said it expected to report a loss for the quarter ending Dec. 31. Production foul-ups and disappointments in new products have also contributed to the setback at the company, which is owned by Quaker Oats. [37.]
Anheuser-Busch and Miller Brewing are offering non-alcoholic beers in an attempt to increase the industry's flat sales. The whole market for such brews is so small as to be seemingly beneath the giants' notice, merely around 700,000 barrels this year, or less than one-half of 1 percent of U.S. beer sales. But beer company executives say the non-alcoholic segment is growing in an otherwise stagnant market. [37.]
 
The Economy
It's an uneasy holiday season for New York's apparel makers. The uncertainty in the garment district reflects the uncertain fate of Federated Department Stores and Allied Stores. The Federated and Allied stores account for about 6 percent of the $160 billion-a-year American department store market. [37.]
Ore carriers on the Great Lakes have been hurrying to beat the ice, which has seized harbors and shipping channels. George J. Ryan, the president of the Lake Carriers' Association, said the early winter would force carriers to leave an estimated 1.6 million tons of ore and other materials on docks. It will either have to be moved by rail, at much higher costs, or left there until the ice breaks up in the spring. [22.]
 
The Media Business
Time magazine has been shifting its editorial tone to one that is more personal and less institutional. But questions are being raised by staff members who are worried that the large debt incurred in the merger of Time and Warner earlier this year is causing the company to focus more attention on costs. [40.]
The holiday films of yesteryear have advantages for television networks and cable stations that show them. The most striking example is probably ''It's a Wonderful Life,'' which will be seen 29 times during the holiday season in New York City alone. [40.]
The problems of Qintex and its leader illustrate the risks of building a highly leveraged company. Christopher C. Skase has gone from being seemingly ready to take on the world to becoming what he himself has called ''a minus millionaire.'' [37.]

HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL REPORT;
Japan Plans Tax Credits For Imports

BYLINE: By DAVID E. SANGER, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: TOKYO, Dec. 24

 BODY:
Fearing that trade tensions with the United States are worsening, Japanese officials said today that they had agreed on a plan to give large tax credits to companies that greatly increase their imports of foreign-made machinery, computers, autos and other manufactured goods.
The agreement, described today after a special meeting of the Cabinet to review the Government's 1990 budget, marks a complete reversal in Japan's postwar industrial strategy.
In the 1960's, the Government gave tax credits to companies that raised their exports, hoping the incentive would speed the development of large industry in a country that was still rebuilding from World War II.
''We decided that our continued trade surplus, even though it is diminishing, required an extraordinary initiative,'' a senior official of the Ministry of International Trade and Industry, which conceived the plan, said today. 
 
Other Ways Demanded
It is unlikely, however, that the tax program will be viewed with equal enthusiasm by Japan's trading partners. None of them have called for the measure, though they have demanded that other steps be taken to balance trade. [In Washington, a senior United States trade official said, ''We welcome the allocation of budget resources for an import incentive plan, but it will not substitute for a number of structural changes in trade policy that we would like to see as well.''] By Japan's own estimates, the credit is likely to increase imports by only $3 billion or so, a small fraction of the country's $48 billion merchandise trade surplus with the United States and $78 billion surplus with the world. 5 Percent of Increase Under the details of the plan announced today, companies that increase their imports of manufactured products by at least 10 percent next year will receive a tax credit equal to 5 percent of the amount of the increase. Thus, a company that brought in $1 million worth of American computers this year, and $2 million next year, will be entitled to a credit of $50,000.
The announcement of the tax credit plan came as Japan entered the last few days of its highly politicized internal struggle over the 1990 budget year, which begins in April. The bureaucratic fight was particularly fierce this year because national elections for the lower house of the parliament are expected in February, the first elections since the ruling Liberal Democratic Party suffered a huge setback in the less vital upper house elections in July.
At a series of briefings at the Ministry of Finance today, officials disclosed a $473.38 billion budget, an increase of 9.7 percent from 1989.
The most unusual feature of the document was one huge omission: For the first time in 15 years, Japan will issue no bonds to balance the budget. For years, Japan has been one of the largest deficit spenders of the industrialized world, and its longterm Government debt amounts to nearly half the country's annual gross national product - bigger, on a percentage basis, than the debt of the United States.
Over the last few years, Japanese officials have attempted to wean themselves from deficit spending. The move was regarded as a political as well as an economic necessity, because Japanese officials have been arguing that the proclivity of the United States to spend far more than it raises in taxes lies at the heart of its trade and competitiveness problems.
''You have to practice what you preach,'' Makoto Utsumi, the vice minister of the Ministry of Finance, said recently.
 
Rise in Military Budget
Government officials also said they would increase Japan's military budget by 5.5 percent, just shy of the expected rise in the country's gross national product next year. Japan's military expenditures are currently roughly equal to those of Britain and West Germany, the United States' two largest allies in the North Atlantic Treaty Organization, but the United States has been pressing for even bigger increases to pay a bigger share of the cost of keeping American troops in Japan.
The Japanese Government currently pays about 40 percent of that cost, excluding soldiers' salaries.
If the $29.5 billion military budget is not changed in last-minute negotiations within the Cabinet, it will slip to just below 1 percent of Japan's gross national product, a traditional ceiling on Japanese military expenditures that was only broken in recent years after great political debate. Officials here denied that the slippage was linked to the relaxation of East-West tensions, or the expectation that the United States would sharply cut the Pentagon's budget this year.
The tax incentive program for imports was championed by senior officials of the trade and industry ministry, which has the primary responsibility for increasing Japan's imports, just as the ministry once had the main responsibility for turning Japan's economy into an export one.
For months, the ministry has been battling its longtime rival, the Ministry of Finance, over the details of the package. Finance officials feared that the incentive would lead to a major loss of revenue, just at a time when Japan is struggling to service its huge debt, which will take up 21 percent of the budget this year.
Yutaka Kiyokawa, the senior deputy director for tax incentive measures at the trade ministry, said the program was expected to cost Japan around $642 million next year in lost tax revenues. Not all that will come from increased imports. Some will also come from an accelerated depreciation rate, enacted to encourage companies to buy machinery and other goods more often.
 
U.S. Asks Other Steps
WASHINGTON, Dec. 24 (Special to The New York Times) - American trade officials today praised the Japanese tax credit plan, but described it as only one of many steps that Tokyo would need to take to encourage more imports.
A senior United States trade official said, ''We welcome the allocation of budget resources for an import incentive plan, but it will not substitute for a number of structural changes in trade policy that we would like to see as well.''
The official, who spoke on the condition that he not be identified, said Japan specialists at the office of the United States trade representative and the Department of Commerce had been following the progress of the initiative for months and had been uncertain about whether the Cabinet would accept it.
 
Pressure Is Cited
''We were worried it wouldn't happen, and the fact that it did is a measure of how much pressure the Japanese Government is feeling from all of its trading partners,'' he said. ''I would not sniff or sneer at $3 billion. The important thing is to get those import levels up, and any step that furthers that ojective is welcome.''
William T. Archey, vice president for international relations at the United States Chamber of Commerce, said: ''Standing alone, it amounts to a nice gesture. The question is, what is the larger policy. Clearly the move by Japan reflects some pressure from their allies, but it also reflects the reality of a very closed import market.''
In talks with the Japanese, the United States Government has called for major changes in Japan's distribution system, the country's interlocking corporate relationships and restrictions it places on foreign investment, among other things.

LENGTH: 646 words

HEADLINE: Maine Faces Budget Cuts as Economy Sags

BYLINE: AP

DATELINE: AUGUSTA, Me., Dec. 25

 BODY:
Barely a year ago state taxpayers were cashing preholiday rebate checks worth nearly $42 million. But with the Northeast's economy in a tailspin, Maine officials face spending cuts of half again that much.
While the officials say that they hope to avoid any serious disruption in existing services or layoffs of state workers, they acknowledge that it otherwise may be impossible to achieve a $67 million budget cut through mid-1991. That figure represents 2 percent of the state's two-year, $3.2 billion budget, which by law must be balanced. 
''To assume that we can cut this level of dollars without some impact on services, I think, is unrealistic,'' State Finance Commissioner H. Sawin Millett said last week. ''Sooner or later you get into programs.''
Heads of state departments and agencies have until Tuesday to propose the initial round of cuts for the rest of the fiscal year, which started July 1.
 
A New Austerity Policy
Gov. John R. McKernan Jr., who has expanded a partial hiring freeze and called for cutbacks in state employees' travel as part of the new austerity policy, is expected to make the final decisions by mid-January and present a budget-reduction bill to the Legislature by the end of the month.
Mr. McKernan, a Republican serving his second term, has ruled out any increase in state income or sales taxes.
State executives say it is too early to specify what cuts will be proposed.
''We're all scrambling,'' said Robert L. Woodbury, chancellor of the seven-campus University of Maine system.
''At this point nothing is sacred,'' said H. Rollin Ives, the State Commissioner of Human Services, whose department administers most social service programs. ''The last thing I want to do is cut essential, existing services.'' The pending cuts come in response to a sharp decline in the economy that has caused budget problems of varying degrees for other states throughout the Northeast after several years of robust growth in the mid-1980's. That growth generated such a windfall in Maine's income tax revenue that lawmakers voted last fall to return nearly $42 million in an election-year rebate.
 
Big Deficit in Massachusetts
Among the states worse off now is Massachusetts, which faces a budget deficit for the fiscal year 1990 that Gov. Michael S. Dukakis estimates at more than $800 million. Mr. Dukakis has urged a tax increase by the end of the year, but that prospect appears unlikely as lawmakers approach the end of this year's session.
In New Hampshire, Gov. Judd Gregg is forecasting a shortfall of $30 million to $50 million. Mr. Gregg, who imposed a hiring freeze in October, is working with lawmakers to pare state spending by about $18 million for the biennium.
Governor McKernan's call for spending cuts in Maine, which came after a review of state finances by an outside accounting consultant, resulted from the second reduction this year in his administration's projections of sales tax revenue.
The consultant, the Washington-based Peat Marwick Maine & Company, concluded that the money generated by Maine's 5 percent sales tax, which is second only to the individual income tax in the amount of revenue generated by the state, should continue to grow in the months ahead but that the increases would be much smaller than anticipated. Sluggish sales of motor vehicles and building supplies have been cited as the chief reasons.
The Governor ordered department heads to recommend spending cuts equal to 5 percent of their discretionary income for the six months left in this fiscal year and to revise their fiscal 1991 budgets to eliminate any growth.
Those proposals are expected to yield about $94 million in potential cuts, administration officials have said.
Some agencies are expected to be affected more than others, because Mr. McKernan has pledged to preserve critical services as much as possible.

HEADLINE: War on Drugs Must Begin on the Poverty Front

 BODY:
To the Editor:
''Drug War: Fool's Errand No. 3'' by Joseph A. Califano Jr. (Op-Ed, Dec. 8) should revitalize Bush Administration thinking on getting at the causes of drug abuse. Unfortunately, the only proposals strongly pressed by the Administration are more prisons and more law enforcement. Both are needed, but we must move beyond solely supply-side solutions. 
The scientific solutions to drug abuse cited by Mr. Califano, like substitute drugs to reduce the craving for chemical dependency and new methods to quit smoking and avoid abusing prescription drugs, are important. We need more medical and biological research. Mr. Califano has been a leader on this issue for years, and it is important that people of his stature help lead the fight.
However, unless we attack the root causes of drug abuse, we are likely to see continued record prison overcrowding - and record hospital emergency room cases, record economic costs to society through lost productivity and lost tax revenues - no matter how many prisons we build or how much we threaten punishment.
We need to focus on the problems that bring people to the desire for illicit drugs - homelessness, unemployment, lack of education, lack of health care, lack of family and, above all, poverty. There is a major gap in the President's antidrug strategy in not examining the causes of drug abuse and possible solutions. It is to be hoped that the strategy update early next year will address these issues. I have introduced legislation, H.R. 3775, to establish a commission to study the causes of drug abuse in the United States.
We need coordinated community-based efforts to address the many social and economic conditions that are at the root of serious drug addiction and drug crime. We must look at these root causes and how to plug the gaps in our national drug strategy that make our cities especially vulnerable to drug abuse and to drug crime.
 
CHARLES B. RANGEL
Member of Congress, 16th Dist.
 Washington, Dec. 13, 1989
The writer is chairman of the Select Committee on Narcotics Abuse and Control.

SECTION: Section A; Page 26, Column 6; Editorial Desk

LENGTH: 472 words

HEADLINE: War on Drugs Must Begin on the Poverty Front;
Nothing Like Butter

 BODY:
To the Editor:
Judge Robert W. Sweet suggests legalization of crack, heroin and other drugs (front page, Dec. 13). It is a complicated social, political and economic issue. However, from a psychiatric perspective, legalization would be a mistake. Cocaine, opiates and stimulants such as amphetamines cause physical addiction and medical complications. 
Judge Sweet states that ''If our society can learn to stop using butter, it should be able to cut down on cocaine.'' Unlike butter, these substances cause a dangerous disruption of behavior, mood, judgment, an intense neurobiologically mediated craving and physical dependency.
Judge Sweet suggests that under legalization, ''no one without a doctor's prescription would be able to buy a lethal dosage at one time.'' He doesn't seem to understand that even small doses of cocaine can cause serious cardiac complications and even death. (Damage is especially severe to unborn fetuses.) Furthermore, as use of cocaine and stimulants progresses, the amount needed for the desired pleasurable effect increases. With increased use however, dangerous medical and psychiatric side effects, such as psychosis, depression, suicidality and violent and impulsive behavior, also increase. Italy, where heroin (arguably more benign than cocaine) has been legalized, now has the highest incidence of death from overdose in Europe and a burgeoning of human immunodeficiency virus infection.
Judge Sweet compares the state of drug policy to the failure of alcohol prohibition in this century. But cocaine and heroin are much more addictive than alcohol. And, from a public health perspective, Prohibition was a success. During Prohibition, the incidence of cirrhosis of the liver and alcohol-related admissions to psychiatric hospitals decreased dramatically. All, including Judge Sweet, seem to agree that legalization would lead to increased use; consequently, legalization would lead to an increase in the medical complications of use.
It is estimated that half of the mentally ill have had problems with substance abuse. Many patients with other primary psychiatric diagnoses attempt to treat their symptoms with cocaine, amphetamines, marijuana and opiates. Ultimately, this self-medication leads to severe worsening of symptoms. Recovery becomes impaired by addiction and poor judgment. The most effective deterrents to abuse seem social sanctions against drugs and their subsequent limited availability.
Our drug policy, with its focus on interdiction, is a failure. However, there are many options other than legalization. Our resources would be better spent on education and treatment.
 
CHARLES H. SILBERMAN, M.D.
 New York, Dec. 18, 1989
The writer is a senior resident in psychiatry at the Payne Whitney Psychiatric Clinic, New York Hospital-Cornell Medical Center.

CORRECTION-DATE: December 28, 1989, Thursday, Late Edition - Final

 CORRECTION:
In a letter opposed to drug legalization published on Tuesday the writer's name appeared incorrectly. He is Charles H. Silberstein, M.D.

HEADLINE: ON MY MIND;
'How China Works'

BYLINE: By A. M. Rosenthal

 BODY:
China has disappeared from the news, but it will be back, soon.
To start with, any day between now and Jan. 23, the rulers of Beijing will toss a few political bones to Washington.
That will be in contemptuous payment for the American desertion of the Chinese protesters, who stood up for freedom just months ago, died for it or suffer for it still in new oppression meted out to them day by day.
Americans understood fully that when President Bush sent two of his top men on a secretly carried out mission to Beijing he was reneging on a public pledge. 
After the massacre of Tiananmen Square, he promised that there would be no high-level dealings with the murderers, at least until they recognized the validity of the students' aspirations. Americans understood, all too well.
But Mr. Bush was rescued by Panama and Rumania from full awareness sinking into the American mind of two other shameful moves toward Beijing.
The first was something the Administration had never dared reveal before CNN disclosed it. The same officials had been sent on another secret mission to Beijing, only weeks after the massacre. To have announced the second mission while concealing the facts of the early one was duplicity.
While we were absorbing that, the Bush Administration lifted economic sanctions, imposed as a penalty for the massacre. American companies doing business with China can now receive tax-supported credit.
So when you read about a new American commercial venture in China you can feel a real warm sense of participation - someday you may be paying for it.
Then Mr. Bush sent the troops into Panama and Rumania exploded. China was ripe for the TV news and newspaper front pages.
Washington knows that this piece of good luck will not last forever. So it is sending out anxious signals to Beijing to toss those bones - let a dissident leave his refuge in the American Embassy, lift some martial law regulations, do something.
China will probably oblige, but it will not mean anything. The rulers our diplomats toasted with such cordiality now know that some freedom can lead quickly to enough freedom to threaten them. They do not intend to be threatened again if they can avoid it.
But American pressure might have pushed them along. Beijing held firm and nasty and in a few months American ''pressure'' turned into American submission.
Still, some kind of cosmetic payoff is called for for those missions and the lifting of sanctions. The Bush people want it done before Jan. 23 and are saying so to Beijing.
That is when Congress reconvenes. One of the first orders of business will be a bill that has the effect of assuring 38,000 Chinese students in this country that they will not be forced to return to China as long as their freedom is endangered.
The bill was passed without a dissenting vote. Mr. Bush promptly vetoed it. The President's argument was that he could and would do the same thing by regulation, so no new law was necessary.
But regulations can be changed overnight by the President who issued them - the lifted sanctions taught us that.
It has become a matter of prime and political importance to pass the bill over the President's veto -quickly. For our sake, not just for the Chinese students. It will be one reply to the stealthy missions in the dark.
President Bush considers himself an expert on China. ''I know how China works,'' he assures us.
No, in respect, he does not. He knows something about how the thin top layer of Chinese Communists work, or how they want us to think they work - proud, powerful, mysterious.
But they are not China any more than Ceausescu was Rumania or those other dictators, hardly remembered already, were Poland, Czechoslovakia, Hungary or East Germany.
Somehow the President and the geopoliticians who advise him cannot see that there is no mysterious Orient, just a lot of people who want what other people want. A decent life under freedom, that is all.
Chinese students and Chinese workers, throughout the country, showed this spring that they knew what they wanted and would struggle for it, even before most of the nations of Eastern Europe did.
How can Mr. Bush have forgotten their passion, so soon?
One day, not too distant, the Chinese will show again what they want. They do know how China works.

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

TYPE: OP-ED

LENGTH: 1229 words

HEADLINE: Asbestos Costs Give Schools Hard Choices

BYLINE: By KIRK JOHNSON, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: NEW CANAAN, Conn.

 BODY:
Twenty years ago, before the hazards of asbestos became known, the steel beams inside sprawling, brown-brick New Canaan High School were sprayed with it. Though tests have shown that the flame-retardant coating - harmful only if its particles are inhaled - is mostly intact and safe for now, it is to be removed anyway, at a cost of perhaps $10 million.
That is twice as much as the next-highest school asbestos cleanup bill ever recorded in Connecticut.
The hard choices forced on school and local officials across the country, when government scientists started viewing asbestos more as a dangerous carcinogen than as a remarkable flame-retardant, can be seen in this Fairfield County town's soul-searching over the future of its high school. 
Other schools are taking different roads under Federal regulations that give local administrators wide latitude in choosing when and how to take action. The asbestos-management plans took effect on July 1, and from here to Rapid City, S.D. and Burbank, Calif., administrators, teachers and students are feeling the effects in ways that differ almost as much as the communities themselves.
In New Canaan, school officials said that although the asbestos would have been taken out eventually, it will be done now partly because of factors that have nothing to with the flaking, chalk-white insulation. The state fire code, for example, requires the school to upgrade its wiring and improve access for wheelchair-bound students. Doing that work will disturb the asbestos and require its removal.
''It's a chicken and egg thing,'' said Arvid Anderson, director of personnel and facilities for the New Canaan public schools. ''The fire code work needs to be done, and to do that work requires that we get up above the ceiling tiles and tamper with the asbestos - but after we do that, no general contractor is going to come in until the asbestos is removed.''
Under the new Federal regulations, every school district in the country has been required to write an asbestos-management plan tailored to the needs of each school.
Some schools, especially in wealthy communities like New Canaan, which is ranked as the single richest town in Connecticut by income and property values, have decided to pay the bills now and make a clean sweep of their asbestos. Other districts have put their buildings on extended plans that will remove some asbestos, entomb some safely in place and monitor the rest for decay over the years.
In New York State, for instance, school officials plan to manage and maintain in place nearly 88 percent of the 253 million square feet of asbestos-containing materials that has been found in the schools, according to the state Education Department.
Some schools, like Bren Mar Park elementary school in Fairfax County, Va., will close this spring for a year to allow for asbestos cleanup, while other districts, including New Canaan, have designed staggered work plans over a series of summers.
''You are going to see a variety, unfortunately, in schools' approach to managing asbestos even when material conditions are the same from one building to another,'' said James A. Brownlee, director of asbestos control service for the New Jersey Department of Health. Mr. Brownlee said that he sees schools in wealthier communities removing all their asbestos next year because the fear is so great and money to erase the fear is available.
 
Feeling Adrift and Alone
Officials at the Federal Environmental Protection Agency, which issued the regulations requiring the management studies, also conceded that the asbestos plans vary widely in thoroughness and quality, but stressed that flexibility and local control were intended under the law. Critics say the regulations have left some schools adrift and alone.
''The management plans you'll see across the country vary from a few sheets of yellow note paper to a computerized format for laboratory analysis, inspectors' reports and floor plans,'' said Bill Waeckerle, administrator of buildings and grounds for the Rapid City, S.D. public school district. ''The law was very vague,'' he said. ''That was a weakness.'' Mr. Waeckerle said that his district opted for a 15- to 20-year plan under which all asbestos will be removed as it starts to flake and become dangerous. Unfortunately, he said, because of a freeze on property taxes in South Dakota and because his district is not eligible for any Federal asbestos grant money, the $600,000 a year required under the plan will have to come out of the $1.4 million capital improvement fund.
''That takes away from computer equipment and upgrading of facilities,'' he said. ''But you have to do it.''
 
Problems in Remodeling
The burdens have also fallen differently on older districts. In Burbank, Calif., for instance, where school buildings date from the 1920's through the 1950's, an expanding school-age population in recent years has forced the district to remodel and expand. As in New Canaan, that means disturbing the asbestos, which was widely used in buildings until the 1970's, when it was found to cause cancer and other diseases.
''If we leave everything as it is, we're okay,'' said Dr. Richard M. Tighe, assistant superintendent of business services for the Burbank public schools. ''But our buildings are so old and we're going to have to do a lot of remodeling for the future; the problems will be compounded by the asbestos.''
In New Canaan, officials said that the town's affluence - while making the asbestos cleanup costs easier to absorb - has also led to a faster timetable. They said that under the State Department of Education grant system, towns are awarded fire code and asbestos-abatement money on a sliding scale, with the state paying 80 percent of the costs in the poorest towns and 40 percent in the richest.
On July 1, 1991, however, the scale will change and New Canaan, ranked number one in wealth among the state's 169 towns, will be eligible for only 20 percent if it has not yet finished its plans and filed its grant application. In a project that could cost $19 million or more, including $10 million for asbestos removal, the 20 percent difference could mean nearly $4 million more out of the town's pockets.
 
Wave of Summer Removals
''They didn't know how much money it was going to cost every poor little town,'' said C. J. Colman, chairman of the town committee supervising the work at the school. ''I think they had no idea what they were causing.''
At the New Jersey Health Department, Mr. Brownlee said he expected a wave of asbestos removals across the country this summer as administrators - often pushed by unions and parent-teacher associations - remove asbestos that might in some cases be safely left in place. He said he believes ''fear and panic'' are still driving many asbestos decisions, despite all the new technical information available because of the management plans, which school districts must make public.
Other officials say they believe the simple economics of inflation will push schools forward as well.
''You should not let an economic driver dictate a public health issue,'' said Zachary S. Cowan, a spokesman for the National Asbestos Council, a not-for-profit asbestos-information group based in Atlanta. On the other hand, Mr. Cowan added, ''the longer you wait, the more expensive it's going to be.''

GRAPHIC: Photo of C.J. Colman, who is helping to supervise the removal of asbestos from the high school in New Canaan, Conn. (NYT/Steve Miller)

HEADLINE: Cigarettes and Schooling

BYLINE: AP

DATELINE: ATLANTA, Dec. 25

 BODY:
Anti-smoking efforts should be directed at young people with relatively little schooling because the use of cigarettes drops sharply among those with more education, Federal health researchers said last week.
A study by the Centers for Disease Control said that while other factors may influence smoking, education is increasingly important.
A 1988 survey of 36 states and the District of Columbia found that those with less education, who also tend to be of a lower social and economic status, are more likely to be smokers than are others. 
''There has been progress in reducing cigarette smoking,'' said Dr. Luis Escobedo of the centers. ''But the study shows most of the progress is limited to the well-educated.''
The survey, based on telephone interviews with 19,822 people age 18 or older, showed that for people over 35, the likelihood of being a current smoker increased as the level of education fell.
For those age 18 to 34, however, the chance of being a current smoker decreased substantially only for those with more than a high school education, while smoking rates for high school dropouts and high school graduates were more nearly equal. The study said cultural factors also may affect who smokes. For example, Utah, which has a high population of Mormons, whose church opposes smoking, had the lowest rate of smokers, 18.1 percent, and former smokers, 9.1 percent.
Kentucky, a tobacco-growing state, had the highest percentage of current smokers at 37.9 percent. The highest percentage of former smokers was in Maine, 20.3 percent.
The median figure for current smokers was 26.2 percent, meaning that half the states were above that figure and half below. The median figure for former smokers was 15.1 percent.
The study said other factors affecting who smokes include school anti-smoking programs, state cigarette taxes and the intensity of promotional events and advertising by the tobacco industry.

HEADLINE: Troubles at the Whitney, Both at the Top and in the Future

BYLINE: By GRACE GLUECK

 BODY:
The trustees of the Whitney Museum recently set up a committee ''to review the current status and consider future directions of the museum,'' but their mild language blurred the fact that serious problems are plaguing the institution, the country's foremost museum of American art.
One of the Whitney's problems is a conflict among the trustees over whether Thomas N. Armstrong 3d, the museum's director for 16 years, should remain.
Another is the museum's projected addition, designed by the post-modernist architect Michael Graves. Plans for the addition have yet to be approved by the New York City Landmarks Preservation Commission and have aroused heated opposition.
A third problem, laid at Mr. Armstrong's feet by those trustees who would like to see him leave, is a view that the Whitney lacks direction as a museum. Its critics point to what they consider the rudderless drift of its exhibition programs, the trendiness of its shows - particularly its market-conscious Biennials - and the lack of a substantial curatorial presence that would give the museum a more scholarly focus. 
 
Committees for Committees
''The whole thing is a mess,'' said a benefactor of the Whitney - who, like almost everyone else connected with the museum, declined to be identified. ''But at each meeting of the board, instead of coming to grips with the situation, they appoint another committee. It will end up with the 19th committee meeting choosing another committee. That has been the procedure.''
As for Mr. Armstrong, apparently a majority of the 35-member board favors his ouster. His resignation was requested several weeks ago by William S. Woodside, the museum's president. But he has refused to resign, say sources close to the museum, and he is said to have the important support of Flora Biddle, the chairman of the museum and a granddaughter of its founder, Gertrude Vanderbilt Whitney. Neither Mr. Woodside nor Mrs. Biddle would comment.
Similarly, neither Mr. Armstrong nor the trustees would discuss for the record the reasons for the trustees' disenchantment with him. But fiscal problems are apparently not among them. For the last three years, thanks to practices credited to Mr. Woodside, the museum, on Madison Avenue at 75th Street, once burdened, like nearly all nonprofit institutions, with a deficit, has had a modest surplus. In 1989 its operating budget was $10.7 million.
Among other considerations, however, Mr. Armstrong is said to have alienated several benefactors, among them the collectors Jean and Howard Lipman. The Lipmans, who have been the Whitney's biggest donors of art since the founder, have made it known that they will not give the cream of their collection - works by David Smith, Alexander Calder and Louise Nevelson - because of their disappointment with Mr. Armstrong.
 
Free-Wheeling Style
There apparently is also dissatisfaction among some board members with what they regard as Mr. Armstrong's free-wheeling management style. He has told friends, for example, about the time he was rebuked by a prominent trustee for growing tomatoes in a garden on the Whitney roof and selling them for the benefit of the museum.
Another board member said of Mr. Armstrong: ''I find him very much in the spirit of some of the artwork we show that's more for fun than serious. All the people who are negative about Tom have expressed great friendship for him. He's a lovely man, a bright man, and everyone recognizes the great job he's done since Jack Baur left. But not lately.''
Mr. Baur was the Whitney's director from 1968 to 1974.
Staff members who admire Mr. Armstrong defend his record. They contend that while the Whitney has presented retrospectives of marketable recent arrivals on the art scene, including Eric Fischl, Julian Schnabel, Cindy Sherman and Robert Mapplethorpe, it has hardly neglected more established figures like Charles Demuth, Charles Sheeler, Ralston Crawford and Edward Hopper - whose work it owns in great depth - along with older contemporary artists like Donald Judd, Ellsworth Kelly and Willem de Kooning.
 
Points in Defense
Mr. Armstrong's defenders also note that during his tenure the museum has collected more vigorously than at any time since the days of Gertrude Vanderbilt Whitney, who founded the museum in 1931. Since the director's arrival in 1974, they point out, the museum's total number of works has increased by more than 2,000, to a current total of about 8,500. The acquisition drive has focused on contemporary masterpieces - like Jasper Johns's ''Three Flags'' - obtained through gift and purchase, along with an emphasis on the works of individual artists in depth, among them Marsden Hartley, Mr. Judd, Georgia O'Keeffe, Mark Rothko and Smith.
Paul Cummings, a former curator of drawings at the Whitney, said: ''Tom did something for the Whitney that no one else has done. He came to an institution where the family support was declining and turned it from a regional exhibition space with a minor collection into a museum with an international reputation, both through his aggressive collecting and by producing exhibitions that traveled abroad.''
Arthur Danto, a professor of philosophy at Columbia University and a writer on art for The Nation, addressed the criticism of the Whitney's ''trendy'' exhibitions. ''That's part of what the Whitney's about,'' he said. ''What people go there for is to find out what's going on. In a way it's like one of those glass-bottom boats in Hawaii: you see all that fauna down there, and that, for me, is a service.''
He added: ''I feel as though the museum is participating in the art world rather than standing outside it, but that's part of what it probably means to be a museum of American art in New York City now. I've been critical of the Biennials, but they really have a purpose, giving some sense of where the art world is heading. And you can't do that without playing a part in it.''
 
Toward a Cohesive Policy
A continuing criticism leveled at Mr. Armstrong is that he has failed to bring to the museum strong curatorial talent that might develop a cohesive policy and a more discriminating sense of its relationship to American art.
The Whitney has also been the target of critics who maintain that no definitive studies of 20th-century American art along the lines of the works produced by scholars at, say, the Museum of Modern Art have yet emerged from the museum.
''The big problem is that they have absolutely lost contact with the history of American art for the contemporary flashiness thereof,'' said one scholar specializing in American art. He declined to be identified because he did not wish to jeopardize his professional dealings with the Whitney.
''Over the last 10 years,'' he continued, ''there's been just too much contemporary schlock and too many superficial exhibitions of meaningful American artists. There has been no in-depth program to explore American art. And by that I mean a serious publications-and-exhibition program, and scholarly curators capable of doing this. There really isn't a sense that we have a national culture out there, a national visual culture. It's all New York, L.A., Houston, where the money is, where the dealers operate.''
 
Addition a Costly Project
Compounding the Whitney's troubles is the projected $37.5 million addition, which would double the museum's size. Although still in the drawing-board stage, it has already proved a costly project, entailing some $2.7 million to date in design and legal fees, and to relocate those to be displaced by the expansion. Mr. Armstrong was strongly involved with the selection of Mr. Graves, whose designs have been part of the post-modern movement away from the austerity of International Style architecture. But the selection was approved by the museum's building committee and by the full board.
Mr. Graves's first plan, made public in 1985, wrapped the new structure around the old museum, which was designed in 1966 by the respected modernist architect Marcel Breuer. It was scrapped because of strong opposition from the local community over its size, and complaints from leading architects that it violated the Breuer building.
The second Graves design, while scaled down, met with less opposition and was approved by Community Board 8. But it remained architecturally controversial and was withdrawn in anticipation of Landmarks Commission disapproval. Mr. Graves has prepared a third design, which has been more favorably received by architects. But it has not yet been submitted to the commission.
One reason is that the five brownstones adjacent to the Whitney at Madison Avenue and 74th Street, the site for the new building, have proved resistant to demolition. Bought by the museum and scheduled for razing, four of them have since been designated as ''contributing buildings'' in the Upper East Side Historic District, with approval required by the Landmarks Commission for their demolition. In addition, 10 tenants remain in the rent-controlled apartments. After winning a series of court battles earlier this year, the museum still awaits a decision from the State Division of Housing and Community Renewal on whether it can move the tenants and take possession of the buildings - a decision that could generate another series of court appeals.
 
Doubts About Expansion
Although more than $12.6 million has been received toward the $52.5 million building campaign goal -which includes $15 million as an endowment cushion - some observers say the building in its present form will never go up.
''Sooner or later the Whitney will get its addition,'' said Ulrich Franzen, a prominent architect who has designed the Whitney's satellite museum spaces at the Philip Morris building in New York and the Champion Paper Company in Stamford. ''The need for expansion is very real. But it may wind up being far more modest than the Graves design. We are going into another era. Things will be much tighter, and inflation in construction is going up by 6 to 7 percent a year. That factor, along with the community opposition and the problems of the brownstones and their tenants, will tend to minimize the ambition of the addition.''
In an interview in 1975, several months after he took the job, Mr. Armstrong said, ''What the museum basically needs is a clearer understanding of its role in supporting American art, a precise direction for its energies.''
For many concerned about the museum, it would seem, 15 years later, that the Whitney is still grappling for ''a clearer understanding of its role'' and that the committee appointed by the trustees to ''consider future directions for the museum'' has its work cut out for it.

International
The Bank of Japan moved today to raise its discount rate by half a point, to 4.25 percent, apparently winning a bitter tug-of-war with the Finance Ministry. The increase was the third this year and was widely anticipated. Bank of Japan officials said the rate would be raised to bolster the yen. The currency's value has declined significantly this year against the dollar, and inflationary pressures have been building. [Page D1.]
Many economists say the crash plan proposed last week by Poland's Finance Minister is the right economic medicine to revive that nation's crumbling Communist economy. But they worry that the medicine might be too strong to be politically acceptable. They warn that the plan can cause so much immediate pain that the Government may be forced to water it down. A weakened plan, they say, will cause less social discontent among Poland's 38 million people but will be less effective economically. [D1.]

President Carlos Saul Menem of Argentina replaced most of his economic advisers in recent days and ended an arrangement under which a large company had drafted economic policy. The president acted in the face of a return to soaring inflation, as well as military restiveness and conflict within his party. [A9.]

HEADLINE: COMPANY NEWS;
Refinery Fire Could Raise Heating-Oil Cost

BYLINE: By RANDALL ROTHENBERG

 BODY:
An explosion and fire that damaged parts of a huge Exxon Corporation oil refinery in Louisiana on Sunday could raise heating bills for consumers, at least temporarily, oil industry executives and analysts said yesterday.
Even before the fire ignited several storage tanks, these experts said, bitterly cold weather in much of the country had begun to strain heating oil supplies and prices rose to unusually high levels.
The explosion, at 1:30 P.M. Sunday, killed one man at the Baton Rouge refinery, the second largest in the United States. It ignited tanks containing 3.6 million gallons of heating oil and about 882,000 gallons of lubricating oil. The fire was extinguished more than 15 hours later, at about 5 A.M. yesterday. 
The manager of the plant, Ed Galante, told The Associated Press that a release of gas might have led to the explosion but that the cause remained under investigation.
Exxon officials were still trying yesterday afternoon to determine the extent of the damage. ''The processing units at Baton Rouge appear to be undamaged,'' an Exxon spokesman in Houston said. ''The accident is in the storage area.''
Nevertheless, industry experts said that because the nation's heating oil supplies were already under severe pressure because of the month-long cold spell that has chilled much of the United States, the slightest disruption was almost certain to raise prices.
William L. Randol, a senior analyst with the First Boston Corporation, predicted that the price of heating oil futures would ''skyrocket.''
John H. Lichtblau, the president of the Petroleum Industry Research Foundation, said: ''Because of the long and extreme cold spell, a tight heating oil market existed at the time of the explosion. If the refinery is out for any length of time, it would obviously continue the tight market.''
''We haven't had a cold spell this early or this deep for 30 or 40 years,'' he added.
But energy experts note that a change in the weather, particularly a warming that has been forecast for the Northeastern United States, would reduce demand and act to hold down prices. If the Baton Rouge refinery is out of commission for a week or less, the impact on heating oil prices should be only temporary, they say.
The Baton Rouge refinery has a capacity to process 450,000 barrels - or 20 million gallons - of crude oil each day. The plant, the largest after an Exxon refinery in Baytown, Tex., accounts for slightly more than 3 percent of the United States' total oil refining capacity.
 
'Full Conversion' Refinery
The Baton Rouge facility, which has historically been a training arena for Exxon's top management, is known as a full conversion refinery, capable of producing not only the heating oil and lubricating oil that were destroyed on Sunday, but gasoline, which can account for half of the refinery's output at certain times of year. It also produces jet and diesel fuels.
Two heating oil storage tanks were damaged in Sunday's fire. One remained intact, despite a charring of its shell, but the other suffered extensive damage, its roof blowing off and its walls folding in, collapsing the tank to half its height and rendering it useless, said Dave Gardner, an Exxon spokesman at the refinery.
Mr. Gardner identified the man killed in the blast as Harold Guillory, a 31-year-old employee of Vernon McKenny Enterprise, an Exxon contractor. Three Exxon employees and four contract employees who were injured in the explosion and its aftermath were treated at local hospitals and released on Sunday.
 
Dependent on Pipe Damage
Mr. Gardner said the refinery was closed, although some units were not completely shut down, to ease their start-up after a damage assessment was completed. The ability to resume refining, he added, rested on the harm suffered by a collection of pipe systems that carry oil throughout the plant.
He said the company did not know how much oil from the damaged tanks could be salvaged. Saving some of that oil could have an effect on the prices and availability of domestic heating oil; the 3.6 million gallons in the tanks represents about 3 percent of the 115 million gallons of America's heating oil reserves, Mr. Randol said.
Wholesale prices for No. 2 heating oil, the kind used in homes and commercial businesses, closed at 81.74 cents a gallon on Friday, a rise of 11.3 cents for the week and of about 30 percent during the last month. Mr. Randol said he had heard of retail prices in some areas as high as $1.30 a gallon.
What Mr. Randol termed the ''extremely high'' prices for heating oil reflected in part the low supplies that existed at the start of the nationwide cold spell. But other factors also combined to place great strains on domestic heating oil supplies.
 
Not Enough Barges
One industry analyst noted that the intense demand for heating oil in December meant there were not enough barges to bring oil from refineries to local terminals, limiting supplies and raising prices in some areas of the Northeastern and Middle Atlantic states, which account for 75 percent of all the home heating oil used in the United States.
On top of that, ''this has been a year of accidents,'' said Daniel Yergin, the president of Cambridge Energy Research Associates, a consulting firm in Cambridge, Mass. He noted the damage done by Hurricane Hugo in September to an Amerada Hess refinery at St. Croix, in the Virgin Islands, that is even larger than the Exxon plant in Baton Rouge and is an important source of heating oil for the United States.
''Then there was the Exxon Valdez, and there were several accidents in the North Sea over the past few months that damaged supplies,'' Mr. Yergin added. ''And there's still nervousness about what might happen to Soviet oil supplies this winter, because of strikes and internal problems. If Soviet supplies to Western Europe become short, the market here would certainly feel it.''
 
No Shortage Expected
Mr. Lichtblau said that despite the higher prices, consumers have been able to buy all the oil they needed. ''There have been no physical shortages, and it looks as if the industry will be able to get through this winter without any,'' he added.
Despite the cold and the mechanical and natural disasters, a rosy outlook is possible in part because of the weather in Europe, which exports refined oil to the United States.
While much of Europe experienced a cold spell in November, the last month has been quite warm, enabling European refiners to shift their supplies to the United States.
Exxon also says its other refineries, particularly in Baytown and in Linden, N.J., are capable of filling any gap in heating oil for the United States that might be created by damage to the Baton Rouge plant.
 
Gasoline Inventories High
The Baton Rouge fire is not expected to have any impact on gasoline prices. Because gasoline inventories are currently high, at 227 million gallons, prices are unlikely to rise, Mr. Randol said.
Gasoline is produced as a byproduct of the same process that creates heating oil; increases in heating oil refinement to meet increased demand during the last month have increased inventories.
What is more, demand for gasoline has been weak, down 4 percent during the four weeks from mid-September to mid-October from the same period in 1988, Mr. Randol said. Among the reasons he cited were consumer fears of a weakening economy, artificially high demand last year by middlemen who purchase gasoline from refiners, and slow sales of new cars.

HEADLINE: World Bank Seen Shifting China Stance

BYLINE: By CLYDE H. FARNSWORTH, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Dec. 25

 BODY:
As the Bush Administration gingerly moves to repair economic ties with China, the World Bank seems likely to soon resume lending programs suspended after the crackdown on pro-democracy protesters in June, say officials of the bank, the United States and foreign governments.
To resume its lending, the bank needs formal approval from its 152 stockholders, including the United States, which holds 20 percent of the shares. The bank and Administration sources say the loans could be made as early as next month.
 
A Step Toward Approval
The Administration officially insists that its policy against World Bank lending to China remains unchanged. But the lifting of some American sanctions against China on Dec. 19 was seen as a step toward Administration approval of such lending in the near future. 
''That's the kind of talk we're hearing around the bank,'' said a senior World Bank official. A World Bank mission has just returned from two weeks in China.
Criticism of any new China loans is likely in Congress, where some members are seeking tougher sanctions against Beijing because of what they consider continued represssion of human rights.
But Administration officials plan to argue that new lending should encourage liberal forces within the Chinese leadership pressing both for a greater opening to the outside world and more respect for human rights, an Administration economic official said.
The China director for the World Bank, Shahid Javed Burki, a Pakistani, has just returned from his second mission to China since June. In an interview, he said that projects are ready to begin in areas like agricultural development, rural road building and thermal power generation.
Asked when the programs might start, he referred to a statement made Dec. 14 by the bank's president, Barber B. Conable Jr.: ''It is our hope that in the not too distant future we can resume lending to China, but we do not have a specific date.''
Mr. Conable had also said the bank would be guided by China's economic performance, not political considerations.
 
Others Would Also Make Loans
Because of the World Bank's prestige as the biggest lender to the third world, approval would encourage lending by others, like the Manila-based Asian Development Bank and Japanese commercial banks, which also stopped loans after the June crackdown on dissent.
The World Bank, which is based in Washington, has provided $8 billion to China since 1981. It suspended $750 million of loans last June.
Since fall 1988, Beijing has moved toward central planning and away from the market-oriented policies that over the decade had attracted $14 billion of investment from industrial countries, of which $3.5 billion came from the United States.
An Administration official said Washington is trying to use a promise of World Bank lending to get the Chinese back to market-oriented policies.
Last Tuesday, the Adminstration announced that it had decided to approve the export of three American-built civilian communication satellites to China, all built by the Hughes Aircraft Company, and to lift bans on lending to China by the Export-Import Bank, an agency that provides financing for American exports.
Within 48 hours of the American action, Beijing announced plans to lift some restrictions on foreign investors. It said it would provide guarantees against confiscation, give investors the right to choose the chairman of a joint enterprise and end rules on the length of time a foreign project may operate in China. Previously, all joint ventures were for fixed periods, often 20 or 30 years.
Administration officials said the reaction indicated China's keen interest in maintaining economic links.
In defending his actions both in easing the sanctions and dispatching high-level missions to China after the crackdown, President Bush, a former ambassador to China, told a press conference Thursday, ''I know how China works.''
He added that the Administration wanted to ''see what we can do, make a representation on how strongly we feel against the human-rights abuse, but see what it's going to take to go forward.''
 
Cloudy Prospects
Business representatives said that despite the recent moves by both sides to improve the climate, the prospects for business remained cloudy.
''Nobody wants to pull out,'' said Roger W. Sullivan, president of the United States-China Business Council, ''but companies are operating at a lower level than before.'' The council represents 300 American multinational companies that do business in China.
Mr. Sullivan, a former State Department China specialist, said that American business was now most concerned about China's ''backtracking on enterprise reform.'' He said that the Chinese had previously wanted enterprises to respond to market forces, but they now have upgraded political and ideological control, giving party functionaries greater authority in factories.
''Faith in the inexorable progress of China has been badly shaken,'' he said. ''Companies can't deal predictably anymore.''
Although the Export-Import Bank had been barred from making loans to China until the Administration's action earlier this week, the bank, which makes loans to finance American exports, continued to study China projects.
Since June it has made preliminary offers on four projects totaling $108 million of exports. Loans totaling $39 million are in the final stages of approval.

HEADLINE: CREDIT MARKETS;
Bad Year Seen for Primary Dealers

BYLINE: By KENNETH N. GILPIN

 BODY:
Primary dealers of Government securities are winding up their worst year in a decade, and possibly longer, industry experts say.
None of the 44 firms that have been designated by the Federal Reserve as primary dealers, those authorized to purchase bonds directly from the Treasury, will disclose their trading profits. The Fed, which guards the numbers jealously, only gives a general picture of how these firms are doing once a year, generally in November.
The news out of the Fed early last month was not reassuring: Profits for the first eight months of the year were down by two-thirds from the $300 million primary dealers earned in 1988. And profits in 1988 were half of those recorded a year earlier, when the stock market crash produced a wildly successful fourth quarter for bond traders. 
 
No Improvement Seen
''People are not very happy,'' said Heather L. Ruth, president of the Public Securities Association, an industry group that represents fixed-income securities firms.
People in the business say that conditions have not improved, and may have deteriorated further, since the Fed's general report.
''This is probably the worst year since 1978 or so,'' said S. Waite Rawls, vice chairman at Continental Bank in Chicago. ''Volatility has fallen a lot as a result of the gradualist approach of the Greenspan Fed toward monetary policy, compared with the let-the-market-go-where-it-wants-to-go approach of the Volcker Fed. Trading volume has gone up a little, but it hasn't gone up much. We have too many primary dealers, and overhead is very high.''
 
Squeeze on Profit Margins
In addition, advances in high technology have given customers instant access to pricing information. Computers have made markets more efficient, but in so doing they have further squeezed profit margins.
For corporate and municipal bond traders, the picture is not much different. ''A number of firms will take losses in corporate bonds,'' said Perrin H. Long, an analyst who follows Wall Street for Lipper Analytical Services.
''Over all, the municipal business hasn't been that good,'' said Austin V. Koenen, a managing director at Morgan Stanley & Company and the current chairman of the Public Securities Association. ''Spreads are low for a lot of issuers, and the industry is still suffering from the excess capacity created in 1985-86.''
 
Shakeout Is Expected
Excess capacity is an issue that dealers in Government bonds will have to deal with as well if profits are to improve, analysts and industry executives said. ''For profits to be there, the number of primary dealers you need is probably closer to 30 than it is to 40,'' Mr. Rawls said. ''A couple of more primary dealers will be shaken out - if not in the next year, then over the next several.''
The shakeout may come sooner rather than later, Mr. Long said. Without naming names, he said that ''two major securities firms I talked to last week told me they were thinking about getting out of the government bond business.''
Aside from calculating profits and losses, little activity is expected in this holiday-shortened week.
With little economic news expected, there is a chance the bad taste left by the surprisingly strong report on durable goods orders during November, which was released on Friday, may linger into the new year.
 
'Spooked' by Increase
The durable goods number, which showed an increase of 5.1 percent, ''spooked people,'' said Donald J. Fine, chief market analyst for the Chase Manhattan Bank. ''People had the impression the economy would drop forever,'' he added. ''This number showed there is some light at the end of the tunnel. But even if activity in the industrial sector may be starting to bottom out, the economy in the first quarter of 1990 is likely to be just as soft as it is in the fourth quarter of 1989.''
Mr. Fine said the durable goods report was sufficiently strong to shift market psychology about the timing of the next move by the Fed to ease credit conditions.
Last week the Fed sent a strong signal that it had lowered the overnight Federal funds rate to 8 1/4 percent, from 8 1/2 percent. And some market participants were of the view that the Fed would move again before the December employment figures are released on Jan. 5. As a result of the durable goods report, the next easing move may be delayed until later in the month, Mr. Fine said.
Bond prices slipped in response to the durable goods report, and by late Friday the Treasury's closely watched 8 1/8 percent issue of 2019 was offered at a price to yield 7.87 percent.
 
Further Easing Possible
Bond prices may ease a bit further in the coming week, as dealers try to deal with heavy inventories of shorter-term securities.
But one staple of the year-end holiday season, erratic upward movements in the overnight Federal funds rate, is not expected to take place, analysts said. ''We think the funds rate may actually ease off rather than increase'' this week, said Maria Fiorini Ramirez, a managing director at Drexel Burnham Lambert.
''Instead of waiting until the last minute, people tend to do financing that carries them through the year-end earlier than they used to,'' she added. ''That means if there is any rally in the market this week it will be in the short end of the curve.''

HEADLINE: Order Is Shifted on Mobil Oil

BYLINE: AP

DATELINE: NEWARK, Dec. 25

 BODY:
A Federal judge unsealed confidential corporate documents last week in a lawsuit against the Mobil Oil Corporation, but he withheld the order when lawyers for Mobil said they would appeal.
The company said on Friday that the reports on environmental conditions at its chemical division plants were self-critical evaluations and that their disclosure would have a chilling effect on the company's efforts to be candid about its operations. 
But Federal District Judge Harold A. Ackerman, ruling in favor of the Associated Press and a former Mobil employee suing over his dismissal, said the public's right to know was paramount. Mobil said it would appeal Judge Ackerman's order to the United States Court of Appeals for the Third Circuit, in Philadelphia.
The judge admitted the Associated Press into the courtroom Friday over Mobil's objections.
The former employee, Valcar Bowman Jr., contends he was dismissed as Mobil Chemical's environmental affairs manager for refusing to go along with changes ordered by company lawyers in the reports. He contended that revisions had been imposed to minimize pollution problems.
Mobil said that the changes were innocuous and that it was committed to environmentally sound practices. Mobil says that Mr. Bowman, 47 years old, of Riverdale, Ga., was let go in an economic cutback.

HEADLINE: Careers;
Nurturing Technology Businesses

BYLINE: By Elizabeth M. Fowler

 BODY:
WHETHER the American economy achieves a soft landing in 1990 or tumbles into a full-scale recession, it will be bolstered by thousands of technological entrepreneurs who have started small companies, Robert G. Hawkins says.
Dr. Hawkins, the dean of the School of Management at Rensselaer Polytechnic Institute in Troy, N.Y., said: ''We will continue to rely on small and medium-sized high-tech companies for the bulk of job creation. They become even more important in recession than in expansion.'' Such companies introduce products and hire executives forced out of troubled large companies. 
Rensselaer was a pioneer in providing an incubator for high-technology businesses. ''We were the first to provide such a university-based center,'' Dr. Hawkins said. ''We started with six companies in 1980.'' Such an incubator provides new businesses with basic needs for their survival, including low-cost space, expert advice and help in raising capital.
Currently, 375 business incubators, including 52 that are linked to univerisities, belong to the four-year-old National Business Incubator Association, based at Ohio University in Athens, Ohio.
David L. Birch, the director of Massachusetts Institute of Technology's Program on Neighborhood and Regional Change, and the founder and president of a marketing consulting firm, Cognetics Inc. of Cambridge, Mass., agrees that high-technology companies can help the economy next year.
Dr. Birch estimates that about the same number of companies were formed this year as in 1988 - 700,000 corporations, 500,000 self-employed units and 100,000 partnerhships. ''My guess is the numbers would rise in a recession.'' he said. ''I don't know how many can be called high tech.''
''The failure rate of small companies is insignificant - 30,000 to 40,000 a year, however,'' he said, explaining that ''people tend to confuse failure rate with the closing rate of 500,000 or more.'' Closings occur because of retirement, death, or discouragement, he said.
At Rensselaer, Dr. Hawkins said. ''I think our objective at this school is to train effective entrepreneurs, giving them technical and managerial skills.''
The management school offers a concentration in the subject, which he calls a ''relatively new discipline.'' This year it introduced a course called Technological Entrepreneurship taken by 17 students in the spring semester and 22 this fall, working for course credit at incubator companies.
''There is value added on both sides,'' Dr. Hawkins said. ''The company gets the help of student teams and students work on real business problems.''
Sometimes the students take jobs with incubator companies after graduation, as did John Cerveny, who worked on a marketing project for Grasp Inc., a robotics company, and became its marketing director after his graduation in the spring.
The incubator at Rensselaer works with 19 companies, said its director, Mark P. Rice, who described it as ''no Taj Mahal.'' Mr. Rice also acts as co-director of the new Center for Entrepreneurship of New Technological Ventures, set up by the management school.
Mr. Rice said the incubator building owned by Rensselaer had been a Roman Catholic girls' home. ''We give space to companies at rates of $7 to $10 a square foot a year and month-to-month leases including utilities. We provide fax and copying machines and computers, nearness to the library and student workers.'' There is readily available advice from professors and the chance to take courses.
''We plug them into a network of contacts, including sources of capital,'' Mr. Rice said. About 65 percent of the 55 incubator companies since 1980 were started by students, graduates or faculty, and the remainder were spinoffs from large companies or start-up companies in the area.
''The incubator environment,'' he said, ''can mean a much better survival rate.'' For example, 19 are still in the program and another 20 are still in business, including ''7 or 8 that have moved to the nearby technological park beause they psychologically or physically outgrew us''.
Mr. Rice said, ''Five merged with other companies, and eight exist no longer,'' but only a few of those failed financially.
One stopped operations because ''a husband-wife team got divorced'' and another stopped ''because the professor who founded it died,'' he said, adding that three begun by faculty members went out of business when the professors drifted back into research laboratories.
''My goal for the incubator companies is for them to achieve $50 million to $100 million revenues,'' Mr. Rice said. ''A couple do $20 million or so.''
Last week, he was working to add to the incubator a company named Surcon Inc., formed by ''a midlife entrepreneur'' with an M.B.A. from Rensselaer.
''We are still trying to put pieces together - management team, capital and international connections.'' he said, explaining that Surcon would market a spot-welding technology developed by an area company called Duffers Scientific Inc.

HEADLINE: Africa Fears Its Needs Will Become Secondary

BYLINE: By JANE PERLEZ, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: NAIROBI, Kenya, Dec. 26

 BODY:
African officials say they are concerned that with attention focused on Eastern Europe, sub-Saharan Africa is likely to be relegated far down on the global agenda.
Expecting an abandonment of Africa for more emphasis on Eastern Europe, B. A. Kiplagat, Permanent Secretary in the Kenyan Foreign Ministry, a widely traveled diplomat in Africa, said in an interview, ''Eastern Europe is the most sexy beautiful girl, and we are an old tattered lady.'' Sadly, he noted: ''People are tired of Africa. So many countries, so many wars.'' 
Many African leaders are nervous that aid to Africa from the World Bank and other donors will be severely cut in order to provide Eastern Europe with more. In Zimbabwe last month, the president of the World Bank, Barber Conable, tried to persuade his listeners that the bank would not desert Africa for Eastern Europe, but few fully believed this.
 
Israel Fills a Vacuum
To compensate for an expected disengagement of the Soviet Union and the United States, some African nations are scrambling for new allies, with Israel emerging as one of the countries most politically active in Africa and Japan as the continent's new foreign economic power.
For many years, black African countries played off one power bloc against another to get more military or economic aid. President Mobutu Sese Seko of Zaire was put into power with the help of the Central Intelligence Agency after the country's first Prime Minister, Patrice Lumumba, was considered too closely aligned with Moscow. Mr. Mobutu, who has been thought of a stalwart against Communism, rules a huge and populous country in the center of the continent. He received $800 million in American funds from 1965 to 1987.
Similarly, the Soviet Union has poured around $10 billion in arms into Ethiopia, whose revolutionary Government embraced Marxism-Leninism in the mid-1970's.
Events in Africa in the 1970's even affected attempts to ease the cold war between the superpower blocs. Henry A. Kissinger, national security adviser and later Secretary of State in the Nixon and Ford Administrations, said the possibility of conciliation perished in Angola when the Soviets armed the newly independent Government in Luanda; the United States armed the rebel forces of Jonas Savimbi.
And Zbigniew Brzezinski, national security adviser under President Carter, said the second strategic arms treaty all but perished in the sands of the Ogaden when the Soviets switched sides and armed the Ethiopians against the invading Somalis. The United States switched sides, too, arming Somalia and obtaining an agreement for access to a port there.
 
Undoing the Old Wisdom
But in the last two years, the United States and the Soviet Union have encouraged, in some cases jointly, an end of the civil wars they had financed.
To deliver a clear message of disengagement in the Horn and other African arenas, as well, the Soviets gave First Deputy Foreign Minister Yuli M. Vorontsov, who had served as the Kremlin's special envoy in Kabul at the time of the Soviet withdrawal, responsibility for African relations.
The implications of this were not lost on the Ethiopians when Mr. Vorontsov visited Addis Ababa last month, diplomats say. The Soviets have told the Ethiopian Government that the military treaty that expires in 1991 will not be renewed. And the last Soviet advisers in Eritrea were withdrawn from that war-ravaged province on Dec. 15.
To plug the gap being left by the Soviets, the Ethiopians used historical links to Israel and a diplomatic offensive by President Mengistu Haile Mariam's brother, Kassa Kebede, who speaks Hebrew from his days as a student in Israel. They sought to reopen diplomatic relations with Israel after a 16-year break. The new relationship, cemented last month, was accompanied with promises, and some diplomats say, immediate delivery of arms for the civil war.
 
So Much for East Germany
More bad news for the Ethiopian Government came with the collapse of the leadership of Erich Honecker in East Germany. The ruthless Ethiopian security services were trained by East Germany, a contract that has now apparently ended, diplomats say. And two weeks ago, East Germany announced that it would no longer supply weapons to Ethiopia.
The changes in Eastern Europe are causing some political rethinking on the African continent.
Two countries in West Africa, Benin and the archipelago of Sao Tome and Principe announced this month that they would abandon Marxism-Leninism as their official ideology. Both countries said they would encourage private-sector investment.
At a congress in July, the ruling party in Mozambique, once a ''vanguard party of the worker-peasant alliance'' recast itself as a ''vanguard party of the Mozambican people.'' In a war-torn country where total economic output is about one-quarter of its level before independence from Portugal in 1975, the party, Frelimo, also announced some modest economic changes, putting more emphasis on small family-farm plots.
 
Pluralism Considered a Luxury
But one-party states, whether Marxist as in Angola or capitalist as in Kenya and Zaire, are likely to remain the norm in Africa.
Mr. Kiplagat, who is often put in the position of defending Kenya's one-party rule, does not believe that African countries should automatically follow the political examples of Eastern Europe. ''The major problem is internal conflicts and resolving them,'' he said. ''Before you talk about multi-parties, before anything else, these internal wars that have economic, tribal, historical background, must be settled. The thing we need is moral encouragement to resolve these problems.''
The opening of Eastern Europe to Western investment does not spell good news for Africa, either. With a well-educated labor force available at relatively cheap wages, the countries of Eastern Europe present much more appealing possibilities than Africa, where even in the best economic environment, like Kenya, badly needed foreign investment has dropped.
A decade ago, Japan, now the biggest aid donor to Kenya, had 15 commercial companies operating there. Today, because of red tape, corruption and restrictions on sending remittances overseas, only two are left. The amount of American and private investment has also declined.
