LENGTH: 1013 words

HEADLINE: Savannah Torn Over Its Direction: Past or Future?

BYLINE: By PETER APPLEBOME, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: SAVANNAH, Ga.

 BODY:
To the north is Charleston, which despite Hurricane Hugo gets as much economic mileage out of Old South charm as anyplace south of Williamsburg.
To the south is Jacksonville, a sprawling paradigm of Sunbelt prosperity that is short on moonlight-and-magnolias allure but long on breakneck growth.
In the middle, here at the site where James Edward Oglethorpe founded the 13th colony in 1733, is one of the South's most atmospheric riddles: a place that admires something about each of its two neighbors but has not quite caught up with either.
Savannah, with its incessant quarrels over the virtues of preservation and growth, has always been an amiably contentious place. But these days, with its preservation movement slowing and its economic growth sluggish, almost everyone seems to have his own idea about the proper direction for one of the South's most historic cities. 
 
A Decade of Growth
''There's a lot of gnashing of teeth, but it's one thing to gnash your teeth and another thing to do something,'' said Lee Adler, the prime mover among the city's preservationists.
It's hard not to be entranced by Savannah. With its canopy of moss-draped oaks, elegant geometry of green urban squares, restored waterfront and 19th-century homes, Savannah rivals Charleston in both history and architectural treasures. Its port and manufacturing base give it a varied economy, and the city of 140,000 has had healthy growth for most of the past decade. Boosters see little cause for concern. ''We've balanced historical preservation at its best with economic growth, the most beautiful restored buildings in the country with new banks, new business, new development,'' said Mayor John Rousakis, who has headed the city for 20 years. ''If I sound like a cheerleader, well, I am, but I've got something to cheer about.''
 
A Seedy Thoroughfare
Others are less sure. Preservationists worry that Savannah's restoration movement, which peaked with its waterfront project in the early 1970's, has run out of gas. Broughton Avenue, the main thoroughfare for the historic district, has become a seedy string of struggling businesses and vacant storefronts. So far, city, preservation and business leaders have not been able to agree on a plan to turn it around.
Others complain that the city's economic growth has faltered to the point that it is falling further behind its neighbors.
An informal coalition of local residents called Renaissance Savannah in early December released a report titled ''Is Savannah Growing Senile?'' It said the city has trailed most of its Southern rivals in growth rate for the 80's. The report also criticized most of the major governmental figures, and it compared Savannah to an underdeveloped country. It is one of several reports in recent years that raised warning flags about the city's future.
''The frustration lies in the fact that the business community just is not moving forward,'' said Julie Smith, a member of the Chatham County Commission who is co-chairwoman of Renaissance Savannah. ''We have a wonderful way of living here, but people get lulled into the comfort zone and don't exert themselves to make things better.''
 
Political Motive Is Seen
Mayor Rousakis, who is one of the main targets of the report, says it is largely a political document aimed at him and his administration. Even some of his critics see more than a bit of politics in it. He is up for re-election in 1991 amid widespread speculation he could face a serious challenge.
But outsiders agree that Savannah has never been mistaken for an economic juggernaut.
''When you talk to Savannah people, they say, 'Sure, I'd like to have property values go up,' but they don't want to work for it,'' said Donald Ratajczak, director of the Economic Forecasting Center at Georgia State University. ''Savannah is a sleepy town. They haven't fought the image of being an underachieving place.''
There is widespread concern that the city needs fresh thinking but also widespread skepticism that the interested parties could all agree on anything.
 
'Step Up to the Plate'
''This town's very historic, and goes all the way back to when everyone got off the boat,'' said Merritt W. Dixon 3d, a local developer who built the Hyatt Regency Hotel here, which is the only modern structure on the waterfront and is detested by local preservationists. ''Some people don't want anything to change. I'm the only guy in town willing to step up to the plate and take a swing. This is a place where everyone wants to come up with 40 reasons why you can't do something.''
Preservationists say the city is squandering its greatest asset by letting much of the downtown decay, and they argue that buildings like Mr. Dixon's are destroying the history that is Savannah's greatest asset.
''In Charleston, the people know they have a national treasure,'' said Emma Adler, a prominent preservationist who is Mr. Adler's wife. ''Here, the economic development people see the preservationists as obstructionists.''
But even the preservationists are split into competing camps. And the crucial political force could be the city's blacks, now more than 50 percent of the population, who have no clear links to either camp.
 
New Leader for Chamber
But almost everyone agrees that Savannah could use new leadership and ideas. It may have got some of that on Dec. 8, when Alan Beals, executive director of the National League of Cities, was named president and chief executive of the Savannah Area Chamber of Commerce.
Business leaders hope his experience with urban issues will lead to progress on a number of Savannah projects instead of endless wrangling over a few.
''A friend says Savannah has been like a bushel basket of crabs,'' said Eli Karatassoss, who runs a local public relations company and who is the chamber's new chairman. ''Every time one crab climbs to the top to get out, all the others reach out to pull it back in. The way to beat that is to have a lot of crabs crawling to the top at the same time, so you know some of them will get there.''

HEADLINE: Burlington Journal;
The Mayor Still Leads With His Left

BYLINE: Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: BURLINGTON, Vt., Dec. 26

 BODY:
Peter Clavelle was miffed. Halfway through his first term as Mayor of Vermont's largest city, he was being asked once again in an interview the other day to compare himself with his predecessor, Bernard Sanders, the flamboyant Socialist who attracted international attention to this municipality of 40,000 people on the eastern shore of Lake Champlain. And it was once too often.
''Bernie was a great Mayor, I love the man dearly, but give me a break,'' said a clearly irritated Mr. Clavelle, who, unlike his predecessor, rarely sounds irritated, at least in public. 
Mr. Sanders was elected in 1981 in a stunning 10-vote victory over the Democratic incumbent. He left office last winter, having decided not to run for re-election and having also nearly captured a seat in the United States House of Representatives in 1988. As Mayor, he mesmerized much of the state with his powerful rhetoric and blunt attacks on establishment politics.
Like Mr. Sanders, Mr. Clavelle is a member of the leftist group that calls itself the Progressive Coalition. And when he came into office after four turbulent two-year terms of the Sanders administration, the most intriguing question was whether Mr. Sanders's politics would outlast Mr. Sanders the Mayor as a staple of city government.
''Is the Progressive movement as strong as it was?'' Mr. Clavelle said in the interview. ''In fact, I think the movement is stronger than it's ever been. I'm sitting in the Mayor's office; I think that should answer the question.''
Indeed, Mr. Clavelle, who was Mr. Sanders's director of economic development, has either picked up on issues where the Sanders administration left off or, in some cases, identified new ones.
He continues to press for zoning legislation that would require developers to build some low-cost homes where they build more expensive ones, an unheard-of concept in these parts when Mr. Sanders first proposed it. And Mr. Clavelle has ordered the municipal electricity department not to buy power from Hydro Quebec because of the utility's plans to expand its hydroelectric plants and in the process flood territory that belongs to a number of Indian groups. In addition, Mr. Clavelle's administration, like that of Mr. Sanders, regularly issues statements condemning United States policy in Central America.
Most observers, including Mr. Clavelle himself, would say that the differences between the two administrations are more a matter of style than of substance.
''My style is more relaxed, mellower than that of my predecessor,'' said Mr. Clavelle, a native son born in Winooski 40 years ago. ''I have a calmer relationship with the business community and the Legislature. I'm less intimidating to them than Bernie was.''
Mr. Sanders was on particularly chilly terms with local business people. Under Mr. Clavelle, there has been a thaw, although some say it is far from complete.
''He is much more open, much more available, more willing to listen, more tolerant and all those adjectives like that,'' said Burr Vail, chairman of the Lake Champlain Regional Chamber of Commerce. ''But with Bernie, you knew exactly where you stood. Many people think Peter has a more cooperative face, but the results are the same: anti-business. Inclusionary zoning is a good example.''
The complaints of the business community notwithstanding, Mr. Clavelle's most troublesome constituents may be the coalition of leftists who elected him last March.
''The coalition is just that - a coalition,'' said Garrison Nelson, a political science professor at the University of Vermont. ''It's not a single-minded group. There's the beacon-on-the-hill group that sees Burlington as a model for the world. That's Bernie's group; they love him.
''The others are neighborhood liberals who just want to improve their communities. Peter is more comfortable with those people, although he knows he has to champion the symbolic issues'' like those reflected in the foreign policy manifestoes.
Mr. Nelson believes that Mr. Clavelle's strength as Mayor will be in his ability to integrate the economic interests of Burlington with those of surrounding Chittenden County and in the managerial skills that he demonstrated as Mr. Sanders's economic development director.
''Peter wants to be Mayor of Burlington, and that's the important point,'' said Mr. Nelson. ''Bernie saw being Mayor as a means to an end: statewide or even national office. Peter just wants to be Mayor. And in the absence of some gigantic calamity or a scandal of major proportions, he could probably be Mayor for life.''

HEADLINE: School Offers Day Care For Teen-Age Mothers

BYLINE: By SETH MYDANS, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: LOS ANGELES

 BODY:
When she was just a child, Joanna Rivas used to look at her parents and think: ''How easy it is to have a child. It must be fun.'' Now she is 17 years old, a 10th grader with a 5-month-old daughter, and she knows better.
''When my baby is asleep or happy I can go and do my homework,'' said Miss Rivas, rocking her baby, Cassandra, as her school's cheerleaders marched past. ''Usually that means I'm up all night.'' 
Miss Rivas is lucky. Her school, Jordan High School, is one of a small but growing number in the country that provides care for its students' babies.
The child care service can make a crucial difference for teen-age mothers, most of whom, like Miss Rivas, are unmarried. Surveys show that motherhood is the leading reason girls fail to finish high school. #40 on the Waiting List The Jordan Infant Center, which receives money from the State of California, cares for 20 babies up to the age of 2. Two of the students each have two children at the center. Forty more young mothers are on its waiting list.
Patricia Cannon, the administrator of the school's infant center, said she would probably be able to accommodate most of the current waiting list before the school year ends because of a high dropout rate.
The number of adolescent mothers in the United States has leveled off in this decade, to about 470,000 a year. But the proportion of teen-age mothers who are unmarried has risen from about 3 in 10 to nearly 7 in 10.
In some areas, like the Watts section of Los Angeles, where Jordan High School is situated, the need for child care programs is particularly high.
 
'Dysfunctional Households'
When the school's infant center was opened in 1983, Mrs. Cannon said, she was told that 40 percent of the students enrolled at the school had children.
''A lot of the girls come from dysfunctional households, and having a baby is the least of their problems,'' Mrs. Cannon said. ''There may be substance abuse in the home; a lot of their own mothers are young; they are living in the housing projects.''
Having a baby can confer status on a teen-age girl, said Grace Hibma, a consultant to the Los Angeles County school system.
''In some of these families, a girl reaches 13 or 14 and never receives recognition for doing anything good until she has a baby,'' she said. ''In some communities it's like a rite of passage.''
Although it is against school rules, teen-age mothers can often be seen in the school's courtyard showing off their babies and passing them around among friends.
 
Pregnancies Seen as Intentional
''The population is exploding,'' Mrs. Cannon said. ''A lot of girls who have gone through our program have come back with new children.''
Indeed, she said, a number of the pregnancies seem to have been intentional.
''A lot of second pregnancies might be by a second father,'' Mrs. Cannon said. ''They believe that giving him a baby, too, will prove their love. But by nine months many have already cut off their ties with the father.''
Ray O'Brien of the Children's Defense Fund, an advocacy group in Washington, said nearly two-thirds of all teen-age mothers are unmarried, a dramatic shift from the early 1970's when about two-thirds were married.
''This means they are on their own, and if they can't find day care and can't get back into school they are lost to the system and the economic cycle continues,'' he said.
 
High Cost of Care
While the number of child care centers at schools has increased since the first ones opened in the past decade, the increase has been slow.
Only 14 states now provide money for child care for adolescent parents at schools, said Amy Wilkins at the Children's Defense Fund.
''The largest reason is it's terribly expensive,'' she said. ''Infant care is the most expensive form of care.''
There is also community resistance from people who see child care centers as a reward and an encouragement for teen-age mothers.
But Ms. Hibma offered a pragmatic argument for care centers. ''We cannot afford to have that many girls drop out of school and spend the rest of their lives on welfare,'' she said. ''Teen mother programs are probably the most cost-effective programs we have.''

HEADLINE: Official Thanks

 BODY:
The corruption scandal that marred Mayor Edward Koch's third term made it easy to forget that he brought to city government some of the finest public officials ever to serve New York. Those who worked tirelessly for the people of New York far outnumbered the losers. Here are a just a few who have earned the city's gratitude. 
Stanley Brezenoff, the affable First Deputy Mayor, kept government running smoothly, even during the scandal. He oversaw the daily operation of city agencies with great skill, tried to tame his sometimes overbearing boss and, though a manager by definition, never lost sight of government's job: serving people.
Housing Commissioner Abraham Biderman kept one eye on the bottom line and the other on his mission: orchestrating the city's 12-year, $5.1 billion program of housing construction and rehabilitation. So far, more than 20,000 new apartments and houses have been finished or are being built. Mr. Biderman's efforts, and those of his predecessor, Paul Crotty, will benefit New Yorkers for years.
Budget Director Paul Dickstein was the self-appointed Grinch of City Hall. His clever strategies frustrated commissioners who wanted more money. But his prudence kept the city sound, and even his victims couldn't argue with his credo: more bang for the municipal buck.
Mr. Dickstein's able predecessor, Alair Townsend, brought relentless energy to her next job, as Deputy Mayor for Economic Development. She worked to keep corporations in New York and attract businesses to boroughs other than Manhattan. Sanitation Commissioner Brendan Sexton started the city's new recycling program and maintained high morale in his department. Bob Linn, director of the Office of Municipal Labor Relations, negotiated fair agreements with the city's unions and pushed productivity reforms. Parks Commissioner Henry Stern embraced his job with enthusiasm, as did Rosemary Ginty, who lobbied fiercely for the Administration during her many years as Director of Intergovernmental Relations.
Former Police Commissioner Benjamin Ward suffered from a tendency to shoot from the lip, but he cracked down hard on corruption and introduced innovative community patrol programs. Former Health Commissioner Stephen Joseph took firm, courageous stands on such difficult issues as the AIDS crisis, often in the face of vehement criticism.
Transportation Commissioner Ross Sandler and his First Deputy, Sam Schwartz, began a strong and badly needed program to repair bridges and roads. Finance Commissioner Anthony Shorris won high marks for running an efficient department.
Corporation Counsel Peter Zimroth devised the strategy behind the city's new campaign finance law. He also built on the work of his predecessor, Frederick A. O. Schwarz Jr. to produce an agreement with the Census Bureau that could prevent another undercount of the urban poor. Mr. Schwarz also calmly steered the government through the corruption scandal, providing advice to a besieged Mayor and devising sweeping reforms.
Many others have worked hard, served well and earned the city's thanks.

HEADLINE: Nuclear Industry Needs a Watchdog That Bites;
Other Options

 BODY:
To the Editor:
Your bullish case for nuclear power (''Revive the Atom,'' editorial, Dec. 8) ignores two important components: nuclear proliferation and competition.
Weapons-grade plutonium is an inevitable byproduct of reactor operation, typically generating enough for 20 nuclear bombs each year in a large reactor. If conventional energy projections come to pass, in the next 50 years the world will be circulating 5 million to 10 million pounds of plutonium annually to and from reactors. This is enough for 500,000 nuclear bombs - 10 times the world arsenal of nuclear bombs. 
To make reactors proliferation-resistant would require reducing the annual discharge of weapons-grade plutonium by 80 percent to 90 percent. Incredibly, there is virtually no serious discussion among reactor vendors, nor in your editorial, to develop such diversion-resistant designs. From this vantage point, the Department of Energy's decision to pay $150 million for new reactor designs, without diversion-resistant criteria, is squandering the taxpayers' dollars.
Instead, the Department of Energy could have saved $100 million by financing a demonstration of aircraft-derived gas turbines. These highly efficient, durable and easily repaired turbines were developed by General Electric and Pratt-Whitney, as part of a $5 billion Air Force research and development program. Detailed testimony to Congress has shown that it would take roughly $50 million to commercialize this technology, using gasified biomass as the fuel source. The estimated capital costs are two-thirds less than those for nuclear reactors.
The United States holds the world lead on this extremely promising technology. In the United States, for example, advanced gas turbines could largely displace all the coal burned by utilities by using a combination of logging wastes and tree crops grown on some of the 120 million acres of classified erodible farmlands. Comparably large uses have been identified in developing countries, where biomass fuels are combusted in horrendously inefficient boilers.
Sweden is planning to use its forest industry wastes to fuel this technology, which the Swedes estimate can back out as much as 80 percent of their nuclear reactors. Sweden is phasing out over the next 15 years all of its reactors, which provide more than 40 percent of the nation's electricity.
Sustainably harvested biomass fuels would also help reduce greenhouse gases and acid rain pollutants. This win-win strategy is good for the environment and for enhancing America's competitive edge. Let's not lose the opportunity, once again, to our foreign competitors.
Finally, your editorial is misleading in implying that the Federal Government has abandoned nuclear technology. Quite the contrary, the nuclear fission program for fiscal year 1990 exceeds $700 million, compared with less than $200 million for energy-efficiency research and development and $100 million for research and development on all solar and renewable technologies. Moreover, the Federal nuclear accident insurance subsidy (the Price-Anderson Act) has been extended for 15 years, and the Senate has voted to forgive the nuclear industry's $10 billion debt for past Federal uranium enrichment services. This is hardly an equitable playing field for solar and efficiency options.
 
CLAUDINE SCHNEIDER
Member of Congress, 2d Dist., R.I.
 Washington, Dec. 11, 1989

LENGTH: 1441 words

HEADLINE: Money Dwindles for Purchase of New York's Vanishing Open Land

BYLINE: By ERIC SCHMITT

 BODY:
Long a national leader in preserving open space, New York State is in danger of falling behind as it rapidly runs out of money to buy environmentally sensitive lands.
At a time when several states are committing vast resources to protect their endangered natural landscapes, by early next year New York will have spent the $250 million for land acquisitions and historic preservation included in the $1.45 billion Environmental Quality Bond Act that voters approved in 1986.
Under pressure from environmental groups, Gov. Mario M. Cuomo is expected to propose a new land acquisition program, probably another bond act, in his State of the State speech on Jan. 3. Environmentalists, while praising the state's current pace and scope of land conservation, say that New York needs to commit at least $2 billion over the next decade or lose thousands of acres of valuable land to development.
Last year Californians approved a $775 million bond act for acquiring open space. Florida is spending almost $100 million a year to preserve rivers, coastline and other natural areas. Massachusetts has committed $105 million in the last two years to protect open space and parks. 
In the New York metropolitan region, where rising property values enticed farmers and timber companies to sell large tracts to builders through the 1980's, land preservation has become a rallying cry for civic, recreation and environmental groups.
Voters in New Jersey last month overwhelmingly approved a $300 million bond act to preserve open space as part of the state's Green Acres program. Gov. William A. O'Neill of Connecticut plans to spend $100 million in the next five years to buy environmentally sensitive lands.
''There's a tremendous sense of urgency,'' said Helen Fenske, New Jersey's assistant commissioner for natural and historic resources. ''The land we save in the next five years is about all we'll save in the future.''
New York officials and conservation groups describe their efforts as a race against suburban sprawl in eastern Long Island and the Hudson River Valley, and against housing subdivisions in rural regions including the Catskills and Adirondacks.
''We're proposing that the state look at open space not just as pretty places, but also as an economic resource for flood control, water supply and tourism,'' said Albert F. Appleton, conservation chairman of the New York City Audubon Society and a leader of the Heritage 2000 Alliance, a coalition of recreation, environmental and historic preservation groups that favors a new bond act.
The 1986 bond act provided $1.2 billion for the cleanup of hazardous waste sites and $250 million for land acquisition, historic preservation and parks.
The State Legislature has appropriated $120 million of the bond money to the Department of Environmental Conservation to buy environmentally sensitive lands or development rights to the land.
The Legislature has also appropriated $95 million to the Office of Parks, Recreation and Historic Preservation, which has used $50 million to expand or improve municipal parks, $25 million to restore historic sites and $20 million to develop 14 urban cultural parks statewide. That leaves $35 million for both agencies in 1990.
Bureaucratic delays hampered the start of the program. In an audit of the parks office's programs through mid-1988, for example, the State Comptroller, Edward V. Regan, criticized the agency for failing to plan how it would spend its share of the bond money. Parks Commissioner Orin Lehman called the report ''off base.''
 
Turning Point: the Lassiter Deal
Since then, however, both state agencies have streamlined their procedures and have earned high marks from recreation and conservation groups.
''They've done an outstanding job in the past year in land acquisitions,'' said Lee Wasserman, executive director of the Environmental Planning Lobby in Albany.
A turning point in the land-acquisition process came last December when Mr. Cuomo intervened to speed the state's purchase of 55,000 acres of Adirondacks wilderness. The state's inability to acquire the land and additional acreage before a developer, Lassiter Properties Inc., bought it in September 1988 had been criticized by environmentalists as emblematic of weaknesses in the process.
The state has since reduced the acquisition time to an average of eight months, from 16 months, partly by working with groups like the Nature Conservancy, which buys the property and sells it to the state.
The state has also empowered its negotiators to offer a premium above appraised fair-market value for properties that have extraordinary public value.
 
Playgrounds to Bike Trails
The Lassiter purchase also illustrated the state's increasing use of conservation easements, which give the public access to land and allows its owners to cut timber but not to build or otherwise alter the land.
In the Lassiter purchase, the state bought 15,000 acres outright and easements on the other 40,000 acres. This preservation tool also promotes the concept of working landscapes, where farmland and forests important to rural economies remain in commercial and recreational use but cannot be developed.
Using bond money, New York has bought or agreed to buy 53,553 acres and easements on 67,992 acres. That total includes 1,369 acres of freshwater wetlands, 10,560 acres of wildlife habitat and more than 97,000 acres of forest in the Adirondacks and Catskills.
The purchases range from the Lassiter land in the Adirondacks, the largest state land deal since the turn of the century, to Denning Point and Sloop Hill, Hudson River peninsulas that are feeding areas for bald eagles.
Parks and historic restoration projects, financed by municipalities and nonprofit organizations with matching state grants, range from playgrounds and bike trails to renovated churches and synagogues.
 
The Need for More Money
''This bond issue helped identify and quantify the preservation and conservation agenda for the rest of the century,'' said Peter R. Borrelli, associate director of the Open Space Institute, a land preservation agency.
Identifying a wide range of valuable parcels and projects also pointed up the bond act's major shortcoming: not enough money to go around. To prevent soaring land prices from eroding the state's purchasing power, agency officials were directed to identify and buy qualified properties within five years. Land values and rapid acquisitions have depleted bond money within about three years.
As the bond money runs out, the Environmental Conservation Department still has $400 million worth of properties that qualify for protection. The parks office has a similar backlog.
''We're only able to fund one of eight projects that are really important,'' said Julia Stokes, a deputy commissioner for historic preservation.
The Heritage 2000 Alliance estimates that it would cost $6 billion to acquire or restore the most important parcels and historic sites in the state.
 
Using Tax Dollars for Land
No one expects state officials under fiscal constraints to come up with that kind of money. But the state is expected to continue playing the principal role in preserving open space.
Municipalities are devoting a greater share of their budgets to open space, but most cannot afford large conservation programs. Rare are places like Suffolk County, L.I., which has spent $100 million in the last three years to buy more than 6,300 acres essential to protecting underground water supplies.
Roughly half that money was raised this year through a quarter-cent addition to the 7.25 percent sales tax that county residents pay.
Facing a budget shortfall of more than $500 million in the next fiscal year, legislators ruled out any special appropriations for land acquisition.
Several parts of the country use special taxes to raise money for land acquisition. Florida has a phosphate-mining tax; Texas a tax on cigarette sales, and Nantucket Island, Mass., a real-estate transfer tax.
A proposal by Maurice D. Hinchey, an Ulster County Democrat who is chairman of the Assembly's Environmental Conservation Committee, would create a permanent $1 billion trust fund for land acquisition by raising the state sales tax by 1 percent for 12 months.
The fund would yield about $100 million a year in interest that could be used for land preservation, Mr. Hinchey said. Other legislators and aides to Mr. Cuomo, however, said that new taxes are unlikely.
Environmental groups favor a bond act that would generate at least $200 million a year. The earliest that voters could act on such a measure would be in November.

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

TITLE: ENVIRONMENTAL QUALITY BOND ACT (1986)

COUNTRY: UNITED STATES (99%); 

STATE: NEW YORK, USA (99%); NEW JERSEY, USA (92%); MASSACHUSETTS, USA (79%); CALIFORNIA, USA (79%); APPALACHIAN MOUNTAINS (79%);

HEADLINE: Gunmen Kill 2 Bystanders In 'Power Play'

BYLINE: By JAMES C. McKINLEY Jr.

 BODY:
A group of men, apparently trying to show that a drug location was their territory, fired randomly as they drove down a Queens street Monday night, killing a teen-ager and mortally wounding a pregnant woman, the police said.
An hour after the shooting, doctors at Queens Hospital Center delivered the wounded woman's baby by Caesarean section while she fought for life, a hospital spokeswoman, Beryl Williams, said.
The woman, Lisa Biffle, 25 years old, died yesterday at 2:55 P.M. after refusing to accept a blood transfusion for religious reasons, the police said.
''She obeyed her conscience,'' Mrs. Biffle's father, Hugh Carter, said. ''More important than life is to maintain a good relationship with God, because he can give everlasting life.'' 
Lieut. Eugene Dunbar, commanding officer of the 103d Precinct detectives, said the shooting in South Jamaica, Queens, ''looks like a power play.''
 
'Someone Else Is Moving In'
''The area is a drug location,'' he said.
Lieutenant Dunbar said it is not uncommon for drug dealers in South Jamaica to drive down a street and fire at people ''to get a message across to other drug dealers that someone else is moving in.'' In the last year, he said, there have been at least three similar shootings in the neighborhood.
As of last night, no arrests had been made in Monday's shootings and the police had no suspects, investigators said.
The shootings occurred at 11:50 P.M. Monday on the west side of 106th Street between 107th and 108th Avenues in South Jamaica, opposite the South Jamaica Houses, a public housing project where cocaine dealers have a thriving business, Lieutenant Dunbar said.
The slain teen-ager, Ebony Williams, 18, of 144-02 Linden Boulevard in South Jamaica, was hit twice in the head as she talked on a pay telephone at the corner of 107th Avenue and 106th Street, he said. She died at the scene.
The gunmen fired from a black 1985 Toyota Camry traveling south on the nearly deserted street, the police said. Seven 9-millimeter shell casings and two rifle shells were found scattered along the street, but it was unclear whether the gunman fired one weapon or two, investigators said.
After shooting Ms. Williams, the gunmen in the Camry coasted another 150 feet and pulled up next to Mrs. Biffle and her husband, Dwayne, 29, who were getting into a Volkswagen Jetta after visiting an uncle of Mr. Biffle who lived nearby, Lieutenant Dunbar said. The men fired several shots into the couple's car.
Mr. Biffle was hit in the left foot and Mrs. Biffle, nine-months pregnant, was struck once in the abdomen, the police said. The Camry sped away.
The bullet that hit Mrs. Biffle ripped through the aorta, spleen, pancreas and colon but somehow missed the unborn child, Mr. Carter said.
The Biffles were taken to Queens Hospital Center, where a team of surgeons delivered their 6-pound 7-ounce boy at 1:09 A.M., Ms. Williams said.
Mrs. Biffle would not allow doctors to give her a blood transfusion despite her great loss of blood because she is a Jehovah's Witness and her religious beliefs proscribe it, Mr. Carter said. Jehovah's Witnesses oppose transfusions because they believe the Bible -specifically Leviticus 17:11 - forbids the ''eating'' of blood.
Mr. Biffle, who underwent surgery yesterday afternoon, and the new baby were listed in good condition last night, Ms. Williams said.
The Biffles were married four years ago and were expecting their first child, Mr. Carter said. Mrs. Biffle worked as a secretary at the Manhattan law firm of Dreyer & Traub, and Mr. Biffle recently began working as an asbestos inspector for the city.
 
Was Headed to a Movie
Last week, her fellow employees gave her a baby shower, Mr. Carter said, and she spent the weekend turning one of the rooms in the couple's small house on Sayre Avenue into a nursery. She planned to leave work later this week to have the child. ''This was something very exciting for her,'' Mr. Carter said. ''They just happened to be in the wrong place,'' Mr. Carter said. ''It's sad, but there is a lot of sadness in this world today.''
Ms. Williams, the slain teen-ager, was an unemployed high school graduate who lived alone with her mother and wanted to attend York College next fall, the police said. She was on her way to a movie theater with a girlfriend when they stopped to call some aquaintances, Lieutenant Dunbar said. Then the shooting started. There is no evidence that she knew the men who fired at her or that she was involved in drug dealing, Lieutenant Dunbar said.

CORRECTION-DATE: December 28, 1989, Thursday, Late Edition - Final

 CORRECTION:
An article yesterday about the fatal shooting of a teen-ager and a pregnant woman in Queens misstated the site. It was the west side of 160th Street, between 107th and 108th Avenues.

HEADLINE: What's in a Name? 50 Signs and a New Era.

BYLINE: By DENNIS HEVESI

 BODY:
Fifty slots on 50 signs on major roads connecting the five boroughs were waiting for official word on an 'N.'
That's 'N' as in Norman as in David N. Dinkins.
''We just need to confirm that that is how he would like it - David N. Dinkins, or simply David Dinkins,'' said Ross (No Middle Initial) Sandler, New York City's Transportation Commissioner, before the decision came from City Hall last Friday. Until then, the 50 signs were on hold. Not a big problem. The department maintains a million street signs of 7,000 different varieties and manufactures and replaces 70,000 of them a year, so 50 signs would all be in a day's work. Actually, it was all in about two hours' work last week. 
And there was no doubt, once the word on the letter came down, that the signs heralding a new mayor and a new era for New York City would get high priority.
''They will be up early in January,'' Mr. Sandler said, pointing out that the ''borough welcoming signs'' are designed so that only a new nameplate has to be painted and bolted into place. The folks at the Transportation Department's sign shop - housed in an old Renault assembly plant in Maspeth, Queens - are up to the job.
One day last week, Steve Harbeck, ''a traffic device maintainer,'' as he and his colleagues are called, was punching holes -three on top, three on the bottom and four on each side - through 18-by-12-inch metal plates, and then rounding the corners. ''It's a safety feature,'' Mr. Bruno said of those clipped corners, ''in case the sign falls.''
Each of the plates was sectioned from one of the 5-by-12-foot metal sheets out of which all city street signs are fashioned, whether they are a ''postage stamp'' - as the workers call the 5-by-7-inch time indicators that are affixed to parking meters - or the giant signs that hang over major highways. ''The biggest is on the Grand Central Parkway at the Northern Boulevard split; it's 39 feet by 12 feet,'' said James Meyer, director of the Maspeth factory, where the city's parking meters and traffic lights also are repaired.
The sign shop's blacksmith, Sam Prioleau, stood beside his anvil, bending metal strips into Z-shaped hooks. ''I designed them from scrap,'' Mr. Prioleau said proudly. ''They save the city 60 cents apiece.''
The Z-hooks are used to hang blank sign plates, one below the other, from a clothesline-like conveyer belt that carries them through an electrostatic powder coater and then into a huge oven. The coater, Mr. Meyer said, uses negative electricity to fix the white powder to the plates.
 
Official and Not So Official
In another part of the room, John Coffey ran a squeegee-like device over a silkscreen so that black ink seeped through and deposited ''Quarters Only'' onto a series of the newly coated plates.
Nearby hung a not-so-official sign designed by the workers. ''Phil, The Job Will Be Ready Tomorrow,'' it said.
''Think I push them a bit?'' asked Phil Cupo, the shop foreman. ''Every time I bring in an order they point to that sign.''
The sign makers must work fast. Lives depend on them. And in recent years, to speed that effort, all signs have been bar coded, like grocery items.
If a citizen complains that a nearby sign is damaged or obliterated by graffiti, said Elizabeth Theofan, assistant commissioner for traffic engineering, an inspector can go to the site, read the bar code and order an identical replacement from one of the shops maintained by the department in each of the five boroughs.
 
Eyes of Many Observers
Each of the five shops has about 7,000 standard signs in stock. ''If it's a life-protecting sign - 'Stop,' 'One Way,' 'Do Not Enter' - these are top priority,'' Ms. Theofan said. ''It must be up within 10 days.'' Mr. Sandler said the department has lived up to that standard 100 percent of the time for the last three years.
Besides citizen complaints, the Transportation Department takes reports from the Police and Fire Departments. And it depends on its employees, ''from the commissioner on down,'' Ms. Theofan said, to watch for missing or damaged signs.
If by chance a borough shop does not have a particular sign on hand, the order goes to the plant in Queens, where 40,000 standard signs are in storage.
But not all signs are standard. In 1988, when the Williamsburg Bridge was closed for structural repairs, the city established an emergency ferry service across the East River. It took one weekend for the shop to create a series of large signs saying, ''Williamsburg Express Ferry Terminal.'' To serve an ethnically diverse population, the signs were written in English, Spanish and Yiddish.
 
A Matter of Revenue
There is also an economic factor requiring haste in the replacement of defective signs - one that parking violators might not appreciate. A defective sign means a parking ticket is invalid.
''If the sign is missing or faded,'' Mr. Sandler said, ''the summons can't be written at all.'' A departmental survey several years ago, he said, showed that the city lost $80 million in five years.
''Budget reductions during the last four years have eaten away at the city's capacity to maintain and replace the signs,'' Mr. Sandler said ''We've lost 22 people, and that translates into 32,000 fewer signs annually.
''We think this is penny wise but pound foolish because, by 1993-94, we could be losing upwards of $10 miilion a year.''
That will be a consideration for the new Mayor - David N. Dinkins.

HEADLINE: Koch, in Veto, Discounts Risks In Computer Use

BYLINE: By ARNOLD H. LUBASCH

 BODY:
Mayor Edward I. Koch yesterday rejected legislation aimed at protecting New York City municipal employees who use video display terminals.
In a rare veto, the Mayor said he had not been shown compelling medical evidence that the terminals posed a serious health risk. He said that the bill could hurt the city's business climate, and that the issues it addressed should be resolved through collective bargaining. 
The bill requires uniform standards for the equipment, providing rest breaks for the employees and obligating the city to pay half the cost of eye examinations and lenses needed as a result of operating the terminals.
Peter F. Vallone, the Council majority leader, said he intended to reintroduce the legislation next year and would seek the new Mayor's support to ''see that city workers are protected.''
 
Possible Danger to Health
Advocates of the legislation, including municipal-union representatives, contended at a City Hall hearing last week that the health and safety of employees are endangered by regular, long use of video display terminals.
Opponents of the bill, including the New York Chamber of Commerce and Industry, contended that the terminals do not pose a risk when they are operated properly and that the legislation for city employees could lead to imposing regulations in the private sector.
Mr. Koch said he believed the issue had to be settled through collective bargaining unless there was ''compelling evidence that they pose a serious health threat.
''Even if there was such compelling medical evidence,'' he continued, ''the economic provisions of the bill, such as eye examinations on city time and city payment for eye examinations and lenses, must be the subject of collective bargaining.''
 
Wants Collective Bargaining
Mr. Koch noted that the city has been negotiating with District Council 37 on some of the issues and that the legislation ''represents an attempt to circumvent these negotiations.''
The city's budget office estimated that the bill would cost $30 million in the next fiscal year, Mr. Koch said. He noted that a chief sponsor of the bill, Councilwoman Miriam Friedlander, said the cost would be $3 million.
Mr. Koch said he was also concerned that the measure ''represents the first step toward'' regulating the use of video display terminals in the private sector, which ''might endanger the business climate and cause firms to relocate outside the city or deter new ones from moving into the city.''
Suffolk County has adopted similar legislation.

HEADLINE: EDUCATION;
Lessons

BYLINE: By Edward B. Fiske

 BODY:
Wouldn't it be nice to receive 16 years of education - a high school diploma and a college degree - in 10 minutes for an investment of 5 cents?
That is what Lewis J. Perelman of the Hudson Institute estimates would be possible if the power of educational technology had increased at the same pace in the last 40 years as the power of computer technology.
The analogy, of course, is extreme. Delivering information is only one element of education, and there is always the matter of how much the human brain can handle on the receiving end. But Mr. Perelman has a point. 
Education has, arguably, the worst productivity record of any major industry. It is difficult to imagine that decentralized school systems and the other changes widely proposed for American schools will have much impact unless schools figure out how to make better use of the resources they already have.
Evidence of inefficiency is abundant.
In ''Technology and the American Economic Transition,'' a report published last year, the Congressional Office of Technology Assessment concluded that, with staffing levels rising and student test scores stagnant, the ''real productivity'' of American schools was declining.
A prime reason for the decline, it suggested, is that education invests a smaller portion of its resources in labor-saving technology than any other major industry. As a nation, the United States invests 2.5 percent of its gross national product in research and development.
By contrast, the two main supporters of educational research, the Education Department and the National Science Foundation, together spent $130 million, or 0.025 percent, of all spending for education on such activities in 1987.
Mr. Perelman, in a paper published in October for the Hudson Institute titled ''Closing Education's Technology Gap,'' calculated that whereas the average job in the American economy required $50,000 of investment in plant and equipment, the figure for schools is $1,000 per employee.
Actually the figure is much lower, for, as he notes, education is one of the few businesses in which it is the consumer, not the employee, who does the ''essential work.'' If students are thought of as the ''workers,'' then the investment drops to $100.
Educators typically respond to such arguments by pointing out that 93 cents out of every dollar in the school budget pays for salaries. Because their enterprise is so labor intensive and because machines cannot run classrooms, the argument goes, education cannot be automated to the same extent as other industries.
But that argument can be turned on its head. Because education is so labor intensive, the potential for improving productivity is enormous.
Education is a complex enterprise, involving everything from transferring data to the shaping of human values. Few would argue that the most sophisticated learning experiences - the give and take of a high-level seminar or the Socratic dialogue of the single student and teacher - can be automated.
Such learning, however, constitutes a small percentage of educational experience. Much, perhaps most, learning, especially at the elementary and secondary level, can be enhanced by the use of word processing, videos and other forms of technology.
Compelling evidence can be found in the fact that educators with a big stake in efficiency, notably the military and proprietary trade and technical schools, invest heavily in technology. Mr. Perelman estimates that 30 percent of the $50 billion that American employers spend annually on employee training goes into computer-based instructional systems.
''The difference is that employers and the military have big incentives to teach more efficiently,'' he said. ''Those incentives are missing from public schools.''
Vendors of computer-assisted learning systems, which allow students to work at their own pace under the guidance of a classroom teacher, argue that they can substantially increase the learning of basic skills like arithmetic and grammar.
''We can cover 12 years of learning in eight,'' the president of the education systems division of Wicat Systems, John J. Gottsman, said. ''You can spend the rest of the time on great books or whatever you want.'' Other manufacturers make similar claims.
The Congressional report called for establishing a federally supported Learning Research Institute, on the model of the National Institutes of Health, to promote greater use of technology in education. Mr. Perelman wants states to get schools to put 1 percent of their budgets into educational research and share findings through a National Institute for Learning Technologies.
Although the idea of 16 years of education for 5 cents may be just a fantasy, the pressure is on for schools to find ways of getting more for their nickels.

HEADLINE: New Jet Fighter: Risks Are High

BYLINE: By RICHARD W. STEVENSON, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: LOS ANGELES, Dec. 22

 BODY:
The two teams of military contractors competing for a contract to build a new generation of jet fighters are finding their gamble is even bigger than anticipated.
For the two teams - one led by the Northrop Corporation, the other by the Lockheed Corporation - the program represents an opportunity to capture what is expected to be one of the few big weapons contracts of the 1990's. But it has also become perhaps the most visible example of how stricter procurement rules imposed by the Pentagon earlier in the decade have staggered arms makers, even before they confront the deep military budget cuts being contemplated in Washington. It also illustrates how the industry's willingness to take big risks to land new business may not pay off, even for the winner.
Indeed, both the industry and the Pentagon seem to have learned a lesson from programs like the Advanced Tactical Fighter, as the proposed plane is called. The industry is taking a harder line about the terms it will accept on any new project. And the Government appears to have concluded, even as it tries to tighten its belt, that in some cases it has pushed contractors too far. 
 
Policy of Sharing Costs
The Advanced Tactical Fighter is being designed to replace the F-15 as the plane that controls the skies over a battlefield, allowing attack planes and bombers to strike enemy forces. It is being built under a policy that the Pentagon calls cost-sharing. The Government agreed three years ago to pay each team $691 million to design and build two prototypes, knowing that each team would have to spend far more than that to meet the Air Force's performance standards.
In fact, each team has spent almost as much of its own money as the Air Force's - more than $600 million each - making this the largest cost-sharing arrangement ever, analysts said. Northrop's partner is the McDonnell Douglas Corporation, and Lockheed is teamed with the Boeing Company and the General Dynamics Corporation. Northrop and McDonnell have each put up about $300 million, and Lockheed, Boeing and General Dynamics have invested $200 million or so apiece.
A showdown between the two teams will take place sometime next year in the skies over Edwards Air Force Base in the California desert. The rival prototypes will engage in a ''flyoff,'' with the winning design destined to become one of the nation's standard combat aircraft well into the 21st century.
When the flyoff is complete and a selection is made in mid-1991, the losing team's $600 million - roughly the equivalent of Lockheed's $624 million in net earnings for all of last year -will have essentially gone down the drain. The winner will presumably have a chance to recoup its investment in the more profitable full-scale development and production phases of the contract, which could extend for a decade or more.
But with improved relations with the Soviet Union and pressure in Congress to cut military spending, even the winner risks emerging with a limited profit if the program is slowed down or scaled back, or as an outright loser if it is canceled altogether. The Air Force wants to build 750 of the fighters at an estimated cost of $45 billion, or an average of $60 million per plane.
The project has already hurt earnings at all of the competing companies for three years as they write off the money they poured into designing and building the prototypes. The expenditures have raised the companies' debt levels, helped depress their stock prices and diverted money and engineering talent from research and development and from other programs. The companies are now grappling with the effects of a $200 million cut in the program's budget for this year and a subsequent decision by the Air Force to try to save money in the current fiscal year by extending the prototype phase by six months.
 
'Money Out of the Industry's Hide'
''This is one example of how the Government and the Defense Department have more or less taken money out of the industry's hide in order to keep a program going despite cuts to the defense budget,'' said Paul H. Nisbet, an analyst at Prudential-Bache Securities. ''It may keep the program alive for the Government, but the ability of the industry to compete is impeded by this kind of contract.''
The contractors were all aware of the program's terms going into the competition, and chose to participate anyway, although they spread the financial risks by forming teams. Only now, after several years of absorbing the harsh lessons of the strict contracting terms imposed by the Pentagon on a host of other programs, are executives of some of the contractors beginning to wonder whether the gamble was worth it.
As a result, the industry is taking a harder line with the Pentagon about what terms it will accept on new projects. Rather than pay any price to win business that might keep production lines and laboratories humming, as they have for the last few years, weapons makers are increasingly bidding only if the economics make sense.
Over the last year or two, several of the largest contractors, including Northrop and Lockheed, have stopped bidding for programs that pay a fixed price for the development of new weapons systems. The companies say those contracts have often led to huge losses when unexpected technical problems and delays have produced higher-than-planned costs. Indeed, virtually every large company has suffered a loss on a fixed-price development contract in the last several years. The industry prefers contracts that pay a fee or a certain percentage above the cost of a program.
 
Demands for Reimbursement
Some companies, including the Rockwell International Corporation, are shedding their previous reluctance to pick a fight with the Government and are asking the Pentagon to reimburse them for losses that they consider the results of changes in contract demands midway through a program. Rockwell is planning to seek to recover some of its $100 million in losses on a program to develop the AC-130 aircraft gunship.
Many companies have simply stopped doing business with the Pentagon, citing the low profit potential. According to a recent study by the Center for Strategic and International Studies, a research organization in Washington, the number of military suppliers or subcontractors dropped to fewer than 40,000 companies in 1987, from 138,000 in 1982, although other experts say the decline was much smaller. Some big companies, like Honeywell Inc., are selling all or most of their military-related businesses to concentrate on more profitable commercial ventures.
Those companies that have remained in the business are mostly living off older, established programs, many of them highly profitable. The military sales of virtually every company in the industry have begun to fall off in the last few years, and overall profit margins have been badly squeezed. The industry suffers from overcapacity in important segments like airplane manufacturing and shipbuilding. Many companies have had trouble raising capital to invest in new plants and technologies because investors have pushed their stock prices down sharply.
 
Pentagon Eases Up
For its part, the Government has been talking of becoming somewhat less demanding. The Pentagon is ending its demands for fixed-price development contracts, for example, and has slightly speeded up the rate at which it pays its contractors.
Addressing what he called the adversarial relationship between the Pentagon and the arms industry, Donald J. Atwood, the Deputy Defense Secretary, said in a speech last month that the Government would try to improve the business climate for contractors.
''We are taking steps to improve this relationship by reinstating the proper risk-return balance in the defense business,'' he said. ''It is important that we acknowledge that it is proper for industry to make an equitable profit. We want to give our suppliers the incentive to make the necessary investments in the high-technology equipment and facilities needed to develop and produce today's sophisticated weapons systems.''
But for now the industry is stuck with deals it made over the last few years, and it is continuing to pay a price for them. On the fighter jet program, the Northrop-McDonnell Douglas team took the unusual step of sending a letter to the Air Force last month detailing its concerns about ''uncertainties'' in the program's financing and asking for reassurances that delays in the program schedule would not increase the team's financial risk.
Northrop and McDonnell Douglas told the Air Force that unless they received those reassurances, they would reduce their spending and work on the program to levels sufficient to meet minimum contract requirements, and no more.
 
An Offer to Pay More
Analysts said the Air Force had offered to pay each team an additional $52 million to cover the cost of the six-month extension. But Northrop is reported to have told the Air Force that its costs for the extension will be $115 million, and the Lockheed team is thought to have placed its figure at $170 million.
Because the contracts call for the bulk of the payments from the Air Force to be made to the competitors toward the end of the prototype program, the Northrop team has spent $180 million more than the Air Force has reimbursed it for, separate from the $650 million that Northrop, McDonnell Douglas and their biggest subcontractors have put up of their own money.
Lockheed executives declined to be interviewed, but their team is thought to have spent at least as much of its own money as the Northrop team and to have similar financial concerns.
''Everyone accepted cost-sharing at the beginning,'' said an executive of a company in the competition, who agreed that the program had become riskier for the contractors. ''What you have now is not only cost-sharing, but shortfalls in funding and extensions in the timetable.''
 
Shrouded in Secrecy
The competition itself remains largely shrouded in secrecy. But analysts and industry executives say that the Northrop-McDonnell Douglas team has delivered its first prototype to a hangar at Edwards Air Force Base in the California desert and that the team's second prototype is nearing completion at a Northrop plant near Los Angeles. The first prototype is expected to be outfitted with engines built by the United Technologies Corporation's Pratt & Whitney unit and to fly for the first time in the first three months of next year.
The Lockheed team is thought to be behind schedule. Its prototypes have still not been assembled. Lawrence M. Harris, an analyst at Bateman Eichler, Hill Richards in Los Angeles, said the delay may have resulted in part to problems at General Dynamics, which has apparently been slow in building the middle portion of the fuselage. Mr. Harris said Lockheed was also thought to be using more advanced composite surfaces and avionics, the systems that control the plane's flight.
Some analysts see the Air Force's decision to slow the program by six months as an attempt to let the Lockheed team catch up with Northrop, which has been bedeviled by indictments and investigations of its performance on a variety of programs in recent years and is enduring close Congressional scrutiny over its work on the $70 billion B-2 Stealth bomber program.

HEADLINE: Economic Scene;
Foreign Owners For U.S. Airlines?

BYLINE: By Peter Passell

 BODY:
FIRST there were Pan Am and T.W.A. and United and American. And now - Discovery?
Actually, Hawaii-based Discovery Airlines, set to begin inter-island operations in February with five leased aircraft, is not about to challenge the giants of the domestic airline industry. But the six-month-long brouhaha over its certification, tentatively approved last week over the bitter opposition of its direct likely competitors, presages far more important battles over the issue of foreign control of American carriers. 
The time is ripe, argues Dan Kasper, an airline consultant and former Federal regulator, for a dramatic turnaround in airline policy. Rather than protecting domestic carriers from competition, Washington should welcome foreign investment -provided American airlines are offered reciprocal opportunities abroad.
Since the skies were deregulated in 1978, anyone with both the knowledge and the bankroll has been permitted to start an airline. The only catch - the one that almost grounded Discovery - is that foreigners may not own more than 25 percent or exercise substantial control.
The prime movers behind Discovery are the Japanese Nansay Corporation, which wants to funnel Japanese vacationers to its multibillion-dollar Hawaiian resort developments, and the British Aerospace Corporation, which wants to sell its sleek BAe-146 jet in the American market. They stitched together a deal to cover nearly all the airline's start-up costs with foreign cash while leaving American citizens with both 100 percent of the common stock and control of the board.
Aloha and Hawaiian, the established inter-island carriers, went crackers over the threat of a third airline in a market that has not been particularly profitable for two. Discovery, they charged, was a Trojan horse for foreigners: dependence on Japanese money and concessionary British leases would effectively leave foreigners in control.
Undecided on the legal or policy merits of the case, the Transportation Department delayed approval through the fall. But last week - too late for Discovery to catch the cream of the winter bookings - Washington relented. Discovery will be permitted to fly while the lawyers wrangle over the degree of influence exercised by Philip Ho, a Chinese-American who is both an employee of Nansay and the carrier's principal stockholder.
Perhaps all is well that ends well. Hawaii will gain an airline eager to compete on both price and service. But the long delay and muddy conclusion to the Discovery case shows that the Bush Administration has yet to make up its mind about foreign ownership. And that issue is not about to go away.
Airline deregulation can work in the interests of the traveling public, it is widely agreed, only if established carriers are disciplined by the threat of new competitors. But the failure of a half-dozen start-up airlines in the last few years has made it almost impossible to raise the vast sums needed to challenge an American or a United on its home turf. The only players with both the incentive to take the risk and pockets deep enough to mount a credible threat seem to be foreign.
That is why the Bush Administration is walking the narrow line. On the one hand, it is policing the spirit as well as the letter of the prohibition against foreign ownership - forcing Northwest, for example, to rewrite its passive financing arrangement with KLM. On the other hand, it is reluctant to close the door to any deal that would increase competition.
But the luxury of such ambivalence is growing more costly. Braniff, grounded by bankruptcy, is not likely to fly again unless it is sold to a foreign airline that covets domestic American routes. Both T.W.A. and Pan Am, moreover, are losing a small fortune on domestic operations. The best guess is that their only long-term alternatives to liquidation or mergers with other domestic carriers will be sales to foreigners.
To many economists, the solution is simple: repeal the law against foreign ownership. There is no obvious reason, after all, why it is in America's interest to allow Honda to make cars in Ohio - but not allow Japan Airlines to offer service between Cincinnati and Cleveland.
To Mr. Kasper, who negotiated international airline agreements for the Carter Administration, that answer seems politically naive. The domestic market cannot be opened, he argues, unless there is something in it for established domestic carriers. And that something, Mr. Kasper suggests, should be reciprocal investment rights abroad.
Some countries, notably Japan, would initially resist. But how long, one wonders, would they be able to hold out if the European Community cut a deal to allow an American presence in Europe? The time to negotiate such liberalization, Mr. Kasper argues, is sooner rather than later. If Washington waits until another United States carrier goes belly up, the terms of the deal are bound to be less attractive to American interests.

HEADLINE: Tisches Add to Holdings Of Bank of Boston Stock

BYLINE: By MICHAEL QUINT

 BODY:
The Bank of Boston Corporation, hard hit by losses on real estate lending, has received a vote of confidence from Laurence A. Tisch, president of CBS Inc., who has bought a large block of the banking company's stock.
Mr. Tisch, widely regarded on Wall Street as a canny investor, has a history of buying into banking companies whose stocks have been battered but are fundamentally sound. In the case of the Bank of Boston, he led a group of family members in acquiring 6.6 percent of the company's shares. 
News of the Tisch family purchases, which were disclosed yesterday in documents filed with the Securities and Exchange Commission, caused the Bank of Boston's stock to rise by $1.375, to $18.125. $94.5 Million Invested Since Oct. 23, when the Bank of Boston's stock closed at $21.75, Mr. Tisch has bought about 4.4 million shares; he already held more than 300,000 shares. So far, Mr. Tisch has invested $94.5 million, resulting in an average price per share of about $20.02, well below the Bank of Boston's high earlier this year of $30.625, but higher than yesterday's close.
''Let's not kid ourselves, they made some loans they regret,'' said Thomas J. Tisch, a son of Laurence Tisch, and managing partner of FLF Associates, one of the buyers of the Bank of Boston stock. ''But they have been forthright in dealing with the problems.''
Mr. Tisch added that despite its $125 million loss in the third quarter, the Bank of Boston remained more strongly capitalized than many other banks its size. The banking company is the 15th largest in the country and the largest in New England.
 
'Over Penalization' Seen
The Tisch investment in the Bank of Boston is a contrarian one. Problems in real estate lending have led to heavy selling of bank stocks, particulary in New England. Mr. Tisch said, however, that the Bank of Boston's stock had been ''over penalized'' and ''over discounted'' for the region's problems.
At the Bank of New England Corporation, the Bank of Boston's regional rival, mounting problems with real estate loans led its directors to demand the resignation of Walter J. Connolly Jr., its chief executive, once a successor is found. The Bank of New England has been even harder hit than the Bank of Boston, having recently rescinded its fourth-quarter dividend, and announced an increase in its reserve for loan losses to more than $1 billion from $354 million. Analysts expect that will result in a loss of $350 million or more for the year.
Mr. Tisch compared the Bank of Boston investment with his family's purchase in 1986 and 1987 of stock in First Interstate Iowa. Share prices for that banking company have since doubled, as the values of farmland and the Iowa economy have recovered.
Marc Perkins, chairman of Perkins, Smith Inc., a Tampa, Fla., securities firm that advises the Tisch family on many bank stock investments, said, ''There are many banks, like Bank of Boston, who are victims of an overheated economy, but were intelligent lenders and will turn out to be excellent investments.''

HEADLINE: BUSINESS PEOPLE;
As Westmark Divests, Its Chairman Resigns

BYLINE: By Lawrence M. Fisher

 BODY:
Adm. Bobby R. Inman has resigned as chairman, president and chief executive of Westmark Systems Inc. and its subsidiary, Tracor Holdings Inc., effective Dec. 31.
Admiral Inman said he decided to resign after determining that another executive would be better suited to a recently announced program to sell various assets of Tracor, a military electronics and instruments company based in Austin, Tex. 
Admiral Inman said he ''made the judgment in early spring, looking at the defense market and at our debt structure, that Tracor would not be stable in the long term.'' At that time, he said, the decision was made to sell the company's aviation systems unit, the instruments group and some or all of the military electronics business. But the sales were delayed for five months, he said.
''I have been very frustrated with this,'' said Admiral Inman, who is 58 years old. ''I feel infinitely better now that this will be put in the hands of an old pro, someone who has been to the table before,'' he said. ''I bring no expertise to bear as we proceed with asset sales and begin to restructure.''
Westmark said a committee of board members was evaluating candidates to succeed Admiral Inman on a permanent basis. In the meantime, Elvis A. Mason, managing partner of the Mason Best Company, will assume the position of chairman and chief executive of Westmark. Mason Best is a Dallas-based merchant banking company that founded Westmark in 1986 and is its largest shareholder.
Dr. William C. Moyer has been named acting president and chief executive of Tracor. Dr. Moyer joined Tracor in 1960 and holds the title of group vice president.
Admiral Inman was recruited by Westmark, which was formed to acquire military and technology companies. Westmark acquired Tracor in September 1987 for $694.4 million.
Admiral Inman is a former deputy director of the Central Intelligence Agency, director of naval intelligence and head of the National Security Agency. In 1983, he founded the Microelectronics and Computer Technology Corporation in Austin, Tex., a a research consortium of 20 computer and military companies.
Admiral Inman said he had received several offers since letting it be known he was leaving Westmark but that he would wait at least six weeks before deciding what to do. He said he plans to continue team-teaching a graduate course in economics for national security at the University of Texas. He is also a director on several corporate boards and lobbies on behalf of the United States' ability to compete in the international marketplace.
He is married, with two grown sons.

HEADLINE: C.D.'s and Bank Funds Off

BYLINE: By ROBERT HURTADO

 BODY:
Yields on certificates of deposit and money market accounts at commercial banks and savings institutions were mostly down for the week that ended yesterday.
''The odds favor a drop in the prime rate,'' said Robert K. Heady, the publisher of The Bank Rate Monitor, ''but by waiting until after the New Year, it may enable some banks to charge-out January loan payments at the previous higher rate instead of the new one.
''Continuing rumors of rising inflation have been discounted by major banks, especially in New York, where yields on have dropped 2 points since April,'' Mr. Heady added. ''If the banks thought that inflation would be a factor, they'd be raising rates, not lowering them.'' 
At the Treasury's regular weekly auction of three- and six-month bills yesterday, interest rates increased sharply. But analysts said the results were distorted by holiday factors. The auction results often influence what many banks and savings institutions pay on money market accounts and C.D.'s.
The average rate for a three-month bill rose by 15 basis points, to 7.77 percent, while the rate for a six-month bill increased by 21 basis points, to 7.64 percent. A basis point is one-hundredth of a percentage point.
 
General Market Decline
The Bank Rate Monitor's weekly survey of New York area banks showed that C.D. yields at commercial banks and savings institutions were all down by nearly the same.
At commercial banks, the yield on an average money market account declined by 2 basis points, to 6.65 percent, while three-month and six month C.D.'s fell by 3 basis points each, to 7.93 percent and 7.80 percent, respectively.
Money market accounts at savings institutions were also off by 2 basis points, to 6.62 percent, while three-month and six-month certificates fell by 4 basis points each, to 8.16 percent 8.19 percent, respectively.
Among 20 large banks nationwide, the average yield on money market accounts and on six-month C.D.'s dropped by a basis point each, to 6.44 percent and 7.83 percent, respectively.
For the third straight week, the yields offered on certificates and money market accounts held at large credit unions were mixed. Money market accounts rose by 2 basis points, to 6.77 percent, while six-month and one-year C.D.'s were unchanged at 8.01 percent and 8.16 percent, respectively. Depositors seeking to buy longer maturities will find yields on two-and-a-half-year and five-year C.D.'s down by 2 basis points each, to 8.24 percent and 8.23 percent, respectively.

HEADLINE: U.S. Stake Abroad Is Up

BYLINE: By Reuters

 BODY:
American companies are increasing their investments overseas, particularly in Europe, where they do not want to miss growth opportunities, economists for the Conference Board say.
''Europe is a dynamic growth area,'' said James Greene, a consultant to the board, citing the European Community's plan to establish a single market by the end of 1992. 
The Conference Board is a New York-based research group that is supported by many corporations.
The Ford Motor Company's acquisition of Jaguar P.L.C. of Britian and the General Motors Corportion's purchase of 50 percent of Saab-Scania A.B. of Sweden are just ''the tip of the iceberg,'' said Stephen J. Cooney of the National Association of Manufacturers, an industry group.
American companies have so far this year worked out plans to establish 220 manufacturing projects overseas, up from 180 projects in 1988, Mr. Greene said. He added that he expected the trend to continue for at least four years.
United States direct investment abroad rose by $25.01 billion in the first nine months of last year, to $351.91 billion, after rising by $18.9 billion in all of 1988, according to Commerce Department estimates.
In the same period, direct investment by foreign companies in the United States grew faster, as it has for most of the decade. Foreign investment rose by $22.65 billion, to $350.15 billion, after surging $58.44 billion last year.
