HEADLINE: Market Place;
Banks That Shine Amid the Gloom

BYLINE: By Michael Quint

 BODY:
THE last few months have been terrible times for bank stocks, as losses from real estate lending at some New England banks have raised fears of similar problems in other regions.
After record earnings in 1988 and the first half of 1989, banks are now suffering from a rise in delinquent real estate loans, particularly loans to developers for building new houses, condominiums, office buildings and shopping centers. Loans past due by 90 days or more have tripled at many banks since the end of 1988. As prices fall for the real estate used to secure the loans, banks are increasing the reserves they set aside to cover losses on the loans. 
When these reserves increase, profits decline, a process that is well under way in New England and is becoming more apparent in other states, including New Jersey and Arizona. Although loan-loss reserves have not been increasing sharply in Florida or California, investors have been wary about bank stocks in those states.
''Real estate lending is not the only villain,'' said James J. McDermott, senior vice president of Keefe, Bruyette & Woods Inc., a securities firm that specializes in banking companies. ''Banks are also hurt by expectations of a weakening economy and problems with loans for leveraged buyouts.''
As the outlook became more negative, Mr. McDermott said, many investors decided to get out of banking stocks - including those with solid earnings, like the BankAmerica Corporation, the First Chicago Corporation and Wells Fargo & Company. Although Wells Fargo has been an active lender for both real estate and leveraged buyouts, its management continues to assure analysts that problems are not building.
The possibility that large retailing companies might declare bankruptcy has raised another cloud over banks.
Given the present and potential loan problems of banks, it is not surprising that since early October, prices of many bank stocks have fallen by 25 percent and more, while the overall market has fallen only slightly. According to an index compiled by Keefe, Bruyette & Woods, bank stock prices have risen only 15.2 percent since the end of 1988, compared with a 25.1 percent gain for the Standard & Poor's 500. From the end of 1988 to Oct. 6, however, bank issues were much stronger than the overall market, rising 37 percent, compared with a 29 percent gain for the S.&P. 500.
Although it is clear that the banking industry has lost the luster it had earlier in the year, securities analysts have identified many banks that they expect to escape the worst of the problems, either because of a strong regional economy or astute lending policies.
Within New England for example, the State Street Boston Corporation, which did not participate heavily in New England's real estate boom of the 1980's, is not vulnerable to losses as the bubble bursts. State Street has focused on processing transactions for other banks and mutual funds.
The Fleet/Norstar Financial Group of Providence, R.I., is another New England company recommended by some analsyts. Besides the benefit of its operations in upstate New York, where there have not been severe real estate problems, Fleet/Norstar cut back on real estate lending far sooner than its neighbors at the Bank of Boston Corporation or the Bank of New England Corporation.
And not everyone is avoiding those institutions. Laurence A. Tisch, the president of CBS Inc. who has a reputation as a canny investor, has bought 4.72 million shares in the Bank of Boston, or 6.6 percent of the outstanding shares. Since Oct. 23, when the bank's stock closed at $21.75, Mr. Tisch has bought about 4.4 million shares. So far, Mr. Tisch has invested $94.5 million, resulting in an average price per share of about $20.02, well below the Bank of Boston's high this year of $30.625, but above yesterday's close of $18.125, up $1.375, on the New York Stock Exchange.
Among banking companies outside New England, Virginia Adair, an analyst at Drexel Burnham Lambert Inc., recommends the Corestates Financial Corporation of Philadelphia; the Sovran Financial Corporation of Norfolk, Va.; the First Wachovia Corporation of Winston-Salem, N.C., and the Norwest Corporation of Minneapolis. All have a history of avoiding bad loans and speculative real estate ventures.
New York City banks, whose nationwide lending exposes them to bad markets as well as good, have been reporting higher levels of delinquent loans. An exception is the Republic New York Corporation, which has no loans for leveraged buyouts and practically no exposure to commercial real estate. Republic is known for its reluctance to lend to any but the safest borrowers; its stock closed yesterday at $50.875, up 12.5 cents and near its high for the year of $51.625.
Analysts at Oppenheimer & Company are recommending banks in the economically stable Midwest. Among their picks are the NBD Bancorp of Detroit, which has only 8 percent of its loans to companies in the sluggish automobile industry; Comerica Inc., another Detroit banking company, and the National City Corporation of Cleveland.

HEADLINE: Stocks Are Mixed in Very Slow Trading

BYLINE: By PHILLIP H. WIGGINS

 BODY:
Stock prices ended narrowly mixed yesterday in extremely slow post-Christmas trading. The Dow Jones industrial average slipped 2.13 points, to 2,709.26, but advances on the New York Stock Exchange edged out declines by 712 to 664.
Two hours into trading only about 28 million shares had changed hands, one of the slowest starts in recent months. By the close, volume on the Big Board was only 77.6 million shares, well below the 121 million traded last Friday, a relatively slow day itself. Yesterday's volume was the lowest since 68.87 million shares were traded on July 3, the Monday before Independence Day. 
Equities appeared to be unaffected by an early and sustained tumble in bond prices. The decline was considered distorted by some credit market participants, who cited thin trading. One reason for the slowness in both stocks and bonds was that many overseas traders were still observing the Christmas holiday. 30-Year Treasury Issue By late in the day the bellwether 30-year Treasury issue was down 1 10/ 32, to 101 19/32, to yield 7.98 percent, up from last Friday's close of 7.87 percent.
''The market appears to be almost asleep,'' one trader said late yesterday, while noting that stocks traded thinly and in a narrow range throughout most of the session.
''Investors apparently were still on holiday as the market shrugged off the rise in interest rates in Japan, the steep slump in U.S. bond prices brought about by renewed inflationary fears over oil prices, a weaker dollar and what appears to have been a pretty decent Christmas season,'' said Larry Kekst, senior portfolio manager at the National City Corporation in Cleveland.
Movement in the broader market measures was almost as minuscule as that of the Dow. The Standard & Poor's 500-stock index slipped 0.61, to 346.81, while the New York Stock Exchange composite index lost a mere 0.23, to 191.72. Traders said that an expected spate of ''bottom fishing'' -when investors attempt to pick up year-end bargains - failed to develop.
 
Weakness In the Dollar
Slight weakness in the dollar against both the Japanese yen and the West German mark was one thing holding back the stock market, analysts said. They also noted that oil stocks were mixed in the wake of the extensive fire that ravaged petroleum storage facilities in Louisiana. Production operations, however, were largely unscathed, industry experts pointed out.
Phillips Petroleum rose 1/2, to 25 7/8, even though the company said it would reduce gasoline production at its Sweeny, Tex., refinery about 10 percent for 10 to 12 days because of a small fire in a processing unit.
Exxon was off 1/2, to 50 1/8. A blast over the weekend shut down the company's 455,000-barrel-a-day refinery in Baton Rouge, La. An Exxon spokesman said that although some internal pipelines were damaged, the plant's production facilities were not affected.
Elsewhere in the group, Chevron dipped 5/8, to 67 1/8, and Mobil was unchanged at 62 3/8.
Among other individual issues, Avon Products added 1/2, to 36 3/4. Chartwell Associates L.P. said it had bought 401,000 additional shares of the cosmetics company's stock, bringing its total holdings in the company to 8.7 percent.
L.A. Gear jumped 2 points, to 33 1/4, in heavy trading, partly because of a report in Barron's magazine that said the athletic footwear maker might rally in early January after late December selling pressure eases.
Bank of New England was the most active stock, as well as the biggest percentage gainer, rising 1/4, to 7 3/8, on a volume of 2.2 million shares. The company said it was developing a program to deal with the depressed real estate market in New England and that it continued to explore alternatives, like potential mergers and sales of assets. The bank also said its chairman and chief executive, Walter J. Connolly Jr. would step down as chief executive as soon as a replacement is named.
The Bank of Boston Corporation gained 1 3/8, to 18 1/8. Traders said Laurence A. Tisch, the investor, and the rest of the group that had bought a 6.6 percent interest in the company believed the stock was oversold and that the bank would weather its real estate problems.
UAL jumped 7 1/4, to 170 1/4. Traders said there appeared to be concentrating purchases by a single buyer operating through Bear, Stearns & Company, although that buyer could not be immediately identified. Later a second investor was said to be buying heavily.
On the American Stock Exchange, the market value index dipped 0.04, to 370.80, while in over-the-counter trading, the Nasdaq composite index edged up 0.69, to 445.26.

HEADLINE: CREDIT MARKETS;
Prices Off Sharply in Thin Trading

BYLINE: By H. J. MAIDENBERG

 BODY:
Prices of Treasury securities plunged yesterday in thin trading.
Dealers said that many market participants in the United States and overseas remained on holiday and that many dealers and portfolio managers had either closed their books for 1989 or were reluctant to take on any significant new positions.
''We have few players, no sizable trades, and those seeking to sell Treasury notes and bonds found prices falling through air pockets,'' one dealer said. ''Given the thinness of the market, prices could just as easily reverse course and go through the roof tomorrow.'' 
 
'A New Willingness'
But Jonathan B. Greenspan, chief trader at Aegis Capital Management, said: ''Of course the market was thin and the price gaps between bids and offers very wide. Still, we have been detecting a new willingness by the market to finally respond to negative news, such as the recent surge in oil prices, however temporary it may be.''
Price weakness was also evident in the results of the Treasury's regular weekly bill auction, which Christmas delayed a day.
The average discount rate on the 90-day bills was 7.77 percent, up from 7.62 percent a week ago, and the highest since Oct. 30, when the rate was 7.78 percent. The average discount rate on the six-month bills was 7.64 percent, up from 7.43 percent the week before, and the highest since Oct. 2, when it was 7.92 percent. The outstanding one-year bills climbed 11 basis points, to 7.30 percent. A basis point is a hundredth of a percentage point.
Dealers said the bill auction results were not affected by the Federal Reserve's move to add reserves to the banking system through two-day repurchase agreements.
 
Seasonal Factors
The move was attributed to seasonal factors. After the auctions, the Treasury announced that it will sell an additional $15.5 billion of three- and six-month bills on Tuesday because Monday is New Year's Day.
In late and even thinner dealings, the Treasury's benchmark long bonds, the 8 1/8 percent issue maturing in 2019, was being offered at 101 19/ 32, down 1 10/32, or $13.13 for each $1,000 of face value. The long bond's yield climbed to 7.98 percent, from 7.87 percent at Friday's close.
Among other representative Treasury issues traded in the secondary market, the 7 5/8 percent notes of 1991 fell 9/32, to 99 17/32, for a yield of 7.88 percent; the 7 5/8's of 1993 dropped 15/ 32, to 99 5/32, and a yield of 7.87 percent, and the long notes, the 7 7/8's of 1999, lost 27/32, at 99 20/32, and now yield 7.93 percent, compared with 7.80 percent at Friday's close.
Leif H. Olson, who heads a money management and consulting firm bearing his name in New Canaan, Conn., said: ''The sharp drop in prices of Treasury paper is being attributed in some quarters to the rise in fuel prices, by others to the weakness of the dollar. But the fact is we had a very thin market today, which always lends itself to exaggerated price moves.''
 
'Winter Will End'
Asked about fears that the uncommonly cold early winter weather was causing oil prices and inflation to rise, Mr. Olson replied: ''While fuel oil is not as elastic a commodity as orange juice, winter will end and many people will have to switch to other juices. We don't believe the Federal Reserve is overly concerned about transitory rises in the Consumer Price Index or any other yardstick of inflation.''
What does concern Mr. Olson, who was formerly with the Federal Reserve, is that rising energy and food costs, however temporary, will force many consumers to spend less on other goods, thus further weakening the economy. In any event, the inflation fears and weakness of the dollar did not impress the gold market, where prices fell by more than $5 an ounce.
Given the rise in key Japanese interest rates over the weekend and the recent decline in the dollar against major foreign currencies, Mr. Olson noted: ''While a weakening dollar is bothersome, we should not fear any massive unloading of dollars by the Japanese or anyone else. When Japanese financial institutions sell dollars for yen, the buyers are usually other Japanese houses exchanging yen for dollars.''
Following are the results of the Treasury's regular auctions of three- and six-month bills:

HEADLINE: Japan Urged to Lift Living Standards

BYLINE: By STEVEN GREENHOUSE, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: PARIS, Dec. 26

 BODY:
The Organization for Economic Cooperation and Development today praised Japan's strong economic growth, but called on Tokyo to increase its people's living standards to help the Japanese consume more and reduce that nation's huge trade surplus.
Noting that the living standards of the Japanese are low in light of the nation's industrial might and financial assets, the O.E.C.D. urged the Japanese Government to take several steps to raise living standards: reduce working hours, make more land and housing available and increase competition in the distribution sector to help make consumer goods more affordable.
In its annual report on Japan, the organization stated that even though Japan ranks fifth among industrial nations in per capita income, its people rank 10th in purchasing power, partly because of the inflated price of goods in Japan.
 
'Substantial Discrepancy'
''There is still a substantial discrepancy between the country's economic strength and the relatively poor quality of life,'' said the O.E.C.D., a Paris-based organization of 24 industrial nations that promotes economic cooperation. 
The O.E.C.D. criticized the clubby, closed nature of Japan's distribution system, saying it has artificially inflated prices, created obstacles to imports and helped keep Japan's trade surplus high.
The organization projects that Japan's current-account surplus will climb from $60.1 billion this year to $61.1 billion next year and to $68.6 billion in 1991.
''It is a political fact that the persistence of a surplus of the size of Japan's causes considerable friction between major trading nations and risks provoking protectionist measures in some countries,'' the report stated.
 
Domestic Demand
The organization praised Japan for stimulating domestic demand in recent years to keep growth strong as the yen soared in value. The yen's rise was expected to slow growth in Japan inasmuch as the rise was intended in part to slow Japan's export momentum by making its goods more expensive abroad.
The O.E.C.D. foresees robust growth of 4.5 percent in 1990 for Japan and 4.3 percent in 1991. That compares with the 2.3 percent growth the organization projects for the United States next year.
The report noted that Japanese workers work more hours each year than the workers of any other industrialized nation. According to the organization, Japanese workers put in 2,064 hours of work on average in 1975, but that climbed to a total annual average of 2,111 in 1988.
In Japan, the share of workers with two days off each week was only 30 percent last year. Although Japanese workers are entitled to 15 paid days off each year, they take only 7.5 days off on average. That compares with an average of 20 paid days taken off in the United States and 30 days in Europe.
Shortening work hours, the report said, may improve the welfare of the Japanese people, as well as ''make a useful contribution'' to reducing the trade surplus.
 
Obstacles to Imports
Regarding the distribution system, the organization said there are numerous obstacles to the entry of imports that inflate prices and discourage imported goods. It mentioned the distributors' preference for long-term trading relationships with suppliers, close links between producers and distributors and the atomistic structure of the retail sector. The United States Government has repeatedly pressed Japan to open up its distribution sector to make it easier for American companies to sell goods in Japan. In theory, that would help reduce the American trade deficit and Japanese trade surplus.
The O.E.C.D. strongly criticized the idea of fixing official targets for Japan's trade surplus or assigning shares for foreign suppliers in specific Japanese markets. Those ideas have been suggested by some American legislators. The O.E.C.D. said such policies would undermine free trade and lead to an inefficient allocation of resources.
The report noted that Japan had used its current-account surplus to invest elsewhere, most notably in the United States, which has contributed to the American trade deficit. It said that as these ''outflows increasingly take the form of direct investment'' in property and businesses, there ''are signs they may create frictions of their own.''
 
International Pattern
The organization said the Japanese trade surplus should be viewed as part of an international pattern of imbalances that if continued for a prolonged period might lead to a cumulative position that could disrupt world financial markets.
''For all these reasons,'' the report concluded, ''it is important for Japan's surplus in relation to gross national product to continue on a downward trend.''

HEADLINE: CURRENCY MARKETS;
The Dollar Falls Broadly While Gold Also Retreats

BYLINE: By The Associated Press

 BODY:
The dollar declined yesterday against most key foreign currencies in extremely thin post-holiday trading. Gold prices fell after rising in Asia. 
The financial markets were closed on Monday in the United States and in Europe in observance of Christmas.
Trading remained slow yesterday as many American traders decided to extend their holiday and most European markets remained closed for Boxing Day.
Traders said the market had little reaction to the Bank of Japan's decision on Monday to raise its discount rate - the interest charged for loans to commercial banks - to 4.25 percent from 3.75 percent. The move, which raises the value of the yen against the dollar, had been widely anticipated by the market, they said.
Nonetheless, the overall sentiment toward the dollar remains bearish as prospects for lower United States interest rates rise with more evidence of economic weakness, said Earl I. Johnson, a trader with the Harris Trust and Company in Chicago.
In New York, the dollar traded at 141.845 yen, lower than 142.35 yen on Friday. The dollar lost value against the pound, which cost $1.6265, higher than $1.62425 Friday.
Other late dollar rates in New York, compared with late quotes Friday, included: 1.6987 West German marks, down from 1.7070; 1.54825 Swiss francs, down from 1.5490; 1.16005 Canadian dollars, up from 1.15925; 5.8020 French francs, down from 5.8345, and 1,272.75 Italian lire, down from 1,277.75.
On the Commodity Exchange in New York, gold for current delivery fell $6.40, to $406.80 an ounce. The Republic National Bank in New York quoted a late bid for gold at $407 an ounce, off $6.75 from Friday.
Earlier, in Hong Kong, gold rose 40 cents to close at $413.85 an ounce.
Silver bullion settled at $5.512 an ounce on New York's Comex, down 4.8 cents from late Friday.

Rumania's most repressive controls on individual freedoms, the legacy of Nicolae Ceausescu, were removed by the new Government. Among laws reversed were a ban on abortion and a law requiring registration of all typewriters. Page A1

HEADLINE: AFTER NORIEGA: U.S. AND ROME;
Vatican Balks at Handing Over Noriega

BYLINE: By THOMAS L. FRIEDMAN, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Dec. 27

 BODY:
The Vatican appeared today to reject President Bush's argument that Gen. Manuel Antonio Noriega was a common criminal who should be handed over to the United States for trial.
The chief Vatican spokesman, Joaquin Navarro-Valls, told reporters in Rome that the Holy See was not inclined to turn over General Noriega, who took refuge in the Papal Nuncio's offices in Panama City on Sunday, because the church believed that his asylum request had certain legitimate political dimensions.
The United States, which attacked Panama on Dec. 20 with the capture of General Noriega as one of its primary goals, views him as a ''narco-terrorist'' avoiding prosecution.
 
Bush Shuns Clash With Vatican
Like most countries, the Vatican does not grant asylum or temporary refuge to criminals, but will do so for individuals fleeing political or religious persecution. 
President Bush, speaking to reporters in Corpus Christi, Tex., at the start of a six-day hunting and fishing vacation, said he still wanted General Noriega brought to the United States for trial on drug charges, and that he has ''made clear our preference'' to the Vatican. When apprised by reporters that the Vatican spokesman seemed to be publicly rejecting these arguments, Mr. Bush said: ''That complicates things if they said that.''
But the President avoided being drawn into any public criticism of the Vatican's position.
''How would you like it if people were negotiating and talking, and then somebody jumped up and said they were wrongheaded, especially at this time of the year?'' Mr. Bush asked. ''Especially since this is the Vatican?''
 
No Time Limit on Noriega Case
Mr. Bush added that he has put ''no time limit'' on how long he will continue to seek General Noriega, ''just like we didn't have a time set on when Noriega would no longer be in the field fighting.''
Tonight, speaking to a group of Bee County Republicans, the President stressed that he wanted to ''work with our friends in the Vatican and work with the new Endara Government'' to bring General Noriega to trial in the United States.
''I want to see this man, under indictment in this country, come to justice for poisoning children and people around the world,'' he said.
 
Release of Noriega Unlikely
The manner with which Mr. Bush was treating the Vatican's statement seemed be the first public indication of what many Administration officials had been saying privately: that whatever their legal case against General Noriega, it is most unlikely that the Vatican, with its long history of granting political and religious asylum, is going to depart from that tradition and put him out on the street.
Indeed, it is with the assumption that General Noriega is most likely to be dispatched to a third country that the Justice Department today filed legal papers with the governments of France, Switzerland, Luxembourg and Britain, asking them to freeze bank accounts where the Panamanian ruler is believed to have hidden millions of dollars in illegal drug profits.
Administration officials said they want to do all they can to freeze and seize General Noriega's foreign bank accounts to deprive him as much as possible of any economic resources with which he might foment trouble in Panama from exile.
 
'More Than a Criminal Case'
Speaking to reporters in Rome, Mr. Navarro-Valls was quoted by Reuters as saying, ''Based on my knowledge of international law and diplomatic procedures I cannot see any possible way that a nunciature accredited to a certain country, in this case Panama, can hand over to another state somebody who is in it.''
Asked to explain the differences between the White House and the Vatican over General Noriega's status, Mr. Navarro-Valls said: ''I don't want to get into the complex problems of General Noriega, but he had been for a time head of a government, had been for a time head of the armed forces. So there is something more than a criminal case involved here.''
Putting General Noriega out into the streets, where he would immediately be seized by United States and Panamanian troops, would be ''absolutely outside usual norms of diplomatic procedure and international law,'' Mr. Navarro-Valls said. ''I don't see how it could be done.''
 
Support for Papal Nuncio
Mr. Navarro-Valls said Vatican and American diplomats have been holding ''frequent, clear and cordial'' meetings in Rome. He said that the Papal Nuncio in Panama City, Msgr. Jose Sebastian Laboa, accepted General Noriega without prior consultation with Rome, but defended the move anyway. ''I have to underline,'' Mr. Navarro-Valls said, ''that the attitude of the Apostolic Nunciature in Panama helped in a very positive way to put an end to the conflict and to hasten the time of peace in a country with a high number of victims and suffering.''
General Noriega, he added, was accepted after he made ''a very serious commitment to help end the bloodshed. The developments of the facts show that he has succeeded.'' He did not elaborate on General Noriega's commitment.
Mr. Navarro said Pope John Paul II had been kept informed about the case but was not involved in the negotiations. He said that the Vatican actually considered its main negotiating partner in the case to be the new Panamanian Government of President Guillermo Endara, which had not yet made any request for General Noriega.
Tonight, Panamanian officials in Washington said that Mr. Endara sent a letter to the Pope today asking him to turn General Noriega over to American authorities. The Panamanians said that they had not yet received a response from the Vatican.
 
U.S. Pursuing Its Goal
Despite these arguments, President Bush insisted that the Administration was still doing all that it could to convince the Vatican to hand over the deposed Panamanian general. Asked if in fact he wouldn't prefer that General Noriega be shipped to a third country instead of facing a trial where he might disclose any Central Intelligence Agency information from the days when he was on the C.I.A. payroll, Mr. Bush answered flatly, ''No.''
''I think that's history, and I think that the main thing is that he should be tried and brought to justice,'' Mr. Bush told reporters upon his arrival at Corpus Christi Naval Air Station. ''We are pursuing that course with no fear of that. You may get into some release of certain confidential documents that he may try to blindside the whole justice process. But the system works, so wouldn't worry about that.''
 
No Calls to the Pope
Mr. Bush, who likes to pick up the telephone and call leaders directly in times of crisis, said today that he had not called the Pope or Monsignor Laboa in in Panama.
In Paris, Reuters quoted judicial contacts as saying that the authorities have frozen between $3.4 million and $4.3 million held in French bank accounts controlled by General Noriega. They said at least five accounts, in the names of Noriega and members of his family, had been frozen since Friday.
In Switzerland, the Justice Ministry issued a statement saying it had ordered a precautionary freeze of two accounts in Swiss banks in Zurich and Geneva after a request from the United States to freeze General Noriega's assets.

HEADLINE: AFTER NORIEGA: LATIN SHOCK WAVES;
MANAGUA ECONOMY HINGES ON PANAMA

BYLINE: By MARK A. UHLIG, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: MANAGUA, Nicaragua, Dec. 27

 BODY:
By deposing Gen. Manuel Antonio Noriega, the United States may end up gaining important new economic leverage over Nicaragua and Cuba, diplomats and business officials say.
For both countries, the officials say, the Noriega Government in Panama served as a major intermediary for evading American trade restrictions and providing access to a broad range of American-made goods, from machine parts to toothpicks. The fall of his Government could thus force costly changes across the spectrum of Nicaraguan and Cuban commerce, threatening new instability in both hard-hit economies.
The new Panamanian Government has made no formal decision about its future ties with either country, or, in particular, whether it will support American trade sanctions against them. But the mere prospect of new American control over the Panamanian economy has already sent shock waves through the region. And the threat of a change in Panama's economic relations has had special impact in Nicaragua, where even short-term economic setbacks could have important implications for the outcome of national elections scheduled for Feb. 25. 
 
Panama, the Clearing House
''As far as Nicaragua is concerned, there has already been a de facto break in relations,'' noted Juan Jose Medina, who edits an economic newsletter in Managua. ''At this point, we can't even get our people out of the country.''
Since an American trade embargo was imposed against the Nicaraguan Government in 1985, Panama has emerged as a central clearing house for Nicaragua's foreign commerce. Nicaraguan experts say the Government maintains an estimated 80 local front companies there dedicated to evading American trade restrictions.
To avoid American financial sanctions, Nicaragua has also used Panama as a base for its official banking, maintaining its principal Government funds there in private, dollar-denominated accounts.
At a retail level, the most visible of Nicaragua's connections to Panama is its growing system of so-called diplotiendas, or stores that permit customers to spend in dollars to buy high-quality American and European merchandise that is otherwise unavailable here.
 
Vital Source of Currency
First established as a special service to the foreign diplomatic corps in Managua, the Government-owned chain of stores has expanded dramatically in recent years, fueled by large quantities of dollars that are sent back to relatives from Nicaraguans who have emigrated to the United States.
With large American-style supermarkets and associated services that range from gourmet food shops to one-hour film processing, the diplotienda system is estimated to generate more than $100 million a year in sales. That sum breaks down to about $30 for every Nicaraguan citizen - roughly one full month's pay for the average Nicaraguan worker.
The system has been a vital source of hard currency for the Sandinista Government, and has provided an important, controlled means of satisfying consumer demand for high-quality goods that cannot be produced locally.
Government economists estimate that as much as 80 percent of the diplotienda system's inventory is purchased directly from Panama, and the country has no ready means of replacing that supply.
Pro-Government economists argue that Nicaragua, if it is willing to pay higher costs, could develop new supply routes through Guatemala, Mexico or South America within a matter of months. But they acknowledge that the delays involved would exhaust current inventories, which are believed to be sufficient only through late January.
They say that a resulting shortfall could pose a serious political problem for the Government in the February elections, which are expected to hinge largely on economic issues.
Foreign experts point out that any restrictions on Nicaraguan trade with Panama could have serious repercussions for any government ministries and quasi-official enterprises, many of which have developed their own wholly owned Panamanian subsidiaries to procure badly needed American goods and technology.
A strict enforcement of trade sanctions against Nicaragua could also prevent Copa, the Panamanian passenger airline, from stopping in Managua on its daily shuttle among Central American capitals, depriving Nicaraguans of their most important remaining means of regional air transportation. ---- Sandinista Warning MANAGUA, Nicaragua, Dec. 27 - In an unusually harsh radio message, the Ministry of Defense warned today that, if the United States were to invade Nicaraguan territory, Sandinista security forces would execute all Nicaraguan ''traitors'' who encouraged the American action.
''At the beginning of the Yankee intervention,'' the Defense Ministry declared, military and police units would ''carry out plans for the neutralization, trial and execution of all the most recalcitrant, traitorous elements that openly or covertly have incited the Yankee intervention.''
The message, read as a special announcement over national radio, was repeated twice without pause for emphasis. It appeared to underscore the Government's mounting alarm and frustration over the American invasion of Panama, and it provoked new concern about Nicaragua's political campaign process, which is to culminate in elections on Feb. 25.

HEADLINE: AFTER NORIEGA: REBUILDING;
Efforts Abroad to Help the Economy

BYLINE: By CLYDE H. FARNSWORTH, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Dec. 27

 BODY:
Panama faces the daunting task of rebuilding an economy ravaged not only by bullets and bombs but also by two years of economic war with the United States.
The Bush Administration has dismantled economic sanctions and is preparing both emergency aid and longer-range economic support that could involve donors like Japan and lending organizations like the World Bank and the International Monetary Fund.
Japan's interest in Panama stems from its interest in the canal, an artery for its cars, videocassette recorders, headphones and other exports to the Eastern United States and Western Europe.
After a series of inter-agency meetings on Panama this week involving members of the Treasury and State Departments, an American team is expected to fly to Panama ''in coming days'' to evaluate specific needs, a State Department official said. 
 
No Prediction on Cost
No officials will predict how much the aid might cost American taxpayers. ''It would be analytically misleading to come up with any number,'' one official said. ''It depends on what other donors do and on the public policy decisions of the Bush Administration.''
Asked for a broad estimate, he said $50 million would be too low and $1.5 billion too high.
To work with the American authorities in coordinating the aid, Panama's newly installed President, Guillermo Endara, has dispatched a Panamanian economist, Guillermo Chapman, to Washington.
Mr. Chapman, who is serving as ambassador-at-large, has already participated in some of the inter-agency meetings of what is known as the Panama Economic Reconstruction Committee.
 
Unemployment a Key Problem
William D. Rodgers, a Washington lawyer working with Mr. Chapman, identified unemployment, which is running at more than 20 percent of the labor force, as one priority problem for Mr. Endara.
Another high priority is finding accommodations for 16,000 to 25,000 people made homeless during the military operations.
Mr. Rodgers, a former Under Secretary of State for economic affairs, put at $1 billion the direct losses in housing, business inventories and capital goods resulting from the American invasion and subsequent looting.
But he said the Panamanian authorities had decided against extensive Government intervention through public works programs. Instead, the intention is to anchor reconstruction efforts in a revived private sector.
 
Role for U.S. Companies
American companies, which still have a major stake in Panama's economy, are expected to play a vital role in recharging it.
''We're starting to talk to companies about going back and restoring things to normal,'' a Commerce Department official reported.
Keith L. Miceli, executive vice president of the American Chambers of Commerce in Latin America, said he expected the American chamber in Panama to be a catalyst.
''We will be instrumental in urging members to retool and reinvest to get the economic recovery going,'' he said.
About 125 American companies operate in Panama, including the International Business Machines Corporation, the Xerox Corporation, the Eastman Kodak Company, Citicorp and the United Brands Company. United Brands exports bananas and is the country's biggest private employer, with about 14,000 workers.
 
Growth After Cuts Is Seen
Many of the companies, with the exception of United Brands, have reduced their operations. Citicorp, for example, closed two of its 11 branches, cutting staff by about 25 percent, to about 200 workers.
''Following recent events, we expect the local economy will stabilize and begin to grow,'' said Cynthia Stone, a Citicorp official in New York. ''We have a long-term commitment to Panama and will make every effort to meet our local customers' needs as business activity in the country picks up.''
Panama, which until the mid-1980's had a per-capita income more than twice the average in neighboring Central American countries, used to be a leading Western Hemisphere banking center, with deposits in the early 1980's reported around $50 billion.
Today, after blows to business and banking confidence by Gen. Manuel Antonio Noriega and the economic sanctions imposed in 1987 and 1988, deposits have shrunk considerably and have mostly been frozen.
 
Banks Set to Reopen
Panama's banks, which have been closed since the start of last week, are expected to reopen Thursday for limited business.
But bank officials here said a return to normalcy would require major infusions of cash and credit in Panama's banking system.
As one specialist at the Inter-American Development Bank put it: ''It is essential to build up credit both for consumption and production in agriculture and industry. The credit has to come from external sources because there is no money in the economy.''
Despite the economic dislocation, Panama's efforts at rebuilding are still likely to be easier than those of most countries of Eastern Europe.
With just 2.3 million inhabitants, Panama is smaller and more manageable than a country like Poland, with 37 million people.
In the reconstruction efforts of Eastern Europe, currencies like the zloty of Poland must still be made convertible into Western money to ease trade and other transactions with Western countries. Panama, on the other hand, has used the American dollar as its local currency for years.
 
A Sense of Responsibility
While there is strong support in Congress and the Bush Administration for helping Eastern Europe, the fact that the United States itself must share some of the responsibility for Panama's troubles has made Washington even more willing to help that country.
''It's only common sense and justice that our first obligation be to Panama,'' said Robert A. Friedlander, Republican chief counsel on the Senate Foreign Relations Committee. ''We have a responsibility to clear up that difficulty first.''
To try to restart Panama's economy, the Treasury has begun to release some of the $375 million in Panamanian assets that the United States froze under sanctions by the Reagan Administration against the Noriega regime in April 1988.
In 1987 Congress voted to cut off virtually all economic and military aid to Panama.

HEADLINE: U.S. Plans to Stop Paying Fines for Nuclear Arms Plant Operators

BYLINE: AP

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Dec. 27

 BODY:
Within a few months the Energy Department plans to end its decades-old practice of paying all bills, including environmental fines and other penalties, incurred by the companies that run the nation's 17 nuclear weapons plants, department officials say.
Under the plan, the Government would continue paying normal operating expenses, as well as the base fees and bonuses that constitute these contractors' profits. But for the first time since nuclear arms production began in the 1940's, most costs resulting from negligence by the contractors would be borne by them instead of taxpayers. 
The new policy would apply to any future acts of negligence by the contractors, not to any costs they may have incurred for negligence in the past. It would be instituted as part of the regular periodic negotiations in which the Energy Department and the contractors set the level of performance bonuses.
The change in policy comes at a time when the department has been under attack in Congress for accepting liability for criminal penalties, fraudulent losses and other questionable costs of the contractors.
 
Vital Issue of Liability
The issue of liability is important because the plants have severe environmental problems, and some continue to violate environmental laws.
Stephen A. Wakefield, the general counsel of the Energy Department, said in an interview last Friday that the decision to end blanket indemnification for the plant operators would be formally announced next month and that it could become effective by late spring.
In exchange for assuming a bigger share of the financial risk of operating the weapons plants, the contractors will be offered bigger bonus payments for excellent work, Mr. Wakefield said.
He declined to say how much extra bonus money would be made available, but he said ''it would not be unreasonable'' to think current fees might be doubled.
A 15 percent increase will be applied to the bonus payments across the board to adjust for inflation, Mr. Wakefield said, and increases beyond that will reflect the department's desire to provide more incentive for excellent performance.
 
Fees for Operating Plants
Typically the companies can earn several million dollars a year for operating the plants. For example, Westinghouse Electric Corporation, which holds contracts to run several of the plants, earned $3.9 million in bonus fees from April through September for operating the Savannah River nuclear plant near Aiken, S.C.
While stressing that some details of the planned changes had not been worked out, Mr. Wakefield said there are already varying levels of concern among the contractors.
''A couple of them have said, 'Well, this is one more thing we have to consider in - deciding do we want to be in this business,' '' he said, adding that so far, none has indicated it will withdraw as a result of the changes.
He cited several examples of circumstances under which the department would no longer reimburse the contractors. Among them were environmental fines, and related legal costs, stemming from actions by the contractor that could reasonably have been avoided; damage to Government property as a result of negligence, and damage to third parties, including people and property outside the plant, as a result of negligence by the contractor.

HEADLINE: Washington Talk;
Some Need Crystal Ball To Peer Into the Present

BYLINE: By ROBERT D. HERSHEY Jr., Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Dec. 27

 BODY:
In economics, as in other spheres, it is the simplest questions that are often the hardest to answer.
Take, for example, the No. 1 economic question of the day: Is there going to be a recession?
The simple answer, of course, is yes. Inevitably. Sooner or later the expansion that has just entered its eighth year will simply come to an end. 
In all likelihood, this will more or less coincide with a Commerce Department report that the real gross national product, the nation's total output of goods and services adjusted for inflation, has contracted for the second quarter in a row.
But the formal designation of a recession is another matter. This will take place when the National Bureau of Economic Research, a private organization that is the semiofficial arbiter of recessions, decides that the nation was in a recession. And it is very possible this will not happen until after the worst effects are over.
It was not until July 1988, for instance, that the Commerce Department concluded that the spring quarter of 1986 was really down instead of up. The summer of 1986 was also weaker than had been thought at the time, but the revised figure remained positive and recession was avoided. But that is the simple answer. What people really want to know when they ask about recession is whether there will be one soon, say in 1990.
This is the hard question, the kind that prompts economists to offer an assortment of self-deprecating one-liners like, ''Give them a number or a date but never both,'' and ''If you must forecast, forecast often - and not about the future.''
Even predicting the present or the immediate past poses not inconsiderable risks, what with all the big revisions the Government has been making in many of its figures (in August, for example, one learned that retail sales for May were up substantially instead of slightly down).
Yesterday, the long-bubbling issue of apparent decline in the quality of the official data was raised again, this time by Representative Lee H. Hamilton, an Indiana Democrat who heads the Joint Economic Committee. Citing budget cuts for the slippage, Mr. Hamilton declared, ''The deterioration of Government statistics is a matter of increasing concern among members of the academic and professional communities.''
But frustrating as this may be, statistical inadequacy is not the main reason it is so hard to predict even the near-term economic future with accuracy. The honest answer is that like the stock market, the economy cannot be completely fathomed even by the brightest people using the most advanced computer models. Alan Greenspan, an esteemed economist who now heads the Federal Reserve, cannot always do it. Nor can your stockbroker or bartender, though they may not yet realize or admit their limitations.
The ever-changing relationships of myriad factors in the economy are too complex, and too much depends on a mercurial psychology and on uncontrollables like foreign actions or natural disasters like drought.
In recent months there has been overwhelming evidence of virtual stagnation in manufacturing. So last Friday the Government reported the year's biggest jump in orders for durable goods. Housing has been so weak that party conversation in the Northeast is no longer about real estate coups but rather horror stories of price declines and unsold property. So today the National Association of Realtors reported the year's biggest jump in sales of existing homes.
Predicted disasters, economists note, have a way of never occurring. On the other hand, recessions - once a euphemism for depression but now frightening enough in their own right - tend to come on when they are least expected, and very rapidly.
Still, economists will continue to make predictions, hedging as best they can. Drexel Burnham Lambert Inc., for example, says, ''There are several alternative outcomes which are possible for the U.S. economy in 1990.'' It then lists various possibilities, ranging from actual recession, to a slowdown that falls short of recession, to an inflationary boom.
And so on Friday, when the Government publishes the latest reading of the Composite Index of Leading Indicators, its main predictive index for the economy, one mustn't take it too seriously. It does predict most recessions. But it also predicts many that never occur.

HEADLINE: Florida Growers Rush To Save Frozen Crops

BYLINE: By JEFFREY SCHMALZ, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: MIAMI, Dec. 27

 BODY:
When the temperature plummeted into the low 20's over the weekend, making much of Florida colder than Anchorage, Ben Abbitt prayed for warmer weather to save the 7,000 acres of oranges owned by him and 250 other members of the Haines City Citrus Growers' Assocation.
But the sun came too late. For two days in a row, the oranges were frozen solid. And now Mr. Abbitt and hundreds of other Florida citrus growers, who produce 70 percent of the orange juice consumed in the United States, are reversing their prayers, asking for cool weather, not warm. 
With the fruit already damaged, their best hope is that cool air will slow its rotting, so they can get it to processors in time to make juice. But it will take weeks to pick all the damaged oranges and the processors are already backed up, leaving much of the Florida citrus industry in a race against time and temperature.
 
Quarter of Crop Lost
''I'd love to be able to dial upstairs and have 40-degree nights and 50-degree days,'' Mr. Abbitt said. But as he spoke, temperatures were already beginning to climb into the 60's.
Some state officials estimate that 25 to 30 percent of the orange crop will be lost in this state where the crop's wholesale value is about $3.8 billion a year. But growers say they cannot estimate the damage until they see how many oranges make it to processing plants. They add that they will not know until spring how much damage has been done to the orange trees themselves.
For consumers, the freezing temperatures will almost certainly lead to an increase in the price of fresh oranges. Price increases for orange juice, however, will be kept down by imports from Brazil.
Here in South Florida, below the main citrus belt, temperatures in the 30's have caused extensive destruction to vegetable farms. Farmers reported damage that ranges from 25 percent to 100 percent of their crops of celery, lettuce, tomatoes, beans and squash.
 
'Little Bald Heads'
''The wrapper leaves are falling off the heads of lettuce,'' said Frank Teets, a salesman for South Bay Growers. ''It looks like little bald heads sticking out of the rows.''
The loss of the vegetable crops means that as many as 50,000 migrant farm workers face the prospect of no work at all for several months.
''They'll bail out the farmers,'' said Greg Schell, a lawyer who represents migrant workers. ''But the farm worker will get none of that.''
He added that many workers would not be eligible for unemployment compensation because some growers had not contributed to the fund. ''They somehow survive,'' he said of the migrant workers. ''I don't know how they do it.''
 
Recovery Just Beginning
For the orange industry, the destruction comes at an especially bad time. Florida was just beginning to regain its share of the market in the face of competition from Brazil. In 1985, 50 percent of the orange juice consumed in the United States was coming from Brazil. In the last year, the figure dropped to 30 percent.
And the destruction comes as the citrus industry here had just recovered from two other severe freezes this decade. Because of the freezes, the citrus belt has been moving south, concentrating in central Florida instead of slightly to the north.
''But there's only so far south we can go,'' Mr. Abbitt said. ''We're limited in terms of the amount of land available, the cost, the quality of the land.''
Oranges begin to be damaged when the temperature drops to below 28 degrees for four hours or more. In many areas of Florida over the weekend, the thermometer dropped to the low to mid-20's for two days.
 
Still Usable for Juice
Damaged oranges are unacceptable for sale as fresh fruit. But if they can be transported to the processor in time, they may still be used for making juice concentrate. Ninety-four percent of Florida's oranges usually end up being used that way.
Growers no longer focus on saving the fruit, devoting their efforts to saving the trees, which is more important economically in the long run.
In Haines City, about 60 miles east of Tampa, Mr. Abbitt and the other members of the citrus growers' association fought with a mix of old-fashioned pluck and new technology. Although only 5 percent of Florida citrus growers still use the diesel-fired heaters known as smudge pots, some members of the Haines City group, which is 80 years old, continue to rely on them.
 
Dirt as Insulation
Others did what is called ''banking the trees,'' piling up dirt around their bases and trunks to act as insulation. Most rely on ''microjets,'' small underground nozzles that bathe the tree roots in currents of water to prevent their freezing.
Nearby, Bob McLean, the head of J. E. McLean and Sons, a grower and harvester whose crop is 75 percent oranges and 25 percent grapefruit, said, ''We're picking frantically.''
Mr. McLean is drawing on about 100 pickers who are available because the strawberry crop in the area, where they would ordinarily be employed this time of year, was 50 percent destroyed.
''I've been here all my life, the fourth generation,'' Mr. McLean said. ''And this is the worst 10-year period in the industry that I've seen.''

HEADLINE: ESSAY;
Office Pool, 1990

DATELINE: WASHINGTON

 BODY:
The originator of annual prognostication was Jonathan Swift, whose ''Predictions for the Year 1708'' confidently named ''the great actions and events of next year particularly related, as they will come to pass. Written to prevent the people of England from being further impos'd on by vulgar almanack-makers.''
The great satirist quit after the first year; not me. Guesswork in this space has become one of the hoariest journalistic traditions extant - 16 years of error, never a day of doubt -and events foretold here last year included the fall of the Berlin wall. (Forget the rest.) To the crystal ball: 1. First Bush insider to find himself on the outside will be (a) John Sununu after his campaign to oust C.I.A. chief William Webster backfires; (b) Agriculture Secretary Clayton Yeutter after scandals rock his Commodity Credit Corporation; (c) cuff-shooting Joseph Verner Reed after some protocol gaffe; (d) James Baker, after repeatedly slamming into the everlasting Gates. 2. Major White House problem will be (a) major shootout at credibility gap; (b) plunge in Bush popularity at alarming economic prospects; (c) Sununu's press ambush of the Fed's Greenspan for worrying more about inflation than recession; (d) revelation of a secret deal at Malta; (e) Poindexter's threatened tell-all book. 3. Democratic front-runner in the 1992 sweepstakes will be (a) Mario Cuomo, who will not run again for Governor of New York; (b) the new Mayor of Washington, Jesse Jackson; (c) Senator Bill Bradley, after abandoning the snore-inducing third world debt; (d) ever-aging Senator Al Gore, heated by global warming; (e) Sam Nunn, already beating Wall Street bushes for financing. 4. Years,'' by Manuel Noriega. 5. Diplomatists concerned with the German Question will be muttering about (a) another Rapallo; (b) another Locarno; (c) another Tauroggen; (d) another Brest-Litovsk; (e) another Peace of Tilsit. (This is a hard one.) 7. As superpower dominion lessens, (a) Poles and Germans will argue about the Oder-Neisse line; (b) Hungarians will demand a return of Transylvania from Rumania; (c) anti-Communist Rumanians and Bessarabians will demand Moldavia back from the Soviets; (d) Finns will agitate for the Soviets to return Karelia; (e) The New York Times will grimly continue to spell Romania with a ''u.'' 9. The source of Mikhail Gorbachev's most job-threatening trouble will be (a) dissident Yuri Afanasyev; (b) Prime Minister Nikolai Ryzhkov; (c) populist Boris Yeltsin; (d) the K.G.B.'s Vladim Kryuchkov; (e) the Red Army's Ogarkov faction. 10. Best news of the year will be (a) the repeal of Article 6 of the Soviet Constitution; (b) the emergence of moderate Palestinian leaders; (c) the reality of the peace dividend; (d) the winning of independence by the Baltic republics; (e) the quieting of legalizers by progress in the drug war. 11. Worst news of the year will be (a) the sobering realization that many superpower interests are still in conflict; (b) multibillion losses in Federal credit and insurance programs beyond the S & L's; (c) the Islamic bomb; (d) big Democratic gains in the Senate. 12. The big geopolitical headache will be (a) quick German reunification; (b) the rush to a Start treaty to save a Gorbachev who may not be there; (c) suddenly expansionist Japan; (d) the Sino-Soviet conflict. 13. If you don't play, you can't win; no sideline snickering allowed. My own picks are: 1-b, 2-b, 3-a, 4-c, 5-b, 6-a, 7-b, 8-e, 9-b, 10-d, 11-b, 12-a, 13-f. I do this only to prevent you from being further impos'd on by vulgar almanack-makers.

HEADLINE: Fixing New York City: Needs Are Awesome

SERIES: New York Rebuilds; Battling Urban Decline - Second of two articles.

BYLINE:  By ALAN FINDER

 BODY:
While New York City has begun to dig out from decades of neglect, much rebuilding remains to be done.
The central tasks are fairly clear. The administration of Mayor-elect David N. Dinkins will have to give priority to the schools, bridges and highways, the sewage system and sanitation, many experts said.
But it is uncertain whether the city will have enough money to do the job, and whether it can devise enough new management strategies to get it done, said the experts, including some senior members of the new administration.
 
New Management Techniques
The needs are awesome. Eighty-three percent of the schools are in disrepair, according to a Board of Education study. Fourteen bridges are at least partly closed for repairs. More than 40 percent of the 846 bridges owned and operated by the city are rated poor or fair under the city's rating system, and need renovation. 
All but two landfills have been shut, and the sole remaining large garbage dump, Fresh Kills on Staten Island, could grow as tall as 50 stories by the year 2,000 unless, after years of delay, the city begins construction on five huge incinerators. Mr. Dinkins has called for a moratorium on building the first incinerator, in the Williamsburg section of Brooklyn, so that alternatives can be studied.
City and state officials have already created several new management techniques to try to address those serious problems.
The city's Department of Transportation, for example, has established a cadre of city engineers and construction workers to repair and maintain bridges. Transporation officials said that by using fewer outside contractors, they were able to save money and complete work faster. A year ago, twice as many bridges - 30 -were at least partly closed for repairs.
To speed school construction, the State Legislature last year created a new quasi-independent agency responsible solely for building schools.
But even if those and other management changes prove successful, New York may not be able to afford all the reconstruction it needs. The city spent $19 billion over the last decade to begin reviving the physical plant, and it plans to spend $57 billion during the next 10 years to put it in good condition.
The Mayor-elect's challenge will be to assure that the city can spend that much. Some people said its long-term fiscal problems will likely force Mr. Dinkins to scale back the rebuilding plan.
''There just ain't no dough,'' said George Sternlieb, the University Professor of Urban Studies at Rutgers University. ''I think the operational mechanisms are finally in place; the issue is what do you feed them with. There is no significant money coming from Washington and Albany, and I think the immediate human problems of the city are going to preclude putting more money into bricks and mortar.''
Others said New York could not afford to retrench. Paul Dickstein, the city's departing Budget Director, said the need to rebuild was so paramount that the new administration should consider raising taxes or reducing other spending, if necessary, to complete the capital program.
''Everything being done is virtually essential,'' Mr. Dickstein said. ''There is not much point in having street cleaners when there are no streets to clean.''
''New York City is going to be very well positioned going into the future, by having a very solid and well-built infrastructure,'' he said, ''and it is going to contrast with many other cities.''
Because the city finances the cost of its construction projects over many years, the deficit in the current operating budget does not pose an immediate threat to the rebuilding effort. But long-term fiscal problems would.
The city floats bonds to finance the capital program, and it repays interest and principal each year out of the operating budget. About 10 percent of the operating budget is now used for debt service, Mr. Dickstein said. In four years, as much as 11.5 percent will be used to repay capital debt.
Many experts expect New York's economy to remain static and social needs to expand. Under those circumstances, they said, it may be difficult if not impossible to maintain so large a portion of the operating budget for debt service. Many said the city would likely be forced to reduce the rebuilding effort or find new revenues to sustain it.
 
Treating Sewage And Trapping Water
A vital part of the future investment will be in the city's water and sewage systems, which have been the beneficiary of billions of dollars in construction over the last decade.
The first stage of a new $1 billion water tunnel is to be completed in 1992, and additional stages are scheduled to be constructed later in the decade.
About $1.5 billion will have to be spent in the 1990's to build large holding areas at all 14 municipal sewage-treatment plants to prevent untreated sewage from overflowing into rivers and bays during heavy rains.
The city will also have to spend another $500 million to compost or incinerate sludge, which it now dumps in the Atlantic Ocean. Congress has ordered such dumping halted by 1991, but municipal officials say they will be unable to meet the deadline.
A decision will also have to be made on another critical matter: finding new sources of fresh water.
The city's reservoirs now have a capacity of 550 billion gallons of water. Consumption goes up an average of 1 percent a year, largely because of the increased use of air-conditioners and other appliances that require large amounts of water. The long-term need for more water is independent of the occasional problems caused by droughts, officials said.
While planners have made no final decisions, the most likely alternative will be to tap the Hudson River, city environmental officials said.
 
Incinerator Plans Stymied for Years
No effort illustrates better how difficult it has become to build large public works than the city's plans for disposing of its garbage. In 1979, the Koch administration proposed to build eight large incinerators. Ten years later, construction has yet to begin.
''It's been a remarkable process, an astounding process,'' the Sanitation Commissioner, Brendan Sexton, said.
The plan has been delayed by environmental, technological, legal and political concerns. After years of studying and debating the plan, the Koch administration won approval from the Board of Estimate in 1984 to build five incinerators, one in each borough. The first is to be constructed at the Brooklyn Navy Yard in the Williamsburg section.
The proposal then survived three lawsuits. For the last four years, the city has been seeking a permit for the incinerator from state environmental officials. Twice in the last two years, municipal officials thought they were about to receive the permit - the last step before construction. Both times they were wrong.
The state's Environmental Commissioner, Thomas C. Jorling, said last year that the city had to improve plans for recycling garbage and for disposing of the ash produced by incinerators.
The Council then passed a bill last March mandating the recycling of 25 percent of the city's garbage. Mr. Jorling said last month that everything about the Brooklyn plant was now in order, except for the question of what to do with its ash.
The city hopes to resolve that matter within six months, probably by arranging to ship the ash to sites outside New York until a local disposal site can be prepared, said Vito A. Turso, a Sanitation Department spokesman.
But the saga is far from over. Mr. Dinkins said during the mayoral campaign that he would impose a moratorium of up to two or three years on building incinerators while planners studied whether more garbage could be recycled, thus reducing the need to burn it. And Mr. Jorling threatened last month to shut the last large city landfill, at Fresh Kills, in two years unless the city complied with his orders to clean it up.
The frustration has begun to show at the Sanitation Department. Mr. Turso described the proposed Brooklyn incinerator as ''the most litigated, most scrutinized waste disposal project in the history of mankind.''
 
A System 'Biased Against Action'
Environmental concerns are just one reason why it is so difficult to build. Many communities are reluctant to accept unpleasant public works like incinerators, jails and homeless shelters.
Legal and governmental safeguards also slow the process. Contract approvals are often required from a half-dozen or more municipal agencies, from the Department of Investigation to the Office of Management and Budget. The requirement to accept low bidders on city contracts helps guard against corruption, but also reduces efficiency because the most reliable contractors do not necessarily submit the lowest bid.
''The system is biased against action,'' said Mr. Sandler, the Transportation Commissioner.
He and others contend that the municipal agencies responsible for much of the rebuilding need more autonomy. He cited management changes, like reducing the work awarded to outside contractors, that have enabled his department to rebuild bridges and roads more quickly and inexpensively than expected.
Samuel I. Schwartz, the First Deputy Transportation Commissioner, noted one example: the Carroll Street Bridge over the Gowanus Canal in Brooklyn. The bridge had to be entirely reconstructed, a job estimated to take 5 years and to cost $3 million. It took a year, he said, and cost $2.5 million.
Mr. Sandler and others are urging the Mayor-elect to consider many more management reforms. But a different concern - money - is likely to dominate debate on the city's rebuilding effort over the next few years. Can it afford to finance $57 billion during the 1990's to finish the job?
Professor Sternlieb of Rutgers said Mr. Dinkins faced a daunting task, particularly since he could not expect much help from the state and Federal governments.
''The city's infrastructure problems are very real,'' he said. ''He will be trying to cope with them in a context in which environmental concerns are at an all-time peak, the capacity to get moving at an all-time low and the money that's around, fundamentally, is self-raised revenue.''

HEADLINE: Neighborhoods in New York Seeing Red Over Blue Videos

BYLINE: By MICHAEL FREITAG

 BODY:
In the last four months, at least 10 stores that specialize in selling pornographic videocassettes have opened in Manhattan. Three are in Times Square, where such merchandise is commonplace.
But four others have opened on Canal Street at the edge of SoHo. Another has appeared on the Avenue of the Americas in Chelsea and two more have turned up among the bistros and boutiques on the Avenue of the Americas in Greenwich Village. And in these communities, particularly the Village, some residents are furious.
''This was a real assault on our neighborhood,'' said Diane Whelton, a spokeswoman for No Times Square in Greenwich Village, a group formed to protest the opening of the video stores. More than 2,000 Village residents have signed the group's petition opposing the stores, she said, and dozens of people have joined demonstrations in front of the shops. 
Mrs. Whelton and other opponents contend that the store owners are test marketing neighborhoods to serve as the city's new pornography center now that Times Square is facing redevelopment.
The store owners maintain that they are just entrepreneurs who have spotted a new niche in the videocassette market. As the cost of the cassettes has declined recently, they say, the demand has risen, and customers seem more willing to buy the tapes in their own neighborhoods.
Mrs. Whelton and other critics insist that they object less to the tapes' content than to the way in which they are being sold - with large, colorful signs covering store windows, proclaiming: ''ADULT MOVIES, XXX!!!'' and ''X-MAS SALE!''
These opponents say such signs will give their community a poor image. And they say they fear that the shops will attract peep shows and other similar businesses to the area while scaring away other merchants.
''We are worried about the impact this kind of store could have on the economic health of the neighborhood,'' Mrs. Whelton said. ''The Village is having serious problems. We have stores that have been empty for more than half a year, even with rents declining.''
Judith Joice, the president of the Greenwich Village Chamber of Commerce, said most of its 500 members were opposed to the video shops. Ms. Joice is the co-owner of the Lion's Head, a neighborhood bar.
''We have a history of accepting just about anything in the Village,'' she said. ''But this is one step too far.'' The video stores, Ms. Joice said, are ''run by sleazy people with sleazy intentions.''
Ygal Mizrahi, who owns Crazy Fantasy Video at 333 Avenue of the Americas near Fourth Street, said the community's complaints are unfair and hypocritical. All he is doing, Mr. Mizrahi said, is selling tapes that have been available for years in most video-rental stores. And, he added, there are plenty of other places in the Village that sell pornographic paraphernalia.
The Pink Pussycat Boutique, which is just around the corner from Crazy Fantasy Video, at 161 West Fourth Street, has been selling ''erotic novelties'' for nearly two decades, Mr. Mizrahi noted.
Karl R. Paley, a retired doctor who has lived in the Village for 42 years, said the Pink Pussycat, as well as similar shops like the Pleasure Chest and the Loft, are not as obtrusive as the video stores. Dr. Paley is president of the Waverly Block Association, which has opposed the video stores.
''We have tolerated porno shops in this area for years, but they have been tolerated because they blend into the whole fabric of the Village,'' he said.
''We are perfectly aware of the First Amendment and do not think that we can censor pornographic stores,'' Mr. Paley continued. ''Our objection is with the appearance and presentation of these stores. They have loud and ugly signs that simply do not represent the kind of ambience that belongs in a landmark district.''
Mr. Mizrahi said he has heard many complaints about the large signs in the window of his store, but he refuses to take them down.
 
'They Are My Neighbors'
''After all, I have to cover the windows with something, or else the children can see in,'' he said. ''And if I put a blank piece of paper there, the store looks closed.''
In October, Mr. Mizrahi and several members of the local community board held a meeting at a restaurant near his store. He agreed to leave the door of the shop closed at all times, so passers-by could not peer in. He also agreed to remove fluorescent signs that the board had found particularly offensive.
''They will have no more problems with me,'' Mr. Mizrahi said. ''After all, they are my neighbors, and we have to live together.''
Mr. Mizrahi said Crazy Fantasy Video, which has been repeatedly inspected by the police, the Fire Department and other city agencies, has received all the appropriate permits. The store has a 10-year lease, he said.
But Fantasy Video World, just a few blocks away at 401 Avenue of theAmericas, at Eighth Street, lost its lease recently and will close within two months, Mr. Mizrahi said. He said the store is owned by his brother, Yoel, who now wants to get out of the video business.
''It's not the way he thought it would be,'' Mr. Mizrahi said. ''You have to put a lot of time into this business.''
 
Police Investigation
Ms. Joice of the Chamber of Commerce said she was pleased to hear that one of the video stores may soon close. But she said she was concerned that another will turn up elsewhere in the Village. She would like the city to pass a zoning ordinance banning such shops from residential neighborhoods, she said.
Ms. Joice said she had asked the police to investigate the video stores for violations of the obscenity laws. ''I am sure they are selling child pornography in there,'' she said. She did not offer any evidence.
Capt. Michael Murray of the Police Department's public morals division said his unit investigated the video stores in the Village after receiving complaints from the community, and it passed its findings on to the District Attorney. He declined to say what had been found.
The state's obscenity laws are very complicated, and convictions are extremely rare, Captain Murray said. What is deemed offensive in one community may be acceptable in another; these standards are ultimately determined by the courts, he said. But the sale of child pornography, which depicts minors engaged in sexual acts, is universally forbidden.
Mr. Mizrahi strongly denied selling child pornography or violating any law. Mr. Mizrahi, a 36-year-old native of Israel who moved to the United States 15 years ago, also denied owning any of the other pornographic video stores.
 
Rows and Rows of Shelves
If many of the video shops look similar, he said, it is probably because the owners are imitating each other, and because all the stores essentially consist of the same thing: rows and rows of shelves piled high with slickly packaged videocassettes.
William H. Daly, director of the Mayor's Office of Midtown Enforcement, which has closed dozens of illegal businesses in Times Square in the last 12 years, said he doubted that the video stores were related to the 42d Street pornography sellers.
The new video stores are probably not the offspring of the sex shops, but a sign of their continuing demise, Mr. Daly said. The sex industry in Times Square, he said, has been hampered by a change in social mores, a widespread fear of AIDS, aggressive enforcement of city ordinances and the advent of videocassette recorders and cable television, which bring pornographic movies into people's homes.

HEADLINE: Judge Thwarts Suffolk's Video-Terminal Law

BYLINE: By ERIC SCHMITT

DATELINE: HAUPPAUGE, L.I., Dec. 27

 BODY:
In a victory for Suffolk County employers, a state judge today struck down a county law that regulates the use of video-display terminals in the workplace.
The ruling came five days before an important provision of the law was to take effect, requiring all computer equipment and office furniture bought by the 170 large employers in Suffolk covered by the law to conform to county standards to protect terminal operators from discomfort.
Business leaders filed suit to overturn the law, the first of its kind in the nation, contending that the measure was an unwarranted intrusion that would discourage new businesses and force existing companies to leave. 
In his decision, Justice John Copertino of State Supreme Court ruled that the Suffolk County Legislature overstepped its authority when it approved the law in June 1988 over the veto of County Executive Patrick G. Halpin.
 
No Decision on Appeal
Justice Copertino said Suffolk had improperly legislated control over workplace safety and health standards that were already covered by state and Federal statutes, which the county cannot supercede.
''Though the legislation is well-intentioned,'' he wrote, ''the Suffolk County Legislature lacked the authority to enact'' the law.
The county's chief deputy attorney, Dennis E. Milton, said the county was reviewing the decision and would decide within the next week whether to appeal.
The law's sponsor, County Legislator John J. Foley, Democrat of Patchogue, said the ruling ''gives a devastating Christmas present to workers in the private sector in Suffolk.''
Business leaders, meanwhile, praised the decision as a first step toward mending a perception outside the region that Suffolk was hostile to economic development.
 
Adequate Eye Care
''We see this as a victory that recognizes the limits on legislative excesses,'' said James L. Larocca, president of the Long Island Association, the region's largest business organization.
Labor groups and experts on workplace safety argued that the law was needed to insure adequate eye care, lighting and other working conditions for employees who used the terminals.
The law applies to operators who spend more than 26 hours a week before the screen at private work sites with 20 or more terminals. The Suffolk law did not address health concerns about low-level radiations emissions from the terminals. The largest companies covered include New York Telephone and the Grumman Corporation.
The first provisions took effect last January, requiring 15-minute work breaks and special training for operators. The most controversial part of the law, a section that would have required employers to pay 80 percent of the cost of eye examinations and glasses for operators, was blocked by a preliminary injunction granted to four businesses by Justice Copertino last year.
When Suffolk enacted its law, many labor groups predicted that it would establish a model for states and municipalities. But the movement failed to gain momentum. Mayor Edward I. Koch of New York, for example, vetoed similar legislation on Tuesday, saying that he had not been shown compelling medical evidence that the terminals posed a serious health risk. That measure would have covered municipal employees only.
Experts on the workplace said, however, that many businesses are voluntarily adopting similar practices.
''The companies are doing it on their own to improve productivity,'' said Louis E. Slesin, editor of VDT News, a trade publication in Manhattan.
