HEADLINE: Town Needed People, So It Offered a Bounty

BYLINE: AP

DATELINE: ROLFE, Iowa, Dec. 27

 BODY:
Two years ago, hoping to save its businesses and its school, this Farm Belt community put out an invitation for new residents, offering a free lot and $1,200 cash to anyone who builds a house worth $30,000.
Although no one accepted the town's offer, the publicity it generated had the desired effect. About 70 people, attracted by reports of low crime and an easier life style, moved here, increasing the population by almost 10 percent. Their 20 children padded school enrollment to 190. 
Four houses have been built, although none by the transplants, who are happy to rent or buy existing homes at a fraction of the price they were used to paying.
''We paid $4,500 for it, plus $1,500 for the garage,'' Becky Roberts said about her 3,000-square-foot century-old house. ''In Sacramento, it would probably go for $300,000.''
To Mrs. Roberts and her husband, Gary, who moved from California this year for their retirement, this town about 80 miles northwest of Des Moines is just what she and her husband were looking for.
''We were thinking about retiring and moving to a small community, and one morning on the boob tube, here comes the story about Rolfe,'' she said. They visited, liked the place and decided to settle here.
 
Cars Don't Have to Be Locked
''It's real slow here,'' she said. ''People are genuinely friendly. If they call on you or visit, it's because they want to. You don't have to be suspicious of people at your door. You go downtown and find cars parked at the curb, running, with babies in them. In California, you would never leave it unlocked, let alone running with a kid in it.''
For that matter, a car has not been stolen here in three years, said the City Administrator, Dave Jochims.
Alcides and Guelly Mendoza, who came from Brazil by way of the Bronx, were tired of the rush and risk of New York City.
The move was especially good for their four children, three in school and an 8-month-old, said Mrs. Mendoza.
''I like it here,'' she said. ''Here many people look after kids. Everybody takes care of everybody. People here make me feel welcome.''
Until her husband found a job in nearby Pocahontas, Mrs. Mendoza received public assistance for the infant. When she picked up her last check this month, she thanked the welfare workers and added, ''We do not need any more.''
Other families have not been so quick to get on their feet.
Ron Walrod, director of social services for Pocahontas County, said he knows of about a dozen people receiving public assistance in Rolfe.
But Mr. Jochims said most of the newcomers are on their own.
''I know there are families who need assistance, like a lot of Iowans,'' he said. ''Whether we like it or not, these people are not disposable. This is a free society. We're concerned about the people who come here.''
The grain elevator is both the major landmark and the main employer in Rolfe, but there are ample opportunities for skilled workers in nearby communities, Mr. Jochims said. The county unemployment rate is 1.1 percent.
''So far, the businesses have been happy with the workers they've received and I feel good about it,'' he went on. ''People are moving to Rolfe to better themselves.''
After her husband died of a brain tumor two years ago, Penny Hollis, 31 years old, decided she and her four children, ages 3 to 14, needed to get away from New Hampshire.
''I saw this article in a woman's magazine and decided to drive out,'' she said about her move last summer. ''I couldn't get over the openness. I kept stopping the car and getting out so I could see how far I could see. I really didn't check out Rolfe very much. It was the land I loved. I put a down payment down on this house right away.'' But now she has reservations. ''I used to socialize all the time and now I don't know anybody,'' she said.

HEADLINE: Losing $2 Billion - An Accounting Quagmire;
The Lapses by Lincoln's Auditors

BYLINE: By ERIC N. BERG

 BODY:
As Federal investigators press their inquiry into the collapse of the Lincoln Savings and Loan Association, the biggest failure in the current savings industry crisis, a number of regulators, auditors and other experts say accounting and auditing safeguards also collapsed during the Lincoln fiasco.
The debate over the role played by the accountants who audited Lincoln's financial statements centers on one crucial issue: were Lincoln's auditors negligent in failing to detect the savings institution's financial shenanigans earlier, or were the accountants simply misled by Lincoln's management?
The answer is being pursued both by Government investigators and in a Los Angeles court, where the three national accounting firms that served as auditor for the California savings and loan during the 1980's are defendants in a class-action lawsuit. All three firms deny they have done anything wrong.
Regardless of the official outcome, Government officials, auditors and other experts agree that the accounting lapse was rooted in an extraordinary mixture of causes. For the accountants, it meant that traditional practices and rules no longer served as a useful guide. There were three main causes of the lapse:
* The sweeping deregulation of the once-staid savings-and-loan industry by the Reagan Administration. 
* Auditing rules that proved unable to keep pace with change in the industry.
* The fierce competition among accounting firms for the audit business of a client paying millions in fees.
For the accountants, it proved a treacherous combination. Under its aggressive chairman, Charles H. Keating Jr., Lincoln struck dozens of suspect deals, ranging from real estate speculation to ''junk bonds.'' The Government closed Lincoln earlier this year, and the financial rescue will cost taxpayers more than $2 billion. Yet as Lincoln was rushing toward collapse, the auditors nonetheless approved financial statements that now appear to have been seriously misleading.
Indeed, just as the savings industry debacle reflected a systemic breakdown of Government regulation, underlined by the forced resignation on Dec. 4 of M. Danny Wall, head of the Office of Thrift Supervision and its predecessor the Federal Home Loan Bank Board, the story of the Lincoln collapse suggests a fundamental lapse in auditing safeguards.
Some experts say the accounting breakdown in the case might have been inevitable. ''We should not be surprised that this happened,'' said John C. Burton, former chief accountant of the Securities and Exchange Commission and now a professor at the Columbia University Graduate School of Business. ''Whenever you confront substantial economic change in an industry such as savings and loans, you will find auditing problems.''
He added: ''Accounting rules may no longer apply, and auditors are asked to look into things with which they are unfamiliar. And there is evidence that the competitiveness of the accounting firms does increase the risk of auditing failure.''
 
Charges in Los Angeles Suit
The Los Angeles lawsuit charges that throughout the 1980's the three accounting firms that successively served as Lincoln's auditor - Arthur Andersen & Company, Arthur Young & Company and Touche Ross & Company - consistently failed to disclose their own misgivings that the savings and loan's financial reports were questionable or that the firms should have steered clear of so suspect a client altogether. The class-action suit has been brought by unhappy investors who bought the bonds of Lincoln's parent company, the American Continental Corporation.
''There would never have been a public offering of the bonds if the accounting had been correct,'' Stephen R. Steinberg, a San Diego-based attorney for the bondholders, asserted.
Lawyers representing the bondholders also contend that the nominally independent auditors were overly reluctant to press Lincoln about its questionable deals because they did not want to lose a big client. The fee for American Continental's annual audit was $2.5 million, roughly one-fifth of the annual billings of Arthur Young's Phoenix office.
All three accounting firms have denied the allegations and said they would be exonerated in court. They have also said that it was routine, after a financial disaster, for the aggrieved to sue the auditors, as the only deep pocket left.
 
The Arthur Young Audits
Lincoln's Reports Staunchly Backed
Arthur Young has been the accounting firm most under fire as a result of the Lincoln collapse. Arthur Young audited Lincoln and American Continental in 1986 and 1987 when, according to experts working with Federal investigators, Lincoln engaged in the most flagrant accounting improprieties, producing a series of deceptive financial statements.
During those years, the New York-based firm, which recently merged with another large auditor, Ernst & Whinney, to form Ernst & Young, issued unqualified opinions, certifying that Lincoln's financial statements and those of its parent company were accurate and reliable.
Moreover, Arthur Young's partner in charge of the account, Jack D. Atchison, seemed to drop the auditor's traditional stance of independence by repeatedly defending the practices of Lincoln and its corporate parent to Congress and Federal regulators.
 
Auditor's Letters to Senators
For example, Mr. Atchison wrote in March 1987 on Lincoln's behalf to Senator John McCain, Republican of Arizona, and to Senator Donald W. Riegle Jr., Democrat of Michigan and chairman of the Senate Banking Committee.
In his letter to Senator Riegle, Mr. Atchison wrote that Lincoln's unorthodox investment policies had ''led to unusually antagonistic positions and actions by the Federal Home Loan Bank Board toward Lincoln.'' He continued, ''This is difficult to fully understand because Lincoln's strategies have thus far proved successful and have turned an association headed for failure into a strong and viable financial entity.''
And in March 1988, Mr. Atchison appeared before the bank board's Enforcement Review Committee, giving what Representative Henry B. Gonzalez, Democrat of Texas and chairman of the House Banking Committee, called a ''glowing presentation of Lincoln's financial condition.'' Darrell Dochow and Rosemary Stewart, two of the board's senior enforcement officials, testified that Mr. Atchison's presentation figured prominently in their decision not to seize Lincoln until last spring.
 
'An Advocate of Its Client'
''Arthur Young became an advocate of its client,'' said Ronald Rus, a lawyer representing American Continental bondholders. ''Since when does the outside accountant - the public watchdog - become a proponent of the client's affairs?''
In response, William Gladstone, Arthur Young's chief executive and now co-chief executive at Ernst & Young, said the firm had never been an advocate for Lincoln but rather appeared before various groups to justify accounting decisions. Mr. Gladstone said Mr. Atchison's letter had caught him by surprise but that in any case Mr. Atchison was merely responding to questions posed to him by regulators and other officials.
''If we agree with a client on an accounting issue and a regulatory agency questions it, our responsibility as an auditor is to explain it,'' Mr. Gladstone said. ''That's not an advocacy issue; it's our job.''
Mr. Gladstone now says that he wished Mr. Atchison had never written the letters to the Senators on Lincoln's behalf.
Mr. Atchison left Arthur Young in early 1988, after heading the Lincoln and American Continental audits for two years, to become a top executive at American Continental at an annual salary of $930,000, far above what he earned at the accounting firm.
 
Arthur Andersen's Role
Signs of Trouble Unnoticed in 1986
Even in 1986, before Arthur Young took on American Continental and Lincoln as an audit client, there were early signs of trouble, but the warning signals went mostly unnoticed at the time.
In early October, Arthur Andersen had resigned as American Continental's auditor, citing a desire to lessen its exposure to liability from savings-and-loan audits in general. Arthur Andersen's resignation coincided with an examination of Lincoln by the Federal Home Loan Bank Board, which questioned its accounting.
Though it will be an issue in the Los Angeles court case, Arthur Andersen partners say they had no knowledge of the bank board examination at the time.
 
Little Hint of Problems
And there was little hint of problems conveyed to Arthur Young in October 1986 during a telephone conversation between Mr. Atchison and Arthur Andersen's managing partner in Phoenix, Jack A. Henry. Arthur Young had decided to make a run for the American Continental account, and Mr. Atchison was calling Mr. Henry to find out whether there was anything Arthur Young should know beforehand.
The firms have both said that Mr. Henry asserted Arthur Andersen had no reason to doubt the integrity of Mr. Keating, American Continental's chairman and chief executive. Yet, Mr. Henry did say that Arthur Andersen had become increasingly concerned over the friction that had been developing between Mr. Keating and the savings-and-loan regulators. But the Arthur Andersen partner denied having any big accounting disputes with American Continental, adding that any accounting debates it had with the company had been resolved in the accounting firm's favor.
In the highly competitive Phoenix accounting market, where all the big national firms maintain offices, American Continental was a prized client. And Mr. Atchison of Arthur Young, hearing little to worry him from the Arthur Andersen partner, pursued the American Continental audit account and won it. Mr. Atchison apparently concluded that the risks of American Continental's posing a problem for Arthur Young were minimal.
 
The Civil Inquiry
Andersen Denies Cover-Up Charge
Arthur Young had been on the job barely two months when it found itself with a client whose bookkeeping and internal accounting controls were being questioned.
In December 1986, the Federal Home Loan Bank Board, acting on information from savings-and-loan examiners, ordered a civil investigation to determine whether Lincoln, to conceal shoddy loan-underwriting procedures, had backdated loan documents and inserted supporting documents into loan files after the loans were made.
According to the investigators, much of this activity was done by employees of Arthur Andersen, Lincoln's auditor before October 1986. Arthur Andersen says that its employees were not involved in any ''file stuffing'' effort. The Federal Bureau of Investigation is examining the matter, including the accounting firm's involvement.
Investigators are also examining whether, under an arrangement completed in early 1986, Lincoln made interest-free loans to its corporate parent. If such loans were made, they would be a violation of Federal banking laws.
 
S.E.C. Notified in January 1987
In January 1987, the bank board notified the S.E.C. that American Continental may have been issuing misleading financial statements to support its sales of bonds. The S.E.C. has since begun its own investigation into the matter.
In terms of challenges to its judgment on complex accounting, however, Arthur Young did not face a problem until May 1987. That month, the Federal Home Loan Bank of San Francisco, Lincoln's primary regulator, completed its 1986 examination of Lincoln.
In a report that would eventually become the basis for two years of fighting between regulators in San Francisco and those in Washington, the San Francisco examiners recommended that Lincoln take a $130 million write-off to account for overstated profits and unrecognized losses. Since Lincoln's net worth - its assets minus its liabilities - was only $210 million at the time, carrying out the examiners' recommendations would have meant wiping out nearly two-thirds of that net worth.
 
Arthur Young Stunned by Report
The report stunned Arthur Young executives, who just three months earlier, in February 1987, had issued their own report on American Continental - a clean audit opinion indicating that the company's accounting was proper. Now, the San Francisco regulators were saying the accounting was anything but proper. Its professional judgment under attack, Arthur Young reviewed the facts but ultimately chose to stick with its unqualified audit opinion.
The San Francisco regulators' report ''didn't even add up arithmetically,'' Mr. Gladstone explained in a lengthy interview that took place recently at his office in New York. ''It came in pieces, and it had some details but no conclusion.''
While Arthur Young did not know it at the time, other public officials were growing increasingly concerned about the accuracy of American Continental's financial reports.
 
Special Meeting of Bank Board
In May 1988, for instance, the bank board held a special meeting to review American Continental's status. At that meeting, Kevin O'Connell, one of the board's senior financial analysts, complained that American Continental's reliance on ''self-created'' income had increased ''markedly'' since Arthur Young became the company's auditor.
At the same meeting, another bank board member, Lawrence J. White, complained that generally accepted accounting principles were not capturing Lincoln's true financial condition.
His specific concern was Lincoln's accounting for ''acquisition development and construction'' loans. Lincoln would lend developers money as loans and also money to pay the interest on those loans. And it then booked the self-financed interest payments as profit. While such accounting was permitted under generally accepted accounting principles, Mr. White complained that such bookkeeping made it difficult to judge the quality of Lincoln's loan portfolio.
''Given the accounting, it's hard to make good judgments,'' he told the bank board.
 
The Leventhal Findings
Phony Profits Seen In 15 Land Deals
For Arthur Young, however, perhaps the most serious challenge to its competency has come in the form of a study by Kenneth Leventhal & Company, a Los Angeles-based firm of certified public accountants that specializes in accounting for complex real estate transactions.
After American Continental filed for bankruptcy last April, Federal investigators hired Leventhal to review Lincoln's accounting for 15 big land sales, all of which resulted in American Continental's posting big gains on its profit-and-loss statement.
In short, what Leventhal argues is that all 15 deals were misleading transactions in which a profit never should have been reported. In each deal, Leventhal says, Lincoln entered into some form of related transaction that had the effect of either nullifying the deal or making its contribution to Lincoln's income far less than reported.
For its part, Arthur Young replies that the Leventhal report is mistaken on some facts and in its interpretation of the deals and that the accounting treatment of many of the transactions is open to varying opinions. ''Reasonable people can differ on this,'' Mr. Gladstone said.
 
Tax Payments Said to Be Diverted
The deals allowed Lincoln to report taxable income, according to Leventhal. It could then make cash payments to its parent, American Continental, in the guise of the subsidiary's portion of payments to American Continental's tax obligation. But in a racketeering lawsuit, regulators have argued that rather than going to the Internal Revenue Service Lincoln's tax payments were diverted to highly speculative ventures ranging from junk-bond deals to corporate takeovers.
''The 15 transactions we analyzed were accounting-driven deals, created for the appearance of profit,'' Roger A. Johnson, a Leventhal partner, told the House Banking Committee recently. ''They involved barren desert land, miles from the population center of Phoenix, and are likely to be undeveloped during this century. In economic reality, these transactions provided no profit but instead exposed Lincoln to huge economic losses.''
Here are four examples from the Leventhal report, along with Arthur Young's response:
* In October 1986, the U. S. Home Corporation purchased from American Continental 425 acres of Hidden Valley, an 8,000-acre tract of barren land outside Phoenix that American Continental had begun acquiring in 1985. While American Continental booked a $3.3 million profit on the deal, Leventhal concluded that it was phony because the sale included a separate provision requiring American Continental to buy back the Hidden Valley land, which it eventually did. Arthur Young's response: There was no repurchase obligation.
* In March 1987, Lincoln sold 1,000 acres in Hidden Valley to a company known as Westcontinental Mortgage Investment. While Lincoln booked an $11.1 million profit on the deal, Leventhal says the sale was a hoax because Westcontinental received the down payment for the purchase from its corporate parent, E. C. Garcia & Company, which Leventhal contends borrowed the down payment from Lincoln. Arthur Young's response: Documents prove that the loan from Lincoln to Garcia was not used as a down payment for the land purchase.
* In August 1987, American Continental sold 963 acres in Hidden Valley to a concern called Richmond American Homes, a subsidiary of M.D.C. Holdings Inc. of Denver, recording a $13.2 million profit. Leventhal says the sale was a sham because at the time that it was selling the land to Richmond American, American Continental was also financing another company's purchase of land from Richmond American. Since, according to Leventhal, Richmond American would not have had the down payment for its purchase unless it had sold its land, the net effect of the two deals is that American Continental provided Richmond American with a down payment. Under generally accepted accounting principles, that arrangement would have nullified the sale. Arthur Young's response: There was no evidence at the time suggesting that the two deals were linked.
* In a series of transactions beginning in May 1987, American Continental claims to have sold its interest in the profits of Rancho Vistoso, a 7,626-acre planned community outside Tucson, Ariz., for a $15 million profit. Leventhal argued that the deal was accounted for improperly because it involved American Continental's actually swapping its profit participation for land. Arthur Young's response: The profit participation was, indeed, sold - for land.
In its report, Leventhal emphasized that it was commenting only on American Continental's accounting and was not evaluating Arthur Young's audit work. Still the fact remains that Arthur Young approved American Continental's 1986 and 1987 financial statements without qualification, which included accounting that Leventhal now contends was flagrantly improper.
 
The Last Straw
Auditor Refuses A Lincoln Demand
By early 1988, Arthur Young and American Continental were arguing repeatedly over accounting issues. These ranged from the losses that American Continental was booking on its real estate to how quickly the company was recognizing profit. In virtually all instances, Arthur Young maintains, the firm's auditors encouraged American Continental to be conservative, ordering it to reduce reported profits by $20 million in 1987.
But Arthur Young officials said American Continental would not listen, eventually pushing them to a point where they no longer felt comfortable being associated with American Continental's financial statements.
The final rupture came Oct. 5, 1988. At a meeting at Arthur Young's Park Avenue headquarters in New York, American Continental officials learned that Arthur Young auditors would not certify American Continental's 1988 financial statements if they included a $55 million gain the company planned to book following an exchange of assets with Sir James Goldsmith, the British financier.
Despite a presentation on Lincoln's behalf by Sidney Davidson, a renowned accounting scholar from the University of Chicago, Arthur Young's auditors insisted that the asset swap was merely an even exchange that did not merit the recognition of gain.
 
Keating Incensed
Mr. Keating, American Continental's chairman, who also attended the meeting, was incensed. In a private session with Mr. Gladstone, Mr. Keating insisted that Janice I. Vincent, who replaced Mr. Atchison as the Arthur Young partner in charge of the American Continental account, be taken off the engagement. Mr. Gladstone refused.
Ms. Vincent recalled Mr. Keating telling her, ''Lady, you've just lost a job.'' But, she added: ''That did not happen. Rather, he ended up losing an accounting firm.''
On Oct. 13, Hugh Grant, an Arthur Young vice chairman, traveled to American Continental's Phoenix headquarters to ''discuss the engagement,'' Arthur Young officials said. It was at that meeting that Mr. Grant informed American Continental that Arthur Young would no longer be the company's auditor.
 
The Wisdom of Hindsight
Today, Arthur Young officials acknowledge that the American Continental engagement has been filled with unexpected turns, and probably should never have been accepted in the first place.
Yet that judgment assumes the wisdom of hindsight, Arthur Young executives note. Mr. Gladstone insists that once Arthur Young detected problems at Lincoln and American Continental, it stood firm and challenged its client.
''It's not like everything they had recorded Arthur Young waved a wand over and accepted,'' Mr. Gladstone said.
Late in 1988, Touche Ross became the auditor of Lincoln and American Continental, and it is still its auditor of record. In the Los Angeles lawsuit, the firm is charged with associating itself with Lincoln, whose integrity has been questioned for some time. The bondholders contend that Lincoln would not have been able to sell as many bonds as it did without Touche's involvement. A lawyer for Touche said he presumed the firm would defend itself. Garcia, E. C.

HEADLINE: Debate on 'Dollarization' Is Growing in Argentina

BYLINE: By SHIRLEY CHRISTIAN, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: BUENOS AIRES, Dec. 27

 BODY:
The return of runaway inflation and the collapse in value of the national currency have opened a growing public debate over whether Argentina should simply adopt the United States dollar as its money.
Proponents of ''dollarization'' think that such a step would reduce inflation to the minimal levels known by the United States, Japan and Europe because the Argentine Government would lose the capacity to print money to cover its immense fiscal deficits.
Contributing to the argument in favor of a dollar economy is that more than enough dollars are circulating in Argentina's underground economy or tucked away in safes and strongboxes to feed an official dollar economy, should it be created. $5 Billion in Dollars Argentines are thought to have about $5 billion in dollars inside the country, mostly in cash, and something in the range of $50 billion invested outside - representing one of the world's highest ratios of flight capital to the size of the economy. 
Private economists and financial analysts have been talking about the idea - pro and con - for several months, but remarks today by the Economy Minister, Erman Gonzalez, in a radio interview suggested the debate may have found its way into the Government as well.
Mr. Gonzalez said he viewed the idea ''with displeasure'' but said the country was being pushed toward ''dollarization'' by the recent run on dollars coupled with the reluctance of grain exporters to exchange their hard-currency earnings for australs, the local currency.
''Technically, there would be nothing wrong with total dollarization,'' Mr. Gonzalez said, ''but there is something wrong from the standpoint of a country that wants to maintain its autonomy.''
 
Other Effects Are Seen
He also said in the interview that converting to the dollar would probably be followed by efforts to align internal salaries and prices with those of more developed countries. But he added that such changes would be complicated by the less-productive structure of the Argentine economy.
''I am determined to continue defending the Argentine currency and monetary system,'' he said.
Argentina's exchange rate, officially pegged at 655 australs to the dollar until the Government freed the exchange markets two weeks ago, has soared in recent days. In currency trading here, it reached 1,200 australs to the dollar on Friday and 2,000 today, before dropping slightly.
Last February, the austral stood at 17 to the dollar before starting its spectacular slide. As the new Government was taking over in July, the austral had reached a crisis point, trading around 500 to the dollar, but the new Government managed to stabilize it somewhat for the last few months at the 655-austral rate.
The dollar idea has gained increased strength in recent days after the inflation rate began to soar again. It is expected to total 50 percent or more this month and even more in January. Prices are now marked up every day.
 
A Headache for Decades
Although it has been a headache for Argentina for decades, inflation this year has exceeded that in any previous year and the rate has been matched only in few other countries.
Inflation began to soar wildly last February as the economic policies of former President Raul Alfonsin foundered and uncertainty grew over the outcome of the May presidential elections.
Inflation hit a high of almost 200 percent for the month of July alone, the month President Carlos Saul Menem took office, but it then began to fall sharply after he imposed wage and price restrictions and set forth a program to reduce deficit spending, sell inefficient state companies and increase the role of private enterprise. The cost of living rose just 5.6 percent in October and 6.5 percent in November before taking off again this month.
Two other countries, Panama and Liberia, now use the dollar as their currency.
 
Move by Grain Producers
The sharp drop in the value of the austral against the dollar was linked in part to the apparent decision of big grain producers to stockpile, rather than to sell for export, the grain they have been harvesting in recent weeks.
Normally, the producers and exporters sell their grain for dollars, which they immediately convert to australs in the central bank, thereby providing most of the dollars to satisfy exchange needs.
But financial analysts said the leading producers and exporters had decided to sit back and wait because of a combination of lack of confidence in the Government and concern that the dollar would rise even more in the next few days.

HEADLINE: Existing Home Sales Rise, Spurred by Falling Rates

BYLINE: AP

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Dec. 27

 BODY:
Sales of existing homes, spurred by a big jump in activity in the South, advanced 3.2 percent in November, climbing at their fastest pace in 11 months, the National Association of Realtors said today.
The real estate trade group said sales of existing single-family homes rose to a seasonally adjusted annual rate of 3.59 million units last month, the best performance since sales reached a rate of 3.92 million units in December 1988. The 3.2 percent October-to-November sales increase followed a 1.1 percent decline in October. It was the biggest percentage gain since a 4.5 percent rise in August. 
Analysts credited declining mortgage rates for the upturn in sales activity. But they said that housing sales presented a mixed picture with some areas of the country, like the Northeast, hurting because of a rapid run-up in prices in the last several years.
 
Housing Recession Fears
Sluggish sales in high-cost areas has prompted some fears of a coming housing recession, but Norman D. Flynn, president of the realtors group, said the pessimists would be proved wrong.
''People who are predicting hard times for housing are not considering how much prices rose in high-cost areas over the past few years,'' said Mr. Flynn, who cited the Northeast, where the median price is up 85 percent from five years ago.
John Tuccillo, chief economist for the trade group, predicted that falling mortgage rates would continue to bolster home sales in coming months. The national average for fixed-rate mortgages dipped to 9.69 percent last week, down from a high last March of 11.22 percent.
The median price for homes sold in November edged up four-tenths of 1 percent, to $93,000.
In November, the sales increase was led by a 9.2 percent jump in sales in the South, where homes were sold at an annual rate of 1.42 million units in November. Sales were up 3.2 percent in the West to an annual rate of 640,000 units. The Northeast posted a 1.7 percent rise, to an annual rate of 590,000 units. Sales in the Midwest were down 4 percent, to an annual rate of 450,000 units.

HEADLINE: CONSUMER RATES;
Yields Fall In Week

BYLINE: By ROBERT HURTADO

 BODY:
Yields of taxable and tax-free money market funds surveyed by IBC/Donoghue's Money Fund Report declined in the week ended yesterday.
Donoghue's seven-day compounded average yield for a taxable money market mutual fund fell 4 basis points, to 8.19 percent, while the 30-day yield, which usually lags behind market activity, fell 2 basis points, to 8.22 percent. A basis point is one-hundredth of a percentage point. 
''On the short end of the market, seasonal year-end factors tend to raise rates around this time,'' said Walter S. Frank, chief economist at IBC/Donoghue. ''The Federal Reserve has eased slightly, and we should see the results of this easing early next year, including a probable decline in the prime rate. But on the other hand we have also had economic news that doesn't contradict a soft landing for the economy, or support the notion of a recession.'' For the next week or two, the whole range of interest rates will be higher than expected, he predicted.
 
Taxable Fund Assets Off
Assets of taxable funds fell $578 million, to $360.2 billion. IBC/Donoghue's analysts said institutional funds were up, but the $1 billion decline in consumer assets more than offset the rise.
The average days to maturity of securities held in managers' portfolios declined by one day, to 41.
Among the general-purpose money market funds with assets of more than $100 million that are surveyed by IBC/Donoghue's, the Dreyfus World Wide Dollar Money Market fund again had the best return, with a yield of 9.15 percent, up a basis point from last week and 96 basis points above the average yield this week.
Tax-exempt assets declined $215 million, to $71.4 billion, as the average seven-day compounded yield increased 4 basis points, to 5.88 percent. The taxable equivalent would be 8.16 percent for investors in the 28 percent tax bracket, and 8.77 percent for those in a 33 percent bracket.
 
Top Tax-Exempt Fund
The top-performing tax-exempt fund in the week was the General California Tax Free Money Market Fund, distributed by the Dreyfus Service Corporation III in Garden City, L.I. The fund posted a return of 6.52 percent, or about 64 points above the average.
By contrast, bank money market accounts were down a basis point, to 6.35 percent, according to The Bank Rate Monitor's national index, while the average yield for a six-month C.D. fell 2 basis points, to 7.93 percent.
Among certificates with longer maturities, an average one-year C.D. was at 7.95 percent, a two-and-a-half-year C.D. at 7.91 percent and a five-year C.D. at 7.92 percent. All were down 3 basis points.

HEADLINE: Market Place;
Tax Laws Spur Borrowing Boom

BYLINE: By Floyd Norris

 BODY:
IN the era of leverage, its founders do not reside on Wall Street, public perceptions to the contrary. The boom in borrowing can, to a considerable extent, be laid at the doorstep of the Congressional tax law writers.
The tax code has always encouraged corporate borrowing by making interest payments deductible, while it discouraged companies from selling stock by not allowing them to deduct dividend payments from income. In addition, changes in the tax laws over the last several years, while advertised as discouraging takeovers, in fact helped to promote them. The issuance of debt has grown even more attractive because of the way the corporate and individual income tax laws interact. 
Before 1982, corporations might have preferred to sell bonds for tax reasons, but individuals had good tax reasons to prefer buying stocks. A rough standoff may have resulted, argues Hayne Leland, a finance professor at the University of California at Berkeley. Still, enough buyers wanted to buy stock that stock was issued.
But those tax reasons for investors to prefer stocks were reduced in 1982 and eliminated by the Tax Reform Act of 1986, when the preferential treatment for capital gains was eliminated and individual tax rates were lowered.
Indeed, 1983 was the last year in which American companies issued more stock than they bought back. In that year, there was a net issuance of $31 billion, said Laszlo Birinyi, head of Birinyi Associates. Last year, there was a net reduction of $208 billion in stock outstanding, and in the first nine months of this year the shrinkage was $143 million.
The scope of the tax encouragements for leverage may be seen in the $22.5 billion leveraged buyout of RJR Nabisco Inc. That price represented a $9.9 billion premium for shareholders, compared with the market price before the company was put into play by the first offer, Mr. Leland notes in an article in the fall issue of California Management Review, published by the Berkeley business school.
Of that $9.9 billion, Mr. Leland calculates, $8 billion, or 81 percent, was justified by the tax benefits to the company from having tax-deductible debt, rather than nondeductible stock, as the major part of the company's capitalization. Of course, some taxes were paid on capital gains by selling shareholders, so the net loss to the Government, Mr. Leland estimates, is about $6.4 billion.
''For all the lip service paid to increasing efficiency, etc., the deal is based almost entirely on tax savings,'' Mr. Leland concludes. ''The bulk of shareholder gains came at the expense of the Internal Revenue Service.''
When the 1986 tax law was passed, many on Wall Street thought it reduced the relative attractiveness of leveraged buyouts, at least slightly. Specific provisions made it more difficult to bust up acquired companies without paying taxes, and the decline in the top corporate tax rate, to 34 percent from 46 percent, seemed to mitigate the nondeductibility of dividend payments. In effect, Uncle Sam was paying 34 percent of an interest payment, compared with 46 percent before the 1986 law.
But Mr. Leland, drawing on work of Merton H. Miller, an economist at the University of Chicago, argues that those numbers tell only part of the story. Stock market investors expect to get part of their profits in dividends and the rest in capital gains. Those who buy bonds at par and hold them get all of their income as interest.
Before 1986, a top-bracket individual paid 50 percent of any interest or dividends in Federal taxes, but only 20 percent of any capital gains. Thus, that individual valued capital gains more highly.
For an investor who expected to get a quarter of the stock profit from dividends and the rest from capital gains, the net result, Mr. Leland calculates, is that each additional dollar of leverage led to a 22-cent increase in the value of the company to its investors, before 1986. If one considered capital gains to be a more important factor, the figure would be smaller. It was even less before top tax rates were slashed in the 1981 tax act.
But by reducing tax rates in 1986 and eliminating the capital gains preference, Congress raised the benefit of substituting a dollar of leverage for one of equity to 34 cents, Mr. Leland calculates.
The disadvantage of leverage is that debt severely reduces a company's operating flexibility if business turns bad. ''A deeply indebted economy is a fragile economy, subject to collapse in any substantial downturn of business,'' Mr. Leland said.
To end the debt advantage, Mr. Leland said, the Government would need to cut the corporate tax rate, raise the individual income tax rate and reintroduce a tax advantage for capital gains. That prescription is politically unlikely, to say the least.
As a result, the odds are that the leveraging of American business will continue until the lenders are no longer willing to put up the money. And that time may not come until enough leveraged companies have been forced to default.

HEADLINE: World Growth Outlook for '90

BYLINE: By The Associated Press

 BODY:
World economic growth will continue next year, but only barely, a business research group reported yesterday.
The Conference Board's composite leading index for 11 leading industrial countries is inching up at an annual rate of 1 percent, down from 4 percent six months ago and 5 percent a year ago. The leading index is intended to foretell economic activity.
''Throughout the industrial world, the outlook for economic expansion is not very exciting,'' said Edgar R. Fiedler, vice president and economic counselor for the group. ''Although neither a recession nor an inflationary boom is impossible in the months ahead, neither seems probable.''
One of the few countries with any vigor is Taiwan. Its leading economic index is rising at an 8 percent annual pace, the same as three months ago and is up slightly from the 7 percent rate reported six months ago.
Among the other countries included in the Conference Board's international economic scoreboard, the United States index is rising at a rate 1 percent, compared with the 3 percent released a year ago.
Japan's rate is also 1 percent, compared with 8 percent a year ago, and West Germany's rate is 5 percent, up from 4 peercent.

HEADLINE: CREDIT MARKETS;
Treasury Bill Rates Up Slightly

BYLINE: By H. J. MAIDENBERG

 BODY:
The discount rates on Treasury bills posted moderate gains yesterday, but prices of Government couponed issues were largely unchanged in light trading.
With most primary dealers in Treasury securities having closed their books for the year, what business there was consisted of trying to reduce inventories in a market with few buyers.
''The problem is that everyone in the Street is trying to reduce their long positions at a time when there are few buyers around,'' one dealer said. ''Given a situation where perhaps six of the 40 primary dealers in Government securities will end 1989 in the black, we can't blame our managers for insisting that we square our positions and, in effect, close our books for the year.'' 
 
One-Point Jump in Funds Rate
Not even a sharp one-point jump in the Federal funds rate, which banks charge each other for temporary loans, ruffled the market or influenced prices. Normally, any sharp move in the funds rate would have an immediate impact on short-term interest rates and later on all rates because the funds are the considered the bedrock cost of credit and often a signal of Federal Reserve intentions.
Nor did the Fed's aggressive efforts to add reserves to the banking system affect this basic cost of credit. The reserves were added through systemwide Fed overnight repurchase agrreements.
''The reason the market did not react to the 9 1/4 percent funds rate or the Fed's efforts to add reserves was the technical nature of the crunch and the remedies the Fed applied,'' said William V. Sullivan Jr., senior vice president at Dean Witter Reynolds. ''Today was not only a time of seasonal pressures on bank reserves, but also the end of the two-week banking maintenance period.''
While many banks balanced their accounts last Friday, Mr. Sullivan said, a sizable number apparently did not and had only two days to do so before the end of business today. This caused a frenzied scramble for Federal funds, which produced an extraordinary rise in this rate.
This is often the case every other Wednesday, when the maintenance period ends. It is so called because banks are required to maintain a certain ratio of reserves to deposits with the Federal Reserve. A day or so before this period ends, or even on the last day, banks that find themselves short of reserves borrow the needed funds from banks with surplus reserves. The cost of these overnight loans, known as Federal funds, also determines a wide range of other interest rates, such as the interest Treasury securities dealers pay to finance their inventories.
The funds closed at 9.5 percent after trading at 9.25 percent for most of the session. The funds have been trading at around 8.25 percent in recent days.
''Given the usual holiday pressures on all sectors of the credit market, we expect the Fed funds to stay high for the rest of this week and perhaps well into next week,'' Mr. Sullivan said. ''Meanwhile, the Treasury securities market will also remain semi-comatose until after New Year's Day. Not even a relatively strong overnight rally in Tokyo helped our market.''
Steven R. Ricchiuto, chief economist at Barclays de Zoete Wedd, said that ''those who expect the Fed to push rates down still have a long wait.'' He added: ''For one, the important economic statistics for December, such as the employment numbers and price indexes, will be greatly distorted by the weather-induced surge in energy and food costs, as well as the return of many strikers to the labor force. The earliest we expect the Fed to act, if at all, is after the preliminary report on the fourth-quarter gross national product is released on Jan. 26.''
 
Rate News Is Negative
Indeed, the only rate news yesterday was negative: The U.S. Trust Company announced that it had raised its broker loan rate by a half-point, to 10 percent, effective immediately. But the Bankers Trust Company, the only other lender to brokers that discloses its loan rate, held its rate at 9.5 percent.
Meanwhile, in late trading, the Treasury's bellwether long bonds, the 8 1/8 percent issue maturing in 2019, was marked up 3/32, at 101 21/32, with the yield easing a basis point, to 7.97 percent.
Among other closely watched maturities, the 7 7/8's of 1999 was up 1/32, at 99 21/32, for a yield of 7.92 percent; the 7 5/8's of 1993 were unchanged at 99 5/32, with a yield of 7.87 percent, and the 7 5/8's of 1991 lost 1/32, to 99 17/32, with a yield of 7.88 percent.
At the short end of the Treasury market, the discount rate on the 90-day bills fell seven basis points, to 7.70 percent; the six-month bills lost six basis points, to 7.59 percent, and the one-year bills were off a basis point, at 7.29 percent.

HEADLINE: CURRENCY MARKETS;
Dollar Off in Thin Trading; 19-Month Low Against Mark

BYLINE: By The Associated Press

 BODY:
The dollar drifted mostly lower in thin trading yesterday, dipping to its lowest level since the spring of 1988 against the West German mark.
Currency dealers said the dollar remained under pressure from the continued strength of the mark and from expectations that United States interest rates will decline further because of weakness in the American economy. 
The mark has been on the rise for several weeks amid rapid changes in Eastern Europe. Many economists predict that West Germany's economy will be bolstered as more Eastern European countries, including East Germany, open their doors to the West.
 
Lowest Since May 1988
In late New York trading, the dollar closed at 1.6895 marks, down from 1.7090 on Tuesday. That is the lowest level since May 1988.
Although sentiment toward the dollar remains bullish, dealers said they expected trading to remain light in the two days before the long New Year's weekend.
In late New York trading, The dollar advanced slightly against the yen, trading at 142 yen, up from 141.85 on Tuesday. But it was weaker against the British pound, which fetched $1.6275, up from $1.6265 on Tuesday.
Most European financial markets were closed on Monday and Tuesday for the Christmas holiday.
Other late dollar rates in New York, compared with Tuesday's quotes, included: 1.5295 Swiss francs, down from 1.54525; 5.7600 French francs, down from 5.8020; 1.15735 Canadian dollars, down from 1.6005, and 1,263.75 Italian lire, down from 1,272.75.

HEADLINE: Banks' Bad Real Estate Loans Spur Rising Worry of Failures

BYLINE: By NATHANIEL C. NASH, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Dec. 28

 BODY:
Federal regulators and banking experts say they are increasingly concerned that mounting losses from troubled real estate loans could lead to a series of bank failures, straining the Federal insurance program that protects depositors' funds.
The regulators and analysts worry that in a severe economic downturn the losses at commercial banks might overwhelm the deposit insurance fund. That would force the Government to choose between raising insurance fees on the banking industry or rescuing some banks with taxpayer money.
The banks' real estate problems come on top of difficulties from other troubled loans, including losses on lending to developing countries and to other high-risk borrowers.
 
'Are of Real Concern'
L. William Seidman, chairman of the Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation, has issued stern warnings to bankers that real estate is ''an emerging area of real concern.'' The F.D.I.C. insures individual deposits up to $100,000 at commercial banks and is considered the front line of the Federal safety net. 
''I've been the Cassandra of real estate forecasting for some time now,'' Mr. Seidman told bankers at a meeting in New York this month. ''Unfortunately, events confirmed this view.''
Mr. Seidman and other experts say that in the last five years commercial banks have become alarmingly dependent on real estate loans. Such lending accounted for 25 percent of loans in 1985; it is approaching 40 percent this year. And two-thirds of all new lending is related to real estate.
They note that with $3.22 trillion in assets the commercial banking system is three times as large as the savings and loan industry. The size of the banking sector means that even a limited number of failures could be a drain on the insurance fund.
The weakness of some commercial banks with large real estate loans has been compared to the savings and loan crisis, but the industries are quite different. Savings institutions concentrate on real estate lending; banks have traditionally had much more diversified portfolios, lending to businesses and making personal loans as well as providing mortgages.
No one predicts that the entire banking industry will suffer the depth of trouble that shook the savings industry in Texas, and the experts do not expect a comparable regulatory failure. Bank regulators have a much better record than their savings and loan counterparts in detecting and limiting problems.
Still, regulators are getting tougher with banks in forcing them to set aside reserves for questionable loans.
 
'It's Pretty Damn Bad'
Many bankers are also worried by the effect of bad real estate loans, but most say the problem can be limited. ''It's pretty damn bad, and I hear the regulators are being extraordinarily tough,'' said Malcolm T. Murray Jr., chief credit officer for the First Union Corporation in Charlotte, N.C.
But Mr. Murray said he did not expect any big bank failures. ''There may be some hasty marriages,'' he said. ''But I am not sure the picture is quite as bleak as it has been painted.''
Charles T. Doyle, chief executive of the Gulf National Bank in Texas City, Tex., added: ''I am not overly gloomy. It is not anywhere near the kind of problem we were faced with in Texas.''
Some regulators, among them Robert L. Clarke, the Comptroller of the Currency, are taking a somewhat reassuring tone. They have announced new computer monitoring procedures and systems aimed at detecting problems much earlier at banks exposed to real estate losses.
Yet besides Mr. Seidman, some respected members of Congress on banking matters are also deeply concerned. ''You have a financial system that is at risk, and it is extremely serious,'' said Representative Jim Leach, Republican of Iowa.
 
Two Things Needed
Robert E. Litan, a senior fellow and banking specialist at the Brookings Institution in Washington, said two things were needed ''to turn the banking problem into one of the magnitude of the thrifts.'' In his view, ''you need a moderate to significant recession and a reluctance by Congress to put new money into the F.D.I.C. and allow a lot of insolvent institutions to stay open.''
At this point the F.D.I.C. can easily absorb losses from small failures. But the failure of only a few large banks could cost the fund dearly.
If the insurance fund, which now has about $14 billion, is run down, pressures would first build on the banks to pay higher insurance premiums. Later, Congress would be likely to be asked to approve more money for the fund - money that, as in the savings bailout, would come from taxpayers.
Some analysts have wondered if Mr. Seidman is trying to prepare the industry for what he sees as the inevitable increases in deposit insurance premiums that his agency was empowered to impose under the savings and loan bailout legislation.
''It is conceivable that even a moderate deterioriation could have debilitating effects on the F.D.I.C.,'' said R. Dan Brumbaugh, a financial consultant in San Francisco.
 
A Growing Dependence
What is troubling many experts, including Mr. Clarke, the Comptroller, is the growing dependence on real estate lending over the last half decade.
In the Northeast, the region with the most new real estate lending, many loans went to developers of condominiums and apartment buildings - financing that is always larger and riskier than single-family mortgages - and were issued by larger regional banks. Until recently, the big regional banks were considered the new wave of banking, replacing the huge international banks, like Chase Manhattan, Citibank and Manufacturers Hanover.
The seriousness of the problem in the Northeast seems to have taken even some top officers of regional banks by surprise.
Senior officials at the Bank of New England, for example, were buying stock in the big Boston-based bank, with assets of $31 billion, only weeks before it said it would have to set aside $700 million against possible losses on its real estate loans.
Then last week, only days after the Bank of New England report, three other big Northeast banking institutions - Dime Savings of New York: Midlantic, the second-largest banking concern in New Jersey, and Citytrust Bancorp of Bridgeport, Conn. - said they would create unexpectedly large loan-loss reserves.
The softening in real estate, and the impact on banks, appear to be reaching beyond the Northeast, however. Mr. Clarke has said that his office sees growing weakness in parts of the booming Florida market. Arizona real estate, particularly in Phoenix and Tucson, has plummeted this year. And some experts see the West Coast as vulnerable soon.
 
'Bicoastal Devaluation'
''I look at the possibility that you are going to see a bicoastal devaluation in real estate,'' Representative Leach of Iowa said.
The potential for trouble in the banking industry as a whole is compounded by several factors.
One is the savings bailout itself. For the next five years at least, the Resolution Trust Corporation, the agency created to manage the liquidation and sale of hundreds of ailing institutions, will have more than $140 billion in half-built apartment buildings, undeveloped land, homes and other troubled assets to sell - the equivalent of almost all the assets of the nation's largest bank, Citibank. This prospect will keep prices depressed and tie up investment capital.
Another factor is the condition of the global banking giants. Though banks like Citibank and Chase Manhattan do not have as big a chunk of their holdings in real estate as the large regional banks, they still have their share, and they continue to be bogged down by third world debt.
 
Squeeze on Profitability
Finally, laws that have prohibited banks from diversifying into securities underwriting and insurance, as well as geographic diversification, have placed what Mr. Clarke considers an alarming squeeze on profitability, putting pressure on banks to seek higher-risk investments. Among these investments have been ''junk bonds'' and highly leveraged transactions; the banking industry in recent months has suffered large losses on such loans.
Other regulators said they were concerned about a marked drop in credit standards. Banks' willingness to lend to businesses they might have turned down several years ago creates the potential for high losses.
''We have systemic problems with profitability,'' Mr. Clarke said in an interview last week. ''And the extent to which the necessity for earnings is forcing banks into high-risk lending.''
Some banking experts note that concern about real estate is affecting the way regulators are working. Mindful of the criticism of M. Danny Wall, who resigned recently as the Government's top savings regulator, some examiners are prompted to force banks to take large losses on their real estate holdings to avoid being accused of underestimating the risks or going easy on certain institutions, these experts say.
Some bankers and analysts say the strains are already appearing as regulators try to get a grasp on how much the real estate market has fallen in key areas. ''These markets have deterioriated a lot faster than people thought at midyear, but I feel that in recent months the regulators have turned up the volume too much,'' said James McDermott, an analyst at Keefe, Bruyette & Woods. ''They have become vocal and very visible, and though their point is well taken, they are tending to undermine confidence in financial institutions.'' Citicorp

HEADLINE: Nairobi Factory Gives Women Hope

BYLINE: By JANE PERLEZ, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: NAIROBI, Kenya, Dec. 28

 BODY:
Jacinta Wanjiku, a 30-year-old divorced mother of four children, strides through the tile-making plant on the outskirts of this city, knowledgeably checking on whether deliveries of mortar and sisal have arrived on time for the production schedules. After a recent three-week training course in England she can also check the machines.
Until she came to the tile factory earlier this year, Mrs. Wanjiku was, like the women who are her co-workers from Mathare Valley, Nairobi's notorious slum district, miserably poor.
In Mathare, hidden from the downtown high rises and the suburban lawns of Nairobi's affluent expatriate community, life is usually eeked out by selling discarded bottle tops or waste paper to pay the rent on a shack most Americans would scorn for their gardening tools. 
 
Survival Skills and Grit
But the women of Mathare Valley, usually bereft of husband, employer and never having known Western-style welfare, are considered to have unusual survival skills, managing somehow to keep themselves and a large number of children alive. It is with these skills and grit for life that women from the valley, the poorest of the poor in urban Africa, have been encouraged by the African Housing Fund, an organization supported by 23 African governments, to start and run a tile-making factory.
Thanks to a $250,000 contract negotiated on their behalf by the fund, the women are working round-the-clock shifts to produce and sell roof tiles to a construction company working on a middle-income housing project financed by the World Bank. The women are keeping the profits for housing for themselves that will eventually allow them to leave Mathare.
 
Not Much Changes for Women
Despite the emphasis by Western-run development projects in the past decade on helping the women of Africa, little has changed in the lowly status of women. Often, the critics say, the well-meaning development efforts are directed to helping women win a better position in the informal sector -producing handicraft, for example -where the proceeds are small and there is little chance in improving women's actual living circumstances.
The Humama tile factory, named after a long-existing women's group in Mathare Valley, is an attempt to bring poor women straight into the formal sector economy. And while many development projects work on the premise that food, health and education are the basics, the African Housing Fund believes that in Mathare, at least, moving out of the shacks, and their disease and crime-ridden surroundings, is the first priority.
''Before I came to the factory, I was taking care of the children, staying with people and making some dolls and leather bags,'' said Mrs. Wanjiku. ''Maybe I'd make a hundred shillings a month and then you'd buy charcoal with it or cabbages and take them to the market to sell.'' $33 a Week, Not Cabbages As a shift supervisor, she now earns 675 shillings every two weeks, or about $33, an amount worked out according to how many tiles the inspectors from the building contractor accepts. When the factory, a long, open-sided pitched roof shed with a wooden frame, opened in February and the women were new to the tile trade, many tiles were rejected for imperfections and the pay was less.
Four male technical trainers, graduates of the National Polytechnic and specialists in such fields as electrical engineering, were hired by the African Housing Fund to help train the female supervisors. Gradually, the male trainers are being withdrawn.
Eighty-five women work at the factory, each chosen by the 230 members of Humama women's groups in the Mathare on the basis of their financial need and their skills. Perpetua Omary, 25 years old, the secretary of the Humama group, so poor she slept in the alleys of Mathare, was known for her diligence at keeping good notes of the group's meeting. She was chosen as bookkeeper for the project and sent to Kenya Women's Finance Trust for business management training.
She showed a visitor impeccably kept books of accounts, detailing wages and inventory. From time to time, she visits the African Housing Fund's headquarters in Nairobi to enter her records on a computer. Mrs. Omary, a shy woman who can now afford a fake pearl necklace and wears a white laboratory-style coat to protect her new dress, said her husband beat her when she went for training. She left him, she said.
Mrs. Omary and Mrs. Wanjiku are also lucky enough to be among the 40 women chosen to live in temporary housing put up at the factory site, a privilege that means they no longer have to endure the hardships of Mathare, where a recent visitor was protected from pickpockets by a flank of six women from the Humama group acting as bodyguards.
Mrs. Wanjiku said the factory site, about four miles from Mathare was safer in another way. ''The women would get drunk in Mathare. Here there is no time to get drunk,'' she said. ''The opening of the factory is good for the ladies. We are eating well and have clothing.''
 
Better Food and Clothing
To those who still live in Mathare, the new earnings from the factory make a big difference in their ability to buy better food and clothing, if not better housing. A 30-year-old woman who travels to the factory every day showed a visitor the 15-by-8-foot tin lean-to she lives in with her five children. Before being chosen to work in the factory, she spent six months in jail after the Nairobi police swept through Mathare picking up people making changa, the alcoholic brew of maize and sugar that is illegally made as a means of making money.
The African Housing Fund has persuaded the Nairobi City Commission to give some land, left over from a middle-income housing scheme to the Humama women's group. There, from their knowledge of tile making and the profits of the factory, they will construct their own houses. Mrs. Wanjiku said she now sees the possibility of having a clean and safe home, once a fantasy.

HEADLINE: Kenya's Plan for Tower Annoys Aid Donors

BYLINE: By JANE PERLEZ, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: NAIROBI, Kenya, Dec. 28

 BODY:
Kenya's major financial donors, including the United States and Japan, have expressed their disapproval of plans to build a 60-story, $200 million office tower, which they say the country cannot afford.
The donors believe the expenditure on the building, which has also become a cause celebre here on environmental and political grounds, violates the spirit, if not the letter, of agreements that Kenya has with the World Bank and the International Monetary Fund.
The $160 million loan from foreign banks that the Government has said it will guarantee, as well as a $40 million local loan, breaks an agreement that Kenya will keep its economic house in order and its commercial loans at a minimum, diplomats here said.
While the major donors have not yet threatened to cut their financial aid, it could come to that, the diplomats said. If the parliamentary bill in which the Government guarantees the loans breaks the agreements with the World Bank and the I.M.F. hundreds of millions of dollars of aid could be in jeopardy. 
President Daniel arap Moi annnounced that the 60-story tower, which would be the tallest office building in Africa, would house the headquarters of the governing Kenya African National Union and a media center run by the party. He has defended the project as a prestige edifice for Kenya and contends that its position in what is now a tree-laden downtown park is environmentally sound. The building will feature a larger-than-life-size statue of Mr. Moi.
 
Other Loans Taken Out
Until now Kenya has been praised by Western donors for being fairly prudent in its borrowing policies. But in the last few months commercial loans have been taken out not only for the building but also for aircraft and spare parts for Kenya Airways, a gas pipeline and sugar factory equipment. The loans total about $400 million, twice the size of Kenya's foreign exchange reserves.
The loan for the office tower is far the most troubling because it is not only the biggest but is money that ''could otherwise be used for the productive sector,'' a diplomat said.
The loan also comes when the Kenya economy is not looking as perky as it once did. In a public address here, the charge d'affaires of the United States Embassy, George Griffen, noted that Kenya's economic growth is expected to drop from 5.2 percent in 1988 to 4.9 percent in 1989. Foreign investment is continuing to decline, he said.
In an address to a group of senior Kenyan officials, a Japanese diplomat warned about the effect of the building loans on Kenya's balance of payments at a time when the prospects for foreign exchange earnings were not good. Japan is Kenya's largest donor, far outstripping the United States and even Britain, the former colonial power.
 
'Politically Desirable'
Western diplomats said that when they make their objections to senior Kenyan civil servants it is acknowledged that the building is economically undesirable but ''politically desirable.'' This is interpreted to mean that President Moi is determined to have it built and that no one within the Government has the power, or the courage, to stop it.
When the new United States Ambassador to Kenya, Smith Hempstone Jr., made his first call on the Finance Minister, George Saitoti, recently, the wisdom of the project was broached. Professor Saitoti said that donors were always urging Kenya to become more competitive and that to do so Kenya, like Hong Kong once did, needed a major office tower.
The leader of an environmental group, Prof. Wangari Maathai, tried to stop construction of the building by taking the issue to the High Court. But the case was thrown out on the ground that the professor had ''no right of action.''
Days later, President Moi attacked Professor Maathai, saying that as a woman she had no right to criticize. The African tradition, the President said, was for women to respect men. The next day, the Nairobi police turned up at her offices and ordered her organization out of the premises it had occupied for 10 years.

HEADLINE: Kinsman From U.S. Is Taking Greece by Storm

BYLINE: By PAUL ANASTASI, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: ATHENS

 BODY:
Reversing America's low-profile diplomacy in Greece, he insists on braving the threat of terrorism by displaying the American flag wherever he goes. He does not hesitate to step into the crowd to cheer at basketball games, and he jokingly reassures Greeks that he, like most of them, is an islander - from the island of Manhattan.
After 15 years of strained relations between the United States and Greece, both members of NATO, easing tensions between the two nations may well have a lot to do with the unorthodox tactics of a Greek-American New Yorker: Michael Sotirhos, the new American Ambassador to Greece.
Mr. Sotirhos, 61 years old, arrived in Greece in September and, much to the dismay of the traditionally hostile Greek press, has plunged into a public relations campaign that his predecessors would never have attempted. In several cases, he has left his Greek audience crying for more. 
Greece first got a hint of the Ambassador's new approach when he turned up at the funeral of Pavlos Bacoyannis, the chief spokesman in Parliament of the conservative New Democracy party who was killed by far-left terrorists in September. For the first time in years, the American flag flew from the Ambassador's armored limousine. Mourners broke ranks and burst into applause at the sight.
 
Visit to Communist Headquarters
Similarly, it was front-page news when the Ambassador scored another first by visiting Communist Party headquarters to talk with the party leader. He next turned up at a hastily summoned town hall reception for Boris N. Yeltsin, the maverick Soviet legislator, while the Soviet Ambassador failed to appear.
Not only has Mr. Sotirhos been shaking up the political status quo with his maneuvering, but he has also managed to capture the public's attention with his style.
Recently, he broke with protocol by strolling onto the court to greet the stars of Greece's top basketball team. On another occasion, he mingled with fans at a heated soccer game. In both cases he was applauded and even embraced by fans.
As evidence of his adherence to the Greek Orthodox faith, Mr. Sotirhos attends Mass every Sunday at churches in Athens and sometimes sings along with the choir. Always, he wears an American flag pin in his lapel.
''We're going to take every necessary security precaution, but we're not going to hide,'' a diplomat recalls the Ambassador telling staff members. ''Having armored cars and bodyguards, that's security. Not flying the flag is hiding.''
 
A New Approach
The Ambassador's new approach differs considerably from diplomatic practices adopted since 1974, when simmering anti-Americanism and terrorist attacks compelled most Americans to maintain a low profile.
Now, Mr. Sotirhos has ordered that the American flag fly on all occasions. He has encouraged diplomatic personnel to widen the circle of leaders they meet to include Communists and to seek contact with the general public.
At meetings with American servicemen, he urges them to emphasize rather than hide their official American status. ''Go out, go to the countryside, find the mayor and introduce yourself as an American,'' he personnel, according to the diplomat.
''Anti-Americanism has been declining for the past few years,'' another foreign diplomat said. ''But the new Ambassador is accelerating the gradual decline of anti-American sentiment and taking it one step further to revive traditional pro-Americanism among Greeks.''
The United States and Greece had warm relations in the years after the World War II, largely because of American military and economic aid and the fact that many Greeks had relatives or close friends in the United States. But American tolerance of the right-wing dictatorship, which ruled Greece from 1967 to 1974, and of the Turkish invasion and continuing occupation of Cyprus led to a reversal of sentiments, violent demonstrations and terrorist attacks. More Greeks Favor U.S. Matters have improved in recent years. According to Eurodim opinion polls, an independent polling bureau, 59 percent of Greeks questioned in March would like an improvement in Greek-American relations, compared with only 31 percent in March 1981. But Panayotis Dimitras, the director of the bureau, says research shows that one in three Greeks today remains unreservedly hostile to the United States and unconditionally wants the expulsion of the American bases and Greece's withdrawal from NATO.
While developments in Eastern Europe and the decline of Communist domination may be one coincidence explaining Mr. Sotirhos's warm reception, the Ambassador also has the advantage of being the first Greek-American in the post. His wife, Estelle Manos, is also Greek-American, and both speak Greek fluently.
The advantage of language and the ethnic connection is evident in most of the Ambassador's public appearances. One witness recounted an incident when Mr. Sotirhos, questioned by an elderly couple in the streets of a small town, informed them that his father was from the island of Kythira and his mother from the island of Milos.
''So you are a Nisiotis, an islander, like us?'' the couple asked him.
''Yes,'' the Ambassador replied. ''I'm from Manhattan.'' A Background in Business Born in New York City, Mr. Sotirhos studied business at City College and founded Ariston Interior Designers. He was also a partner in Marta Realty and Hampton Properties of New York. He served in numerous public and political posts and received honors ranging from the man of the year for the Juvenile Diabetes Foundation to the Republican Party's ethnic man of the year. His last assignment was as Ambassador to Jamaica.
So far, Mr. Sotirhos's public diplomacy in Greece seems to be paying off. Both the conservatives and the Socialists have indicated acceptance of his proposal for extending the May deadline on the expulsion of the American bases, thereby allowing time to renew the accord. And though he has not won agreement from the Communists on the bases, he broke new ground when the party's leadership conceded that economic and cultural exchanges between Greece and the United States should increase.
''The Ambassador deplores the poor state of Greek-American relations over the last 15 years,'' another senior diplomat said. ''He feels that too much time has been wasted on such issues as the bases and terrorism. Instead, he wants to concentrate on bilateral ties, on strengthening educational and economic exchanges.''
''He's not a career diplomat but a practical businessman,'' the diplomat said. ''He puts protocol aside and gets things done.''

HEADLINE: China Line: No Thawing

BYLINE: By STEVEN ERLANGER, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: BEIJING, Dec. 28

 BODY:
Government anxiety over the domestic impact of the fall of Nicolae Ceausescu in Rumania makes it less likely that the Chinese leadership will respond substantively to President Bush's request for the easing of martial-law restrictions before Congress returns to Washington on Jan. 23, ready to do battle with Mr. Bush over his overtures to Beijing.
Mr. Bush drew significant criticism at home early this month when he sent his national security adviser, Brent Scowcroft, to China, six months after the Government's crackdown on the student-led democracy movement. The President felt it was time to begin to restore relations with China, and Mr. Scowcroft, saying he came as ''a friend,'' urged the Chinese to lift martial law and end the repressive measures that followed the June killings.
The criticism of an American ''kowtow'' to a tarnished Chinese leadership heightened when it was revealed that Mr. Scowcroft had also visited Beijing in July, barely a month after the killings and despite a White House ban on high-level contacts. 
 
Congress and Bush at Odds
Legislators vowed to pass laws imposing new sanctions against China when they returned to work. Mr. Bush then proceeded to lift some economic sanctions on doing business with China.
American officials said they wanted the Chinese to lift martial law, stop the continuing series of investigations, trials and executions, restore normal information flows to Western embassies and allow a noted dissident and astrophysicist, Fang Lizhi and his wife, who had sought refuge in the American Embassy here, to leave the country.
The Chinese agreed to allow a Voice of America correspondent to work again in Beijing, repeated an earlier promise not to sell medium-range missiles to Syria and softened their invective about the United States and Mr. Fang, whose case still appears to be under serious discussion.
But senators and members of Congress were already saying this response was insufficient to justify Mr. Bush's gamble, which was fast becoming a central issue for Democratic Party criticism of the President when the invasion of Panama and the upheaval in Rumania diverted attention from China.
 
China Increasingly Isolated
Asian and Western diplomats here agree that Mr. Bush remains dependent on Beijing to provide some return on his diplomatic and political investment, and that after Rumania, an increasingly nervous and isolated China is less likely to reciprocate.
Watching the collapse of Communism in much of Eastern Europe, China had drawn closer to Mr. Ceausescu, pledging ''militant unity'' and ''revolutionary friendship'' with an old-style Stalinist who had maintained close relations with Beijing during the Chinese-Russian split.
Diplomats and students say security forces here were placed on alert and reinforced after Mr. Ceausescu's spectacular fall, with instructions to monitor any student gatherings and even to follow any groups of students who left the campuses.
 
Student Posters Ripped Down
In the last few days, at least three posters have gone up at Beijing and Qinghua universities, students said. The posters were quickly ripped down. At Beijing University on Saturday, two days before Mr. Ceausescu's execution, one poster called him a ''lost dog,'' and suggested that he might be coming to China to join four other dogs - Deng Xiaoping, the senior leader; Prime Minister Li Peng; President Yang Shangkun, and the party chief, Jiang Zemin.
At Beijing University on Wednesday, according to The Associated Press, some students hissed at the State Council spokesman, Yuan Mu, when he came to answer questions from a ticket-only audience of some 300. When asked about Rumania, Mr. Yuan, standing up and banging his hand on the table, said, ''No matter what the situation is in the rest of the world, China will always walk the path of socialism, uphold the socialist flag and adhere to the leadership of the Communist Party of China.'' #3 Factors Blamed for Collapse As the party struggles with the aftermath of Rumania, the tone of argument is becoming increasingly aggressive. Two weeks ago, in a high-level party meeting to discuss Eastern Europe, the collapse there was put down to three factors: the influence of President Mikhail S. Gorbachev of the Soviet Union, who is regarded as something of a dangerous madman; the presence in Eastern Europe of ''uneradicated bourgeois and social democratic elements,'' and ''the interference in internal affairs'' by capitalist countries, in particular the United States.
The feeling, one party member said, is of defiant pride: that without China, there would be no true Communism surviving.
''This is not a time to expect concessions from the Chinese leadership,'' a senior Western diplomat said. ''They've got enough to worry about without lifting martial law. Bush may have been right in theory, but it seems he may have misjudged his timing.''
