HEADLINE: Once-Prized Area Struggles To Recoup Quake's Losses

BYLINE: By JANE GROSS, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: SAN FRANCISCO, Dec. 28

 BODY:
When night falls and lights go on in houses throughout the city, whole blocks of the Marina district stand black, the rows of dark windows mute testimony to the damage left behind by the Oct. 17 earthquake.
''It's a ghost town,'' said Bob Mulhern, owner of a neighborhood bar where the Marina's remaining residents gather to commiserate about the cracks in their foundations, the contractors shoring up their houses, the patina of dust that coats everything they own and the rumble of jackhammers and backhoes that still clog their streets.
Residents, merchants and realtors estimate that 3,000 people, 15 percent of the Marina's population, have quit this neighborhood on the edge of San Francisco Bay, one of the city's most prized addresses until two and a half months ago, when dozens of buildings set on unstable landfill buckled, collapsed or burned in the quake.
The setting is no less spectacular these days, with the Golden Gate Bridge and the Marin Headlands in the distance, yachts bobbing in the harbor and sunsets that wash the sky with bright strokes of pink and orange.
 
Now a Desolate Place
But the Marina is now a desolate place. Scattered throughout the area are muddy, vacant lots where apartment houses once stood, condemned buildings that are empty until they are restored to safety and structures declared habitable but no longer attractive to the young professionals who once rented here. 
''If you look at the mailboxes, only about 50 percent of the names are left, and I'm sure only a quarter of us are still in the building,'' said Gene Ann LaMoria, who is about to move from an apartment on Cervantes Street, one of the hardest hits blocks in the Marina, to a condominium across the bay in Sausalito. ''On bedrock,'' she noted.
By and large, it is the young renters who have fled the Marina, leaving behind the elderly men and women who will not uproot themselves after a lifetime in the same place or who cannot afford to move from rent-stabilized apartments. Also wedded to the Marina, at least for the time being, are the homeowners who have sunk their savings into houses that ranged in value from $600,000 to several million dollars before the quake and would now sell, some realtors say, for a third less.
The exodus of renters has been costly for neighborhood merchants, who depended on the free-spending young residents. And outsiders have stayed away from the Marina shopping strip, initially because repair work on nearby buildings, gas lines and water mains made the area a maze of detours and roadblocks, and more recently because the scars of the earthquake are depressing and unsettling.
 
'A One-Two Punch'
''It's a one-two punch,'' said Harold Hoogasin, a florist and president of the Marina Merchants Association, referring to the loss of business from both residents and nonresidents. ''And I can't in my heart blame folks. Who wants to look at devastation?''
The neighborhood has lost vibrancy in other ways as well. There are still joggers and kite-fliers on the Marina Green, a strip of parkland that borders the bay, but their numbers are way down since the quake temporarily turned the grassy area into a staging ground for utility crews and the site of makeshift showers for residents without hot water. Utility service was restored around Thanksgiving, but the Green remains marked by the temblor, its once-flat surface buckled and its running paths cracked.
''The young guys and gals, the joggers and the bicyclists, you don't see as much of that anymore,'' said 66-year-old Bernard Boren, who has lived in his Marina apartment for 25 years and has no intention of leaving.
So far, landlords with vacant apartments have resisted lowering rents to attract new tenants, largely because local rent control laws would then lock them into annual increases of 4 percent on a smaller base. ''For Rent'' signs abound, some advertising the available apartments as ''Safe.'' Several local realtors said the current vacancy rate is 60 or 70 percent, as against 2 percent before the quake, although they assumed the area would regain its popularity as time passed and memories of the earthquake receded.
Homeowners, unlike renters, have shown no signs of fleeing the neighborhood. Many admit in private that they have no choice but to stay, given the depressed value of their houses. But to say that out loud would make a bad situation worse, so most homeowners declare that they love the Marina for its beauty, would not dream of leaving and are not frightened at the prospect of future earthquakes.
''It's basically a great area,'' said Audrey DiFilippio, a homeowner. ''Sure some people left, but the initial outpouring, that's over now.''
Mr. Mulhern, the bar owner, is skeptical. ''They're so stuck that they have to think positively,'' he said. ''I know that if they could get a fair price, 30 percent of them would sell. They can't, so they'll do rehab, wait it out, pray nothing happens for two years and then put the house on the market.''
 
Instant Experts on Construction
In the meantime, it seems, everyone here has become an instant expert on construction techniques and soil conditions related to earthquakes. Homeowners talk incessently of retrofitting and liquification, arcane vocabulary that has become commonplace since the quake.
Houses that cracked or toppled are now propped up on wooden cribbing while new foundations are laid beneath them. Houses that withstood the quake are getting plywood shearing in the walls and 8-inch bolts in their foundations to secure them better next time around. People who can afford it have hired soil engineers to drill holes in their backyards searching for bedrock, which is 40 feet below the landfill on certain lots and 265 feet down on others. The rest of the residents are waiting impatiently for the results of soil tests being conducted by Federal, state and local governments.
These bleak winter days, the streets here are often empty except for construction workers, movers and tourists, who since the quake have flocked to the Marina with their cameras to record the destruction. The tourists poke their noses in open doors to watch the progress of construction, touch the wide cracks in the stucco facades and pose for pictures before the inspection notices that categorize houses as safe or unsafe for habitation.
There are 11 vacant lots in the Marina district where collapsed buildings once stood, including one at the corner of Beach and Divisadero Streets, where millions of television viewers watched the city's most spectacular blaze on Oct. 17, and another at Filmore and Cervantes Streets, where an infant and two adults died in the rubble of a three-story building. It is this empty lot that has become an evolving tableaux of the neighborhood's suffering in the months since the earthquake.
At first, the lot on Cervantes Street was heaped with the possessions of the 40 people who had lived there: golf clubs and lampshades, a vacuum cleaner and an empty bleach bottle, dated copies of Life magazine and the attachments for a Cuisinart food processor.
Then the debris of daily life was cleared away and an angry sign took its place, handwritten by an unknown author on a piece of plywood: ''People like you with your children coming to our neighborhood to take pictures is truly sick.''
Now, new fencing keeps the tourists away and the anger seems to have cooled, giving way to a quiet sadness. Several white carnations are laced in the steel mesh and a Christmas tree stands in the center of the lot.

HEADLINE: FLORIDA GOVERNOR SEEKS DISASTER AID

BYLINE: By ALAN JUDD; New York Times Regional Newspapers

DATELINE: TALLAHASSEE, Fla., Dec. 28

 BODY:
Gov. Bob Martinez sought Federal disaster aid today for Florida farmers whose crops were damaged in the statewide freeze last weekend.
Mr. Martinez asked the Federal Agriculture Secretary, Clayton Yeutter, to approve low-interest disaster-relief loans to Florida farmers, many of whom saw crops wiped out as temperatures plunged.
Calling the freeze ''devastating'' to the state's agriculture interests, Mr. Martinez said in a letter to Mr. Yeutter, ''Preliminary damage reports show that the freezing temperatures caused extensive damage to the citrus, sugar cane and vegetable producing regions, as well as heavy losses to ornamental crops, nurseries and tropical fish breeders.'' 
Mr. Martinez, who did not give an estimate of total losses, also declared all 67 Florida counties to be disaster areas as a result of the freeze.
 
U.S. Survey of Losses
Federal agriculture officials will survey losses in each county before determining whether Florida farmers qualify for disaster loans from the Farmers Home Administration.
Mr. Martinez has not yet decided whether to ask President Bush to declare the state a disaster area, said Jon Peck, the Governor's press secretary.
If the President takes that action, it would make low-interest loans available to other Floridians who suffered losses, not just farmers, and would provide emergency unemployment benefits to farm workers who were put out of work by the freeze.
State officials need detailed, county-by-county damage reports before Mr. Martinez could seek disaster aid from the President, Mr. Peck said, and the Agriculture Department's survey will provide that information.
The two-day freeze severely damaged citrus and vegetable crops deep into South Florida. Some citrus growers have estimated that they lost at least 40 percent of their crops, and many vegetable crops were wiped out.
It will take agriculture officials three to four weeks to gather the information Mr. Yeutter will use in deciding whether to grant disaster aid, said Wilbert Campbell, director of the Farmers Home Administration's emergency designation staff in Washington.
Disaster loans carry a 4.5 percent interest rate, and farmers may take as long as 20 years to repay. Farmers could receive loans no greater than their actual losses, as high as $500,000.
Today Mr. Martinez also extended an emergency order allowing trucks hauling fruit and vegetables to processing plants to exceed weight limits on state highways.

HEADLINE: Tempers Rise Over Fate of Rare Book Collection at Harvard

BYLINE: By CONSTANCE L. HAYS, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: CAMBRIDGE, Mass., Dec. 28

 BODY:
A frozen hush lies over the Charles River here in the holiday lull, but tempers on both banks remain hot over the future of a rare-book collection established 51 years ago at the Harvard Business School.
The feud centers on the Kress Library of Business and Economics, a trove of 37,000 economic history texts, some of them hundreds of years old. The collection, housed in the business school's Baker Library, is regarded as one of the world's finest. It was begun in 1938 with money given to the school by Claude Washington Kress, one of three brothers who made a fortune in dime-store retailing. 
Now some say the Kress legacy is threatened by a tougher attitude toward the bottom line, both at the business school, on the Boston side of the river, and in the rest of the university's library system on the Cambridge side. A reorganization of Baker Library has been carried out, merging the Kress collection staff with those of other archival materials. Some fear the change is the first step toward making the Kress collection inaccessible, since library visitors often require substantial assistance in using rare books.
The university's various graduate schools and faculties are set up as separate entities, each with its own budget that is controlled by the school. The business school's library budget is independent from the budget of the rest of the university's 12-million volume library system. Thus, the handling of the Kress collection is mostly the province of the dean of the business school, John H. McArthur. The dean could not be reached for comment. A spokeswoman for the business school said he does not speak to reporters. #4 Quit in Protest So far, three of the five staff members who oversaw the Kress collection have resigned to protest the changes, as has the associate director of Baker Library. A delegation of professors urged the university's president, Derek C. Bok, to intervene and protect the collection. In the absence of a declared plan for the collection, rumors are flying. Some reports have the collection being moved to a storage building in Southborough, Mass., or locked away in favor of microfilms.
''There has been an almost spontaneous cry of dismay,'' said David S. Landes, a professor of history and economics who met with Mr. Bok over the future of the collection. ''This was clearly intended to be a secret operation, and the business school is surprised and discommoded by this reaction.''
Mary Chatfield, the head librarian at Baker Library, said no final plan had been settled upon. ''I'd really like to allay these rumors that we're the Hunnish horde over here, doing some dreadful thing,'' she said. Long-term plans call for a renovation of the library building in the next 10 years, and all its books will be removed while that work is carried out, she said. ''We wanted to make sure our most rare and fragile materials are handled with a lot of care,'' she said.
The controversy is fed by disagreement over who uses the collection and who ought to pay to sustain it. In meetings last summer, officials at the business school ''said the Kress collection needs to be rationalized,'' said its former curator, Ruth R. Rogers. ''The collection stops at 1850, and much of it is in French, German or Italian,'' she said. ''More and more, it is not what the school is doing.''
Others say most of the collection's users are from outside the business school, and therefore another wing of the university ought to support it.
 
Merging of Staffs
During the summer, school officials announced a plan to merge the Kress staff with those of Baker Library's manuscripts and archives collections.
''It was brought to our attention that we should reorganize, and so we formed a department of special collections,'' Ms. Chatfield said. ''One of the main reasons for this consolidation was to oversee all the preservation activities that were going on in Baker Library. It was an opportunity to leverage our staff.''
Others say the reorganization was dictated by budget constraints that are afflicting libraries everywhere. ''In any kind of an organization, there are going to be reductions of staff, but that is not going to be a mortal blow,'' said Thomas K. McCraw, an economic historian and professor of business history. ''Every library in the world is going through a budgetary crisis.''
The director of Harvard's library system, Sidney Verba, said he hoped the Kress collection would remain accessible to scholars and students. ''If the business school doesn't keep it, it would be preferable to move it to another location on the campus,'' he said. ''I'm very anxious to see that the collection is maintained in a way that people can get access to it, and I would very much prefer to see it stay in Baker Library.''
But the decentralized manner in which Harvard's schools are run means the administration has little to say about what happens except in the most extreme case.
''The dean of the business school makes the decisions,'' Professor Verba said, ''but if it were a major decision, such as disposing of the Kress collection, it would have to be done in consultation with the president and with me.''

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

COUNTRY: UNITED STATES (79%);

HEADLINE: Why Hong Kong Is Turning Back Boat People;
Illegal Immigrants

 BODY:
To the Editor:
''Sinking the Boat People'' (editorial, Dec. 9) suggests that Hong Kong is in violation of Article 33 of the United Nations Convention on Refugees by repatriating Vietnamese boat people.
But it is precisely this article - that no one fearing persecution because of race, religion, membership in a particular social group or political opinion should be forced to return to his country - that provides the basis for finding many of the Vietnamese boat people illegal immigrants.
This determination has been made after exhaustive screening and appeals designed and monitored by the United Nations High Commissioner for Refugees, which may still declare any person to be a refugee, even if that person has been screened out and had his appeal rejected. It has done so in more than 100 cases. 
The United States abides by the same criteria, as the boat people in Hong Kong have been told by United States officials visiting them - counseling that is vital because nearly all the boat people left Vietnam with the expressed hope of going to America.
The Lawyers Committee on Human Rights has chosen to present a highly distorted and misleading picture of how the authorities in Hong Kong are handling this difficult problem. It is nonsense to suggest that the boat people are ''helpless to contest adverse findings.''
The reason so few of Hong Kong's boat people are eligible for refugee status is largely that more than 90 percent are from North Vietnam. Relatively few can show a well-founded fear of persecution.
You call for a one-year grace period so that the United States, Britain and others can come up with a better solution, notwithstanding the agreement reached by the international community at a conference in Geneva last June that all illegal immigrants would have to go home.
In the last year, Hong Kong has had to cope with a flood of boat people. If nothing is done before the next ''sailing season,'' which begins in February, another substantial influx is likely over the next 12 months. A grace period would, therefore, only exacerbate the problem.
There is, finally, no question of sending illegal immigrants home without firm assurances from the Vietnamese Government of proper reintegration.
 
KERRY MCGLYNN
Director, Hong Kong
Economic & Trade Office
 New York, Dec. 11, 1989

HEADLINE: Why Hong Kong Is Turning Back Boat People

 BODY:
To the Editor:
Your reporting on Vietnamese boat people in Hong Kong, most recently in ''Hong Kong Forcibly Returns 51 Boat People'' (front page, Dec. 12), misrepresents the problem. Having lived in Hong Kong and having volunteered in the Vietnamese detention camps, I share your viewpoint that their situation is pitiable, but the blame for it cannot rest solely, or even mainly, on the shoulders of Hong Kong.
When the British Government of Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher proposed making Hong Kong the port of first asylum for Vietnamese boat people, it was proposing a system in which Hong Kong was a clearinghouse for refugee resettlement to Britain, its allies and its European partners. It is the failure of those countries to accept the Vietnamese influx that has caused the backlog of boat people in Hong Kong. 
You note that some 13,000 individuals who have been granted refugee status by the United Nations High Commissioner for Refugees await resettlement, and it is the 40,000 who were not declared refugees who face repatriation. You fail to explain that this distinction between economic and political refugees is not Hong Kong's but the creation of destination countries, like the United States, which do not accept economic refugees. For those who do not receive refugee status, the system does not work.
For many readers, repatriation will seem cruel in any case, and they may wonder why Hong Kong does not absorb these immigrants. The answer is threefold: (1) the boat people do not want to settle in Hong Kong - they are willing to wait almost endlessly for resettlement, but they see Hong Kong only as a way station; (2) while Hong Kong is wealthy compared with Vietnam, it is crowded and ill equipped to provide social welfare to so large a group, and (3) China, which resumes sovereignty over Hong Kong in 1997, has indicated it will not accept the Vietnamese boat people.
Beijing has also indicated that it will use the Army if necessary to quell social disturbance in Hong Kong. Since riots in the camps (which are frequent, as there are groups from both North and South Vietnam) would qualify, the specter of Chinese troops in Hong Kong has added weight to the arguments of those proposing rapid repatriation.
Hong Kong is composed of refugees; more than half of its population derives from the flood of humanity that left China after 1949. Hong Kong residents understand the risks one takes in starting a new life elsewhere. But they too face an undesired repatriation, in 1997, and must prepare for it as best they can. The decision to repatriate the Vietnamese refugees was not made lightly, but only after years of feeding them, keeping them and hoping that destination countries would accept them. Given our own failure, can we blame Hong Kong?
 
EDWARD T. L. HARDIE
Stanford, Calif., Dec. 13, 1989

HEADLINE: Deregulation Created Our Thrifts Crisis

 BODY:
To the Editor:
For many years, the thrift industry enjoyed the protection of Regulation Q, which controlled the maximum interest to be paid to depositors. The thrifts could then write fixed-rate mortgages at interest rates that provided a modest ''spread'' over deposit cost. Thus, the traditional commitment of the thrifts to provide housing finance was made more secure. 
All went well until the rise of money market funds and other unregulated competition for the depositor's dollar. This was accompanied by an outcry from elderly depositors, organized under the title Gray Panthers, lobbying for abolition of Regulation Q. When the Government began to respond, by slowly dismantling deposit rate regulation, many thrifts could see the handwriting on the wall. If they continued raising deposit rates to meet unregulated competition, they could not survive on the meager returns from fixed-rate mortgages entered into 5, 10 or even 20 years earlier.
The thrifts approached Washington proposing that the Federal Government take over some low-rate mortgages at par, for a limited adjustment period, to give time for the thrifts to alter their asset mix. Thereafter, say in five years, the thrifts would repurchase the mortgages at par. Meanwhile, the portfolios would have been diminished by amortization, somewhat reducing the problem.
This helpful, but by no means perfect, palliative was rejected as too costly. It might have been less costly than the expenses facing us now.
Instead, the Government, aided by action of state legislators, began dismantling the asset controls and usury limitations that had hampered thrifts from asset reallocation. The barriers to conversion of mutuals into stock companies also began to come down, which made it easier for high rollers to crowd into the thrift industry. Thus the door was opened to speculation, negligence and, in a few cases, outright criminality.
It's a pity that the foresight of reputable thrift leaders did not receive encouragement from the regulators and legislators. All of us must now pay the price.
 
COVINGTON HARDEE
New York, Dec. 10, 1989
 The writer is chairman emeritus of a New York-based bank.

HEADLINE: Metal Detectors Make Schools Like Prisons

 BODY:
To the Editor:
Sandra Feldman, head of the United Federation of Teachers, advocates use of metal detectors in each school that requests them (news article, Dec. 7). I'd like to point to some possible limitations and unintended consequences of the security system Ms. Feldman advocates. 
In the school at which I work, since the installation of the system, fights, disruptions and, especially, assaults on teachers are up - with no corresponding increase in overall safety. More important, a jailhouse atmosphere inappropriate to an educational setting has resulted, relegating teaching and learning to a secondary status at best.
Three of the deaths Ms. Feldman refers to took place outside of schools and were caused by offenders the security forces would not have been able to search. The fourth death, of Alexander Stephens at Alfred E. Smith High School on Nov. 13, could better have been prevented had undercover officers been present. Undercover officers would be less disruptive of school routine, more economical and more reflective of a humane concern for the majority of the students.
A student intent on serious crime is not dissuaded by a security force whose appearances are telegraphed by a truck parked on or near school grounds.
 
DAVID RABINOVITZ
Brooklyn, Dec. 7, 1989

HEADLINE: IN THE NATION;
Gorbachev At Bay

BYLINE: By Tom Wicker

 BODY:
The revolt of the Lithuanian Communist Party has brought Mikhail Gorbachev face to face with the most threatening consequence of his reform policies. If nothing is done, he told the party Central Committee in Moscow, ''we will deliberately be heading toward the disintegration of the Soviet Union.''
Yet, what can he do? And from the West's point of view, would that disintegration be undesirable?
Mr. Gorbachev's planned trip to Lithuania clearly is an exploratory measure, in which he hopes to find some way out of the crisis caused by the Lithuanian party's declaration of independence from the Soviet Communist Party. Lithuanian party leaders also have explicitly declared that their goal is an independent Lithuanian republic. 
That goal takes on added force from Moscow's previous admission that its absorption of the Baltic States, including Lithuania, during World War II was ''illegal.'' No one doubts, moreover, that the Lithuanian people, not just a few political leaders, support the idea of independence.
After permitting limited steps toward democracy within the Soviet Union itself, after permitting the nations of Eastern Europe to renounce their externally imposed Communist governments and move toward self-determination, and after condemning efforts to repress this movement in Czechoslovakia and Rumania, Mr. Gorbachev would have to reverse himself totally, as well as his reform program, if he were to smash the Lithuanian independence movement by force.
To do so, first of all, might involve much bloodshed - witness the toll of Rumanians sacrificed to Nicolae Ceausescu's effort to cling to power. Armed repression in Lithuania also would cost Mr. Gorbachev most of the credibility he has in the West as a genuine reformer intent on undoing some of the worst aspects of the cold war years; that would be costly to his reform plans for the Soviet Union, which are highly dependent on Western cooperation. And though repression might manage the problem temporarily it could not solve it permanently - in Lithuania or in other restive Soviet republics.
On the other hand, if Mr. Gorbachev takes no effective steps to mollify the Lithuanians - if any such steps are possible - it can hardly be doubted that they will proceed toward independence. That, in turn, surely would set off similar independence movements in the other Baltic States, Latvia and Estonia, perhaps also in other dissident Soviet republics -leading, Mr. Gorbachev warned, ''to the disintegration of the Soviet Union.'' Latvia seems already to be following Lithuania's course.
Some bitterly anti-Soviet Americans undoubtedly would celebrate such disintegration - the final victory of the capitalist West over ''the evil empire'' with which the U.S. and its allies have been engaged in cold war for nearly a half-century; the downfall of what they regard as the most oppressive of the world's states.
The disintegration of any great nation, however, is not so simple a matter as its disappearance. Soviet leaders, from Mr. Gorbachev down, can hardly be expected to acquiesce in any development so cataclysmic to them or to their heritage and culture; in fact, their permissive course in Eastern Europe was a recognition of necessity and reflected their desire to preserve their own regime rather than imperil it in a vain attempt to impose their will on surrounding states.
Who knows what forces, in a disintegrating nation, might seize power, or to what methods they might resort in trying to redeem the situation? Even a truncated Soviet Union, so threatened and so led, and with a mighty nuclear arsenal, could prove a far more serious threat to peace than any Soviet regime so far. A threatened and crumbling Soviet Union also could become a more malignant oppressor of its own peoples. And what effect on stability in Eastern Europe, and elsewhere around the rim of the present Soviet Union, might there be from the emergence of a handful of new nations eager to recoup the lost years of captivity?
If the U.S., despite its actions in Central America, stands for the self-determination of peoples, it can hardly oppose the ultimate independence of Lithuania and other captive Soviet republics. There may be better and safer ways to realize that independence, however, and better ways for the U.S. to support it, than through the ''disintegration'' of the Soviet Union. A sound Soviet economy, leading to a stable Soviet political regime, promises more to the West - and perhaps even to Lithuania - than a disintegrating nation desperately trying to salvage itself.

HEADLINE: Our Towns;
Someone to Call When Jobs End And Pain Grows

BYLINE: By WAYNE KING

DATELINE: LAKEWOOD, N.J.

 BODY:
rrFifty-seven-year-old George Jagger had worked at the Excel Wood Products Company here for 11 years before he was laid off last April.
He had suffered several disabilities, serious back problems and mysterious fractures that seemed to have little or no cause. Before the layoff, the Teamsters union medical plan at the plant paid most of his medical bills, ''well into the thousands,'' but since then, the union contract expired and the union ''just walked away'' the workers say.
All but about 40 of the 400 employees have been laid off. The plant owner informed them last February that the plant would ultimately be closed. It was about that time that Mr. Jagger learned he had osteoporosis, a disease that causes bone degeneration, and that caused his fractures. He still managed to get two other jobs, in a ceramics factory and as an electrician's helper, but his back collapsed again and he had to quit. 
It has been tough, but with the support of his co-workers and a self-help group called the Worker Resource Center, he is ready to try again. He is participating in a federally financed rehabilitation program that includes physical therapy and job retraining that will enable him to take on employment that will not threaten his disabled back.
''I've been looking for work that wouldn't affect my back,'' Mr. Jagger said. ''I didn't know about the vocation rehab. If I had known, I would have looked into it a year ago.''
The training was arranged through the Worker Resource Center, a three-year-old private nonprofit group that is trying to fill the vacuum that invades worker's lives when their jobs disappear. It is just when workers need help the most - when their jobs are gone -that little help is available.
''Unions represent people when they have jobs,'' said Stanley Fischer, who was president of the Oil, Chemical and Atomic Workers local at a 3M plant in Freehold that laid off 360 workers when it closed in 1985. ''After the closure, the workers really didn't have anybody to represent them,'' said Mr. Fischer, 39, who had worked at the plant for 19 years and made $10 an hour as a machine operator.
Mr. Fischer's union - down to 90,000 members from nearly twice that 15 years ago - sent in a transition team, but could do little in the long term. Several of the laid-off workers talked of suicide. Alcoholism and stress-related illness increased, family quarrels erupted and child abuse went up.
With a $25,000 donation from Bruce Springsteen, whose song ''My Hometown'' about growing up in Freehold amid industrial collapse became a blue-collar anthem, Mr. Fischer formed a group called Hometowns Against Shutdowns that also enlisted Willie Nelson, Ed Asner and a score of other celebrities.
But he soon realized it was a losing battle -plant shutdowns in America are dictated by the incontrovertible bottom line - and the Worker Resource Center evolved, as he puts it ''to deal with the carnage.''
Since then there have been a dozen other shutdowns displacing more than 3,000 workers in Ocean and Monmouth counties alone - 600 at CIBA-Geigy Chemical in Toms River, 550 at Charles of the Ritz in Holmdel, among the bigger ones - and the center is trying to pick up the pieces.
At Holmdel a laid-off mother of three developed hysterical breathing problems, withdrew to her home and began keeping the children home from school to be with her. Here in Lakewood a diabetic in his 50's could no longer afford insulin. The center arranged counseling for the woman and arranged for a pharmaceutical company to donate the insulin for the diabetic. There are 75 outstanding medical claims totaling more than $40,000 and neither the company nor the union is willing to pay them.
But for the most part, the center relies on peer counseling: laid-off workers meet from once a week to once a month, as they do in a church here, to talk about their problems. Here, they are mostly Hispanic, and a number do not speak English.
Leon C., 72, a Colombian without papers, made $4 an hour as a cleaning man and assembly line helper, but was asked by his family to leave home after he lost his job because he could no longer pay his way.
Rafael Gonzales speaks no English, and his Spanish is mangled by a severe speech impediment. The center is trying to find a way, without insulting him, to introduce the idea of speech therapy. Tuesday was his 51st birthday, and about a dozen other laid-off workers sang ''Happy Birthday'' at a supper after the meeting. Mr. Gonzales and several others took extra plates home with them.

LENGTH: 588 words

HEADLINE: Court Rules on Assessment Of Subsidized Units in Jersey

BYLINE: By GEORGE JAMES

 BODY:
A New Jersey appeals court has ruled that subsidized housing should be assessed for tax purposes on its actual purchase price, rather than on its higher market value.
A three-judge panel of the Appellate Division of Superior Court on Wednesday reversed a 1988 State Tax Court ruling that allowed Ridgefield Park to assess condominiums bought under the state's affordable-housing guidelines without regard for restrictions on their resale intended to preserve their lower prices.
For advocates of affordable housing, the decision affirmed New Jersey's commitment to building affordable housing. But others, including the New Jersey State League of Municipalities, see the ruling as eroding the tax base of many communities. 
There are about 3,000 to 4,000 units built under the state's affordable-housing guidelines, with another 13,000 to 20,000 planned or under construction.
 
Assessors and Restrictions
Deed restrictions, in order to assure a unit's affordability, limit resale value to the initial purchase price plus consumer price index increases. In the decision, Judge Sylvia B. Pressler, wrote that such restrictions must be considered by assessors in fixing assessments.
The deed restriction, she wrote, is ''a restriction whose burden on the owner is clearly designed to secure a public benefit of overriding social and economic importance, namely the maintenance of this state's woefully inadequate inventory of affordable housing.''
Kathleen Dunleavy, one of two homeowners who had appealed the assessments, said she was ''thrilled, because, aside from expecting a tax refund, ''to tell you the truth, I think a lot of people will benefit from this decision.''
Mrs. Dunleavy, a 31-year old divorced mother of a 10-year old boy, had been paying about $2,000 in taxes based on full market value as opposed to $1,000 she would have paid under the deed restriction on a condominium bought in 1981 for $40,000.
 
Decision to Be Appealed
Martin T. Durkin, the lawyer for Ridgefield Park, said he had conferred with the Mayor and Commissioners and would appeal the decision.
''They were somewhat disappointed because there's a lot of tax exempt property in Ridgefield Park,'' Mr. Durkin said. When the village meets a goal of about 120 units of affordable housing, it stands to lose about $120,000 in taxes because of the decision, he said.
In 1975 and 1983 rulings, the New Jersey Supreme Court required the state's 567 communities to include in their zoning plans housing for low- and moderate-income people. The rulings stemmed from a zoning case in Mount Laurel near Philadelphia.
Sidna Mitchell, a spokeswoman for the state Council on Affordable Housing, said, ''We're delighted because obviously the effect of this decision will be to continue to insure the affordability of the units.''
Under the Mount Laurel formula, after a 10 percent down payment for a unit has been made, the monthly principal, interest, insurance, condominium fees and taxes cannot exceed 28 percent of a family's gross monthly income.
Brian Campion, a Paramus lawyer who represented Mrs. Dunleavy and another resident, Wayne Prowitz, said assessments on full market value would have required developers to absorb the cost of the increased taxes and discouraged the building of affordable housing.
But Jim Moran, legislative analyst for the New Jersey State League of Municipalities said the decision would cause the ''tax burden to fall more heavily on other homeowners'' in many communities, including the elderly.''

HEADLINE: BUSINESS DIGEST

 BODY:

THE ECONOMY
 
Federal regulators and banking experts are concerned that mounting losses from troubled real estate loans could lead to a wave of bank failures, straining the Federal insurance program that protects depositors' funds. The danger, regulators and analysts say, is that when the country enters an economic downturn, as most economists say it eventually must, the losses at commercial banks may be so large that the Government might have to raise insurance fees on the banking industry or rescue some banks with taxpayers' money. [Page A1.] 
 
American industry should enjoy an eighth straight year of expansion, but gains among manufacturers, at 2 percent, will be lower than this year's 2.2 percent, the Commerce Department said. [D2.]
 
INTERNATIONAL
 
Even as the European Community moves to scrap its internal trade barriers by the end of 1992, it is trying to limit access by Japan's powerful auto makers. It is putting pressure on Tokyo to accept a system of ''voluntary import restraints,'' but with a tough twist. Under proposals disclosed this month, even cars that Japanese auto makers assemble at their new European plants would fall within the quotas on Japanese cars. [D1.]
 
COMPANIES
 
American Express has agreed to sell its private banking subsidiary in Geneva to another Swiss banking institution for about $1 billion. [D1.]
 
Three members of the Dorrance family plan to sell their 17.4 percent stake in Campbell Soup, they told the S.E.C. That puts them in opposition to the two sons and one daughter of John T. Dorrance Jr. Mr. Dorrance headed the company until he died in April. The sons and daughter, who own 31 percent of Campbell's stock, last week reaffirmed their intent to keep Campbell independent. [D1.]
 
Eastern Air Lines said it was laying off 600 employees, mostly managers, and cutting wages by 10 percent or 20 percent for about half its work force. [D3.]
 
RJR Nabisco said it had completed the first phase of its plan to reduce its $25 billion debt and would embark on the next stage -refinancing its remaining debt - by seeking Government clearance to sell $1.25 billion in new senior notes. [D3.]
 
L. F. Rothschild Holdings reached agreement with creditors on a bankruptcy court reorganization plan. [D3.]
 
MARKETS
 
Orange juice futures prices rose again after Brazil halted exports to assess the damage in Florida from the cold snap and decide whether to raise prices. HEADLINE: American Express to Sell Geneva Bank for $1 Billion

BYLINE: By KURT EICHENWALD

 BODY:
The American Express Company has reached an agreement to sell its Geneva-based private banking subsidiary to another Swiss banking institution for about $1 billion, American Express said yesterday.
The unit, the TDB American Express Bank, serves only wealthy clients and has assets of about $12 billion. The assets will be assumed by the Compagnie de Banque et d'Investissements of Geneva, or CBI, a leading private banking and asset-management institution in Switzerland.
Under the terms of the deal, a new bank, to be known as the TDB-CBI Bank, will be created through a combination of the institutions. CBI will own 80 percent of the new bank, with American Express owning 20 percent. 
The new bank will be headed by Edgar de Picciotto, CBI's managing director and primary shareholder.
Executives with American Express said yesterday that deposits at TDB American Express would be transferred to the new institution and that CBI would undertake a marketing effort to persuade American Express Bank's clients to invest their deposits with CBI's asset-management activities. Those activities will operate out of the combined bank.
The sale of TDB American Express ends a six-year effort by American Express to break into the clubby world of international banking in Switzerland, and signals that its original hope to become a comprehensive international financial institution did not succeed.
Indeed, while American Express will be selling the subsidiary for more than what it paid for it, the company executives said that changes within the structure of the bank, along with inflation, would mean that the New York-based company would make only a small profit on the sale.
The American Express executives said the agreement to sell the Geneva operation stemmed from a decision last summer to abandon those businesses that it could not dominate.
 
'Critical and Core' Focus
''Because we have so many businesses, we knew we needed to focus on those criticial and core to us,'' said G. Richard Thoman, the president and chief executive of the American Express International Corporation, the unit of the American Express Company that oversees its banking operations. ''The first thing that we decided was that we had to stick to those businesses where we could be the leader.''
Mr. Thoman said that the money from the deal would be used to build up the company's other international financial specialties, including charge-card and other travel-related services.
Negotiations with CBI began about six weeks ago. But European executives outside the company who were familiar with the situation said yesterday that American Express had approached CBI for the second time in three years.
The sale does not affect the American Express Bank Ltd., which has 86 locations in 39 countries. Unlike the Swiss banking operations of TDB American Express, which attracts the wealthiest of clients, these banks serve a broader range of wealthy clients and their businesses.
The company said it expected its American Express Bank Ltd. unit to continue operating in Switzerland through a license to serve its global clients.
 
Flagship Operation
But TDB American Express had been the flagship of the company's international banking effort. American Express bought the bank's core operation, the Trade Development Bank, from Edmond J. Safra, who founded the institution in the 1950's and has developed a reputation for being one of Geneva's leading bankers. The operations were sold to American Express in 1983 for $520 million, with the understanding that Mr. Safra would continue to direct the banking operations.
But Mr. Safra left American Express within two years amid rumors that strains had developed between him and the company's top management in New York. Mr. Safra was allowed to buy back portions of the Trade Development Bank as part of a separation agreement, and they formed the nucleus of the banks he now runs, Safra Republic Holdings S.A. and the Republic New York Corporation, the parent company of the Republic National Bank of New York.
Like TDB American Express, Mr. Safra's operations cater to wealthy clients.
 
Disinformation Effort
The resulting competition between Mr. Safra's banking operations and TDB American Express led to one of the more unusual events in American Express's history. In August, the company apologized to Mr. Safra for conducting a disinformation campaign that led to defamatory news articles about him. The articles, some of which had been found libelous by foreign courts, linked Mr. Safra and the banks he controlled to drug trafficking, organized crime and the Iran-contra affair.
In settling the matter, American Express agreed to pay $8 million to four charities. Executives with the company have said that the campaign resulted from overzealous executives competing with Mr. Safra.
The American Express executives said yesterday that the sale of TDB American Express was not related to last August's events. They declined to say whether they had approached Mr. Safra about selling him the Geneva operation, although they said they had been approached by interested parties whom they declined to name.

HEADLINE: Economic Scene;
Reality's the Thing This Field Needs

BYLINE: By Leonard Silk

DATELINE: ATLANTA

 BODY:
FOR the thousands of economists attending the annual meetings here of the American Economic Association, and for the millions of people in the world undergoing rapid and often chaotic change, there is a crucial question: How good is the state of economics?
The answer from some leaders of the profession: Not so good. Herbert A. Simon of Carnegie-Mellon University, a winner of the Nobel Memorial Prize in Economic Science, contends that the differences and sharp conflicts among economists demonstrate that the state of economic knowledge is insecure.
''The public is not mistaken in its perception that economists disagree frequently and vociferously,'' Mr. Simon said. ''We have Keynesian economics, monetarism, supply-side economics, rational expectations and budget balancing, not to mention free trade, protection for infant industries, and proponents of the income tax, the single tax, the sales tax and almost no taxes at all.'' 
Michael J. Boskin, chairman of the President's Council of Economic Advisers, sought to resolve these clashes by taking what he called a ''pragmatic, eclectic'' position. He said the public could not expect to find a ''pure monetarist, pure Keynesian or pure rational expectationist'' on his staff. ''We are not sticking slavishly to any one of them,'' he said, adding, ''This view is shared by most people in the Administration and fits in with the way President Bush thinks.'' He counseled much greater humility for economists.
Despite differences among economists on both analyses and policies, some critics insist that economists share a common and incorrect approach to understanding human behavior - that they exaggerate human rationality, alleging that people act on the basis of calculations and forecasts of how they can get the most income, profits or well-being.
Kenneth J. Arrow of Stanford University, who won the Nobel Memorial Prize in 1972, observed in an essay in a new book, ''The State of Economic Science,'' that ''the impossibility of carrying out such calculations is manifest from everyday observation and confirmed by the inability of economists using our theory and our computing power to make good forecasts - even good contingent forecasts.'' A contingent forecast is one based on certain assumptions.
Mr. Arrow noted that in experiments, cognitive psychologists had found systematic kinds of bias in human behavior, strongly contradicting the economists' assumption of rational behavior. Both Mr. Arrow and Mr. Simon urged the economists to learn from these psychological studies.
The inability of economists to forecast reliably remains a persistent criticism of the profession. There is increasing question, after the development of chaos theory in mathematics, about whether economic systems, given their complexity and the possibility that small changes in some variables will produce enormous changes in the overall system, is inherently chaotic and does not lend itself to dependable forecasts.
Even some of the most mathematical economists now complain that the field has become overly wedded to abstract theories and too careless and casual in amassing the empirical data on which understanding must be based.
While noting that no serious economist opposes applying mathematical techniques to economics, Henry Woo of the Hong Kong Institute of Economic Science said, ''What causes concern over present-day economics is the dominance of mathematics almost to the exclusion of other methods of inquiry and the imposition of a mathematical finality on the subject.''
Despite this bill of indictment, economists remain a cocky and feisty group. Because they are consulted routinely by public, press and Presidents, they believe, perhaps correctly, that they are the only wheel in town. Economics is certainly too important to be left to non-economists, with their own heavy political or personal interests.
But there is more to be said in behalf of the best of the profession. They have over the years developed concepts of the interdependence of elements within a system that are not obvious to lay people looking at one event at a time. They have tackled problems, increasingly interesting to other sciences, of decision-making in the face of uncertainty. And they have sometimes shown an imagination and inventiveness in problem-solving that society urgently needs.
The danger is that economists, with their infatuation with abstruse theory, neglect the hard empirical work on which public policies must depend.
In brief, as some outstanding economists see it, the field needs to be both richer in its intellectual and empirical content and more of a science in the true sense. As Mr. Simon put it: ''What distinguishes science from every other form of human intellectual activity is that it disciplines speculation with facts. Theory and data are the two blades of the scissors. But the metaphor is not quite right, for the blades are not symmetrical. When theories and facts are in conflict, the theories must yield. Economics has strayed from that simple principle, and it must return to it.''
One way of getting there is for more economists of this generation to get as involved in economic problem-solving as their predecessors during the Depression, World War II and the Marshall Plan.

HEADLINE: Slower Growth Is Seen For U.S. Manufacturers

BYLINE: By ROBERT D. HERSHEY Jr., Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Dec. 28

 BODY:
American industry should enjoy an eighth straight year of expansion in 1990, but the gains among manufacturers, at 2 percent, will be lower than this year's 2.2 percent, the Commerce Department said today.
High-technology and health-related industries are expected to post the biggest increases in growth, with the auto makers and construction prominent among the laggards.
''Over all, in 1990 we see continued but slower growth for the vast majority of industries, both manufacturing and services,'' said J. Michael Farren, Under Secretary of Commerce for International Trade. ''This is consistent with the expected overall performance of the United States economy.'' 
 
Based on G.N.P. Assumptions
Mr. Farren briefed reporters as the department published summaries of ''U.S. Industrial Outlook,'' its annual survey of the prospects for more than 350 manufacturing and service industries.
The survey was based on the Bush Administration's mid-1989 assumption that gross national product would rise by 2.3 percent next year. But if a recession occurs, the department's expectations will not be met, one official ackowledged.
Although officials cautioned that the survey did not constitute a forecast for the entire economy, the Outlook's broad scope excludes only government, utilities and wholesaling among the major sectors.
One of the more noteworthy items disclosed by the publication is that receipts from foreign visitors to the United States this year will for the first time exceed spending by Americans traveling abroad. With total expenditures for travel services expected to rise nearly 7 percent in 1990, the United States will run a trade surplus of more than $1 billion in this area, the department said.
 
Growth in Chemical Exports
Another positive sign involved exports, which have shown little growth in recent months.
The chemical industry, which by some measures is the nation's biggest industrial exporter, is expected to post ''moderate'' growth, with its exports rising above $38 billion. ''This industry is at the focal point of a 'new material' renaissance,'' Mr. Farren said. The industry has been shifting its focus to high-value-added speciality products from inexpensive bulk chemicals.
Aerospace, probably the No. 2 exporter, will show a 3.5 percent increase in constant-dollar shipments despite a decline in military sales, the department predicted. More than 500 large commercial jets are to be delivered next year, more than three times the number in 1984.
Other strong industries are projected to be medical equipment and measuring and control devices. The paper industry is expected to show ''steady growth'' and sales of wood products, while slow domestically, are expected to rise abroad.
 
'A Lot of Export Strength'
''There's still a lot of export strength out there,'' said Jonathan C. Menes, director of the Office of Industry Assessment.
Of the 193 manufacturing industries in the survey, 150 of them are expected to grow, officials said.
The manufacturers and the service industries covered in the Outlook are measured by revenues, receipts, expenditures, manufacturing value or other benchmarks and cannot be directly compared.
On the negative side, the auto makers in 1990 will suffer another year of falling sales, the department said, although the decline should be less than 100,000 vehicles units, far less than this year's drop of 600,000 vehicles. Analysts saw little change in the overall market share for imported vehicles, but they expect the Japanese to continue to take market share from European luxury cars.
Construction activity was projected to be about the same in constant dollars, with housing starts probably flat after a drop of 90,000 this year. The value of residential construction, however, should rise because of an increase in home improvements and a greater proportion of larger new homes.
 
Services Lead the Way
Service industries are again expected to outperform manufacturing industries, the department said, but it provided no aggregate growth rate. Business and information services will lead the way. In the first half of 1989, business services generated a trade surplus five times the rate of 1985.
The 500-page Outlook, prepared by 130 industry analysts supported by economists and statisticians, is to be available at the end of January for $27 through the United States Government Printing Office and at its 23 regional bookstores.

HEADLINE: Eastern Plans Wage Cuts, 600 Layoffs

BYLINE: By AGIS SALPUKAS

 BODY:
Eastern Airlines said yesterday that it was laying off 600 employees, mostly managers, and cutting wages by 10 percent or 20 percent for about half its work force.
Thomas J. Matthews, Eastern's senior vice president of human resources, estimated that the measures would save the carrier about $100 million a year. He said at a news conference in Miami that the steps had been taken because of Eastern's sale of the airline's Latin American routes to American Airlines for $471 million and because of a decision to downsize. 
The carrier disclosed last week that it would scale back its operations to two-thirds its size before a crippling strike began on March 4 and said that some ''furloughs'' would result.
 
Back to Earlier Plan
Several months ago, Eastern, buoyed by its ability to rebuild faster than expected under the protection of the Federal bankruptcy court, said it was planning to rebuild to about 80 percent of the size it had maintained before the strike by machinists' union began. The carrier's pilots and flight attendants walked out in sympathy, but called off their actions before Thanksgiving.
But last Friday, Eastern said it had decided to go back to its original, more modest plan. Mr. Matthews said yesterday that the decision had resulted from low traffic, stiff competition in Miami from such carriers as Pan Am and an uncertain economic outlook for next year.
He said Eastern planned to file its reorganization plan soon with the United States Bankruptcy Court for the Southern District of New York.
Eastern sought bankruptcy protection five days after the strike began last March, and, with the approval of the court, has sold more than $1.5 billion in assets to keep operating and to reorganize.
Judge Burton R. Lifland, the chief judge of the court, has supported Eastern management's attempt to rebuild the carrier, which has most of its routes on the East Coast.
The 10 percent wage cuts will affect the more senior employees, not the new and recently hired workers who receive much lower wages. The 20 percent cut will affect senior management.
 
Some Not Affected
Mr. Matthews said the job cutbacks, totaling about 3 percent of its employees, would not affect pilots, mechanics or flight attendants, who make up most of Eastern's work force of 20,000. He added that the current layoffs would be the last for Eastern to put into effect under its reorganization plan.
Many of the reductions will be made in the Miami area, where Eastern is based and where flights will be cut to 50, from 75, by Jan. 31. Other reductions will be made when American takes over the Latin American routes on July 1.
The Pan Am Corporation said yesterday that it would object to the route sale to American, which must be approved by the Justice Deprtment, the Transportation Department and the bankruptcy court.
Eastern plans to rebuild by making Atlanta its primary hub and expects to operate about 75 percent of its flights from there.

HEADLINE: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: ADVERTISING;
An Emblem Is Renewed For Merrill

BYLINE: By Randall Rothenberg

 BODY:
AMERICA can rest on this last weekend of the 1980's secure in the knowledge that ''Merrill Lynch is bullish on the 90's.''
On Sunday, the brokerage house that took the bull out of the pasture and thrust him into Wall Street nearly two decades ago (where the menagerie also included the Dreyfus lion) will premiere the latest stage in the evolution of its lasting advertising concept.
Actually, the new broadcast campaign, which will saturate televised sports events on Sunday and Monday, is the confluence of two themes that Merrill Lynch has been developing through its advertising agency since 1986, Bozell. While extolling the risk-taking investor symbolized by the bull, the commercials close with the slogan the company introduced last year, ''A tradition of trust.'' 
The underpinning of the campaign was revealed in a handwritten statement written and read by Bozell's chief executive, Charles D. (Chuck) Peebler Jr., in an early-morning interview two days after Christmas.
Mr. Peebler went on for many minutes about how ''Merrill Lynch believes in the American spirit,'' which he said was exemplified by the country's 138 million telephones, $25 billion in annual charitable giving, 47 electrical appliances in the average American home and mere 18 minutes it takes the average American to earn enough money to purchase a pound of hamburger. ''Sometimes,'' Mr. Peebler said, ''the positives don't get accentuated the way they should.''
Fortunately, such dryly statistical positives are not accentuated in Bozell's new ads for Merrill Lynch. Instead, the commercials are a showcase for the creative reformation that Jay Schulberg promised to instigate when he left Ogilvy & Mather last year and became creative director of Bozell, New York.
The three dramatic spots are visually surprising panoramas that use much of the technical trickery familiar from the plethora of MTV-influenced ads on the air. But they use the technology in soft and inspiring, rather than harsh and jarring, ways.
''We wanted to be future-oriented without looking too high tech,'' said Paul Critchlow, Merrill Lynch's director of corporate communications.
In ''Skies,'' for example, a bull marches silently across a plain, while in the sky above him a century's worth of images glide by, from biplanes and doughboys to Iwo Jima and Yalta to Solidarity and the space shuttle.
''The point of that commercial is the role Merrill plays in understanding and interpreting events for its customers,'' said Charles Mangano, the company's director of corporate advertising.
Interestingly, the other two commercials, ''Bullseye'' and ''Glass Hallway,'' also use sky imagery.
In the first, which addresses the importance of family savings to America's economic competitiveness, the camera pulls back from a simple slice of life - a mother sending her child off to school - to present the scene in an ever-wider context, showing in turns aerial views of their block, neighborhood, town, state, nation and planet. In the end the globe turns out to be a reflection in a bull's eye.
''Glass Hallway'' opens on an office corridor, transparent except for an endless series of doors, and suspended in midair. As the announcer talks about the future's ''limitless possibilities,'' the camera goes through the doors, skimming through a toxic-waste dump and an old-age home, then to more uplifting scenes of a robotics factory and active senior citizens. Here, the bull is a subtle presence, reflected in the grain of a desk.
''Creatively, the point is to break out of the sameness in the financial services category,'' Mr. Schulberg said. ''Everyone is saying, 'Let us manage your money.' No one until now is saying it in a distinctive way.''

HEADLINE: CREDIT MARKETS;
Treasury Security Prices Advance

BYLINE: By KENNETH N. GILPIN

 BODY:
Prices of Treasury securities moved higher in very light trading yesterday, as dealers took advantage of a recent fairly steep drop to do some buying.
''We have had a nice little tailspin over the last few days, with yields on some securities rising by as much as 25 basis points,'' one government bond trader said.
''We got roughly a 5-basis-point reversal from those levels during this session, and I think we are poised for a rally once the new year begins. But the key will be what the December employment data show a week from Friday.'' 
The urge to buy was buttressed by a dip in energy prices and a firmer dollar. Despite the importance of the December employment data, traders were unmoved by a weekly report that showed a slight rise in initial unemployment claims.
''On balance, dealers spent the last couple of days closing their books,'' said Raymond W. Stone, a managing director at Stone & McCarthy Research Associates, a firm that provides research and commentary on the credit and foreign exchange markets. ''For the most part, both dealers and investors have just been riding out the last few days of the year.''
 
Collapse of Bond Dealer
Traders said the collapse of Swink & Company, a small Arkansas bond dealer, had little impact in the credit markets.
On Wednesday the company, which is based in Little Rock, said it had permanently closed its doors after sustaining more than $1 million in losses trading government bonds.
''A trading loss of that size is not big enough to cause even a ripple in this market,'' one bond trader said.
By late yesterday, the Treasury's 8 1/8 percent bonds of 2019 were offered at a price of 101 7/8, up 7/32, to yield 7.95 percent.
Among note issues, the 7 7/8 percent 10-year notes were offered in late trading at 99 29/32, up 1/4 of a point, to yield 7.88 percent. And the 7 3/4 percent five-year notes were offered at 99 5/8, up 7/32, to yield 7.82 percent.
 
Short-Term Bill Rates
Short-term Treasury bill rates eased slightly even as the overnight rate for bank loans in the Federal funds market moved sharply higher.
Year-end financing pressures often push the funds rate higher at the end of December, and yesterday's increase came as no surprise.
Yesterday the rate traded in a range of 9 3/4 percent to 9 3/8 percent, more than a full percentage point above the 8.25 percent level that most money market analysts say is the Fed's current target for the funds rate.
Treasury bill traders ignored the increase in the cost of overnight money, and bill rates moved lower.
By late in the day, three-month bills were offered at a discount rate of 7.67 percent, down a basis point, or hundredth of a point. Six-month bill rates fell by 5 basis points, to a late offered rate of 7.52 percent. One-year bill rates fell by a similar amount, to a late offered rate of 7.22 percent.
Mr. Stone and other analysts said that if anything today's activity is likely to be even more subdued than yesterday's session, as market participants head off for the long New Year's Day holiday weekend.
''Friday should be a real ho-hummer,'' Mr. Stone said.
Elsewhere, participants in the secondary markets for corporate and tax-exempt municipal bonds said that activity was extremely light. Prices of most issues were unchanged on the day.
No new issues of corporate or municipal debt were priced yesterday.
In other developments, the Federal Reserve Board reported yesterday that all three measures of the nation's money supply rose during the week ended Dec. 18. The report had no impact on prices in the credit markets.

HEADLINE: Dow Rises 7.90 Points, To 2,732.30

BYLINE: By PHILLIP H. WIGGINS

 BODY:
Stock prices rose across a broad front yesterday, but the advance was tempered by end-of-the-year selling.
The Dow Jones industrial average gained 7.90 points, to 2,732.30, as advances on the New York Stock Exchange outnumbered declines, 842 to 673. The Dow moved in only about a 13-point range throughout the day. 
Volume on the Big Board contracted to 128 million shares, from 133.7 million on Wednesday.
In the broader market. the Standard & Poor's index of 500 stocks gained 1.86 points, to 350.67, while the New York Stock Exchange composite index added 0.90, to 193.59.
''The stock market is digesting a change in leadership,'' observed Rao Chalasani, the chief investment strategist at Prescott, Ball & Turben Inc. in Cleveland. ''Money already is moving away from popular stocks, such as some consumer staples and insurance issues, into recently unpopular groups like chemicals, paper, technology and regional banks. This change in leadership seems to be for real.''
 
Champion Jumps to $30.75
He noted, for example, that Champion International, the large building materials and paper products company based in Stamford, Conn., rose 1 3/8, to 30 3/4, in active trading.
Campbell Soup climbed 4 3/8, to 57 3/8, on renewed buyout speculation after a group of Dorrance family members said it wanted to sell its 17.4 percent of the company, based in Camden, N.J. The opening of trading in the stock was delayed because of an imbalance of buy orders, traders said.
Polaroid jumped 3 points, to 44 1/4. An analyst for Prudential-Bache Securities, Alex Henderson, reiterated a strong ''buy'' recomendation on the company, based in Cambridge, Mass., after raising his estimate of the damage award the company would receive from Eastman Kodak in a patent-infringement case to $1.5 billion, from $800 million to $1 billion. Kodak, with headquarters in Rochester, was unchanged at 40 3/4.
For the second day, foreign funds were among the biggest percentage gainers on the Big Board, as they apparently continued to benefit from anticipation of economic change in the Eastern bloc. The Austria Fund rose 2 1/2, to 19 1/2; Spain Fund gained 3, to 31 1/2, and Germany Fund rose 1 3/4, to 19, buoyed by Japanese buying.
Blue chips dominated the most active list, with Philip Morris rising 7/8, to 41 1/8, Chase Manhattan unchanged at 34 3/4 and I.B.M falling 5/8, to 94 1/8.
On the American Stock Exchange, the market-value index gained 0.94, to 373.90, while in over-the-counter trading, the Nasdaq composite added 1.17 points, to 449.98.
In Tokyo, the Nikkei index of 225 issues ended the year at a record 38,876.94, rising 75.31 points, or 0.19 percent.

HEADLINE: CURRENCY MARKETS;
Dollar Is Up Sharply in U.S. After Mixed Day in Europe

BYLINE: By The Associated Press

 BODY:
The dollar finished sharply higher in domestic trading yesterday after a mixed performance overseas.
Trading was thin in Europe, where the dollar was buffeted by trading in other currencies. Dealers in Frankfurt said the Bank of England and the central bank of the Netherlands had intervened to curb the strength of the West German mark against their currencies. 
But when dealings shifted to the United States, the dollar moved sharply higher on technical factors, traders said. The dollar's biggest move came against the yen, which was adversely affected by reports of political uncertainty in the face of coming elections.
 
'Thin Market' Noted
The dollar traded in seesaw fashion throughout the session. Its moves were ''accentuated by the thin market,'' said Michael McDonald, a trader at Harris Trust and Savings Bank in Chicago.
''The mark remained the strongest currency in the world,'' he said, noting that interest-rate differentials are tipping in favor of West Germany over the United States. Further bolstering the mark is the assumption that the opening of East Germany will spur a demand for West German products.
In Tokyo, the dollar rose to 142.15 Japanese yen, from 142.10 yen on Wednesday. Later in London, it rose to 143.15 yen. In New York the dollar closed at 143.55 yen, up from 142.00 yen on Wednesday.
In London, the British pound fell to $1.6137, from $1.6255 late Wednesday. In New York it cost $1.6045 to buy 1, cheaper than Wednesday's $1.6275.
Other late dollar rates in New York, compared with late Wednesday, included: 1.6875 West German marks, up from 1.6855; 1.5390 Swiss francs, up from 1.5295; 5.7675 French francs, up from 5.7600; 1,264.15 Italian lire, up from 1,263.75, and 1.1568 Canadian dollars, down from 1.1574.
Other late dollar rates in Europe, compared with late Wednesday, included: 1.6905 West German marks, up from 1.6895; 1.5385 Swiss francs, up from 1.5355; 5.7665 French francs, down from 5.7760; 1.9000 Dutch guilders, down from 1.9080; 1,264.50 Italian lire, down from 1,266.00, and 1.1563 Canadian dollars, down from 1.1587.
