HEADLINE: Explosive Drug Use Creating New Underworld Prisons

SERIES: Drugs and the Law
Last of three articles:
Addiction Behind Bars

BYLINE: By ANDREW H. MALCOLM

 BODY:
Drug use inside prisons across the United States has become a major problem with a variety of consequences, including threats to prison order, violence among inmates and corruption of guards and other employees.
After years of denying or overlooking the existence of illicit drugs behind the towering walls and ribbons of razor wire that encircle their institutions, prison administrators, as well as academics, have only just begun to study the precise scale of inmate drug abuse.
But a series of interviews, visits to prisons and reviews of the professional literature in recent weeks indicate the problem is more widely acknowledged. Controversial steps are already being taken to combat the surprising ingenuity of prison drug smugglers. And many prison officials express resignation that the problem will never be solved without Draconian measures that American society seems unwilling to impose. 
''There's been a real explosion of drug use in prison,'' said Dr. Harry Wexler of Narcotics and Drug Research Inc., a nonprofit company that does considerable research with Federal grants. ''The explanation is simple: There's been a real explosion of drug users going to prison.'' William Flower, a spokesman for the Connecticut Department of Correction, added, ''What you have on the street is what you have on the inside.''
More than three dozen states are operating under some kind of court order controlling overcrowding, and tough enforcement of drug laws has worsened that problem as more men and women have been convicted of drug violations. Estimates of the prisoners personally involved with drugs now range from 40 to 90 percent.
Thousands of new cells are planned or under construction, costing billions of dollars. President Bush's new anti-drug program contains an 85 percent increase in Federal money for prison construction.
Never in the nation's history have so many of its citizens been imprisoned. As of June 30, state and Federal prisons contained 673,565 prisoners. That was an increase of 7.3 percent, or 56,004 prisoners just since January, a larger increase in six months than the nation has ever experienced in a whole year.
Formal drug rehabilitation treatment within prisons is just in its infancy, and many of those facing long sentences for drug offenses like trafficking were drug abusers themselves.
Often during their daytime rounds of noisy prison common rooms, guards detect the familiar glazed look of an addict intoxicated on drugs. They tell of coming upon inmates shooting up in the private shadows of their cells, and at night, the guards say, they routinely smell marijuana smoke drifting out from the darkness behind the bars. Inmates, too, tell of witnessing frequent drug use.
''I've seen more drugs in here than out there,'' said Charles Capers, a 37-year-old, six-time convict in the Connecticut penal system.
Sharon A. Williams of the National Criminal Justice Reference Service, said, ''The prison drug problem is beginning to emerge now,'' adding, ''You couldn't talk about it before.''
Not every prison system admits to a major problem. Greg Bogdan, a spokesman for the Federal Bureau of Prisons, whose institutions hold about 7 percent of the nation's prisoners, said 49,936 random urine tests of Federal prisoners in the nine months ending last June 30 found only 2.2 percent testing positive, half the 1986 rate.
It is generally in the far larger state and county prison systems that the problem is detected and now openly discussed.
''Prisons are an incredible captive drug market,'' said Bob B., a former New York prison counselor and onetime heroin addict who asked that his full name not be used. ''Drugs inside can bring three times their street value.'' He told of counseling prisoners fearful for their lives because they were caught in wars among inmates competing for control of drug sales. He himself admitted smuggling in some drugs on occasion.
Indeed, announcements of arrests of prison staff for drug smuggling have become frequent. In Michigan, some prison personnel were charged with accepting bribes to arrange for some inmates to transfer from one institution to another to expand the prison drug rings.
 
The Smugglers
 
Liberalized Visiting,
Ingenious Conduits
Though prison staff involvement in drug smuggling and sales is a serious problem, the principal transporters of drugs into prisons, the officials say, are visitors. And the increasingly large numbers of visitors make thorough individual searches unrealistic, if not impossible, given current liberalized visiting policies and procedures. Drug deliveries by visitors and payments to drug suppliers are easily arranged from inside by unmonitored pay phones, the officials said.
The drugs arrive in prison in many imaginative manners - squeezed into the bindings of books, hidden on the back of stamps, inside a girlfriend's bra or a baby's diapers and stuffed into rectums or vaginas.
Searches are often prohibited by courts unless there is good reason for suspicion. To establish such probable cause, all visitors to New York City's Rikers Island prisons, for instance, are assigned numbered seats on special buses. After a short ride, visitors are removed from the bus while trained drug-sniffing dogs check each seat. When the dogs, with names like Curley, Melvin, Major and Roscoe, indicate strong interest in a particular seat, the occupant is required to undergo a thorough body search or his or her visit is canceled.
 
Thick Glass Is Gone
The scale of the problem in checking visitors is evident in the crowded New York City jail system. It has 20,300 prisoners in its 15 institutions, 2,810 more than last December. It has 12,293 employees, including 10,210 correction officers, or guards. Each year the system must also process nearly 400,000 visitors, or several visitors for each prisoner.
And while visitors are screened by metal detectors and a handful of guards monitor the visiting rooms, security is nothing like the popular image from old movies, with prisoners and families separated by thick glass and conversing by telephone.
In the last decade or so, prison philosophy has emphasized helping prisoners maintain family ties as an integral part of their long-range rehabilitation. So most institutions now allow what are called ''contact visits.'' Typically, dozens of prisoners sit across open tables from visitors, holding hands. Embraces and kisses are allowed at the beginning and end of the visit.
One popular means of transmitting drugs is to exchange a balloon packed with drugs during a kiss. Some prisons videotape visiting rooms, and guards replay tapes of the initial embraces to spot suspicious kisses. Those prisoners will then undergo a particularly rigorous examination by guards after the visit before being returned to their cell.
Some prisoners have been known to swallow the balloon before such searches and to recover the drugs later either by induced vomiting or retrieving the container from their own excrement in a day or two.
 
'Sit Around and Connive'
Another exchange method is for a visitor to deposit the drugs in a designated prison washroom, which is then very promptly ''cleaned'' by an inmate crew. Still another is for the visitor to flush a bag of drugs down a prison toilet for waiting inmates to fish from the institution's sewage treatment plant.
Michael A. Chernovetz, warden of the Community Correctional Center in Bridgeport, Conn., said most citizens are unaware of how prisons are run today. ''They think every institution is always locked up tighter than a drum,'' he said. ''But the fiscal reality is that I've got to have nonviolent inmates performing many maintenance and caretaker jobs - sweeping driveways, cutting grass, putting out garbage. That inmate earns 75 cents a day. A staff member earns a little more than that. I can't have one staffer stand behind every inmate who goes outside for a few minutes.
''And all it takes is a phone call to a girlfriend to tell her to leave the bag in the third bush from the corner. We even have mothers bringing in the stuff. We try to get as much as possible. But these guys have a lot of time to sit around and connive.''
 
The Impact Inside
 
Corroded Order,
Imported Hostility
Warden Chernovetz and others say the impact of drugs in prison is not so much that prisoners intoxicated by drugs are likely to assault officers, although that has happened. It is more the danger to the institution of importing wholesale into prison the violent, grievance-filled, debt-ridden drug culture of the streets. A more hostile environment results, with the inmates more prone than ever to argue and fight among themselves.
Prison authorities say the underground drug economy creates a generally unsafe environment that corrodes order, reduces the effectiveness of academic and drug treatment programs and can create staff corruption.
''Sometimes,'' said Bob, the former New York prison counselor, ''these inmates were counseling me like an out-mate. They thought I was a fool, coming into prison every day voluntarily for my $23,000 a year and getting high only on the weekends. They arrived in cuffs, were high seven days a week and had a definite date to get out and start making their 100 G's a year dealing drugs.''
''The guards and the bad guys in prison come from the same neighborhoods,'' Bob added. ''The nice guys became guards going to work every day and the nasty guys became occasional inmates. But, you know, if you go to the zoo every day, when you come home, you begin reeking of the zoo.''
 
Problems in Local Jails
The Illinois Department of Corrections reported earlier this year that 66 employees had been arrested in the previous three years on drug and other illegal contraband charges. In one recent six-month period nearly 650 inmates and 100 visitors were involved in such contraband cases.
''We have a bigger problem than society in general,'' the Cook County Sheriff, James O'Grady, said in Chicago after three deputies were among 19 charged last spring in Federal indictments with running a drug ring to supply inmates in the county jail. Two Connecticut guards were arrested for drug smuggling this fall. In Michigan, a Federal-state study group is investigating reports that state corrections officials allowed visitors to smuggle illicit drugs and protected inmates from searches in return for payments of up to $1,000 a week by dealers.
Ruby Ryles of New York City's Department of Correction said that in the last 18 months, 17 department employees had been arrested on prison drug charges. ''Inmates are very creative finding ways of getting drugs in,'' she said. ''But we're creative in finding them, too.''
 
In Search of Solutions
 
Stiff Enforcement
And Interdiction
Phil Seelig, president of the Correction Officers' Benevolent Association, which has 9,000 members in the city penal system, said that guards who had been arrested on drug charges had been enticed to participate and that the ''widespread drug problem'' in city jails resulted from lax security procedures for visitors and failure to properly prosecute prisoners found with drugs.
''We'd also like to see contact visits abandoned and more thorough regular searches of cells,'' he added. As a result of manpower and time constraints, he said, guards can search the accommodations of only about 50 inmates a day out of 2,000 in each unit. ''That doesn't even make a dent,'' he said. ''The drugs just flow into the unsearched area for a while. And those found with drugs should get more time, not just disciplined.''
Wisconsin has stressed enforcement within prison over interdiction. It uses random announced urine tests to discourage drug use, with progressively stiffer disciplinary penalties imposed with each positive test result. Positive test results shrank over three recent years from around 30 percent to the 3 to 6 percent range, with higher rates in the higher security prisons. Officials say this has meant the removal of 1,150 drug users from the prison market in the same period.
 
Rare Searches of Guards
Search procedures vary. Most systems use metal detectors on visitors, and some use them on guards. South Carolina does a pat-down search of all visitors, but other states hesitate without probable cause, fearing lawsuits. Many systems rely on random inmate strip searches after visits.
Guards could be searched but rarely are without a solid tip. ''That would be really awkward, officers searching officers,'' said Mike Van Winkle of California's prison system.
Mr. Chernovetz of the Connecticut system said: ''Sure, some officers are camels. It would be naive to say that some are not drug-involved.''
Many systems are subjecting newly hired officers to rigorous investigation and drug testing. And Florida has begun stiff prosecution of staff members found with drugs. ''Our best deterrent,'' said Bob McMaster of Florida's Department of Corrections, ''is to let our own people see that we're going to be very tough on our own people.''
''Sure,'' said Mr. Flower of Connecticut, ''you could stop all drugs getting into prison. You'd clamp down so hard - no human contact, no visits, no exchanges - it would create an inhuman, explosive situation probably worse than what we've got.''

PUB-DATE: December 30, 1989

SECTION: Section 1; Page 1, Column 6; Foreign Desk

LENGTH: 1484 words

HEADLINE: AFTER NORIEGA: VATICAN IS BLAMING U.S. FOR IMPASSE ON NORIEGA'S FATE

BYLINE: By ROBERTO SURO

 BODY:
The Vatican blamed the American Government yesterday for the impasse over Gen. Manuel Antonio Noriega's fate, calling the United States an ''occupying power'' with no right to demand that the ousted dictator be handed over to its forces.
The chief Vatican spokesman, Joaquin Navarro-Valls, told journalists in Rome yesterday morning that General Noriega was being urged to leave the Vatican's diplomatic mission in Panama City of his own free will.
Mr. Navarro also said that it was up to the Panamanian Government to seek custody of General Noriega if he was to face criminal charges but that so far no such request had come from Panama.
 
Signs of Impatience
Although in its public statements the Vatican continued to characterize contacts with the Bush Administration as friendly, Roman Catholic Church officials began showing signs of impatience with the Administration's insistence that General Noriega must be turned over to American troops, and for the first time American behavior in Panama was publicly criticized yesterday by the Vatican.
The White House reacted to the Vatican statements by insisting that all is well in relations with the church. 
''The Vatican's doing a fine job,'' said Marlin Fitzwater, the White House spokesman. ''We appreciate their efforts. We will continue to work with them in a positive way.''
 
'A Very Difficult Situation'
''It's a very difficult situation, very tense circumstances,'' Mr. Fitzwater continued. ''Our interest is in establishing a harmonious relationship with the Vatican. The Vatican is acting responsibly and cooperatively. We are going to calmly go about pursuing this matter.''
Roman Catholic leaders in the United States have reacted with indignation to criticism of the Vatican. John Cardinal O'Connor of New York said on Thursday he had been ''appalled by the attacks against the church and the Holy See.''
When Mr. Navarro, Mr. Fitzwater's counterpart in the Vatican, was asked about the blockade of the Papal Nunciature in Panama City by American troops and their practice of blasting the building with rock music, he said it was ''a very serious matter,'' unacceptable under international law because it interfered with diplomatic activity.
Senior Vatican officials interviewed by telephone yesterday said the apparent effort at psychological warfare was ''ludicrous'' and ''childish.''
Loudspeakers outside the Nunciature have been playing tunes like ''Voodoo Chile,'' ''Nowhere to Run'' and ''Smugglers Blues'' in what appeared to be an effort to irritate General Noriega.
Mr. Fitzwater was asked at his briefing in Corpus Christi, Tex., on Thursday about whether playing loud rock music outside the Papal Nuncio's residence was further fraying already frayed nerves inside the building. He replied, ''It was an attempt to disrupt communications so that we could have some guarantees of the security of our conversations.''
''You may recall during the Moscow summit when we had the morning meetings in the Moscow Embassy and all around, we had music playing of various kinds to disrupt microwaves and so forth,'' he said. ''That's fairly standard practice.''
When asked about the selection of songs, Mr. Fitzwater said he was ''certainly glad to see the American sense of whimsy come forward in this situation.''
The Vatican officials, who asked not to be named, said the bloodshed caused by the American invasion had raised moral and ethical concerns for Pope John Paul II, but they asserted that opinions on the validity of the American operation were not coloring negotiations over General Noriega's status.
The officials did, however, express misgivings about the heated language the Bush Administration has used in demanding custody of General Noriega, questioning whether domestic political concerns were coloring the Administration's diplomatic posture.
''Sometimes it seems that this obsession with Noriega is being used as a screen to cover what is a very serious military operation with very high human costs,'' said an official directly involved in the negotiations over the general, who took refuge in the Papal Nunciature, the Holy See's diplomatic mission, on Dec. 24.
Another official said, ''There is an appearance of some efforts at misinformation in order to keep the pressure on us.'' He referred to articles this week in which American officials indicated that General Noriega was moving money among several European bank accounts from within the Vatican mission.
''The Americans know full well,'' the official said, ''that as one of the conditions for entering the Nunciature, Noriega accepted total isolation, no visitors and no telephone conversations.''
The official added, ''The Americans have said they want to restore constitutional and democratic rule in Panama, but on the first major issue faced by the new Government there, they are stepping in and saying in effect, 'Give Noriega to us because we are in charge here.' I am afraid it is a bit contradictory.''
 
U.S. Demand Is Rejected
In a briefing for journalists yesterday, Mr. Navarro said of the United States role in Panama, ''An occupying power cannot interfere with the work of a diplomatic mission nor demand that a person seeking asylum in that mission be handed over to it.''
''If the person who seeks asylum is considered guilty of common crimes, it is up to the Government of the country to which the diplomatic mission is accredited to ask for him to be handed over,'' Mr. Navarro said, adding that the Vatican was not discussing the Noriega case with any nations other than the United States and Panama.
Both in public statements and interviews, Vatican officials have said that the decision to grant General Noriega temporary refuge had brought an end to the fighting in Panama and that his case could be resolved through commonly accepted diplomatic norms governing asylum cases.
The Vatican diplomats also noted that the United States had itself made use of diplomatic asylum to help resolve civil conflicts aboard. They cited the cases of Ferdinand E. Marcos of the Philippines and Anastasio Somoza Debayle of Nicaragua, two deposed dictators who were given asylum by the United States and were protected from facing charges in their homelands.
 
No 'Moral Judgment' Implied
''General Noriega has not been accorded status as political refugee, and the decision to afford him temporary asylum does not imply a moral judgment about the man in any way,'' Mr. Navarro said.
He recalled that President Guillermo Endara, new head of the Panamanian Government installed by the United States, spent several weeks in the Nunciature in Panama City earlier this year when he was being sought by the Noriega Government.
The Rev. Robert Graham, a Jesuit and author of diplomatic histories for the Vatican Secretariat of State, said: ''Diplomatic asylum is a matter of common practice in Latin America, and it is accepted and acknowledged by all the nations there and by the United States as well. It is a question of Latin American diplomatic norms, not of Vatican policies or procedures. Diplomatic asylum is also very different from granting someone residence in a country as a political refugee. This is simply a device to grant temporary haven while a person's status is negotiated.''
Father Graham noted that deposed government leaders and dissident politicians in Latin America had often taken refuge in embassies. The common practice, he said, is for the embassy to then negotiate with the government in power to arrange either a safe passage out of the country or conditions under which the person would surrender to the government or simple assurances that the person could go free.
 
Clarifications Sought
A Vatican diplomat involved in Noriega negotiations said: ''A major problem is that we do not have much of a government in Panama to deal with. If someone down there could tell us what they want to do with Noriega and why, that would be a big step. If Panama and the United States could tell us that they have agreed on whether or not Noriega would be extradited to Florida, that too would be a big step. But there have to be some clarifications from Panama before we can do much unless he decides he wants to step outside and take his chances with the Americans.''
Mr. Navarro said Msgr. Jose Sebastian Laboa, the Papal Nuncio in Panama, is ''doing his best to convince General Noriega to leave the Papal Nunciature of his own free will, but he can not force General Noriega to leave the embassy.''
On another matter, Mr. Fitzwater said that a ''high-level economic delegation'' would go to Panama on Wednesday to confer with Panamanian officials on their economic needs. The delegation will be headed by Deputy Secretary of State Lawrence S. Eagleburger and Deputy Secretary of the Treasury John Robson. They will be accompanied by economic experts from several Federal agencies.

HEADLINE: Upheaval in the East: The Ceausescu Tribunal;
Excerpts From Trial Of Rumanian Leader

BYLINE: Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Dec. 29 -

 BODY:
Nicolae Ceausescu, the executed Rumanian President, and his wife, Elena, were taken before a military tribunal in Bucharest on Dec. 25 and charged with crimes against the country. The charges included complicity in the killings of as many as 60,000 Rumanians during their 24-year rule and plundering the Rumanian Treasury. 
Following are excerpts from the military trial, as broadcast by the Viennese television. The trial was simultaneously translated into German during its broadcast in Austria, and the italicized portions represent the German translator's paraphrase of some of the courtroom testimony.
The English translation was provided by the United States Government's Foreign Broadcast Information Service.
 
NICOLAE CEAUSESCUI only recognize the grand National Assembly. I will only speak in front of it.
 
PROSECUTORIn the same way he refused to hold a dialogue with the people, now he also refuses to speak with us.
He always claimed to act and speak on behalf of the people, to be a beloved son of the people, but he only tyrannized the people all the time. You are faced with charges that you held really sumptuous celebrations on all holidays at your house. The details are known.
These two defendants procured the most luxurious foodstuffs and clothes from abroad. They were even worse than the King, the former King of Rumania. The people only received 200 grams per day, against an identity card.
These two defendants have robbed the people, and not even today do they want to talk. They are cowards. We have data concerning both of them. I ask the chairman of the prosecutor's office to read the bill of indictment.
 
HAIRMAN OF THE PROSECUTOR'S OFFICEEsteemed chairman of the court, today we have to pass a verdict on the defendants Nicolae Ceausescu and Elena Ceausescu, who have committed the following offenses:
Crimes against the people. They carried out acts that are incompatible with human dignity and social thinking, they acted in a despotic and criminal way, they destroyed the people whose leaders they claimed to be. Because of the crimes they committed against the people, I plead, on behalf of the victims of these two tyrants, for the death sentence for the two defendants.
The bill of indictment contains the following points: 1. Genocide in accordance with Article 356 of the penal code. 2. Armed attack on the people and the state power, in accordance with Article 163 of the penal code. The destruction of buildings and state institutions, undermining of the national economy, in accordance with Article 165 and 145 of the penal code. They obstructed the normal process of the economy.
 
PROSECTORDid you hear the charges? Have you understood them?
 
CEAUSESCUI do not answer. I will only answer questions before the grand National Assembly. I do not recognize this court. The charges are incorrect, and I will not answer a single question here.
 
PROSECTORNote. He does not recognize the points mentioned in the bill of indictment.
 
CEAUSESCUI will not sign anything.
 
PROSECTORThis situation is known. The catastropic situation of the country is known all over the world. Every honest citizen who worked hard here until Dec. 22 knows that we do not have medicines, that you have killed children and other people in this way, that there is nothing to eat, no heating, no electricity.
Translator: Elena and Nicolae reject this. Another question to Ceausescu: Who ordered the bloodbath in Timisoara? Ceausescu refuses to answer.
 
PROSECUTORWho gave the order to shoot in Bucharest, for instance?
 
CEAUSESCUI do not answer.
 
PROSECTORWho ordered the shooting into the crowd? Tell us?
Translator: At that moment Elena says to Nicolae: Forget about them. You see, there is no use in talking to these people.
 
PROSECUTORDo you not know anything about the order to shoot?
Translator: Nicolae reacts with astonishment.
 
PROSECUTOR There is still shooting going on. Fanatics, whom you are paying. They are shooting at children, they are shooting arbitrarily into the apartments. Who are these fanatics? Are they the people, or are you paying them?
 
CEASESCUI will not answer. I will not answer any question. Not a single shot was fired in Palace Square. Not a single shot. No one was shot.
 
PROSECUTORBy now, there have been 34 casualties.
Translator: She says cynically! Look, and that they are calling genocide.
 
PROSECUTOR In all district capitals, which you grandly called municipalities, there is shooting going on. The people were slaves. The entire intelligentsia of the country ran away. No one wanted to do anything for you anymore.
 
UNIDENTIFIED SPEAKERMr. President, I would like to know something. The accused should tell us who the mercenaries are. Who pays them? And who brought them into the country?
 
PROSECUTORYes. Accused, answer.
 
CEAUSESCU I will not say anything more. I will only speak at the Grand National Assembly.
Translator: Elena keeps whispering something to him. Prosecutor: Elena has always been talkative, but otherwise she does not know much. I have observed that she is not even able to read correctly, but she calls herself an university graduate.
Translator: Elena answers: The intellectuals of this country should hear you, you and your colleagues.
Translator: The prosecutor cites all academic titles she has always claimed to have.
 
ELENA CEAUSESCU The intelligentsia of the country will hear what you are accusing us of. ...
Translator: Prosecutor: The world already knows what has happened here.
CEAUSESCU I will not answer you putschists.
 
PROSECUTOR The Grand National Assembly has been dissolved. CEAUSESCUThis is not possible at all. No one can dissolve the National Assembly.
 
PROSECUTORWe now have another leading organ. The National Salvation Front is now our supreme body.
 
CEAUSESCUNo one recognizes that. That is why the people are fighting all over the country. This gang will be destroyed. They organized the putsch.
 
PROSECUTORThe people are fighting against you, not against the new forum.
 
CEAUSESCUNo, the people are fighting for freedom and against the new forum. I do not recognize the court.
 
PROSECUTORWhy do you think that people are fighting today? What do you think?
 
CEAUSESCU As I said before, the people are fighting for their freedom and against this putsch, against this usurpation.
Translator: Ceausescu claims that the putsch was organized from abroad. ...
Translator: The prosecutor asks the counsel for the defense to ask Ceausescu whether he knows that he is no longer President of the country and that Elena Ceausescu has also lost all her official state functions, and that the Government has been dissolved.
The prosecutor wants to find out on which basis the trial can be continued. It must be cleared up whether Ceausescu wants to, should, must, or can answer at all. At the moment the situation is rather uncertain.
Now the counsel for the defense, who was appointed by the court, asks whether Nicolae and Elena Ceausescu know the aforementioned facts - that he is no longer President, that she has lost all official functions. He answers:
 
CEAUSESCU I am the President of Romania and I am the Commander in Chief of the Rumainian Army. No one can deprive me of these functions.
 
PROSECUTOR But not of our army, you are not the Commander in Chief of our army.
 
CEAUSESCUI do not recognize you. I am talking to you as simple citizens at the least, as simple citizens, and I tell you: I am the President of Romania.
 
PROSECUTOR What are you really?
 
CEAUSESCU I repeat: I am the President of Rumania and the Commander in Chief of the Rumanian Army. I am the President of the people. I will not speak with you provocateurs anymore, and I will not speak with the organizers of the putsch and with the mercenaries. I have nothing to do with them.
 
PROSECUTORYes, but you are paying the mercenaries.
 
CEAUSESCUNo, no --
 
ELENA CEAUSESCUIt is incredible what they ae inventing, incredible.
 
PROSECUTOR Please, make a note: Ceausescu does not recognize the new legal structures of power of the country. He still considers himself to be the country's President and the Commander in Chief of the army.
Why did you ruin the country so much? Why did you export everything? Why did you make the peasants starve? The produce which the peasants grew was exported and the peasants came from the most remote provinces to Bucharest and to the other cities in order to buy bread. They cultivated the soil in line with your valuable orders and had nothing to eat. Why did you starve the people?
 
CEAUSESCUI will not answer this question. As a simple citizen, I tell you the following: For the first time I guaranteed that every peasant receives 200 kg. wheat per person, not per family, and that he is entitled to more. It is a lie that I made the people starve. A lie, a lie in my face. This shows how little patriotism there is, how many treasonable offenses were committed.
 
PROSECUTORYou claim to have taken measures so that every peaant is entitled to 200 kg. wheat. Why do the peasants then buy their bread in Bucharest?
Translator: The prosecutor quotes Ceausescu, Ceausescu's program.
 
PROSECUTORWe have wonderful programs. Paper is patient. However why are your programs not implemented? You have destroyed the Rumanian villages and the Rumanian soil. What do you say as a citizen?
 
CEAUSESCUAs a citizen, as a simple citizen, I tell you the following: At no point was there such an upswing, so much construction, so much consolidation in the Rumanian provinces. I guaranteed that every village has its schools, hospitals and doctors. I have done everything to create a decent and rich life for the people in the country, like in no other country in the world. ...
 
PROSECUTORWe have always spoken of equality. We are all equal. Everybody should be paid according to his performance. Now we finally saw your villa on television, the golden plates from which you ate, the foodstuffs that you had imported, the luxurious celebrations, pictures from your luxurious celebrations.
 
ELENA CEAUSESCUIncredible. We live in a normal apartment, just like every other citizen. We have ensured an apartment for every citizen through corresponding laws.
 
PROSECUTORYou had palaces.
 
CEAUSESCUNo, we had no palaces. The palaces belong to the people.
Translator: The prosecutor agrees, but stresses that they lived in them while the people suffered.
 
PROSECUTORChildren cannot even buy plain candy, and you are living in the palaces of the people.
 
CEAUSESCUIs it possible that we are facing such charges?
 
PROSECUTORLet us now talk about the accounts in Switzerland, Mr. Ceausescu. What about the accounts?
 
ELENA CEAUSESCUAccounts in Switzerland? Furnish proof!
 
CEAUSESCUWe had no account in Switzerland. Nobody has opened an account. This shows again how false the charges are. What defamation, what provocations! This was a coup d'etat.
 
PROSECUTIONWell, Mr. defendant, if you had no accounts in Switzerland, will you sign a statement confirming that the money that may be in Switzerland should be transferred to the Rumanian state, the state bank?
 
CEAUSESCUWe will discuss this before the Grand National Assembly. I will not say anything here. This is a vulgar provocation. ...
 
PROSECUTORNote the following: the defendant refuses to sign this statement. ...
Translator: The prosecutor to Elena: You have always been wiser and more ready to talk, a scientist. You were the most important aide, the number two in the Cabinet, in the Government.
 
PROSECUTORDid you know about the genocide in Timisoara?
 
ELENA CEAUSESCUWhat genocide? By the way, I will not answer any more questions.
 
PROSECUTORDid you know about the genocide or did you, as a chemist, only deal with polymers? You as a scientist, did you know about it?
Translator: Here Nicolae Ceausescu steps in and defends her.
 
CEAUSESCUHer scientific papers were published abroad!
 
PROSECUTORAnd who wrote the papers for you, Elena?
 
ELENA CEAUSESCUSuch impudence! I am a member and the chairwoman of the Academy of Sciences. You cannot talk to me in such a way!
 
PROSECUTORThat is to say, as a Deputy Prime Minister you did not know about the genocide? ...
 
CEAUSESCUShe was not a deputy prime minister, but the First Deputy Prime Minister!
 
PROSECUTORThis is how you worked with the people and exercised your functijons! But who gave the order to shoot? Answer this question!
 
ELENA CEAUSESCUI will not answer. I told you right at the beginning that I will not answer a single question.
 
CEAUSESCUYou as officers should know that the Government cannot give the order to shoot. But those who shot at the young people were the security men, the terrorists.
Translator: Elena Ceausescu explains.
 
ELENA CEAUSESCUThe terrorists are from Securitate.
 
PROSECUTORThe terrorists are from Securitate?
 
ELENA CEAUSESCUYes.
 
PROSECUTORAnd who heads Securitate? ...
Translator: The court notes that the investigations have been concluded. Then follows the reading of the indictment.
 
PROSECUTORMr. Chairman, we find the two accused guilty of having committed criminal actions according to the following articles of the penal code: Articles 162, 163, 165, and 357. Because of the indictment, I call for the death sentence and the impounding of the entire property of the two accused.
 
PROSECUTORSo far, they have always claimed that we have built this country, we have paid our debts, but with this they bled the country to death and have hoarded enough money to ensure their escape. You need not admit your mistakes, mister. In 1947, we assumed power, but under completely different circumstances. In 1947, King Mihai showed more dignity than you. And you might perhaps have achieved the understanding of the Rumanian people if you had now admitted your guilt. You should have stayed in Iran where you had flown to.
Translator: In response, the two laugh and she says: We do not stay abroad. This is our home.
Ceausescu is accused of having never understood what was important in this country, of having never understood the people, and of course, he does not understand the seriousness of the current moment, either.
 
PROSECUTOREsteemed Mr. Chairman, I have been one of those who, as a lawyer, would have liked to oppose the death sentence, because it is inhuman. But we are not talking about people. I would not call for the death sentence, but it would be incomprehensible for the Rumanian people to have to go on suffering this great misery and not to have it ended by sentencing the two Ceausescus to death. The crimes against the people grew year by year. They were only busy enslaving the people and building up an apparatus of power. They were not really interested in the people. (Picture is cut off).
Translator: After an outage of transmission of Rumanian television, the speaker announces the verdict in the trial of Elena and Nicolae Ceausescu is the death sentence. All their property will be impounded.

The New York Times

PUB-DATE: December 30, 1989

SECTION: Section 1; Page 13, Column 4; Cultural Desk

LENGTH: 1343 words

HEADLINE: Home Thoughts of a Rumanian At a College Haven in the U.S.

BYLINE: By RICHARD F. SHEPARD

 BODY:
Last December when Norman Manea was invited to exercise freedom of thought as a writer and a teacher at Bard College, nobody foresaw what would be happening in Eastern Europe.
Mr. Manea is a 53-year-old author from Rumania, the last of the Warsaw Pact countries to oust a Stalinist leader. His comments and his philosophies had earned him the obloquy of official Rumanian publications as an elitist and a Jew, a situation that encouraged him three years ago to seek more tolerant surroundings in the West.
Why the authorities let him out is one of those unanswerable questions that often arose about Eastern bloc countries before the glacier began its precipitate thaw. Mr. Manea said yesterday that it was more than coincidence that writers were in the forefront of the recent upheavals in that part of the world.
His writings, novels and short stories have been published in German, Dutch, Hebrew, Spanish, Swedish and lately English. 
 
The Main Offering: Freedom
The program that brought him to the Bard College campus at Annandale-on-Hudson in Dutchess County is recent and is intended, in the words of its prospectus, to ''provide serious and gifted writers, scholars and artists from outside of the United States and Western Europe, who are living under conditions that do not permit the free development and expression of their accomplishments or their ideas, with the opportuniy to pursue their work in a nonpartisan environment in this country.''
It is called the International Academy for Scholarship and the Arts and was established by Bard with the help of a $100,000 grant from the Ford Foundation. The academy is actually a consortium of liberal arts colleges, among them Bryn Mawr, Dartmouth, Davidson, Haverford, St. Augustine's, Vassar and Lincoln University. Mr. Manea is the second participant in the program; the first was Miklos Haraszti, a Hungarian dissident writer, poet and sociologist, who was chosen for 1988-89.
The burst of liberalization in Eastern Europe is not a threat to the program, but it will probably cause a change in direction in the quest for writers who have governments reading over their shoulders.
''It will shift the focus,'' said Leon Botstein, the president of Bard. ''There has always been the assumption that it would go from place to place. Freedom of expression is a problem elsewhere as well. There is China as well as countries in the Middle East and Africa. We originally said we hoped the program would not be for East Europe alone. Now it turns out, East Europe needs it least.''
 
Fellowships Offered Elsewhere
Bryn Mawr and Vassar have each given fellowships to Chinese intellectuals. Bryn Mawr's is to a physicist and Vassar's to an economist.
Mr. Botstein explained that the participants in the program need not be engaged in the struggle against dictatorship.
''Writing in un-freedom creates codes through allusion and imagery,'' Mr. Botstein said. ''Where Americans think of these as literary techniques, in other countries they are used as a method of communication, as a way of preserving memory. Much of the political discussion is done through allusions to the past.
''Our judgment of freedom is one of movement. What is freedom for these people is freedom of expression. What Haraszti and Manea are transmitting to American students is that ideas matter. How little Americans know about European intellectuals! The role of being an intellectual is not to earn a living; you are one because it has political consequences, you find a voice to exert leadership. In the United States, an intellectual is often considered marginal, an esthete, but there he or she is at the center of things.''
 
The Ignorance of Americans
Mr. Manea, now almost at midpoint in his stay at Bard, has found academia in America to have areas of self-inflicted ignorance. The course he is teaching is called East European writers, and those under scrutiny include, among many others, Milan Kundera and Josef Shvorecky of Czechoslovakia, the Rumanian Eugene Ionesco and Danilo Kis, a Yugoslav who died just this year.
''I have 24 students,'' Mr. Manea said. ''I think there is a lower level here in a general cultural way. Some students are very good, intelligent, innocent and honest, like good students in Europe, but they lack knowledge and their political knowledge is lower. They are not familiar with Eastern Europe, even though they are interested in what's happening there. They are not really prepared in high school for the geography and history, so I started the class with a map that shows where East Europe and its capitals are.''
''The students are also different from students in Europe because very few have other languages,'' he said. ''I find it very interesting to understand the American youth and I hope it's interesting for them to understand me.''
In the spring, Mr. Manea will be teaching the other of his two courses, Holocaust and literature, a study of short fiction and novels by Franz Kafka, I. B. Singer, Primo Levi, Giorgio Bassani and others. It is a subject he is also pursuing under a Fulbright Scholarship.
 
Preoccupations of a Survivor
Mr. Manea, who was born in Bukovina in 1936, was deported in 1941 to a concentration camp in the Ukraine, where he remained with surviving family members until 1945. As a survivor of extermination policies, physical on the part of Nazis, intellectual on the part of the Communists, the author is immersed in these subjects. He has observed how the techniques of one may be applied by the other, and his 10 books, mostly novels, reflect behavior that threatened physical extermination in the Nazi camps and literary extermination under Stalinist rule.
The literary war began for him in 1981 when, in an interview, he called for writers to take stronger moral stances and reacted to anti-Semitic articles published in Rumanian periodicals. For years afterward, Mr. Manea was subjected to anti-Semitic attacks in the press. In 1986 a collection of his essays won the Prize of the Writer's Union of Rumania. The Government-run Council of Socialist Culture rescinded the prize. His wife was working and this helped tide them over periods when his own income was diminished.
''Anti-Semitism was only one aspect of a dark situation,'' the writer said in in a discussion of the era just ended. ''It was not the most important, but only one of the characteristics of an economic, political and moral crisis that was linked to all of the other aspects of crisis. Forms of life, of creation, of resistance, sustain themselves today in Rumania as much as possible through culture. That is why hatred and repression is primarily directed against cultural figures. When these figures are Jews also, there are also supplementary 'accents' to attack.
''We saw how important culture was in bringing about the changes in Rumania, because we saw a gifted poet, Mircea Dinescu, as the first to announce news of the change. I think that it's not by chance that we now have the President of Czechoslovakia a playwright, the Prime Minister of Poland a journalist and the announcement of change in Rumania by a courageous poet.''
 
A U.S. Book Contract
Mr. Manea has signed a book contract with Grove Press for publication of his short stories that follow a single character from childhood to maturity, first during the Holocaust and then during the Stalinist decades. Mr. Manea said that the book may be out in English translation by the end of next year.
When he first arrived in America, Mr. Manea was reluctant to speak too bluntly about Rumania's ruling class so that he might keep a foot in the door if he wanted to return. Now his last family ties with the old country have been cut and life in the West gave him a taste of freedom even before the turbulent unshackling of repression in his native land.
''My situation has changed,'' he said, ''and I can speak more freely. But the revolution in Eastern Europe went to the intellectuals. We saw that the writer is not only at his desk but in the public squares.''

HEADLINE: Koch Takes His Leave From City Hall

BYLINE: By RICHARD LEVINE

 BODY:
Edward I. Koch walked out of City Hall for the last time as mayor yesterday, his passionate and sometimes obstreperous tenure as New York City's chief executive virtually at an end.
Mr. Koch spent the last weekday of his 12th year in office writing letters, visiting several police precincts, taping a television program, attending an open house at City Hall for senior city employees and coping with one more emergency: a Bronx explosion that left large portions of that borough and Manhattan without electricity, disrupted subway service and delayed Mr. Koch's departure from the building by about a half-hour.
The Mayor's third term officially ends at midnight tomorrow, but aides said he had no plans to return to City Hall, which has so long been his domain, until Monday morning, when his successor, David N. Dinkins, will be inaugurated as the city's 106th mayor.
Mr. Koch seemed in an upbeat mood throughout the day, in keeping with his often repeated assertion these days that his defeat in the September primary was actually his ''liberation.''
 
'I Leave With Joy'
''People think that somehow or other I should be forlorn,'' he said as he chatted with reporters in the morning. ''Not at all. I leave with joy.'' 
The Mayor's public schedule for the day had only one entry: the open house, which was in keeping with a tradition observed when his two predecessors, John V. Lindsay and Abraham D. Beame, left office.
But when he returned to City Hall in the late afternoon after a stop at a police station house in Manhattan, he got a surprise: members of the Pipes and Drums of the Police Department's Emerald Society had assembled on the steps leading up through the rotunda. As he stood on the landing, looking out at hundreds of colleagues, supporters and friends and listening to the bagpipes, he sighed several times and appeared to be fighting to maintain his composure.
Asked a few moments later whether he had cried, Mr. Koch said, ''A tear or two.''
Then he slowly made his way through the crowd to his office in the west wing, where the paintings and photographs had already been removed from the walls, save for the official portrait of Fiorello H. La Guardia. There, Mr. Koch discussed the Bronx explosion and its impact with aides and with Mr. Dinkins, who had stopped by, the Mayor-elect said, to say ''hello and goodbye'' to his predecessor.
At an impromptu news conference in the Blue Room, Mr. Koch said he had been reassured that power would be restored within an hour. The Mayor said he would stay in City Hall until the situation had been resolved. ''This is no imposition,'' he said. ''This is my job.''
He left City Hall at 5:38 P.M., making his way across the inaugural platform and then taking the arm of Diane Mulcahy Coffey, his chief of staff.
 
Subdued Mood
The building had an outwardly festive appearance yesterday, with its facade already bedecked with bunting and banners. But inside, dozens of cardboard boxes containing mayoral papers were stacked in the halls, destined for the archives and for Mr. Koch's new apartment.
As commissioners and others gathered for the open house, the mood was subdued. Asked if it were a sad occasion, Stanley E. Grayson, who is leaving his post as Deputy Mayor for Finance and Economic Development, said, ''Melancholy is perhaps a better way to describe it.''
In any event, the party did not last long. Workers had picked up the rugs and begun cleaning up by 6 P.M.
Mr. Koch arose yesterday at 5 A.M., a half-hour earlier than usual, went to his gym, stopped by the 113 Police Precinct station house in Jamaica, Queens - one of three he would visit during the day - and had breakfast with the author Alistair Cooke at the Carlyle Hotel, breaking yet another mayoral diet, an aide said.
 
Saying Farewell in Person
Chatting with reporters in the morning, he jokingly likened the goings-on at the seat of municipal government to the fall of Saigon. The only thing missing, he said, ''was the sound of the helicopters to take you out.''
Later, he taped a television interview program at the studios of WCBS-TV, learned of the Bronx fire and visited the site, then stopped by two more police station houses in the Bronx and Manhattan.
He said he planned to visit three more station houses over the weekend, fulfilling his intention to stop at all 75 precincts in the city and say farewell in person. Mr. Koch said he might go to a movie tonight.
He is scheduled to attend a New Year's Eve ceremony at the Cathedral of St. John the Divine, his last official appearance. He will host a party that evening at Gracie Mansion for 75 friends and relatives, then head for his new apartment on lower Fifth Avenue at ''check-out time,'' which he said was 3 A.M. Monday.
 
Several Jobs Ahead
On Tuesday, Mr. Koch said, he will report to the Manhattan law offices of Robinson Silverman Pearce Aronsohn & Berman, where he will be a partner.
Since the primary, Mr. Koch has also accepted jobs as a radio and television commentator, newspaper columnist and lecturer. Though he never discusses specifics, he has made it clear he expects his third career to be his most lucrative.
Mr. Koch was a lawyer and then a City Councilman and a United States Representative before he prevailed over a crowded field in the mayoral campaign of 1977. His tenure began with New York City close to insolvency but spanned a time of unexpected prosperity in which the city's economy, driven largely by Wall Street, boomed, tax revenues soared and the annual municipal budget doubled, to $26 billion.
The Mayor's third term comes to an end, however, with the city once again facing fiscal difficulties. Though its credit rating has remained sound, it is under increasing pressure from social ills like homelessness, AIDS and drug abuse, at a time when it can scarcely afford new programs.
Mr. Koch, who frequently recalled the fiscal troubles he inherited and his role in resolving them during his last, unsucessful campaign, continued to monitor the budget, and his administration has twice modified the spending plan for the fiscal year that ends in June, lowering estimates for revenues and cutting expenses.
But for the most part the Mayor has made few decisions of consequence since losing the primary, keeping an uncharacteristically low profile for a politican some considered a quintessentially feisty New Yorker, others considered divisive and abrasive and still others, no doubt, regarded as both.
His quiescence, along with his support for Mr. Dinkins, were credited with helping fuel what has been characterized as a wave of ''premature nostalgia'' for a political figure who was once overwhelmingly popular but saw support fade after a series of corruption cases at the start of his third term and his harsh criticism of the Rev. Jesse Jackson during the New York State Presidential primary in 1986.
''Reporters who beat the hell out of me are suddenly saying nice things about me,'' Mr. Koch noted last week. ''When you've been defeated, you don't make any decision of great importance, and when you don't make decisions you don't alienate anybody.''
 
Raising Mayor's Ire
That is not to say that Mr. Koch has always held his tongue. On Thursday, at his last bill signing, he listened as some black residents of South Jamaica, Queens, and others argued with police officers and officials who had gathered in the Blue Room to speak on a law renaming a street for Edward Byrne, an officer slain while guarding the home of a witness in a drug case.
When several speakers could not resist pointing out that the Mayor would soon be the ex-Mayor, and some taking credit for the transformation, the Mayor merely listened. But when others said that the officer did not deserve to be memorialized, it prompted the Mayor's ire.
Before signing the bill, Mr. Koch said some of the comments ''sickened me . . . as nothing has in 12 years.''
He told that story a few times yesterday. But Mr. Koch seemed determined to end his tenure as gracefully as he could.
''I'm grateful to God and the people of New York City - I hope nobody objects to me putting God first - who gave me an opportunity,'' he said at one point. ''I thank them.''
Even so, when he saw the platform on which Mr. Dinkins would take the oath of office on Monday, he could not resist joking that it was ''at least twice and maybe three times as big as the platform they had for me.''
After a pause and a smile, he added, ''He's entitled to it.''

HEADLINE: Businesses Press Cuomo to Keep Income-Tax Cut Set for Next Year

BYLINE: By ELIZABETH KOLBERT, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: ALBANY, Dec. 29

 BODY:
Despite appeals from the Cuomo administration, business groups across New York State are preparing for a high-pressure campaign to save the income-tax cut scheduled for next year.
''Tax cuts are not the problem, spending is,'' the Upstate New York Roundtable on Manufacturing asserted in a statement recently. The group, representing more than 100 manufacturers, declared itself ''strongly opposed to any delay or repeal'' of the tax cut and vowed to press state lawmakers on the issue when they return to Albany next month. 
The Greater Syracuse Chamber of Commerce went a step further, assembling ''save the tax cut'' kits to make lobbying easy. The kits contain sample protest letters urging lawmakers to preserve the tax cut, as well as orange balloons bearing the message ''Don't Let the Air Out of NY's Economy.'' For $37.50, a company can buy 25 kits.
 
Fierce Fight Likely
Earlier this month, Gov. Mario M. Cuomo's economic advisory committee, whose members include some of the most prominent business leaders in New York, suggested that the tax cut be delayed to help the state solve its fiscal problems. The report seemed to indicate that the Governor had won support from business for a delay in the tax cut.
But the protests from business groups, coming even before the Governor has announced his proposed budget for next year, indicate that he has not succeeded in swaying much of the state's business community. And given the power that business has traditionally wielded in Albany, especially in the Republican-controlled State Senate, it augurs a fierce fight over the tax cut next year.
For the last several months, Governor Cuomo has been toying with the idea of delaying the next phase of the state's tax-cut program, suggesting over and over that the money could be better used fighting drugs or improving education. But he has refused to say whether he will propose delaying the tax cut when he presents his budget next month, and aides to Mr. Cuomo insist that he has not yet made up his mind on the issue.
The next phase of the four-year tax-cut program, initiated in 1987, is scheduled to bring the state's top income-tax rate down to 7 percent from 7.5 percent. It would cost the state an estimated $400 million during the fiscal year that starts April 1, at the same time that the state is facing a budget gap estimated at more than $1 billion.
Over the summer, Mr. Cuomo appealed to business groups to keep an open mind on the tax cut. Some groups, like the New York City Chamber of Commerce and Industry, have heeded the Governor's call and refrained from taking a firm position on the issue. But a growing number of business groups, including the state's largest business lobby, the Business Council of New York State, have come out against a delay.

HEADLINE: BUSINESS DIGEST

 BODY:

THE ECONOMY
 
The index of leading indicators edged up 0.1 percent in November after modestly declining in October, the Commerce Department reported. That was in line with expectations and was seen as a further indication that the nation's sharply slower economic growth is unlikely to deteriorate into a recession. Five of the index's 11 components contributed to the increase, led by a rise in manufacturers' new orders for consumer goods and materials. [33.] 
 
Farmers received 0.7 percent more for raw products in December than in November, the Agriculture Department said. [34.]
 
The United States is headed for permanent levels of dependence on oil imports higher than those that led to havoc in the 1970's, many experts are saying. [33.]
 
MARKETS
 
Stock prices rose strongly, ending the second-best year of the decade, in percentage terms, for the Dow industrials. The Dow settled at 2,753.20, up 20.90 for the day, 41.81 for the week and 584.63, or 27 percent, for the year. [33.]
 
Treasury note and bond prices were mostly lower, and bill rates were mixed, in the final trading session of a year characterized by gradually rising prices of Treasury and investment-grade corporate debt issues and by declining values of ''junk bonds.'' [36.]
 
Prices of heating-oil futures rebounded to close at a six-year high, and gasoline futures jumped amid signs that moves to produce more heating oil are cutting into gas supplies. [41.] The dollar closed higher in light trading. Gold prices rose, with bullion for current delivery ending at $402.50 an ounce on the Comex. [41.]
 
COMPANIES
 
Antonovich Inc. has filed for Chapter 11 bankruptcy protection. The move by the New York-area fur retailer follows the announcement by a competitor, Fur Vault, that it would sell its unprofitable retail operations. Fur retailers face new competition from foreign companies, like Jindo of Korea, and are under pressure from animal rights groups.[33.]
 
Some airlines are seriously considering raising fares or adding ticket surcharges to offset higher fuel prices, people in the industry say. The moves could come just before the time of year when carriers generally cut their fares. [33.]
 
The City of Chicago plans to terminate its franchise agreement with Commonwealth Edison as of Dec. 31, 1990, the company said. Analysts see the action as a first step in negotiations for a new franchise agreement with the big electric utility. [35.]
 
An Australian court appointed receivers and managers for the Bond Corporation's brewing interests. News reports speculated that the move marks the beginning of the end of Alan Bond's diversified empire, which includes G. Heileman in the U.S. [35.]
 
Campbell's chairman said the first choice to become chief executive had accepted the post. The person's name was not announced. [35.]
 
INTERNATIONAL
 
Many American economists are scrambling to understand how centrally run economies can be transformed into systems dominated by free markets. A lack of expertise on that subject was evident at an annual meeting of economists this week in Atlanta. [33.]
 
Nigeria's oil minister was moved to a new position. Rilwanu Lukman also serves as president of OPEC. [34.]
 
TODAY'S COLUMNS
 
Patents for financial instruments are being validated at the Patent and Trademark Office and in court. Established patent law has held that financial products and services, which are ideas rather than inventions, are not eligible for the same patent protection as products. Patents. [34.]
 
Even people who have wills may not have completed an equally important document, a letter of instructions to heirs and executors. Such a letter may list one's assets and liabilities and tell where important papers are kept. Your Money. [34.]

HEADLINE: Worrying Anew Over Oil Imports

BYLINE: By ROBERT D. HERSHEY Jr., Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Dec. 29

 BODY:
After a long period of complacency during which American reliance on foreign oil fell sharply and the price dived to under $10 a barrel, the United States is now headed for permanent levels of dependence on imports that are higher than those that led to havoc in the 1970's, many specialists say.
The United States relies on foreign suppliers for 43 percent of its petroleum needs, and some experts say that may go to 60 percent by the turn of the century. But there is a difference this time. The pinch has been gradual, largely because of lessons learned on both sides of the oil equation. That difference makes the risk of a return to gasoline lines seem more remote than in the mid-1970's, when imports last moved above 40 percent.
Still, with the aid of exceptionally cold late autumn and early winter weather in much of the nation, the price of crude oil has climbed to about $22 a barrel. And in trading today on the New York Mercantile Exchange, heating oil jumped to its highest level in almost six years. 
 
Increasingly Worrisome Threat
The combination of higher prices and the fact that daily domestic oil production fell in 1989 by a record 500,000 barrels has many analysts warning that the American dependence on foreign oil will pose an increasingly worrisome threat in many ways in the 1990's.
''One of the most serious issues facing the United States is how to cope with the growing imports of crude oil and refined products that arise from increased consumption combined with declining domestic production,'' a diverse panel of international business, labor, government and other specialists concluded in a report published this month by the Atlantic Council, a Washington-based center that specializes in economic and other international issues. ''This aggravates balance-of-payments problems, adds to the budget deficit, is likely to lead to higher world oil prices and affects national security.''
Addressing some of the concerns in a speech in London in October, Hisham M. Nazer, oil minister for Saudi Arabia, made it clear that maintaining a steady flow of oil to the West was in the best interests of producers and consumers alike, saying it was ''a purely commercial equation.'' He added: ''We will add political variables to it only to our mutual peril. Let me simplify it even further. You need the oil. We have the oil.''
 
U.S. Output May Fall Further
Although some in the industry believe that American production can at least be stabilized and that the decline can probably be reversed with single-minded efforts, most analysts expect that environmental and other constraints will cause production to continue to fall. This year's average of 7.6 million barrels a day, down from 8.1 million in 1988, was the fourth straight annual decline and was the lowest production level since 1964. Output peaked at 9.6 million barrels a day in 1970.
James E. Akins, a former Ambassador to Saudi Arabia, said in an interview that he considers this a ''frightening'' trend and held that the United States would be ''lucky'' to hold its imports at the turn of the century to the 60 percent that the Department of Energy forecasts to be the worst eventuality.
Spurred by the sharp increases in the world price of oil, which curbed demand and elicited large new supplies from Western sources that could get a decent return for the money they have sunk into new wells, the 1980's was a period of relative energy complacency. President Jimmy Carter's 1977 declaration of the ''moral equivalent of war'' to head off possible national catastrophe was largely forgotten.
American dependence on foreign oil dropped to 28 percent over all in 1982 and 1983, from a peak of 46.5 percent in 1977, and the reliance on Middle East sources dwindled even further as Britain, Mexico, Nigeria and Norway joined Canada in the forefront of American suppliers.
 
Causes of U.S. Complacency
Even a long war in the Persian Gulf between major oil producers, Iran and Iraq, failed to give oil much urgency as pipeline networks expanded, the Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries fell into disarray over quotas and the United States endured a severe two-year recession. In 1986, the price of oil collapsed, falling briefly in the spot market to less than $10 a barrel, from $27 at the beginning of 1986.
Meanwhile, the United States was building a strategic reserve along the coasts of Louisiana and Texas that now holds 580 million barrels -enough to replace all imports for about 80 days - and allies have also created stockpiles.
But with American production in the late 1980's slumping badly and the economy riding on seven years of practically uninterrupted growth, imports are again looming large. At an average 7.3 million barrels a day in the four weeks ended Dec. 15, imports are about 500,000 barrels higher than a year ago and 1.2 million above the levels of November-December 1987.
 
Oil at 44% of U.S. Trade Deficit
Although imported oil costs the nation less than one-tenth as much as President Carter once feared it would cost by 1985, the $49 billion or so it will cost this year can only increase, many analysts agree. Moreover, oil's proportion of the American trade deficit was more than 44 percent through the first 10 months of the 1989. In some months it was more than half.
Most worrisome to various analysts, however, is the prospect that OPEC appears to be regaining leverage as demand rises, particularly in the third world and perhaps also before long in Eastern Europe, as production falls elsewhere. Britain, as well as the United States, is now beyond peak output, and many specialists believe that the Soviet Union, the world's biggest producer, may have to reduce exports even if it manages to keep output from falling.
To be sure, other industrial powerhouses like West Germany and Japan must import nearly all their oil. But they and most other countries tax it at near-punitive rates and use it much more sparingly.
 
Drop in OPEC's Share of Market
OPEC had seen its share of the world market drop to less than a third in 1985, from about half during the 1970's. It is now benefiting handsomely, however, as strong demand, aided by very cold weather in the United States, has helped push the price back up to $22 a barrel.
''World oil consumption is again on the rise, and OPEC's dominance is being re-established,'' asserted the Jefferson Energy Foundation, a Washington group that promotes United States oil production.
What's more, some analysts note, the OPEC members in the Persian Gulf - Saudi Arabia, the United Arab Emirates, Kuwait, Iran and Iraq -are for various reasons becoming even more influential within the organization, at the expense of Indonesia, Nigeria and other members.
 
'Serious Geopolitical Issues'
''There is general agreement that proven world oil reserves are adequate to meet world needs and U.S. import requirements for several decades,'' the Atlantic Council report said. ''However, production will become increasingly concentrated in a few countries, in particular the Arabian Gulf producers. This raises serious geopolitical issues for the U.S. and its allies as dependence on the Middle East grows. The cost of oil imports for the U.S. economy could double between now and the year 2000 -from eight-tenths of 1 percent of gross national product to 1.5 percent of G.N.P.''
Edward H. Murphy, an official of the American Petroleum Institute, agrees.
''For sure,'' he said, ''OPEC is going to have more control in the 90's than in the 80's.'' The question, Mr. Murphy added, is whether it will be disciplined enough to bring about steady, albeit moderate, price increases over the long term or whether short-term demands for revenue could cause wild gyrations and instability.
 
OPEC Capacity Race Possible
Some, in fact, believe a capacity race has already begun within OPEC - with major expasions reportedly planned by Saudi Arabia, the other Gulf producers and Venezuela - that could raise its production capability 20 percent by the mid-1990's and prevent the group from reasserting effective power to increase prices. Mr. Murphy said this race could occur but so far ''we haven't seen the evidence'' of significant actual expansion.
Still the Atlantic Council panel sees such a threat to oil sufficiency - as well as being worried about pollution, climatic change and the need for highway repair - that it proposes an additional 50-cent-a-gallon Federal tax on gasoline, to be phased in over nine years.
The idea of a stiff gasoline levy to curb demand and raise revenue has been endorsed by various Government and other officials but hotly opposed, among others reasons, as unfair to drivers in the West where trips are generally longer.

HEADLINE: New Economic Puzzle: East Bloc

BYLINE: By LOUIS UCHITELLE, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: ATLANTA, Dec. 29

 BODY:
The upheaval in the Soviet Union and Eastern Europe has many American economists scrambling to understand the biggest issue in economics today: how to transform a centrally run economy into one dominated by free markets.
Only a handful of economists in the United States, probably fewer than 200, are expert in Eastern bloc countries, having rejected the study of these non-market economies as a dull specialty. Equally important, a main tool of American economists - computer simulations of existing economies - cannot be easily adapted to those in radical transition.
''Most of us don't know how the Eastern bloc institutions and state enterprises work or how to model an economy that is half market-driven and half controlled by bureaucrats,'' said Robert M. Solow of the Massachusetts Institute of Technology.
 
Shortcomings Evident
The shortcomings were evident in interviews here at the annual convention of the American Economic Association, attended by several thousand economists, most of them college and university professors. 
Mr. Solow, for example, said he had made his first trip to the Soviet Union only last fall - a weekend excursion from Stockholm, where he had attended the Nobel Prize ceremonies. (He won the Nobel Memorial Prize in Economic Science in 1987.) Other American economists are visiting the East bloc, while Russian and Eastern European economists -equally puzzled about transition economics - are coming here. Several were among the economists who attended the convention that ends Saturday, among them Jaroslaw Pietras, a 34-year-old University of Warsaw professor on a Fulbright fellowship at Duke University.
''The transition will inevitably bring irrational behavior from people not used to the unemployment and dislocation that come with free markets,'' Mr. Pietras said. ''In your more stable country, economists aren't trained to deal with unexpected behavior.''
Nevertheless, Mr. Pietras is studying American trade practices that might be applied in Poland. And Russian economists are turning to Westerners steeped in free markets.
''If you are the head of a Russian economics institution, the status thing to do is to have some American economists as consultants,'' said Ed A. Hewett, a senior fellow at the Brookings Institution. As one of the handful of American specialists in Soviet economics, he consults almost daily with his Russian colleagues. He brought one, Genadi Zateev of Gosplan, the Soviet state planning agency, to the conference, and Mr. Zateev declared, rather metaphorically, that the Russian economy was experiencing one of its worst years since World War II.
''The old system has been condemned and a new one not created, so the economy is between two chairs,'' he said. ''It looks like someone standing in front of a curved mirror -bifurcated.''
Mr. Zateev spoke at a session on transition economics conducted by Mr. Hewett. It was so crowded that a loudspeaker was set up for the overflow of professors seated on folding chairs in the hallway. Besides Mr. Zateev, the session featured various American economists speculating on the first steps in tranforming a centrally planned system to a market economy.
 
No Guide and Few Precedents
They noted that there is almost no literature to guide them and very few precedents. Through most of the postwar period economists everywhere assumed that free market and centrally planned systems would exist separately, in a sort of permanent standoff, and neither would evolve into the other.
''I never had a course in graduate school called how to create a market economy,'' said Mr. Hewett, a University of Michigan graduate in the 1960's. Now he and others, including Janos Horvath, a Hungarian-born professor at Butler University, are organizing weeklong sessions, starting next month, at which American and Eastern economists will try to work out transition theory.
The difficulties in doing this were evident at Mr. Hewett's session. The panelists rejected the cold-turkey approach in which a country goes quickly from central planning to free markets, as Poland is more or less attempting to do. This approach calls for the creation of a convertible currency, commercial loans, private companies, new tax laws, and an end to price controls and state subsidies of unprofitable operations - all in one temporarily chaotic swoop.
Among the chief obstacles to the cold-turkey transition cited by the Mr. Hewett's panelists is the huge sums of money held by Russians and many Eastern Europeans who have been forced to save because their economies produced so little to buy.
 
How to Harness Savings
As a means of harnessing this ''savings overhang,'' Ronald I. McKinnon of Stanford University, who has immersed himself in transition economics, proposed a ban on credit to newly entrepreneurial companies in the East, forcing them instead to finance expansion through accumulated profits.
Profits would be big because the companies, as they grew, would be able to raise prices easily, confident that consumers would spend their savings on the new supply of sought-after goods without quibbling over price. Only after the excess savings had been absorbed would credit be allowed and restrictions on imports be fully lifted.
Neither Mr. McKinnon nor anyone else knows whether this strategy would work. He and others suggest it in part because something similar was successfully imposed on West Germany after World War II. The allied forces issued too much occupation currency and the Germans had a lot of money in their pockets. To absorb it, the allies forced companies to pay for rebuilding in the late 1940's with their own funds. To get those funds, the companies pushed up prices and thus increased their profits.
 
Dedicated to Mathematics
But this sort of theorizing is not the way most American economists operate, dedicated as their profession is to mathematical formulas run on computers to simulate the real world. Economists use these models to determine what might happen to car prices, the value of the dollar, wage levels or unemployment if, say, consumer interest rates were moved up or down by a percentage point.
But such models operate best in static economies where assumptions about people's reactions can be built into the equations. But these models are not very useful in transition economics, said Paul Blinder of Princeton University, except for their application to specific issues, such as what effect a currency devaluation in Czechoslovakia might have on that country's exports.
''It is not easy to apply models more broadly to a country that does not know how much like America it wants to look and how to get its economy there,'' he said.
 
Assumption About People
Another problem is that the models rely on an assumption about human behavior that might not hold up well among people who have lived for 40 years in Marxist economies. The assumption is that people in Western economies will always calculate and seek the lowest-priced goods, the highest wage, the best deal - in sum the greatest possible command over goods.
While the concentration on computer modeling fails to equip thousands of American economists for an important role in transition economics, the nation's small group of Marxist economists is not much better off.
Paul Sweezy, the 79-year-old co-editor of the Monthly Review, a socialist journal, explains why. ''A lot of the younger people in the left think that the Eastern Europeans will be good social democrats, but that is fantasy because they can't afford the Swedish type of welfare,'' Mr. Sweezy said. ''I don't know what direction the Soviet Union will go, but the small East European countries will be absorbed in the capitalist world, more or less rapidly.''
