HEADLINE: Leading Indicators Rise 0.1%

BYLINE: By ROBERT D. HERSHEY Jr., Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Dec. 29

 BODY:
The Government index intended to forecast the economy edged up one-tenth of 1 percent in November after a modest October decline, the Commerce Department reported today.
The result, which was in line with expectations, was taken as a further indication that the sharp slowing of economic growth is not likely to deteriorate soon into a downturn.
''The economy is sluggish, but it is not heading into recession,'' said William C. Melton, chief economist for I.D.S. Financial Services in Minneapolis. 
 
Orders Up Sharply
Five of the 11 components of the index of leading indicators contributed to the November increase, paced by a rise in manufacturers' new orders for consumer goods and materials. Of the six elements holding the index down, the biggest was a decline in the price of materials that are particularly sensitive to swings in the business cycle.
Two gauges, compiled by New York investment firms, paint a more negative picture than the Commerce Department's data.
Although the Composite Forecasting Index compiled by Safian Investment Research edged up one-tenth of a point in November, it was only the second advance of the year. The other was in August.
Jesup & Lamont, whose macro-economic index signaled recession in August, said that since the index typically gives five months' warning ''this suggests that the economy is now moving into recession.'' For November, the index fell again, to a reading of minus 71.
The Commerce Department's index, which has now risen six times this year and fallen five, stands at 144.7, scarcely higher than the 144.1 of November 1988.
The other components besides manufacturers' orders that lifted the index last month were a decline in initial claims for state unemployment insurance, a rise in contracts and orders for plant and equipment, a rise in the M-2 money supply and a rise in manufacturers' unfilled orders.
Holding the index back were, besides the decline in sensitive materials prices, lower stock prices, diminished consumer expectations, a decline in the length of the workweek, a decline in building permits and a quickening of deliveries by suppliers.
Revisions to earlier figures show that the leading index eased three-tenths of 1 percent in October, instead of four-tenths as initially reported, while the September gain was one-tenth instead of three-tenths.
The department also reported that its indexes of coincident and lagging indicators each increased four-tenths of 1 percent in November. The rise in the coincident index, which gauges current business activity, was the first since August. The rise in the lagging index, whose components tend to change direction after the economy as a whole, was the biggest since May.

HEADLINE: Stocks Close Strong Year Witha Gain

BYLINE: By PHILLIP H. WIGGINS

 BODY:
Stocks rose strongly yesterday in sharply higher trading, capping the Dow Jones industrial average's second best year of the decade in percentage terms.
For the year, the Dow surged in value by 27 percent and the Standard & Poor's 500-stock index rose 27.3 percent. The Dow's gain was the fifth best rise in the postwar years. In 1985, the Dow showed its best rise of the 1980's, 27.7 percent. 
Among the smaller-capitalized stocks, the Nasdaq composite index climbed 4.84 points yesterday, to 454.82, gaining 19.3 percent for the year, while the Amex market value index jumped 4.10 points, to 378.00, and posted a yearly gain of 23.5 percent.
Yesterday, the Dow Jones industrial average rose 20.90 points, or 0.76 percent, to 2,753.20, as a late ''window dressing'' rally - when institutions seek to even out their positions -lifted equities in the final minutes of trading. For the week, the Dow gained 41.81 points, or 1.5 percent.
Since Dec. 30, 1988, when the Dow closed out the year at 2,168.57, the Dow has gained 584.63 points.
Advances on the New York Stock Exchange yesterday outnumbered declines by more than 2 to 1, with 1,083 issues gaining in price and 484 retreating. Volume on the Big Board jumped to 145.9 million shares, from 128 million on Thursday.
In the broader market yesterday, the Standard & Poor's 500-stock index rose 2.73 points, to 353.40, while the New York Stock Exchange composite index gained 1.45 points, to 195.04, a 24.8 percent gain for the year.
''There were three influences at work in the market today that spurred the rise,'' said David Bostian Jr., managing director and chief investment strategist at the Jesup & Lamont Securities Company. ''One was traders buying depressed stocks; second was index funds putting their cash flow to work at the end of the quarter, and third was the continuation of the institutional portfolio markup that occurs at the end of quarters and the year-end. The latter two will be gone on Tuesday,'' Mr. Bostian continued, ''which will increase the chances that market averages will be headed down.''
 
News on Indicators Ignored
Traders said that the stock market largely ignored the Government's report of a one-tenth of 1 percent rise in the index of leading indicators for November, which was generally in line with expectations.
''Nineteen eighty-nine was an excellent year for the U.S. equity markets,'' said Bernard Spilko, senior vice president at the Zurich-based Bank Julius Baer. ''The Eastern European bloc restructuring should ultimately increase earnings multiples of large U.S. international companies.''
He said that a more relaxed military posture should also help reduce the United States budget deficit, which in turn should allow the Federal Reserve Board to lower interest rates.
 
Good Performance for Year
George O. Zimmermann, director of research at Gruntal & Company, said that the market and the economy's performances this year were a pleasant surprise to many. ''As we entered 1989, the yen was at 125 to the dollar,'' he recalled. ''All was well with 'Smokestack America,' and the trade gap was narrowing. In the meantime, economists were calling for a recession, and the Dow was selling at only 10 times earnings.''
He said he felt the $25 billion buyout of RJR Nabisco Inc. by Kohlberg, Kravis, Roberts & Company was the ''high-water mark'' for buyouts of that size, recalling that on Oct. 13 the proposed $8 billion buyout of the UAL Corporation was aborted. ''Carrying through to 1990, we believe that transactions of this nature will not be as frequent because of a weak high-yield bond market,'' Mr. Zimmermann added.
Other analysts said that the new year should bring lower interest rates. They said the recent drop in the Federal funds rate to below 8.5 percent and higher prices for long-term Government bonds could prompt growth in consumer spending. They said that while the nation may slide into a mild recession or slowing economy in 1990, another long-term economic expansion is highly probable, as interest rates reach their lows probably by the summer of 1990.
Active blue chips yesterday included A.T.& T., off 1/8, to 45 1/2; Pan Am, up 1/8, to 3 7/8; Philip Morris, up 1/2, to 41 5/8; I.B.M. unchanged at 94 1/8, and Eastman Kodak, up 3/8, to 41 1/8.

HEADLINE: Prices Paid To Farmers Increase 0.7%

BYLINE: AP

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Dec. 29

 BODY:
The prices received by farmers for raw products rose seven-tenths of 1 percent from November to December, leaving the monthly average 2.1 percent above the level of December 1988.
According to the preliminary figures released today by the Agriculture Department, the department's price index averaged a record high for the year, surpassing the record set five years ago.
Higher prices for hogs, cattle, milk and eggs were mostly responsible for the increase from the November average, the department's Agricultural Statistics Board said. Lower prices were reported for lettuce, oranges, cotton and broilers. 
 
Milk Prices Up Sharply
The December milk price was the highest on record, and the average price for hogs was the highest since October 1987.
Most of the price information was collected at midmonth before severe cold swept into Florida and Texas, destroying citrus and vegetable crops. The preliminary figures will be revised next month.
John Buche of the department's National Agricultural Statistics Service said the preliminary 12-month price average for all farm commodities, about 147 percent of a 1977 base figure used for comparison, was the highest on record. The previous high was 142 percent in 1984; the 1988 average was 138 percent.
No new figures were provided on prices that farmers paid to meet expenses. That index is now computed only every three months. The most recent such index, for October, was up 2.9 percent from the comparable 1988 figure.
 
Estimate on Income
On Dec. 20, the department's Economic Research Service estimated that net cash income of farmers in 1989 might be $52 billion to $57 billion, compared with a revised estimate of $57.2 billion in 1988. This would be the fourth straight year in which net cash income exceeded $50 billion.
Department economists say the income decline in 1990 is mostly because of higher expenses as farmers put more land back into crops, and because of reduced Federal payments.
Net cash income is the money that farmers have left from gross cash income after cash expenses, including Government payments and proceeds from crops grown previously but sold during the year. It is not equivalent to profits because it does not take into account depreciation.
Based on the preliminary figures, the December price index for livestock and poultry rose 2.4 percent from November and averaged 9.7 percent more than a year ago.
The meat-animal portion of the index was up 2.9 percent from November and 8.4 percent from December 1988. Dairy prices rose 2.5 percent from November and 18 percent from a year ago.

HEADLINE: Patents;
Financial Instruments Protected

BYLINE: By Edmund L. Andrews

DATELINE: WASHINGTON

 BODY:
ONE of the truisms of the financial services industry - that no good idea goes uncopied -may not be true much longer.
Drawing on the ability to patent their own computer software needed to put their ideas into use, a few companies have patented such financial instruments as a novel certificate of deposit or an insurance policy in recent years.
Thus, they have overcome well-established patent law, which holds that financial products and services, which are ideas rather than inventions, are not eligible for the same patent protection as products. And their patents are being validated at the Patent and Trademark Office and in court. Since the early 1980's, Federal courts have increasingly ruled that software can be patented if it is part of a system that performs a specific function. 
Lawyers warn that the case law in the area is still ambiguous. But the financial implications could be profound for banks, brokerage firms and insurers, which have rarely tried to obtain patents for their ideas in the past. Until now, most companies have had to rely on trademarks, which protect a name or a logotype, and copyrights, which prevent the exact copying of language or symbols.
 
Hint of Change
The first hint of change came in 1983, when Merrill Lynch successfully defended a patent covering its Cash Management Account, a computerized trading account that automatically invests earnings from stocks and bonds in interest- bearing accounts and lets customers borrow against their portfolios. Two rivals, Paine Webber and Dean Witter Reynolds, attacked the patent as invalid, but a Federal judge upheld Merrill Lynch, which then forced its competitors to pay for a license on the idea.
A second suit was resolved in November, when the College Savings Bank of Princeton, N.J., which patented a certificate of deposit used to save for college expenses, sued and obtained royalties from the Centrust Savings Bank of Miami.
During the last two years, a handful of other financial products and services have also been patented. Merrill Lynch has obtained at least two more patents related to its Cash Management Account and a patent for a system to calculate employee relocation costs.
Another patent, issued to Henry L. Fox of Jericho, L.I., covers a method for determining the premium cost for insurance policies against adverse weather conditions. Yet another patent, issued to Jeffrey Cohen and Ian Robertson of Boca Raton, Fla., covers a buying club to offer a novel rebate for members when they purchase goods or services.
 
Particular Calculations
Typically, the patents cover a system that carries out particular calculations crucial to the financial product or service. In effect, this provides patent protection for the financial service itself.
The College Savings Bank, founded by Peter A. Roberts, has come closest to patenting a pure financial instrument. Mr. Roberts invented a certificate of deposit that is guaranteed to provide parents a hedge against inflation in college tuition. The C.D. is based on historical cost data at 500 colleges. The data show that college costs rise faster than the general rate of inflation.
To hedge against that, parents can set aside money for schooling at today's prices - plus an additional amount to cover inflation that exceeds any interest income the money will generate. This allows the College Savings Bank to guarantee that a year's payment of tuition now will cover a year's tuition when the child enters college.
Mr. Roberts obtained three patents on a computer system that calculates the amount required for one year at a particular school and initiated the system in late 1987. When Centrust started selling a similar product last year called College Prep Account, he sued the bank for infringement. In November, Centrust settled the suit by agreeing to pay an unspecified royalty.
Mr. Roberts obtained patents 4,752,877; 4,722,055 and 4,642,768.
 
An Unusual Rebate
Mr. Cohen and Mr. Robertson have patented what amounts to a buying club that will give members an unusual rebate when they buy goods and services.
Under the system, vendors agree to offer goods at a discount to club members, who would also be guaranteed a rebate on each purchase. But the rebate money would be turned over to an insurance company, which would guarantee the customer an annuity after 20 years. The annuity, which would be calculated and tracked by the patented computer system, would be based on the rebates and the accumulated interest and would be a form of retirement savings.
According to the inventors' attorney, Robert C. Kain Jr. of Miami, the inventors never succeeded in commercializing the idea, and patent rights are up for sale. The inventors received patent 4,750,119.
 
Weather Insurance
Mr. Fox patented a method for insuring people against weather from floods to droughts. Using historical data on the frequency of weather conditions in a given area, the system would calculate the likelihood of risk, weigh that against the amount and duration of insurance protection being sought and determine the appropriate premium.
Mr. Fox received patent 4,766,539.

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

HEADLINE: CONSUMER'S WORLD;
All-Terrain Vechicles: Still a Safety Hazard

BYLINE: By BARRY MEIER

 BODY:
Nearly two years after the birth of an elaborate plan to reduce deaths involving all-terrain vehicles, the number of youngsters being killed in such accidents is little changed.
The Federal Consumer Product Safety Commission estimates that the 1989 death toll in such accidents will be about 299, with 40 percent of the dead being children under 16 years old.
Injuries, however, have declined in the last three years. All-terrain vehicles have oversize tires capable of traversing rugged terrain. 
Even as the death toll continues, manufacturers are eliminating their child-size models in favor of heavier and faster ones. Consumer advocates see this as ironic because the industry defeated a move in Congress to ban child-size vehicles, arguing among other things that a ban would merely divert children to larger, more dangerous models.
Youthful drivers of all-terrain vehicles are most often killed when they lose control and the vehicle flips over on them or when they drive on public roads and are hit by other vehicles.
In April 1988, Judge Gerhard A. Gesell of the Federal District Court for the District of Columbia approved a consent decree meant to limit use of these vehicles. The makers and distributors of all-terrain vehicles agreed, among other things, to stop selling three-wheel models, to keep powerful four-wheelers out of youngsters' hands and to provide free driver training.
''No decree designed to protect consumers has ever gone this far in meeting such a massive national consumer problem,'' Judge Gesell said. The decree settled a suit filed by the Consumer Product Safety Commission against the five all-terrain vehicle companies.
But today the safety plan is in disarray. Dealers are not bound by the agreement, and many continue to recommend high-powered vehicles to adults who are buying them for children, according to several studies. And efforts to persuade states to legislate age and license requirements have foundered for the most part.
The agreement was bitterly contested by consumer groups, who said the manufacturers should buy back vehicles that were deemed unsafe. Today these critics say the consent decree is an example of a safety program that pulled its punches and is thus failing to do what it was intended to do.
''We have an extremely hazardous product that has escaped regulation,'' said Dr. Jeanine Jagger, a professor of epidemiology at the University of Virginia Medical School who advocates stricter laws on these vehicles.
 
Injuries Drop; Deaths Constant
Some regulators and industry spokesmen disagree. They say that the decree publicized the hazards of the vehicles and that injuries are falling in response. Proponents of the plan say the continuing deaths are a result of a lack of parental supervision and of tough state laws. Officials of the Commission say they cannot explain why injuries are falling, while deaths appear constant.
The controversy over all-terrain vehicles reaches back to the early 1980's when rising death and injury tolls led consumer and medical groups to call for Government action; Government statistics showed that deaths were highest among children 13 to 15 years old.
In December 1986 the Consumer Product Safety Commission voted to sue all five all-terrain vehicle companies: Honda, Kawasaki, Suzuki, Yamaha and Polaris. The Government demanded that the companies offer refunds, post safety warnings in sales rooms and offer free driver training.
''Our feeling was that these products were dangerous and had been misrepresented as safe,'' said Anne Graham, a commissioner.
But the demand for refunds was abandoned and a complex settlement negotiated. Along with agreeing to end sales of three-wheelers, the industry said it would prevent dealers from selling adult-size vehicles - those with engines bigger than 90 cubic centimeters - for use by youngsters under 16.
Four studies, including an undercover inquiry by the Commission, have all shown that many of the nation's 5,000 all-terrain vehicle dealers are still suggesting that adults buy large vehicles for children under 16.
Many dealers say the reports are wrong. ''Every dealer I know abides by the rules,'' said Hy Weitzman, executive director of the California Motorcycle Dealers Association, a trade group in San Bernardino, Calif.
Recent interviews with distributors show that to date only two dealers nationwide, both Suzuki outlets, have faced any disciplinary action by the companies for recommending large vehicles for children. Suzuki dropped one dealer and placed the other on probation, said John Walsh, legal affairs manager for American Suzuki Motor Corporation in Brea, Calif.
While more than 30 states have passed some laws affecting use of these vehicles, only a handful require licensing or have set 16 as a minimum age for operators of adult-sized machines, according to data complied by the Specialty Vehicle Institute of America, a trade group. Opposition to such laws has come from both dealers and enthusiasts. In Wisconsin a law to make 16 the minimum age for operating adult-size machines is opposed by the Wisconsin All-Terrain Vehicle Association, a user group. ''I see the age limit as artificial and totally unnecessary,'' said James Baxter, the group's executive director.
Enthusiasts like Mr. Baxter said they think many youngsters under 16 are big enough to use adult-size machines properly, and can be easily trained to handle them safely.
Proponents of tougher state legislation feel frustrated by such opposition. ''There are a lot of parents who think that nothing bad is going to happen to my child,'' said Bonnie Sumner of Milwaukee, whose son was badly injured in an accident involving an all-terrain vehicle in 1984.
 
Number of Machines Declines
Though only 11 percent of buyers of all-terrain vehicles nationwide are taking driver training programs, the rate is over 50 percent in a few states, among them Colorado and Minnesota. The number of the vehicles reached a record 2.6 million last year, but declined to 2.4 million this year. If it continues to dwindle, childhood deaths are expected to do so as well.
But the pace of that decline, some fear, may be slowed by another trend - the increasing power of ATV's. These days only one manufacturer, Suzuki, produces an all-terrain vehicle deemed suitable for children under 16. Meanwhile, producers have been souping up their products, statistics suggest. For example, while roughly half the all-terrain vehicle models on the market in 1986 had engine displacements greater than 200 cubic centimeters, that number had increased to some 70 percent by 1988, said Gregory Rodgers, an economist for the Commission.
Some child-size vehicles remain in stock, but as they are sold even enthusiasts like Mr. Baxter have little doubt about the hazards posed to children by the faster machines. ''It does mean that young people who do come into the sport could be exposed to greater risk,'' he said.

SECTION: Section 7; Page 7, Column 1; Book Review Desk

LENGTH: 1361 words

HEADLINE: Eden in the Heart of the City

BYLINE: By Anne Rice; Anne Rice has written several novels set in her birthplace, New Orleans, including ''Interview With the Vampire.''

 BODY:

SOUTHERN COMFORT The Garden District of New Orleans, 1800-1900.
By S. Frederick Starr.
Photographs by Robert S. Brantley. 308 pp. Cambridge, Mass.: The MIT Press. $35.
NEW ORLEANS is famous for jazz, Cajun and Creole food, Mardi Gras and the French Quarter. Rediscovered by Americans in recent years, it has become an increasingly popular setting for television shows and motion pictures, and its reputation for decadence and sensuality has earned it the nickname of ''the Big Easy.'' 
One of New Orleans's leading tourist attractions, however, has nothing to do with either its proverbial licentiousness or its colonial past - it is an uptown neighborhood, composed largely of 19th-century homes, known simply as the Garden District, and it is the subject of ''Southern Comfort: The Garden District of New Orleans, 1800-1900,'' S. Frederick Starr's beautifully illustrated, highly readable book.
Tourists can be seen strolling through the Garden District at any time of the year, in winter chill or sweltering summer heat, guidebooks in hand, pausing to inspect the various Greek Revival and Italianate houses. Century-old oaks shade the streets; sidewalks are often made of brick or flagstone; there are numerous wrought-iron fences. All summer long - in the patches of random sunlight - waxen-barked crape myrtles add their airy blossoms of red, purple, pink or white to a landscape already dotted with magnolias.
Many of the town houses are immense, sometimes completely filling their narrow lots. Greek-columned porches abound, as do intricate cast-iron railings. Smaller cottages add to the harmony of the whole, with their shuttered floor-length windows and gingerbread ornamentation. Lost in this part of town, you could easily imagine that you have left the modern world. The very scale of the dwellings, with their 14- and 15-foot ceilings, gives them an otherworldly quality.
These ingredients - gnarled branches, drowsy heat, crowded gardens with Corinthian capitals rising behind them - combine to create an ambiance unrivaled anywhere else in the United States. There is a spell at work in the Garden District that embraces the dilapidated old house as well as the splendid restoration; the workingman's double (two-family) cottage and the towering Italianate villa. On certain evenings the sky turns violet beyond the trees, then fades slowly into a pure and incandescent gold. The song of the cicadas, the random cry of birds, the leafy canopy overhead suggest an enchanted woodland rather than a big-city neighborhood.
The visitor cannot help wondering how such a place has survived, or how it ever came to be. ''Southern Comfort'' has the answers. It is a multifaceted study of the Garden District from its inception in the early 1800's until the end of the 19th century. In an economical and enjoyable style, Mr. Starr, the president of Oberlin College in Ohio, who spent two years as the scholar in residence at the Historic New Orleans Collection, discusses the entrepreneurs who settled the neighborhood, the fortunes they made - in cotton, wholesaling and the like - and the architects and builders they hired to create their often ostentatious mansions. Building materials, interior furnishings and ornament, the servant population and the social life of the neighborhood are all considered. Fully footnoted, the book is a valuable contribution to Southern history and to the history of both American architecture and American cities.
Mr. Starr shows how this most Southern of places was a neighborhood of newly arrived self-made millionaires as opposed to Louisiana-born planter aristocrats. The Garden District houses, mostly designed by non-native architects such as Henry Howard and Lewis E. Reynolds, were built in large part by Irish and German immigrant labor. Standing ''at the threshold between the ancient handcraft tradition and modern industrialization,'' in Mr. Starr's words, the Garden District used slate from Wales for its roofs, flagstones from England and Germany for its sidewalks and garden paths, standardized marble mantels and mass-produced ironwork. French cylinder glass went into its windows.
Though slaves lived and worked in the Garden District, its opulent standard of living was not dependent on the slave economy. Some residents owned no slaves; Irish domestics were common. Occupied by the enemy early during the Civil War, New Orleans and the Garden District survived intact. And in the critical years that followed, Mr. Starr says, ''the rural economy of the lower Mississippi Valley was bled not by Yankee loan sharks directly but by New Orleans bankers and factors domiciled in the Garden District.''
In sum, the history of the Garden District is an American tale. Continuing cycles of boom and bust had their impact as freshly minted millionaires went broke within a few years of erecting the homes that advertised their affluence. Before the end of the century the Greek Revival and Italianate styles had given way to the Queen Anne Victorian style.
It may surprise some readers to learn that the depressed modern economy of New Orleans has been partly responsible for the survival of most of the Garden District. In more progressive, prosperous places, old houses were razed by the thousands to make way for more profitable development, and indeed, as Mr. Starr points out, the oil boom of the 1970's saw enormous destruction in New Orleans as well.
But what Mr. Starr fails to mention is that the 1970's also brought about a national interest in restoring old urban homes. Hundreds of thousands of urban pioneers in San Francisco, Boston, Philadelphia and other cities moved back into the neighborhoods bordering downtown to reclaim the beautiful structures that had fallen into neglect. Preservationists organized themselves; restoration and refurbishing became big business. The prices of vintage houses skyrocketed. New Orleans was no exception to the national trend. This spirit has survived the end of the oil boom, and New Orleans is now militantly protective of its splendid old homes. Mr. Starr's statement that ''there have recently been a few signs that further demolition in the Garden District may finally have been checked'' does not do justice to the present state of the preservationist movement.
''Southern Comfort'' can also be faulted for not doing justice to the esthetic quality of the Garden District and its overwhelming effect upon visitors as well as residents. Mr. Starr's constant comparative observations and some of his criticisms - that only two architects working in the Garden District ''exhibited a measure of genuine originality''; and that, in the 1870's, New Orleans failed to develop an authentic regional style - seem curiously cold, if not sour. His overall tone is rather cool, and though his many negative sentiments may be accurate and historically interesting, his lack of apparent enthusiasm for the marvelous end product of grand design, accident, boom and misfortune is a bit confusing.
After all, it is possible that innovation and originality are beside the point in the Garden District. For no matter how similar its houses may be to others in Charleston or the rural Carolinas, or anyplace else, the enclave as a whole is like no other. That it has endured in the heart of a busy city, just minutes from downtown high-rises, only adds to its mystery.
Surely some analysis or discussion of the neighborhood's undeniable beauty and romance would have broadened the scope of the work, and should not be seen as inimical to sound scholarship. Perhaps in seeking to avoid ''moonlight and magnolia'' superlatives, Mr. Starr has gone a little too far in the other direction.
Be that as it may, ''Southern Comfort'' is a landmark piece of scholarship on the area. Its numerous photographs, maps, architectural plans and other illustrations bring together an amazing amount of significant material. In addition to placing the Garden District in national and historical context, Mr. Starr has done a wonderful job of describing, analyzing and documenting the various elements that went into the creation of this remarkable neighborhood.

SECTION: Section 5; Page 17, Column 1; Travel Desk

LENGTH: 2492 words

HEADLINE: Gone Fishing On the Bridges of Florida

BYLINE: By HENRY LEIFERMANN; HENRY LEIFERMANN is a writer who lives in Florida.

 BODY:
IT'S another easy morning on Little Jim Bridge in Florida's Indian River country, the sun just beginning to warm the backs of the regulars fishing from the catwalks and debating, again, how best to hook the noble snapper.
Just across the mangrove flats, shiny charter fishing boats are running out Fort Pierce Inlet, their captains and clients bound for the open Atlantic Ocean to pursue, more or less, the same fish swimming under the bridge. Similar scenes are happening daily, and frequently nightly, in Florida on bridges all along the Atlantic coast, the Gulf of Mexico coast and in the Keys.
By sunset on Little Jim and other coastal bridges, a socially structured and gregariously seasoned gumbo of old-time and first-time anglers will have come and gone from the fishing catwalks. They take with them a taste of, and perhaps a catch from, one of the most popular and least publicized forms of saltwater fishing - and of simple fun - bridge fishing. 
Bridge fishing is easy and inexpensive. Simply park nearby and walk onto the catwalks separated by guardrails from the bridge traffic. There is no need for a boat, a guide, much fishing gear or a license. The coastal bridges are inviting for their scenic views, so take folding chairs and a cooler of drinks and snacks, because bridge fishing frequently and invitingly has nothing to do with fishing.
Travelers and residents, regulars and rookies, retirees and children from every social, economic, ethnic and racial group living in or visiting Florida go bridge fishing. They line the catwalks and take in the parade of small boats, or the sunset, from the Honeymoon Island bridges at Dunedin near Tampa on the Gulf Coast, bridges leading to secluded Honeymoon Island State Park.
They drive cars onto and park along the old Three-Mile Bridge in the western panhandle at the Pensacola Bay town of Gulf Breeze and watch Navy pilots flying from Pensacola Naval Air Station.
In Miami's Biscayne Bay, MacArthur Causeway (U.S. 41) bridges leading to Miami Beach offer closeup views of Caribbean cruise ships plying Government Cut between their docks and the Atlantic Ocean.
Along St. Augustine's Vilano Bridge, spectator-anglers have a vista of passing yachts in the Intracoastal Waterway and miles of saltwater marsh along the Matanzas River.
In the Keys, where sunrises and sunsets are among Forida's most spectacular, bridge fishers pitch tents for shade on both ends of the old Seven Mile Bridge at Marathon.
As Bobbie Miner, owner of the Little Jim Bait & Tackle shop and marina, said: ''A lot of it is not serious fishing. It's social.'' Her store, next to Little Jim Bridge, is on the State Route A1A causeway leading to North Hutchinson Island, crossing the Indian River lagoon from the mainland and Fort Pierce on Florida's south-central Atlantic coast.
Capt. Bill Lomax, a retired commercial fisherman who often works part-time in the store and enjoys people watching, points out parents who have found something different for themselves and their vacationing children to do. ''They bring their kids, the grandchildren, even the neighbor's kids. The kids love it, it costs hardly anything, and I'll tell you what: fishing is still the greatest thing going,'' he said. FROM a bridge, the simply curious or the serious landbound angler gets access to species normally also caught from a boat in the ocean or in saltwater bays. These include tarpon, grouper, snapper, jacks, barracuda and shark, almost every saltwater fish except swordfish, sailfish or tuna, pelagic species that normally spend their entire lives in the open ocean. Most of the bridges lead from the mainland to the many barrier islands and beaches along Florida's coasts. Some cross broad lagoons like the Indian River; others cross inlets, and some are part of the chain of bridges liking the Keys.
Although most of the bridges are not directly on the ocean or the gulf, the waters they span are dominated by one or the other, which makes coastal bridge fishing saltwater fishing.
If the bridge is meant for fishing, it will have catwalks along one or both sides, usually about 25 feet above water at the level of the roadway. If the bridge is not meant for fishing, it will be posted ''No Fishing From Bridge,'' a sign to look for or ask about since some bridges are closed to fishing even though they still retain old fishing catwalks.
Florida imposed its first saltwater fishing license this year ($30 a year for nonresidents), but fishing from a bridge, a pier or the ocean shore is exempt from the license requirement.
All the best coastal fishing bridges have a version of the Little Jim Bait & Tackle shack nearby - for sandwiches, snacks, drinks, gossip and lore and for fishing advice for beginners, such as the fact that you don't need fishing gear of your own to enjoy bridge fishing.
Mrs. Miner recommends buying a ''yo-yo,'' a big, plastic arm bracelet with curved edges to hold fishing line like thread on a spool. Tie on a hook, sinker and bait (the store that sells it will show you how), then whirl the line overhead and sling it out and down into the water. About $20 buys the entire rig.
There is no predicting what you will catch, and usually a regular fishing nearby can identify it for you. Bear in mind that you might catch nothing but a good time, which is why they call it fishing, not catching.
Mrs. Miner's store, and Little Jim Bridge itself, are classics of the genre. Inside the store are boxes of lures and hooks, spools of line, stacks of weights and floats, a freezer of bait, a cooler of beer and T-shirts and baseball caps with the legend ''Little Jim Bait & Tackle.''
Outside, under a sloping roof, is the veranda, with a view of Little Jim Bridge a long cast away. The shady hangout is furnished with items salvaged over the years, such as picnic tables covered with old carpeting and swivel chairs, whose vinyl cushions are cracked and split but are as comfortable as a favorite rocker.
Mrs. Miner has run her place for only 10 years. The bridge, first in wood, later in concrete, has been there since 1926, and some of the regulars have been fishing from it nearly that long, since childhood.
Some of the regulars are self-proclaimed Florida Crackers, old-timers who look askance at the newcomers who live in high-rise condominiums on the nearby beach. Okeechobee Red, Bailey Quattlebaum and Lake Erie Earl are among the regulars.
Captain Lomax said, ''You can't tell who's a local anymore. People spend six months here and six months up North. But if you see a guy fishing with the reel upside down, you know he's from New Jersey or Boston.''
Upside-down fishing, he explained, is with the rod held so that the reel is on top, along with the eyelets through which the fishing line passes. The captain merely shakes his head at the Northerners who get their share of fish despite going about it all wrong.
Motorists visiting Florida might wonder, as they drive over a fishing bridge, just why anyone would want to fish from a bridge. The answers are, for one, because that's where the fish are, and for another, no, it is not dangerous.
Bridge fishermen need to take care not to rear back and cast a rig of snook hooks and lead weights that might snare a passing convertible behind them. They should also resist climbing over the catwalk rail and entering the traffic lanes to reel in a catch.
There are signs on bridges that open for boats. The ''No Fishing Between Signs'' warnings at either end of the draw spans are not to protect anglers who might be too preoccupied to get off when the span is going up. The warnings are to prevent the shouting contests that can occur when a boat passes under the bridge, snagging hooks and lines in the process.
Any bait or tackle shop along Florida's coasts can direct visitors to the nearest fishing bridge. The best bridges have a strong tidal flow beneath them, such as those near inlets to the Atlantic or the gulf and those near the mouth of bays and rivers. There are scores of good coastal fishing bridges, too many to list, among the hundreds of bridges along Florida's coasts.
In the Keys, bridge fishing is a virtual art form and way of life because there are so many bridges, so little beach for surf casting and such spectacular scenery. This year the state Department of Transportation began turning over many old Keys bridges they have replaced with new ones to other state and local agencies for use as fishing bridges.
The old Seven-Mile Bridge is among the most popular. David Krug, a Marathon resident and supervisor in the Keys for the highway department, also recommended the bridges on either side of Craig Key, which is south of Key Largo and north of Marathon.
Those bridges, called Channel Two and Channel Five, Mr. Krug said, ''are probably the two best fishing bridges in the Keys. You can walk the whole length of them on the catwalks. On Channel Two, get there early before the shrimpers.''
In the Lower Keys, the Kemp Channel Bridge at Summerland Key and the Spanish Harbor Bridge at Bahia Honda State Recreation Area are designated as fishing bridges. In the Upper Keys, try the Card Sound Bridge (State Road 997 to Key Largo from the mainland) and visit Alabama Jack's, an open-air restaurant and gossip shop.
As improbable as it may seem, people do catch shrimp as well as fish from the coastal bridges. Shrimp spawn year round in Florida, but the best spawning runs, and therefore the best shrimping times, are from January through March, especially after a cold snap. Veterans recommend shrimping at night, three days before or after a full moon, on an incoming or outgoing tide.
Hang a lantern or some other light above the water. The light attracts the shrimp drifting by on the tide, and the shrimper simply dips them out of the water with a fine-meshed, long-handled net available in most fishing tackle shops.
The light and the shrimp also attract fish, and anglers can pick up a bonus catch by tossing out a bottom rig just beyond the lighted area. For bait, try a fresh shrimp. There is almost as much advice available for beginning fishermen as there is - potentially - fish to catch. A generally accepted recommendation is to have your bait, tackle, chairs and coolers on the bridge and ready to fish a half hour before the tide starts to change.
There are four tides a day, two lows and two highs, each lasting six hours. Experts like Jerry Metz, an Indian River guide based at Little Jim Bait & Tackle, said it is best to fish the first two hours of the outgoing (low) tide through the last hour of the incoming (high) tide. Peak feeding and fishing occurs on the tide change, he said. Nearly everyone recommends using live bait (shrimp, mullet, pigfish, pinfish, goggle-eyes or whatever the regulars use). Generally, that is whatever small baitfish they can catch or buy.
More experienced bridge fishermen recommend taking two rods for this kind of fishing, one light enough to be sporting on the mostly small species that make up the bulk of the catch (rigged with 10-pound line, for example) and the other heavy enough to lift a large, struggling fish 10 to 15 feet into the air (20-pound line).
The veterans often take with them personalized fish-landing systems like a long-handled net. They also avoid leaders with snap-fasteners for attaching the hook, because the device frequently straightens out and releases the hook under the stress of reeling a thrashing fish up to the bridge.
There are potential hazards for fishing lines around a bridge. Barnacles, coral and shellfish as well as rough pilings can slice a line. Some veterans recommend using a six-foot section of heavy leader line.
If you let it, bridge fishing, like any other type of fishing, can overwhelm you or delight you with the available gimcrack gewgaws and do's or don't's lying in wait as bait for beginners. It requires no skill beyond congenialty and conversation, with a taste for the scenic in nature and the individual in people, to savor the best that bridge fishing has to offer.
 
Getting a line on bridge fishing
If you go Florida bridge fishing, you can buy supplies and get advice from most bait and tackle stores listed in local phone directories. Here is a sampling of some popular spots.
 
Fort Pierce
Little Jim Bridge, on State Route A1A, the North Beach Causeway leading from U.S. 1 and the Fort Pierce mainland across the Indian River lagoon to North Hutchinson Island; Little Jim Bait & Tackle, at Little Jim Bridge; open seven days, 7 A.M. to 9 P.M.; 407-461-9890.

Florida Keys
U.S. 1, traveling south; Card Sound Bridge, turn left onto County Road 997, Old Card Sound Road, at Florida City and park at the north end of the bridge, which is about 11 miles south of the intersection of U.S. 1 and County Road 997; Jack's, 35410 South Dixie Highway, in Florida City just north of the intersection; open 24 hours, seven days; 305-245-5550. Also, Channel 2 and Channel 5 bridges, either side of Craig Key, on U.S. 1, Long Key and the Long Key State Recreation Area beaches; Caloosa Cove Bait & Tackle, Mile Marker 73.5 near the Channel 2 bridge on Lower Matecumbe Key. (Locations in the Keys are given by referring to mile-marker signs.) Open 7 A.M. to 5 P.M., seven days; 305-664-8057. At Marathon: Old Seven Mile Bridge, fishing catwalks at either end off Knight Key and Little Duck Key; Seven Mile Marina, Mile Marker 47.5 just before the bridge in Marathon; open 7 A.M. to sundown, seven days; 305-743-7712. Also, Big Pine Key, Spanish Harbor Bridge just east of Big Pine and Kemp Channel Bridge nearby to the west; John & Jerry's Bait & Tackle, Mile Marker 30.5 on Big Pine; open 7 A.M. to 7 P.M., seven days; 305-872-9872.

Dunedin
Honeymoon Island bridges, the first over the Intracoastal Waterway, the second at the edge of Honeymoon Island; take County Road 586 west off Alternate U.S. 19; Dunedin Bait & Tackle, 1307 Bayshore Boulevard (Alternate 19) two miles south of County Road 586; open seven days, 6:30 A.M. to 7:30 P.M., 8:30 P.M. on Friday and Saturday; 7 P.M. Sunday; 813-736-3474.

SECTION: Section 10; Page 3, Column 1; Real Estate Desk

LENGTH: 1092 words

HEADLINE: Talking: Appraisals;
Lenders Becoming Warier

BYLINE: By ANDREE BROOKS

 BODY:
IN the last few months a growing number of appraisals being made by lenders are falling short of the price agreed upon by buyer and seller.
Say, for example, the buyer and seller decide that $180,000 is a fair price for a home and they sign a contract to that effect. In the past the lenders tended to go along with that decision. But not anymore. Lenders are increasingly likely to decide that such a property is probably worth, say, $160,000. 
''Many of our appraisals are coming in about 5 to 15 percent lower than the purchase price,'' noted Walter Henderson, first senior vice president of Mechanics and Farmers Savings Banks, which has headquarters in Bridgeport, Conn.
The upshot is that the lender will probably not allow the borrower as much financing as had originally been anticipated. But that does not mean the deal will fall through. There are ways around such a problem.
First, it may be worth knowing that the phenomenon is so widespread that rushing to another lender is probably not effective, although it occasionally helps. Low lender appraisals are occurring as a direct result of the national savings and loan crisis, which has led to stricter monitoring by authorities of banking practices. Most lender are thus more nervous and, therefore, more cautious.
The extreme conservatism is being exacerbated by rapidly deteriorating real estate values, especially in the Northeast. Thus, by the time a home closes 30 to 90 days after the appraisal, it may be worth even less, ''so we have to factor in the possibility that the price could drop even lower,'' said Bernard Goodman, a partner in Goodman Marks Associates of Mineola, L.I., which regularly handles appraisals for Long Island lenders.
In other instances the buyers may have been fully aware they were paying slightly more than market value but ''were probably willing to do so,'' said Mr. Goodman, ''because they were anxious to get a certain amenity like a particular school district.'' Lenders did not used to care too much because values would soon catch up; today it it just the opposite.
Yet another reason for low appraisals is that lenders are becoming increasingly uneasy about the economy. ''They worry that borrowers may have difficulty meeting payments if personal income is affected,'' said Mr. Goodman. Should that occur and the property ends up being foreclosed, the lender wants to be certain that at least the size of the outstanding mortgage loan can be recouped. Thus, a mortgage being written for 80 percent or more when values are dropping can be dangerous if market value has not been very conservatively established in advance.
So far only about 10 percent of lender appraisals are falling short of the contract price. ''It would be much higher,'' said Edwin Haflich, a partner in Haflich, Timpanelli & Zeidel, an appraiser in Trubull, Conn., that regularly does work for banks, ''except that in the past few months only the sellers who were willing to make really good deals were finding buyers.''
The properties most frequently affected are condominiums, according to Mr. Henderson, the Connecticut banker, because prices have been weakening most rapidly in this area of the marketplace.
According to Mr. Haflich, low appraisals may also cause some nasty surprises for sellers being relocated by a corporation. When unable to sell their homes, such employees are usually offered the chance to unload them to a relocation home purchase agency, such as Homequity. The custom in these situations is for the employee to get the average of two separate, independent appraisals. But both appraisals may come in far lower than anticipated, he said, ''because we have to assume that house will not sell on the open market for three months or more. And who knows what the value will be then?''
A BUYER who finds that the lender has decided a home is worth less than the contract price can also try to renegotiate with the seller. ''We have seen quite a few instances where the buyer was able to negotiate a lower price,'' said Clark Halstead, managing partner of the Halstead Property Company of Manhattan. In a soft market, sellers are likely to be flexible, he maintained, because they know they might face the problem with another buyer. They may also be under time pressure to sell.
The buyer can try to persuade the lender to change his decision by presenting facts that support the contract price. ''You or your broker should request a copy of the data on which the bank made its decision,'' said Peter Helie, chief operating officer at William Pitt Residential Real Estate of Southern Connecticut. ''And then try to come up with figures that justify what you are paying.''
If no broker is used, an appraiser can be hired to compile an independent set of figures. Expect to pay around $300 for such a service. Sometimes, it can be done at no cost.
Roberta Faulstick, vice president of sales and marketing at William B. May Company of New York City, recalls an instance last summer where a buyer agreed to the full asking price of $750,000 for a Park Slope brownstone. The lender's appraiser said it was worth only $700,000, which meant the loan being requested would exceed 80 percent of value, which the lender would not permit.
''So we asked the bank to get a second appraisal,'' said Ms. Faulstick, ''and offered to pay if it came in at the same price or lower.'' It did not. The second figure was $725,000, enough, she said, to keep the loan under 80 percent of value.
Another alternative is for the buyer to make a larger down payment, a solution chosen by Paul and Susan Stafford of Fairfield Conn. The appraisal for the three-bedroom home they were buying came in at $9,000 less than the contract price. This resulted in the lender's asking for $3,000 more towards the down payment so the loan would not exeed prudent limits.
To lower the size of that loan by lowering the contract prce was not feasible, said Mr. Stafford, because, ''with only two weeks to go to the closing we didn't want to start renegotiating. It would have cost up extra time, which would have been worse.'' So the couple chose instead to pay the additional sum out of cash reserves.
Finally, if the buyer is not borrowing to the limit of his available credit, the difference required by the bank might also be made up through seller financing, said Ms. Faulstick. For example, say there was a $15,000 difference between the contract price and the lender's appraisal. The seller might offer a personal loan for the extra amount the lender is requesting.

SECTION: Section 12WC; Page 10, Column 3; Westchester Weekly Desk

LENGTH: 1603 words

HEADLINE: Czech Couple Keep Eye on Homeland

BYLINE: By ROBERTA HERSHENSON

DATELINE: BRIARCLIFF MANOR

 BODY:
AS history is made in Prague, an American couple with strong ties to Czechoslovakia have watched the events on television in their home here. Milena Jelinek, an assistant professor in the film division of the Columbia University School of the Arts, personally knew many players in the current drama before coming to the United States in 1960.
Frederick Jelinek, who left Prague as a teen-ager in 1949, had returned often with his wife to visit her family (his own family is now scattered, with no one left in Czechoslovakia). He was also there twice in the 1970's as an invited lecturer at the Institute for Information Theory and Automatization of the Czechoslovakian Academy of Sciences in Prague. Dr. Jelinek, who holds a doctoral degree in information theory from the Massachusetts Institute of Technology, heads I.B.M.'s speech-recognition research team at its Yorktown Heights headquarters.
The team has developed a voice-activated word processor that translates speech into type. 
The Jelineks were introduced in Prague by the Czech film director, Milos Forman at the 1957 premiere of ''Easy Life,'' a film shown throughout Czechoslovakia for which Mrs. Jelinek - then a student named Milena Tobolova - had written the screenplay. She and Mr. Forman were colleagues at Prague's Film and Television School of the Academy of Musical Arts. Dr. Jelinek - who had known Mr. Forman from childhood - was on a visit to Prague.
For the next three years, Dr. Jelinek tried to get the woman he wanted to marry out of Czechoslovakia. In 1960 he succeeded - through the combined efforts of Jerome Wiesner, a former president of M.I.T. and President Kennedy's science adviser; and the Cleveland industrialist Cyrus Eaton, who had influence with Nikita Khruschev; and finally, Mr. Khruschev himself.
This illustrious exit was preceded by a period spent as a ''non-person,'' Mrs. Jelinek said. When the Government learned she wanted to leave, she was suspended from film school and dismissed from her job. But because she left legally, she was able subsequently to visit her parents - who have recently died - and her sister's family and to keep in touch with the country's mood.
The couple said they were surprised, however, over the tumultuous events of the last six weeks. During this time the hard-line Communist President Gustav Husak resigned, the Communist monopoly was dissolved and the dissident playwright Vaclav Havel - whom Mrs. Jelinek knew as a student - was agreed upon as the new President by both the Communist Party and the opposition Civic Forum.
The Jelineks had last been in Czechoslovakia in June, when Mrs. Jelinek addressed an international congress of film students. The Czech students had avoided her then, responding, she concluded, to the usual fear tactics of the Communist regime aimed at keeping the Czech population and foreigners apart.
''I wouldn't have suspected that the mood in three months would be this open revolt,'' Mrs. Jelinek said in a recent conversation with the couple in their living room. Their children, Hannah and William, now in their 20's, grew up in the house, with its wooded setting. Graphics by Czech artists who are friends of the couple line the walls.
Dr. Jelinek agreed that there had been ''no revolutionary mood'' last spring, despite certain hints at change. A songwriter named Jiri Suchy, who had written songs for Mrs. Jelinek's films but hadn't been allowed to perform on television since 1968, was appearing in a Prague theater. A petition circulated by a group of artists requesting a more responsive Government had been signed by thousands.
Dr. Jelinek described a system within the Communist system that still flourished in June. Based on what he called ''ingenious barter,'' it consisted of ''everybody helping everybody else'' and ''making deals'' to have a comfortable life.
 
A 'Niceness' Has Grown
''Everything you get has to be a favor from someone,'' Dr. Jelinek said. As a result, he noted, a certain ''niceness'' almost as a philosophy, has grown up under the regime.
''Being nice to each other became the way to survive, to continue having the Czech nation'' in the face of Russian domination,'' Dr. Jelinek said.
On the other hand, an extreme case of materialism grips the nation, he said. ''There is no more materialistic society than a socialist society,'' he added. ''That's all they do, all they think about. The whole family works all the time just to have a car.''
The coin's other side is ''you simply don't have things that you somehow imagine would make a difference,'' his wife said.
Mrs. Jelinek said she did not believe, however, that a desire for ''things'' had fueled the revolution. ''They are demonstrating in the streets because they are not going to allow the Soviet Union to take responsiblity for their lives anymore,'' she said. ''You will exchange social security for responsibility over your own life.''
 
Watches TV for Changes
In 1956 the screenwriter herself protested in the street, but she said she had ''left too soon'' to be among the group of compatriots from the Prague Spring era of 1968 now celebrating in Czechoslovakia. She did not keep in touch with the many artists she knew in Prague, for fear of endangering them. She now watches television to learn of the changes for which she once marched.
''You see these flags and hear these songs and you thought it would never happen,'' Mrs. Jelinek said of the general strike and demonstrations in late November that led to the recent developments. ''Of course, I wanted to see every shot and every face on TV.'' Yet despite the emotional pull to be there and the expense of long telephone calls to family in Czechoslovakia, neither Jelinek is catching the next plane to Prague. While many Czech intellectuals living abroad have been called to return, they have not been asked.
Dr. Jelinek said that he is unknown in the country, having left so long ago. Despite the reputation he has gained on the international lecture circuit, people from his field in Czechoslovakia were ''never allowed to go to our conferences,'' he said.
His situation is unusual because in exchange for a two-year scholarship to M.I.T. from the Mid-European Study Center, a division of the now disbanded Committee for a Free Europe, Dr. Jelinek had agreed to use his education for the benefit of Czechoslovakia if the country ever became free.
Now he is not needed, he said. Besides, he added that he ''wouldn't quit I.B.M.''
Mrs. Jelinek maintained that Czechoslovakia has ''plenty of people who teach film'' and that her presence wasn't necessary. The company spoke of Mr. Forman, now famous for such films as ''Amadeus'' - as well as another Columbia professor, the director Vojta Jasny, who were returning to Prague and being ''welcomed at the airport.'' It was a matter of when you left and with whom you shared struggles, the couple they agreed.
At Columbia, however, Mrs. Jelinek has helped the Czech cause in several ways. She organized a telegram of support to be sent from Columbia film students to the students at her former school in Prague, who, she said, were ''at the center'' of the November strike.
She said she is also in touch with ''various organizations'' requesting aid - such as cameras and videotapes for film students, whose strike has extended through recent weeks. The Columbia film division has had a strong Czech component for many years. Faculty members in addition to Mrs. Jelinek and Mr. Jasny have included Mr. Forman, who is on leave as co-chairman of the division; the Czech Frank Daniel, a former co-chairman and now dean of the film school at the University of Southern California.
The Jelineks said they were optimistic about Czechoslovakia's future, despite what Dr. Jelinek said would be ''enormous economic problems.''
''No one knows how to make the transition,'' from Communism to a market economy which is ''what the people want,'' he said. ''No one wants to have capitalism, but I think you can't have a market economy without capitalism,'' he added.
Observing that capitalism is ''the final aim,'' he said he didn't know how it could be achieved.
''I think it's extremely important not to antagonize the workers,'' Dr. Jelinek added. In their visit last spring to the Czech countryside, the couple said they had found that many farmers did not want change. ''The fact is, agriculture is really quite all right,'' Mrs. Jelinek said. ''The cooperatives are bringing profits back to the people.''
Over the years, Dr. Jelinek has had several run-ins with border police as he was leaving Czechoslovakia. Once he was arrested and interrogated - although quickly released - while taking pictures of the unmarked barracks at the concentration camp where his father, a dentist, died of typhoid during World War II.
Now, looking toward continued reform, he pointed out that ''the army is still run by Communists.''
''The question is who has the arms,'' his wife said. ''You have to have the army on your side and you have to know what to do with the secret police. You have to know you won't be occupied by the Soviets. The Soviet tanks are still on the territory.'' She recalled Mr. Havel, as she knew him 30 years ago.
''He was a member of a small circle of artists,'' Mrs. Jelinek said. ''He was always very shy. Everyone knew his uncle was the owner of a film company.''
''He comes from rich people and a bourgeois background,'' said Dr. Jelinek of Mr. Havel, who spent four months in prison this year for subversion. Most of the dissidents were Communists at one time,'' he added. ''Havel never was.''

GRAPHIC: Photo of Frederick and Milena Jelinek (NYT/Roberta Hershenson)

The New York Times

PUB-DATE: December 31, 1989

SECTION: Section 2; Page 31, Column 1; Arts and Leisure Desk

LENGTH: 1855 words

HEADLINE: ARCHITECTURE/DESIGN
ARCHITECTURE VIEW; From Friend to Mysterious Alien Force in 40 Years

BYLINE: By Thomas Hine; Thomas Hine is the author of ''Populuxe,'' published by Knopf, about design in the 1950's. He is working on a book about imagining the future.

 BODY:
Things from the late 1940's are suddenly quite interesting, not because baby boomers are nostalgic for a moment that was just before their time but because, as eras end, it is natural to look back at their origins and think about some of the roads not taken.
As the postwar era ends its nearly 45-year run, it is time for a look at Eames chairs, Quonset huts, be-bop, action painting, Alexander Calder's improvised kitchen utensils, Raymond Loewy's 1947 Studebaker and Mary Martin singing in the shower.
All of these are phenomena that represent, in some way, a fresh spirit that was prevalent in the United States just as the postwar era was beginning. But their attitude of innovative materialism has been missing from our culture for some time.
Several of them are addressed or at least alluded to by recent exhibitions and books, including the shows ''Blueprints for Modern Living'' at the Museum of Contemporary Art in Los Angeles and ''The Intimate World of Alexander Calder,'' at the Cooper-Hewitt, each of which has an accompanying catalogue, and the book ''Eames Design,'' published by Abrams. 
Postwar America is famous for its prodigious but careless consumption of things. We now have more cars registered than there are licensed drivers, occupy more than twice as much developed space per person than we did in 1945, and lay down landfills that rival the great pyramid at Giza.
Today we build classical porticoes out of plastic foams that can be pierced with a butter knife, showing that we value the image more than the substance. The Seabees with their 50-gallon oil drums, Alexander Calder with his wire, Charles and Ray Eames with their plywood, Jackson Pollock with his paint - all were far more interested than we in the things themselves. They played with things and found new possibilities in them. Yet theirs promised to be a materialism that stopped short of the idolatry implicit in prewar European modernism. The war had been a reminder that materials and technology were, above all, useful. They had no meaning by themselves, but could serve as tools to build and protect a way of life. God did not reside, blasphemously, in the details, but rather in the inspiration that made these things into expressions of life and its infinite possibilities.
The saving grace was probably a faith in the possibilities of improvisation, not just in painting and jazz but even in architecture and design. While Calder had been putting found materials to both practical and artistic uses for decades, the principal impetus for the improvisatory spirit was the war, which had imposed stern disciplines on budgets and materials. The architect Bruce Goff, serving in a naval construction battalion, used string and an electric fan blowing on balloons to create a club on a naval base. Even after the war was over, he kept on using Quonset huts, bending their barrel-vault structures to make houses that were new and entirely unexpected.
But the improvisatory spirit was widespread and shared by people who would never design anything again. Certain expedients became standard procedures. For example, it is likely that the shower under which a real-life Nellie Forbush (from the musical ''South Pacific'') would have washed that man right out of her hair would have been fashioned from oil drums, modified to catch rainwater and be heated by the sun, a primitive solar hot-water system. (It's also likely that her fellow nurses would have told her to stop using all the hot water, rather than joining in the chorus, but then again, nobody ever left a show humming the plumbing.) The clever G.I. was a motif that ran through countless magazine articles from late 1944 on. Women's magazines promised that returning soldiers would be able to fulfill their wives' and fiancees' deepest fantasies: they'd be able to fix things. But even girls could be handy. In 1946, House Beautiful devoted an article to one Thelma Brunette (a blonde), who had, with the help of her father, turned a double-decker bus into a home, complete with fireplace, on the beach at Malibu.
A few miles away, in Pacific Palisades, Charles and Ray Eames were planning what became a landmark of easygoing technology, their own house. Charles Eames did the first design (with Eero Saarinen) in 1945, but because of materials shortages and other problems, the industrial parts from which it was to be built were not delivered until 1948. With the materials on hand, Eames made them into an entirely different building, actually a pair of buildings, one of the most delightful and celebrated designs of the entire postwar era. It is also one of the most written-about, so there is no need to say much here, except to note that one of its best qualities is that it appears to be an artful expedient rather than an artistic expression. Alone among the celebrated glass-and-steel houses of the immediate postwar era, it did not seem to oppress its occupants. The house does not express the tyranny of what many modernist architects spoke of, in near-religious terms, as The Solution. It is a neutral container that admits life. (In fact, the casualness of the Eameses' living style - the exquisite clutter that made visiting there so memorable - was very carefully maintained. Comparisons of photographs from different times show that things that seemed merely to have been scattered about were allowed to move barely a millimeter from decade to decade.) The Eameses became famous for their plywood-and-metal chairs, which grew out of their war work developing splints for wounded soldiers and drew on wartime advances in wood molding, glues and synthetic rubber for shock mounts. Today their house represents a rare example of a humane materialism that many observers hoped would become widespread as the country shifted from war to peace. This was a matter-of-fact modernism, one that would not celebrate machine technology and materials but simply recognize their enormous usefulness. They had helped win the war and could also lead to an era of prosperous and comfortable peace. It was natural to assume that veterans of mechanized warfare and improvised living would feel at home with the new, as would the many women who spent the war working in factories.
These postwar hopes were mixed with fears that the industrial machinery that had produced the victory would be allowed to slump back into depression. Thus, even before the war ended, Americans were encouraged to aspire to new suburban houses, filled with new appliances, as their reward for wartime sacrifices. We were urged to dream about beating our tanks into bungalows.
It seemed to be a moment for innovation. Buckminster Fuller, who had already been dreaming of inexpensive metal houses in easy-to-build kits for 20 years, had Beech Aircraft as a backer, and even announced that he was ready to take orders. Walter Gropius revived Bauhaus dreams of factory-made housing and helped start factories on both coasts to produce it. There was a sudden proliferation of car makes, including the Tucker, the subject of the 1987 movie. DeFoe Shipbuilders announced a homey, metal Cape Cod house, while Kaiser, who had produced the liberty ships, started making dishwashers, garbage disposals, and that peculiar car, the Henry J. Postwar materials shortages kept many of the most visionary schemes from getting off the ground. And Federal Housing Administration and Veterans Administration mortgage insurance policies discriminated against anything that looked too modern (along with houses that were old or in racially integrated neighborhoods). While Levitt and other developers were able to respond to consumer demand with mass-produced housing, war plants were never converted to produce metal house kits. It's likely that people would not have liked them, and that the modernism the war represented was something they never wanted to see again. But we'll never know, because the military plants never needed to find other products to make. The menace of the Soviet Union under Stalin replaced that of the Axis powers, and soon there was war in Korea.
The production of consumer goods did revive, and a lot of novel products were offered. Many of the appliances of the immediate postwar era look prehistoric today, since they represent evolutionary dead ends on the way to material goods that have since become inescapable. Television screens resided deep in wooden cabinets, from which they were reflected, dimly, by mirrors, or they were behind enormous magnifying glasses. The Kaiser Fleetways dishwasher was cylindrical, and it popped out of the counter top, like a periscope, for loading. One company, Thor, brought out an appliance that could wash both clothes and dishes, though not at the same time.
Even the Loewy-designed Studebakers, probably the most advanced mass-produced cars of the period, have the awkward look of something new trying to be born. People claimed not to be able to tell which way they were going - largely because these cars offered unprecedented visibility both front and rear. Their look was open at a time when many of their competitors appeared designed for defense.
By the 1950's the visionaries had dropped out of the marketplace and the giant-sloth appliances had become extinct. But more important, goods had become dematerialized. We learned to become attached not to any particular thing but to the practice of buying things. General Electric told us that its product was not stoves or steam irons, but progress itself. As long as G.E. and its counterparts kept working to improve our lives, the rest of us wouldn't have to worry. Each new generation of products would be so great an advance over its predecessors that it would be unnecessary to ask whether the new things were better than the old. Features multiplied. The workaday turned stylish. Blenders, for example, offered the meaningless choice between ''puree'' and ''liquefy.''
This process has continued, and the more ideals we embrace, the more trash we produce. Like dustballs under the bed, objects proliferate beneath such abstractions as comfort, convenience, progress, prestige. Even our weapons were said to advance some abstraction, like credibility, say, rather than accomplish any concrete goal. (The most powerful weapon was, of course, something that could not be used in any rational way, which pushed the cold war toward the conceptual.) Our lives fill up with products that few of us can understand, let alone repair. We tend to view technology as a mysterious alien force, rather than as the sum of our improvisations, the activity that makes us human.
The easy confidence of the immediate postwar world will never be recovered, and the popular modernism it was expected to produce was probably little more than wishful thinking in the first place. Still, it might be possible - even necessary - to be at ease once again with our artifacts. Issues that seem remote from design, including the proliferation of garbage and the difficulty of sustaining an economy that consumes more than it produces, may force Americans to take their materialism seriously again.

PERSON: ALEXANDER CALDER (72%); RAYMOND FERNAND LOEWY (57%); MARY MARTIN (57%);

PUB-DATE: December 31, 1989

SECTION: Section 4; Page 5, Column 1; Week in Review Desk

LENGTH: 808 words

HEADLINE: The Region;
Floria Starts With Support, Confidence and Big Problems

BYLINE: By JOSEPH F. SULLIVAN

DATELINE: TRENTON

 BODY:
James J. Florio has vowed to be a much different Governor of New Jersey than Thomas H. Kean, in management style if not in his policies. But the discussions of changes he hopes to make in the structure and substance of government are likely to be overshadowed by the slowing economy and a looming fiscal crisis.
The 52-year-old Democratic Representative, who will be sworn in as New Jersey's 49th Governor on Jan. 16, has indicated that he will be a hands-on manager. It would be a marked departure from the style of Governor Kean, who has preferred to delegate authority and lead by persuasion in his eight years in office. In addition, Mr. Florio says he will centralize decision-making, seeking more coordination among cabinet-level officials. 
But while Mr. Florio has discussed his philosophy of management in naming his first six cabinet appointees, he is likely to come into office not as a managerial innovator but in the unpopular role of a budget cutter. For example, recommended pay raises for top state officials will be delayed until 1991 at Mr. Florio's request. After seven years of economic growth, Mr. Kean predicts that his successor will have to raise taxes or cut services in his first year. Mr. Kean faced a similar problem in 1982, his first year in office, and helped enact increases in both the sales and income taxes to close a budget gap.
Mr. Florio's transition team is made up largely of the people who ran his campaign. While there have been few surprises in his appointments thus far, the search is expanding beyond New Jersey. With his landslide victory in November over his Republican opponent, Representative Jim Courter, politicians say that Mr. Florio has few political debts to repay in picking his administration, and Mr. Kean also recruited out of state.
Executive recruiters have been consulted, and a week after the election, Steven P. Perskie, the director of Mr. Florio's transition committee, met with Mayor Edward I. Koch of New York City and Stanley Brezenoff, the First Deputy Mayor, to see if any departing members of the Koch administration might consider moving to New Jersey. ''They were very cooperative, and so far about 40 resumes of some very talented people have been forwarded to us for screening,''
Mr. Perskie said. The candidates could possibly fill jobs from middle management up to cabinet level, he said.
After the initial appointments, the pace of filling the more than 20 cabinet seats and other administration posts has slowed. One reason is Mr. Florio's stipulation that members of his administration be prevented from doing business with the state government for a time after they leave office. The length of this ban and its terms have not been set.
Those who have agreed to serve are regarded by politicians and political scientists as moderate and pragmatic choices. They are Robert J. Del Tufo, a former United States Attorney for New Jersey, who will be Attorney General; Superior Court Judge Judith A. Yaskin, who will become Environmental Commissioner; Scott Weiner, Mr. Florio's campaign treasurer, who will head the Public Utilities Board; Mayor Melvin R. Primus of Camden, who will be Community Services Commissioner; Raymond L. Bramucci, the director of Senator Bill Bradley's New Jersey office, who will be Labor Commissioner, and George R. Zoffinger, executive vice president of the First Fidelity Bank, who will be Commerce Commissioner. In making the appointments, Mr. Florio has emphasized what his staff says is a horizontal rather than vertical view of state government. Instead of a collection of departments operating independently, as many agencies in New Jersey and other state governments do now, Mr. Florio stresses solving problems that cross departmental lines by teams of cabinet-level officials. As an example, Mr. Florio said the first assignment of the new Labor and Commerce Commissioners will be to compress and coordinate some 63 job training programs that have sprung up around the state under various state and Federal programs.
Prof. Stephen A. Salmore of the Eagleton Institute of Politics at Rutgers University said that Mr. Florio's intial appointees are ''a good blend of politics and competence,'' but he said the Attorney General's appointment was a bit of a surprise. ''Usually a governor appoints a political ally as attorney general because of the sensitivity of the position,'' he said. ''Del Tufo is certainly not an enemy, but neither is he politically identified with Florio.''
Professor Salmore said it is clear that Mr. Florio is ''carefully constructing a team that he is comfortable with.'' But he said the idea of cabinet members working as a team is novel. ''Traditionally, cabinet members end up being turf-conscious,'' he said. ''It's almost inevitable. It will be interesting to see if Florio's idea works.''

GRAPHIC: Governor-elect Jmaes J. Florio and his wife, Lucinda, outside Drumthwacket, the governor's official residence, in Princeton Township. (NYT/Eddie Hausner)

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

COUNTRY: UNITED STATES (96%); 

STATE: NEW JERSEY, USA (96%); NEW YORK, USA (79%);
