HEADLINE: The Nation;
For Some, There's No Aid When the Crops Freeze

BYLINE: By JEFFREY SCHMALZ

DATELINE: IMMOKALEE, Fla.

 BODY:
When everything comes together right, when the Florida sun stays warm, Antonio Francisco can pick 90 buckets of tomatoes a day.
At 40 cents a bucket, that means $36. ''It doesn't make me a rich man,'' the 28-year-old Guatemalan immigrant said. ''But I can get along. It's O.K.'' 
But everything has not come together right this year in the agriculture belts of Florida and Texas. Last weekend, for the third time in the 1980's, Florida's vegetable fields and citrus groves were hit by freezing temperatures. The fields around Immokalee and elsewhere in southern Florida that should be ripe with tomatoes and beans and cucumbers and squash are instead a blackened brown.
Mr. Francisco, like thousands of other pickers, has no work. Florida had crop-killing freezes in 1983 and 1985, but has no procedures in place to aid the people who are frozen out of their livelihoods.
In Texas, where officials estimated last week that 60 percent of the Rio Grande Valley citrus crop and 80 percent of the vegetable crop were lost, state agencies and the American Red Cross announced plans to open four relief centers for farm worker families. But like thousands of others in Florida, where private relief efforts were still in the process of being organized, Mr. Francisco has nowhere to turn.
Gov. Bob Martinez declared a disaster in all 67 Florida counties, setting in motion the process that could bring Federal aid. But officials say it will be weeks before they can complete the loss estimates that are a prerequisite for Federal relief. And even then, access to Washington's thinly stretched resources is by no means guaranteed.
Many pickers, in the meantime, are ineligible for unemployment benefits because their employers, in violation of the law, never paid into the unemployment insurance fund on their behalf. Others are illegal immigrants who are leery of approaching officialdom for help and would be ineligible anyway.
Florida, which is usually ranked at or near the bottom of states in terms of social-services spending, offers welfare benefits only for families with children, not for single people like Mr. Francisco. So what will he do?
Like many other pickers, Mr. Francisco will probably go a bit north, to Florida's citrus belt, where growers are frantically hiring as they rush to get their cold-damaged oranges out of the fields and processed into juice before they rot. But the rush in the orange groves will last only four weeks or so, then there will be nothing for two months as everyone waits for the next crop of vegetables to ripen - assuming, that is, that the freezes are over for this season.
Until then, many pickers will simply live in tents or cars or whatever other makeshift shelter they can find. They will eat at soup kitchens, like the one run here by the Roman Catholic church.
''The growers want 5,000 to 10,000 people sitting around waiting for the crops to ripen,'' said Robert Williams, a lawyer for Florida Rural Legal Services, which provides legal aid to farm workers. ''But then when there's an emergency like this, they pretend the farm workers don't even exist.''
No one can say exactly how many of Florida's 200,000 to 250,000 farm workers are illegal immigrants. State officials and farm worker representatives say that roughly 20 percent of the workers are American blacks; 15 to 20 percent are Haitian immigrants, some here legally, some not; about 20 percent are Mexican-Americans, and another 20 percent are Mexicans who are illegal immigrants. The rest are Central Americans, primarily illegal immigrants from Guatemala. Farm worker representatives said the Guatemalans were often willing to work for less than the legal minimum of $3.35 an hour.
State officials and farm worker representatives said that despite tough new Federal laws against hiring illegal immigrants, they could not think of any case in Florida in which a farm owner had been fined for hiring them. Proof that the employer had reason to know that the worker was here illegally is difficult to establish.
''I know of eight Guatemalans in Dade County last month where the grower paid them for the first two weeks, then decided not to pay them for the third week,'' said Gregory Schell, a lawyer for Florida Rural Legal Services. ''He said, 'I know you're illegal.' I told the workers, 'I can get you the money.' They said: 'No. He'll call Immigration.' ''
Florida officials are pressing the Bush Administration to declare a Federal disaster, opening up loans to growers and waiving some conditions for receiving unemployment compensation and making the money available to some farm workers who cannot receive it now. But the Federal Government is reluctant.
Federal officials say that disaster funds are running low because of Hurricane Hugo and the San Francisco earthquake. And they point out that Florida has drawn on disaster aid twice before in this decade for crops lost to cold weather. More and more, Federal officials say, they are coming to believe that freezes in Florida are simply part of an agriculture cycle that growers and workers are going to have to come to grips with.
The extent of crop damage this time is still being assessed, but the human toll in the Tampa area and in Dade County adds up to perhaps 25,000 field hands thrown out of work.
''It's scary to see all these people just standing around this time of year.'' said Mr. Francisco, the tomato picker. ''They got nothing to do but get in trouble.''

LENGTH: 1185 words

HEADLINE: Ideas & Trends;
In College Sports, The Real Players Collect Millions From The Networks

BYLINE: By JOE LAPOINTE

 BODY:
Jim Brock is executive director of the Cotton Bowl football game, which will pay its competing teams about $3 million each to play in Dallas tomorrow afternoon. The five big bowl games - Cotton, Rose, Orange, Sugar and Fiesta -will pay their 10 teams a total of about $36 million, much of the money coming from television. In total, the 18 post-season bowl games will pay their 36 schools about $60 million this year, Mr. Brock said, up from $53 million a year ago.
Talking about money from bowl games and other big events of college sports, Mr. Brock described one school's athletic director as ''a sharp cookie,'' another as ''a good operator'' and praised several others in similar terms. It sounded as if he were describing wheelers and dealers of big business rather than leaders of amateur sport. 
''It is a big business, no question about it,'' Mr. Brock said of college sports. ''It's getting bigger and bigger and bigger.''
The recent seven-year contract between CBS and the National Collegiate Athletic Association for broadcasting the men's basketball tournament starting in 1991 is for $1 billion. It will increase the tournament's television money from $55 million in 1990 to an average of $143 million a year in the next seven years.
The College Football Association, which represents 66 football schools, is negotiating a new contract to replace one expiring with CBS that now pays the association $16 million a year. The new deal is likely to pay more. The 20 schools of the Big Ten and Pac 10 conferences have a contract with ABC that pays them an average of about $16 million a year for regular-season football games, not including the $12.2 million split between the two teams in the Rose Bowl.
How does this kind of cash change college sports, if at all? Are universities getting rich from the efforts of unsalaried performers? Does this encourage cheating to win? Or does the money support other sports and make intercollegiate athletics accessible for more students in more sports?
It takes money to make money and not everyone shows a profit. Robert Atwell, the president of the American Council on Education, which represents 1,400 college and university presidents, estimates that the nation's colleges spend about $1 billion a year on all sports and take in less than that in revenue from television, tickets and other sources.
But some schools make money. One is Notre Dame, which will earn $4.1 million by playing Colorado tomorrow in the Orange Bowl. The Rev. E. William Beauchamp, the executive vice president of the university, says Notre Dame budgets about $9 million a year to operate 20 intercollegiate sports. ''Football and basketball provide the revenue that supports the rest of your athletics,'' he said. ''Especially football.''
Richard Rosenthal, the Notre Dame athletic director, says the university takes in more from sports than it spends. ''We keep our head above water,'' Mr. Rosenthal said, adding that 80 percent of the school's sports income is generated by football, which spends about 35 percent of the budget. He said about 30 percent of his operating budget comes from television money.
''I don't think the so-called prize money is really the inducement for people to cheat,'' he said. ''The illusion and allegation of abuse coupled to money is a little misplaced. People who would take short cuts to win will do so anyway, with or without money.''
Richard D. Schultz, the executive director of the N.C.A.A., says opinion surveys tell him that the public perception of college athletics is a negative one. Changes are needed, he said, starting with a different way to distribute television money from the basketball tournament. Now, winners get the most.
A wider distribution of the money, or ending the system of putting it only into the winners' pool, would be a big change from the current formula under which a school can earn $274,000 for making the first round of the basketball tournament and $1.37 million for making the Final Four. Mr. Schultz says he will urge changes before the new television contract takes effect in 1991.
 
Needing Control
''Right now, colleges and universities are not perceived as controlling their athletic programs,'' Mr. Schultz said. ''You are what you are perceived to be. We need to re-style some things. Universities need to be in control of their athletic programs, and I'm not so sure they always are.''
Some outside critics tend to have a harsher view. They argue that the only way to reform college sports is to tear down the present structure, declare the games to be professional entertainment and pay the players. An advocate of this approach is Rick Telander, a former football player at Northwestern and a writer for Sports Illustrated magazine whose book, ''The Hundred Yard Lie,'' stirred debate and angry reaction in college football circles when it was published this year. ''An ethical housecleaning would turn the whole chummy system into chaos, even if it ultimately brought integrity to the game,'' he wrote. ''So let's forget about the N.C.A.A. as being anything other than an anchor against progress.''
In a recent interview, he said, ''I know I come off as an extremist. But I'm saying nothing that hasn't been said for 100 years. I don't blame TV. I don't blame the N.C.A.A. But at some point you can't keep exploiting free labor. It reminds me of the pre-union days in mining.''
Mr. Atwell of of the American Council on Education said Mr. Telander's book is ''right.'' But he opposes declaring big-time college sports to be professional. Like Mr. Schultz, he favors a redistribution of money, starting with the basketball tournament and the 290 Division 1 schools that field teams for the sport. ''Take the billion and divide it by 290,'' he said. ''That would send a powerful message. Cut the tie between money and winning. I always say money is the single most important factor in corruption of college athletics. You throw that much money on the table and all sorts of bad things can happen.''
 
Not All Are Rich
Mr. Atwell nevertheless argues that the perception of wealth is incorrect. ''One of the great myths is that colleges are getting rich from sports,'' he said. ''They are not.''
That argument is backed by Chuck Neinas, the executive director of the College Football Association, and Jim Delany, the new commissioner of the Big Ten.
Mr. Neinas noted that since Federal legislation of the 1970's forced colleges to expand women's sports, the athletic departments have had to absorb second athletic programs. These new programs, along with inflation, ''obviously strained the budget,'' he said. For most athletic departments, he continued, ''Gate receipts remain the most important financial element, combined with donations and gifts.''
Mr. Delany said that about 30 to 50 percent of the athletic budgets in his conference are financed by television money. At the same time, he noted, some athletic departments in his conference are in debt.
''They feel if you have a $10 million indoor football-practice facility, I have to have one, too,'' he said.

PUB-DATE: December 31, 1989

SECTION: Section 4; Page 2, Column 4; Week in Review Desk

LENGTH: 1060 words

HEADLINE: The World;
As Ideology Recedes, The U.S. Rearranges Its Global Struggles

BYLINE: By THOMAS L. FRIEDMAN

DATELINE: WASHINGTON

 BODY:
Viewing American foreign policy these days can seem a bit like watching a badly dubbed and poorly edited foreign movie. The actors often seem to be speaking the wrong lines and their actions often seem to be all out of order.
Consider the last two weeks. One day the United States intervenes in Panama and the next day it virtually invites the Soviet-led Warsaw Pact to invade Rumania to support the democracy movement there. One day the Administration sends two senior officials to Beijing to patch up ties with China, apparently out of concern that the Chinese leadership, if alienated, might rush into an embrace with Moscow, and the next day it invites the Soviet Foreign Minister to visit NATO headquarters. For years the United States railed against the Marxist Sandinista Government in Managua, but it turned out that the threat deemed worthy of an invasion was from a 19th-century-style tinpot dictator in Panama. 
Is there a method to this melange? Actually, yes. The ideological competition between East and West, so prominent in global politics in the last 40 years, is giving way, making what was unimaginable a year ago, such as a visit by Foreign Minister Eduard A. Shevardnadze to NATO headquarters, almost routine. At the same time, more traditional power politics is becoming more apparent.
In the classic form of power politics, ideologically inspired actions take a back seat to basic territorial and economic imperatives. Dominant powers assert themselves in their own regions or spheres of the world while competing for mastery in areas where there is an opportunity for a contest. This is the real meaning of the Panama invasion, and of Moscow's insistence on keeping Eastern Europe in the Warsaw Pact, even while allowing it to retreat from Communism.
The object of this game of nations is not necessarily a freer world or a workers' paradise, but survival of the fittest and everything this requires: influence, resources and allies.
When the glow over the end of the cold war fades, watch for Washington and Moscow to go on competing for advantage on the Eurasian land mass, just as they have for nearly a half-century. ''The end of the cold war does not mean an end of a global competiton between the superpowers,'' said Michael J. Sandel, a political theorist at Harvard. ''Once the ideological dimension fades, what you are left with is not peace, harmony and sweetness, but old-fashioned global politics based on dominant powers competing for influence and pursuing their national interests.''
But, at least in the view of some critics, it seems that not everyone in the Bush Administration - particularly the President - is alive to the subtleties of this transition and the new opportunities it may be opening. President Bush has never fully explained his decision to send his national security adviser, Brent Scowcroft, on two secret missions to China, except to say that for geopolitical reasons he did not want to isolate Beijing by punishing its leadership too harshly for the murders in Tiananmen Square. Some in the Administration argue that such a policy is the essence of ''realist'' power politics.
To the critics, though, it seems a bad imitation. To be sure, it might not be in America's interest to be isolated from China, both because China is the biggest power in Asia and because of the potential for a Moscow-Beijing alliance against Washington. But the question is not whether links between the United States and China should be maintained but on whose terms and, in the wake of Tiananmen Square, with what timing. And with whom should these ties be maintained - with the current aging Chinese leadership or with the next generation of the Chinese people?
Given the changes in Moscow, Beijing's leaders are not in the same pivotal position in the superpower contest that their predecessors enjoyed two decades ago. And given the alienation of today's leaders from their people, their future tenure is questionable. Therefore, the critics argue, catering to the sensibilities of Deng Xiaoping and his colleagues isn't realism, but an anachronism.
''The Scowcroft China mission is a classic case of cultural lag: a President applying 1970's thinking to a 1990 situation,'' said Edward N. Luttwak of the Center for Strategic and International Studies in Washington. ''The United States-China relationship in the 1970's was a natural coalescence against a dynamically expansive Soviet Union. With Soviet activism in decline, the importance of the Beijing-Washington strategic relationship declines as well. Certainly Washington need not worry that Beijing will be driven into the arms of Moscow. Today it is the economic relationship that is increasingly important, and in that relationship the United States is the giver and China the taker.''
In addition to traditional power politics, something more is emerging as the ideologically driven East-West competition wanes. Moral concerns like human rights could take on new force, while the environment, terrorism, drugs and above all economics rise as factors in international relations. In the days when power depended on who had the biggest army and navy, it was easy to identify which country was predominant. Today, a country's balance of trade is becoming as important an indicator of its status as its place in the balance of power. In this economically interdependent world, America's place will increasingly depend as much on how it deals with its trade deficit with Japan as on how it coexists with the Soviet Union in Europe.
''In many third world areas, we will find ourselves both competing with and cooperating with the Japanese and not the Soviets,'' Geoffrey Kemp, a senior associate at the Carnegie Endowment, argued. ''The Russians just are not going to be players. Aside from military equipment, the Soviets have nothing to sell. Not only are they unable to compete with Europe, Japan and the United States, but also with their own former satellites in Eastern Europe - which is naturally going to draw Eastern Europe westward and leave the Soviets with a shrinking pie.''
As long as the world economy continues to expand, there will be room for the United States, Europe and Japan to act in cooperation, Mr. Kemp noted. But, he added, if there is a global recession ''one would be foolish to assume that this will remain the case.''

SECTION: Section 4; Page 6, Column 1; Week in Review Desk

LENGTH: 977 words

HEADLINE: Ideas & Trends;
A Decade Ends, And the Nouvelles Of New York Are Not Invited

BYLINE: By GEORGIA DULLEA

 BODY:
There was a moment in December 1980, when then President-elect Ronald Reagan was kneeling on the floor of Brooke Astor's Park Avenue apartment after one of her important black-tie dinners. He was looking for a diamond earring she had dropped and together they were laughing. It was an oddly glamorous moment, the philanthropist, the President and the lost diamond.
Soon after that there appeared on the New York social scene the first glints of the gilded era of the 80's. This was a lavish spectacle of wealth and the props of wealth fueled by the sort of fast money from Wall Street that made the word millionaire obsolete. Parties were the thing in this era, million-dollar birthday parties for the middle-aged. 
''In my day, a million was a lot,'' said Mrs. Astor, who put the rich-rich on the charity circuit. ''Today, a billion is more like it.''
The pace setters of the decade were a handful of financial wizards and their younger second or third wives. Suddenly they were everywhere - in the flesh and in print. One could turn to the business section and read about the deals they did and the money they made and then, flipping to the gossip columns, read about the showy ways in which they spent the money.
The ubiquitous billionaires and their followers had no official name until the second half of the 80's when John Fairchild, looking up from a table at Le Cirque, christened them Nouvelle Society. He launched the name in his publications, Women's Wear Daily and W. Nouvelle couples became cultural icons and, in time, objects of criticism.
Glossy magazines devoted articles and even cover stories to their enchanted life styles. One could be at home - a Rubens in the drawing room, a Renoir in the bath - with Gayfryd and Saul Steinberg. Or John and Susan Gutfreund, who entertain with four kinds of caviar. Or Henry Kravis and Carolyne Roehm, who eats Oreos for breakfast.
One could travel via magazine for weekends at their country places, smell their flowers and pet their dogs. One could be there for family birthdays and wedding parties at places like the Metropolitan Museum of Art.
 
A $17,000 Cake
In their conspicuous consumption, the Nouvelles were consumed by the public and served up by a press for whom the point of the story increasingly became not how lovely, but how much. The cake for the wedding of Laura Steinberg and Jonathan Tisch reportedly cost $17,000. Ummm, delicious. Taste that money.
Signs that the social spectacle might be souring came in 1986, when Felix and Elizabeth Rohatyn, a couple with social clout, questioned the opulence of charity balls. The biggest balls were run not by the Nouvelles, but by Old Guard figures like Mrs. Astor, Pat Buckley and Annette Reed.
Yet the Nouvelles, with their big-money connections, were selling $100,000 worth of tables and their friends wouldn't come to dowdy parties. The Rohatyns were squelched.
Then came Oct. 13, 1987, the stock market plunge and Wall Street jitters. Never mind. A week later Nouvelle socialites stepped out in $25,000 poufs to welcome Christian Lacroix, with his couture collection, Luxe, to New York. Then Tom Wolfe's social satire in ''The Bonfire of the Vanities'' - ''Hemorrhaging money!
In some ways, the style of this new society seemed of another century. The period of Louis XIV was mentioned more than once. Donald Trump compared the workmanship on his Trump Towers apartment to Versailles. Court caterers, florists, party planners, decorators and even a troubadour arose to satisfy new and expensive tastes. Auction houses and antiques dealers threw open their doors. Fashion designers stretched out their arms.
In other ways, the Nouvelles seemed the purest expression of the Reagan economic philosophy, which celebrated personal wealth. If this philosophy blurred class distinctions, press agentry buried them.
After all those stories about all those parties, the public could hardly be expected to discern any difference between Pat Buckley of the Old Guard and Ivana Trump of the Nouvelles - not with Mrs. Buckley and friends posing for the paparazzi on the Trump yacht.
 
Stung by Excesses
Nor did the public really care. But the Old Guard did, and by the summer of 1988 its members were being stung by the Nouvelle excesses.
''It's Marie Antoinette time,'' Mrs. Buckley remarked that fall. ''It's the new people. They're getting us mixed up with them.''
Everybody agreed it was time to tone down, at least in public. Liz Smith declared the Nouvelle Austerity on the charity circuit. No more fancy foods and flowers. Shades of the Rohatyns. Some couples said they would cut down on parties, stay home and boil an egg. Maybe some did. Others put on evening clothes and went out again.
The Reagans left the White House. Jerry Zipkin, Nancy Reagan's confidant and permanent representative to New York, though, was still squiring women whose husbands were too busy or too bored to take them to parties. The spring social season was somewhat muted. The Nouvelles had gone underground.
Suddenly last summer, back-to-back fantasy parties broke out. The revels were miles from New York, but news of Nouvelles travels. First was the $1 million party Gayfryd Steinberg gave for her husband in Quogue, N.Y. The next week brought reports of the $2 million-plus party Malcolm Forbes gave for himself in Tangier, Morocco.
That did it. More criticism. More satire. In November 1989, Mrs. Astor, again in diamonds, presided at another important black-tie dinner. As the cameras clicked, she covered her necklace with a chiffon scarf. Her photo appeared in Women's Wear Daily, with those of other women wearing the discreet jewelry of the new Soft Society.
''Forget the hard flash of the Nouvelle Society Eighties,'' said an article accompanying the photographs. ''People are fed up with opulent excess and social showoffs.''

HEADLINE: The World;
It May Prove Difficult to Let Panama Get On With Its Life

BYLINE: By LARRY ROHTER

DATELINE: PANAMA

 BODY:
As American troops sought to secure order here last week after having ousted Gen. Manuel Antonio Noriega from power, the American invasion of Panama turned into an occupation.
No sooner had resistance from the last remnants of General Noriega's forces ended than United States troops and diplomats assumed police duties and supervised the organization of a civilian government -functions reminiscent of the ''elder brother'' role Americans have played here since Theodore Roosevelt created the country to be able to build the Panama Canal.
The critical question is how long the Americans intend to fill the vacuum left by the ouster on Dec. 20 of General Noriega and his Panama Defense Forces, which dominated every government here for 21 years.
''It is too soon to start putting a date and a number together,'' said a Pentagon spokesman, Pete Williams. But civilian officials, both American and Panamanian, were thinking of the matter constantly. They appeared to agree that the sooner the withdrawal takes place, the better. 
''The longer the troops are here, the greater will be the temptation for both sides to fall back into all the bad habits of the colonial relationship that the Panama Canal treaties were intended to end,'' a European diplomat here said. ''This Government needs to establish itself as an independent entity, and it cannot do that so long as the 82d Airborne Division is on every street corner.''
For the moment, the American presence is overwhelming.
The President installed by the Americans, Guillermo Endara, and his Cabinet spent their first days operating out of cramped quarters in the Foreign Ministry building because the presidential palace was in the hands of American authorities.
When Foreign Minister Julio Linares went to meet the diplomatic corps for the first time, he did so in an American Embassy vehicle. At least initially, security for top Panamanian officials was being provided by Americans because the loyalty of what remains of the Panama Defense Forces was still in question.
 
A Question of Legality
In addition, American and Panamanian officials were reluctant to address the legal justification for spiriting Col. Luis del Cid, accused of being one of General Noriega's accomplices in crime, off to Miami last week to face charges of drug trafficking and racketeering. American officials said the action was necessary because the Panamanian Constitution does not permit the extradition of Panamanian citizens to the United States.
Mr. Endara disagreed with suggestions that the country had surrendered some of its sovereignty in exchange for ridding itself of General Noriega and his mafia. ''We will maintain our independence,'' he said. ''The gringos don't plan to affect our independence.''
But that argument has not convinced most Latin American countries. They continued to hold back on diplomatic relations with the new Government, which had informed the world of its assumption of power on a United States Government fax machine.
Latin American diplomats said that some members of the Organization of American States favored linking such recognition, as well as Panama's readmission to the Group of Eight, the regional club of democracies, to the withdrawal of American troops.
The Bush Administration's ouster of General Noriega was of concern to Cuba, whose ambassador here was detained briefly by American troops, and to Nicaragua, which has been able to circumvent an American economic embargo only by using Panama as a resupply center for needed goods and equipment.
Both countries have lost a valuable ally and, acting together, they began efforts last week to have the United Nations condemn the American invasion.
Both Cuba and Nicaragua have also said, at least for domestic consumption, that they feared that the invasion of Panama might presage similar moves against them.
A few Panamanians and some officials of other Latin American countries have suggested that one way for the Endara Government to put some distance between itself and its American patrons would be to call new elections to ratify the results of the vote last May, in which Mr. Endara achieved a majority only to see it nullified by General Noriega.
But in his first news conference, Mr. Endara quickly quashed the notion of a new ballot. ''We were elected for five years,'' he said, ''and it is our obligation to serve that term.''
Later, the same electoral tribunal that had deprived him of victory in May declared him the winner and allowed him to drop his ''provisional'' title and become full ''constitutional President.''
The United States' desire to get out of Panama quickly could well be blocked by the need to clean out the Panama Defense Forces so that another Noriega can never take power.
A senior American Embassy official here said that the replacement for the Panama Defense Forces, the new Public Force, ''is basically the same officers, the same men, the same structure'' as General Noriega's corrupt and brutal military, ''except that they say they support democracy where before they said they supported Noriega.''
 
A Problem to Confront
''There is a problem to be worked on, no question about it,'' the American official added.
The difficulties range from possible criminal charges against senior officers to assuring that the new forces accept the principle of civilian supremacy.
Panamanians of all classes seem for the moment not to be disturbed by the prospect of a long-term American presence, and are counting instead on an American bonanza. But such a bonanza is unlikely to materialize, and this raises the possibility that expectations will give way to resentments when they are not fulfilled.
The rich, for example, anticipate a huge flow of investment back into the country's offshore banking industry. The middle class expects Washington to pick up the tab for stores and residences destroyed in the fighting and subsequent looting. And the poor assume that the American authorities will provide them with food and shelter.
''We belong to you, and we need you to take care of us,'' Waldina Samaniego, a 33-year-old Panamanian woman, said to a Spanish-speaking American soldier guarding a military installation in the working-class neighborhood of San Miguelito one morning last week.
''Everything is being taken care of,'' the soldier reassured her.
Whether both sides will still be saying the same things three months from now will say much about the shape and the character of the new Panama.

HEADLINE: WEEK IN BUSINESS;
Commodity Prices Spurred by Cold

BYLINE: By Steve Dodson

 BODY:

Cold weather drove prices up sharply for several commodities last week. Futures contracts for heating oil reached six-year highs, peaking at $1.02 a gallon before profit taking caused declines at week's end. In November, heating oil futures sold for slightly less than 60 cents a gallon. An explosion that shut down the nation's second-largest refinery, an Exxon complex in Louisiana, added to the upward pressure. The record-breaking cold extended into Florida and south Texas, damaging winter crops of fruit and vegetables. Orange juice futures rose to $1.65 a pound; the previous week they had traded around $1.25. The Brazilian authorities pushed prices up further when they said they were suspending orange juice exports while they assessed the price situation.
Control of Campbell Soup could be unraveling because of a split in the Dorrance family, which owns almost 59 percent of the shares. Since the death of Campbell's chairman, John T. Dorrance Jr., in April, the family had been saying that it wanted to keep the company. But last week three of his nieces and their husbands, who collectively control 17.4 percent of the company, told the S.E.C. they wanted to sell their interests. Mr. Dorrance's two sons and one daughter control 31 percent of the company and are still saying they oppose a sale. The day of the nieces' announcment Campbell's stock rose $4.375 a share, to $57.375. 
A new enforcement chief was named at the Securities and Exchange Commission. The choice was William R. McLucas, 39 years old, who has been with the commission for 12 years and has worked on many of the big insider-trading cases. He will succeed Gary G. Lynch. The head of the S.E.C., Richard C. Breeden, also announced the formation of a new enforcement unit to deal with fraud against individual investors by banks and savings institutions.
The Bank of New England is shopping for a new chief executive as it struggles to deal with mounting losses on real estate loans in the troubled New England property market. The board of the nation's 18th largest bank said Walter J. Connolly would leave the post as soon as a replacement was found. There was no mention of whether he would remain as chairman. The Boston-based bank earned about $122 million in the first nine months of this year, but it expects a fourth-quarter loss that analysts say may exceed $500 million.
A stake in Bank of Boston was bought by Laurence A. Tisch, the president of CBS. Bank of Boston is also suffering from poor real estate loans. The Tisch group paid $94.5 million for a 6.6 percent stake.
The leading indicators were up a scant one-tenth of a percent in November, suggesting that growth in 1990 will be weak at best. The decline in the October index was revised to three-tenths of a percent instead of four-tenths . . . Sales of existing homes rose 3.2 percent in November, the biggest gain in 11 months.
The financial markets were quiet in a holiday week. In Tokyo, Japanese officials raised the discount rate to 4.25 percent, from 3.75 percent, but that did not keep the Tokyo stock market from ending the year with a record high close of 38,915.87 on the Nikkei average, up 20 percent in 1989. The Japanese rate increase was partially intended to help the dollar, and the dollar did show some modest gains on the yen. The bond market in the United States showed a little uneasiness about inflation because of the jump in some commodity prices, but volume was thin and the action was not considered significant. In stocks, the Dow Jones industrial average rose 41.81 points during the week and closed at 2,753.20. That is 584.63 points, or 26.96 percent, higher than where it began 1989 at 2,168.57.
Receivers were appointed in Australia to oversee the brewing interests that are the main business of the Bond Corporation. The court action, taken on a request by Bond's bank lenders, was seen as a grave threat to the diversified empire that Alan Bond built. The holdings include G. Heileman Brewing of La Crosse, Wis.
Eastern Airlines is cutting 600 jobs and reducing the salaries of half its work force by 10 to 20 percent. The changes will affect mostly managerial employees. Eastern said it would need fewer workers as it scales back operations as part of its plan to emerge from bankruptcy.
Miscellanea. American Express will sell its Geneva-based private banking unit to CBI, a Swiss financial institution, for $1 billion. The unit, with assets of about $12 billion, serves wealthy clients . . . The consensus on the Christmas shopping season seemed to be sales gains of about 4 to 6 percent over the previous year, with heavy discounting holding down profits . . . Fares on the Trump and Pan Am Shuttles are going up to $119, from $99, one-way on flights between New York and Boston or Washington.

HEADLINE: Prospects;
How High for Oil?

BYLINE: By Barnaby J. Feder

 BODY:
Frigid temperatures across much of the United States this month sent demand for heating oil soaring, providing a final upward jolt to crude oil prices. Some spot crude traded at prices up 40 percent or more from a year ago. Will these prices hold? Five experts on oil offer their views. 
 
Phillip Chisholm
 
Executive director, Petroleum Marketers Association of America, Washington.
The big price hikes in products like home heating oil over the past two weeks don't represent a long-term trend. When the weather breaks, we will return to price stability, at least for the duration of 1990. A lot of things could upset that, such as a tax on imported oil. A year ago at this time, no one would have predicted the Exxon Valdez accident and the short-term run-up in prices that caused. But absent such blips, you'll see stability. You won't see gasoline prices go above last year's peaks next year, for example.
 
Morris Greenberg
 
Director of energy services, the WEFA Group, Bala Cynwyd, Pa.
There's a lot of uncertainty about the balance in the first half of next year. It looks like there're ample supplies and prices should come down. I wouldn't expect OPEC to be able to cut output so the oversupply could be particularly significant if the economy weakens. But there could be significant volatility. There's far more reliance on Middle East supplies than we got used to in the middle 1980's. That makes it more difficult to react to short-term shocks, such as the recent cold weather. And refiners and consumers have gotten into the habit of living with smaller inventories, which contributes to volatility.
 
Michael Canes
 
Chief economist, American Petroleum Institute, Washington.
Production has been declining in the U.S. at a pretty rapid rate. It should help production that prices are up from a year ago but the drilling rate is still low. Overseas, there are some places coming on - especially North Yemen and India, where it replaces imports - but others are past their peak. Right now, the trends are toward increased OPEC export capacity. But how much of that comes on in 1990 is unclear. Non-OPEC supply should diminish. On balance, OPEC's hand will be strengthened, which could mean upward pressure in the crude markets.
 
Daniel Yergin
 
Cambridge Energy Research Associates, Cambridge, Mass.
Demand is growing. It's strongest in the Far East, but there are signs of it elsewhere including in some developing countries. There will be a lot of discussion in 1990 about the rate at which surplus capacity is disappearing. It's been eaten up a lot more rapidly than people expected a couple of years ago. And the environmental agenda will begin shaping the energy outlook for the whole decade. Natural gas looks like it will be the big beneficiary. I would expect to see stepped up domestic exploration for both oil and gas.
 
Phillip K. Verleger Jr.
 
Visiting Fellow, Institute for International Economics, Washington.
I think prices are going to weaken toward the end of the first quarter, probably substantially. We have classic unexpected seasonal demand now because of the cold weather, but as that wears off you will see the effects of OPEC setting its production levels too high. West Texas Intermediate, for example, will decline to between $18 and $19 a barrel, then climb back to about $20 by the end of year. That's assuming the economy performs as expected - about 1 percent growth in G.N.P. The other big uncertainty is the U.S.S.R. If their production drops more than 4 percent, prices could stengthen.

HEADLINE: Banking's High-Tech Retail Chase

BYLINE: By MICHAEL QUINT

 BODY:
IN the battle among banks for retail customers, the victors are likely to be those that use high technology best. So banks are now spending more than $10 billion a year on electronic technology to attract more customers, serve them more efficiently and keep staffs free to sell more profitable products.
The contest is evident everywhere. Customers of the People's Bank of Bridgeport, Conn., can call from auto showrooms to arrange a loan in as little as 15 minutes. Chase Manhattan promotes its credit cards by listing 34 features, including a free worldwide message network and a legal services program. Teller machines of the National Bank of Commerce in Memphis dispense coupons redeemable for Campbell soups. When the Dollar Dry Dock Savings Bank of New York was raiding customers from a nearby Chemical Bank branch, Dollar Dry Dock teller machines were programmed to flash a reminder about free gifts every time a Chemical customer slipped in a card.
These skirmishes reflect the struggle to wring profits from retail banking and the extent to which innovative marketing will depend on technology. Automated teller machines, telephones and plastic cards are the weapons. Long gone are the days when banks could be content to pump out generic Visas and Mastercards. Now they are trying to become brand names in their own right. 
The cashless society is still a long way off, but banks are hastening the day when going cash-less might be easier than going card-less. Twenty years ago, when Chemical Bank installed the nation's first automated teller machine, it was a primitive contraption that did nothing but dispense cash in $15 and $30 lots. Back then, BankAmericard, the forerunner of Visa, was a local program of the California-based Bank of America. And when a customer called a bank, another live person came on the line.
 
Following Customers Everywhere
Now, a web of computers, telephones and plastic cards lets banks serve their customers wherever they travel and work. ''The credit cards allowed banks to follow their customers across state lines and provide banking services nationally, despite the antiquated branching laws,'' said D. Dale Browning, the president of Colorado National Bank. By giving customers instant loans at any store that accepts credit cards, banks created an industry that is now one of the most profitable parts of their business.
Teller machines now dispense cash down to the penny, accept deposits, transfer money and, in the newest models, help customers apply for mortgages and loans. Banking by phone handles everything from auto loan applications to bill-paying, all with beeps, tones and recordings.
Teller machines and telephone banking services have not generated the same profits as credit cards. But they are crucial for consumer banking, especially in large cities where competition is most intense. Both let banks cut costs and extend their reach far beyond their home states.
Automation and electronics can help limit the growth of costly bank branches, 40 percent of them money-losers. Branches will not disappear. But bankers want teller machines and telephone banking to free the branch staff for selling more profitable products like mutual funds.
Gradually, bank customers are learning to love teller machines, if not as much as bankers would like. Banks have fueled the romance by linking teller machines nationally. ''Customers for some time have come to assume that merchants - with some exceptions like grocery stores - will accept credit cards,'' said J. Paul Bouchelle, executive vice president at the First National Bank of Albuquerque, N.M. ''Now we are reaching a point with automated teller machines that when they see one, they are inclined to expect that they have a card that will let them get cash.''
The nation's 70,000 automated teller machines still belong to individual banks, but almost all also belong to at least one of more than 600 sharing systems. Machines in these systems can serve customers of other banks. Chemical Bank has more than 300 automated tellers, but its customers have access to 28,000 terminals around the country - more, it contends, than any other bank.
The two largest networks of automated tellers - Plus System Inc., an affiliate of Visa, and Cirrus System Inc., a subsidiary of MasterCard - have agreed to grant access to each others' members. When the competing systems link up in June, customers will find that their cash cards work in 44,000 terminals.
Bankers say their surveys show that machines please. ''The automated teller machines answer real consumer dissatisfactions - the inability to get cash after banking hours and long teller lines,'' said Douglas D. Anderson, an executive vice president at the Corestates Financial Corporation in Philadelphia.
But the machines often do not eliminate enough flesh-and-blood tellers for banks to realize any savings. Studies show that a heavily used automated teller can handle transactions for a third to half the cost of a human teller. But if volume is lacking, the machine can cost more than twice as much as the employee.
Bankers have developed a score of strategies for the machines to grind out profits. The North Fork Bank and Trust Company of Long Island installed teller machines near the beaches but far from most of its own customers. The 39-cent fee collected for each use by another bank's customer more than cover the machines' $10,000 to $12,000 annual cost.
In New York, the Dollar Dry Dock Savings Bank flashes ads for its other products during pauses between transactions. Citibank executives say their New York network of 1,100 machines has been a key to expanding its share of the New York consumer market to more than 13 percent from less than 5 percent in 1977.
 
Banking by Phone
Telephone banking also reaches far beyond the traditional, local branch. Customers can send instructions to a bank computer using the tones on push-button phones. According to a survey last year by Banking and Computer magazine, 23 percent of financial institutions were offering telephone banking compared with 13 percent in 1987.
Executives of the People's Bank of Bridgeport, Conn. say that their early introduction of banking by phone has been vindicated. ''When we began the bank by phone service in 1974 it was a very unusual feature,'' said Pat Matteson, a senior vice president. People's finds it has toinnovate to stay ahead ofother banks with telephone service. The Connecticut bank has added loans by phone, handling as many loans as several branches combined. Customers waiting in automobile showrooms can get approval in as little as 15 minutes. Last year, about 30 percent of the bank's individual retirement account rollovers were handled by phone.
Bankers hope more customers let their fingers do the banking. George W. Cole, director of marketing at Periphonics, a vendor of bank-by-phone equipment, noted that for the cost of one telephone operator, a bank can buy the computers and software to handle four phone lines simultaneously, 24 hours a day. ''As much as 25 percent of the calls come on weekends, when most people do their shopping, but the banks are closed,'' Mr. Cole said. Although three-fourths of the calls are for account balances, Mr. Cole said that telephone banking was expanding to include bill-paying. Customers can push buttons on their phones to give the bank instructions for writing checks.
 
Credit Card Boom
To steer more account-holders toward the telephones, some banks offer incentives. At the National Westminster Bank of New Jersey, the 40 percent of its customers who bank by phone earn a half-point more interest on their money market accounts. Thomas J. Dzurkoc, a bank vice president, said that because these customers are not allowed to write their own checks on such accounts, costs are reduced. ''An even greater benefit to us is that bank-by-phone customers are more loyal, have more account relationships and keep higher balances,'' he said.
The credit card business was a money-loser as recently as 10 years ago, but banks have turned it into one of their most profitable lines. There are 190 million cards, with unpaid balances of more than $113 billion. In the wallet wars, it counts to be the first one a consumer reaches for.
The business is profitable enough to attract new competitors like Sears, Roebuck & Company, whose 29.6 million Discover cards are accepted by a million merchants. And A.T.&T. - whose telephone cards are the most widely used credit cards of all - is expected to introduce a more broadly accepted credit card soon.
The 5,000 banks that issue credit cards are spending millions on advertising to convince consumers that their cards are somehow unique. Bankers are no longer content to remain anonymous behind the Visa and Mastercard logos - they're putting their own up front.
As more cards are concentrated among a few dozen large banks, they are less willing to have their products regarded as generic commodities. Like food companies competing for supermarket display space, bankers plot to put their plastic in the most accessible slot in consumers' billfolds. And they want distinctive brand names. Citibank, easily the largest bank card issuer in the country, with more than 25 million cards, addresses the issue directly in its television commercials: ''Not just Visa. Citibank Visa.''
Les Dinkin, a management consultant at KPMG Peat Marwick, said that a brand image can be as valuable for a bank as for a food product. ''It allows a company to charge a premium price for their product, and creates a better platform for expansion.'' After 20 years of promotions, Visa and Mastercard have won wide acceptance. ''But the banks were left without a proprietary product, and now have to overcome the perception that one card is pretty much as good as another,'' he said.
While only Citibank advertises on television nationally, thousands of other banks are filling mailboxes and crowding hotel check-out counters with their card offerings. But large banks are expanding their market share, using many of the same advantages that caused small banks to fight nationwide branching. ''The smaller and medium-sized issuers don't enjoy the economies of scale and the economies of sophistication that the major issuers have,'' said Scott P. Marks, chairman of FCC National Bank, the Delaware bank that issues cards for the First Chicago Corporation.
Economies of scale begin with a credit card loan portfolio of $1 billion to $2 billion, allowing the purchase of computers to reduce paperwork, Mr. Marks said. The economies of sophistication come with a portfolio of at least $3 billion, enough to hire marketing specialists. As one of the banking industry's five largest card issuers, Mr. Marks said, ''I can acquire new accounts more cost efficiently . . . and I can stimulate usage of the cards more effectively.''
As banks quest for brand identity, they have introduced all sorts of special features, which are inevitably matched by competitors. Chase Manhattan was among the many banks to match American Express's insurance for recent purchases.
Mr. Marks of First Chicago says that annual growth of more than 20 percent in credit card balances over the past five years means that the industry has yet to mature. ''Over the next five years, I expect the industry to continue growing comfortably in double digits, but not as fast as the past five years,'' he said. Next: Debit Cards? The next generation of cards is proving harder for banks to promote. Bankers want customers to regard their teller cards as debit cards and use them for much more than cash withdrawals. The cards would make it easy for merchants with the proper terminals to accept payment by automatically deducting funds from customers' bank accounts. Banks would gain tremendous savings as the volume of paper checks fell.
But debit cards face several obstacles, according to Gary S. Roboff, a vice president at Manufacturers Hanover Trust Company and president of the New York Cash Exchange, the largest regional network of teller machines. ''The problem for the industry has been a lack of agreement about how the costs should be shared among merchants, bankers and consumers,'' he said. While Visa and Mastercard have considered a nationwide debit card, neither has promoted the idea aggressively enough. ''No single bank can afford to build its own system alone,'' Mr. Roboff said. ''And merchants' main concern is selling goods, so they want to be sure that whatever system they take will accept everybody,'' not just the customers of a particular bank.
Bankers are not abandoning the effort. In October, the New York Cash Exchange introduced a system of terminals at check-out counters in Wegman's Supermarkets. The terminals accept a wide variety of cards.
But Mr. Anderson of Corestates says that consumers will require more incentives to welcome debit cards. ''It may be necessary to make it economically attractive for consumers to use it, or put another way, economically unattractive not to use it,'' he said. Grocery stores already have some incentives, he added. It costs them 50 cents to process a check, and only slightly less to handle a cash purchase necessitating cash counting, security and insurance. As computers have become cheaper, the cost of processing an electronic payment has fallen to about 25 cents.
For bankers, finally establishing a presence at grocery check-outs is not just a distant dream. If they have their way, the day may be approaching when cash is no longer king.

HEADLINE: 'Open Outcry' Works Well and Cheaply

BYLINE: By Morton Lane; Morton Lane is president of the Discount Corporation of New York Futures. He is a director of the Futures Industry Association.

 BODY:
FOR a number of very basic reasons, I think the open outcry system of trading futures contracts will be with us for a long time to come. The pit system is cheap, efficient and enormously successful. In contrast, the architects of computerized trading systems have yet to show that they can compete economically with the pit system.
Consider: In 1988, the Chicago Board of Trade and the Chicago Mercantile Exchange produced nearly 60 million transactions in the pits on a contract volume of 220 million. Volume is even higher this year, and has grown every single year since financial futures were introduced in 1972. Billions of dollars worth of financial transactions are processed through the system every day. 
The futures pits are both durable and adaptable. The pits in which we trade Eurodollar and Treasury bond futures are simply adaptations of the pits in which Chicago has traded corn and cattle for decades.
The financial world trades futures in massive volume, and it does so because futures are cheaper to trade than the real thing. Perhaps the most striking evidence of this is that primary government securities dealers, who can trade actual Treasury notes and bonds more cheaply than anyone, choose to do nearly one-fourth of all their Treasury bond transactions in the pits in Chicago rather than in their own cash market.
For computers to compete with such a successful mechanism, they must offer better transactions at lower cost. The most obvious of these costs, fees paid by traders to the exchanges, are currently very low. The Chicago exchanges charge members between 20 and 50 cents per contract for each of those 220 million contracts that they trade. Non-member commissions are much higher, but these have been driven down by competition to about one-third of what they were at the beginning of the decade.
Contrast this with early indications of fees on the new electronic exchanges. The semi-automated Tokyo International Financial Futures Exchange recommends customer commissions which are two to three times the rate of existing levels. Globex - the automated system proposed for the Chicago Mercantile Exchange - is expected to increase member fees by several multiples of what they now pay. Given the choice between the pit and the personal computer, I doubt that many will pay extra for the pristine circuitry of computerized trading. A more subtle cost of trading is the bid/ask spread. This is the amount a trader would have to pay to reverse a trade immediately. The spread can also be viewed as what market makers earn in exchange for providing bids and offers.
Futures pits have been remarkably efficient at providing tight bid/ask spreads. Aided by the low exchange fees, traders compete fiercely to provide market-making services. The result is that in the most active commodity pits - the Eurodollar and Treasury bond and note pits - the bid/ask spread is only one tick (the minimum bid possible on the exchange) wide.
Whether the computerized systems can meet the one-tick bid/ask spreads that are available already in the Chicago (and Singapore, for that matter) trading pits is a question that will bedevil the electronic markets. If the traders who compete to provide such markets have to pay more to trade, how can they bid and offer as aggressively as they do in the pits? And if the bid/ask spreads are wider and the bids and offers smaller in the computerized systems, why should anyone trade there? RECOGNITION of this potential flaw in Globex may be the reason behind the Chicago Mercantile Exchange's recent decision to suspend fees for a limited time and for a limited number of large market participants when Globex finally opens next year. If so, they are on the right track, but temporary solutions will not be enough. Finally, there are intangibles that have to be overcome. Locals see the flow of orders and are confident that they are at the center of all such flows. A trader at a terminal will not have as much information. This will increase his risk for which he will need to be compensated. This will again translate in to wider spreads.
I don't mean to suggest that computer trading will not find its niche. It will certainly become cheaper. Nor do I want to suggest that computers cannot help improve the pits by providing certain other functions more efficiently. They already do.
The computer and futures industries have been running on parallel tracks for more than a decade. My guess is that they will continue to march forward together. But I suspect that in the year 2001, when computers are even faster and more powerful, the pits will continue to exist.

HEADLINE: Lifestyle;
Not Everyone Makes Resolutions

BYLINE: By TRISH HALL

 BODY:
For some people the dawn of the century's final decade is not an occasion for cosmic resolutions or personal soul searching.
''I just want to get through it,'' said Susanne Volk, who has made the same vows she makes every year: to get in shape and to pay off her bills. Ms. Volk, who is 27 years old and works as the personal assistant to a rich and famous New Yorker, said the new decade does not coincide with any milestones in her life. ''I'm not 30, I don't have a new job and I'm not getting married,'' she said. She is going to a black-tie dance tonight at the Harvard Club, however, rather than the usual bonfire party with friends. ''It seems more festive,'' she said, ''more memorable.'' 
But for others who were stopped in their holiday wanderings and asked about the New Year, the turn of the last decade of the century is a special time, made more meaningful for some by the recent events in Eastern Europe. ''This year seems like a focal point for change,'' said Christopher Walsh, a 24-year-old accountant at Prudential-Bache Securities who recently moved to New York. ''People are moving together.'' Maybe that will help him carry out his New Year's resolution: he is hoping to meet more people.
 
The Business of the Future
Richard Pait, a captain in the United States Army, said he is excited about the new decade. Because he is convinced that future battles will be economic, he has resolved to go into business when he retires in six years, at the age of 37. ''The shaping of the world will cease to be through military might,'' he said.
Gerard Koch, who is retired from the Museum of Natural History, is glad this decade is ending. ''The '80s were bad, very bad,'' he said. ''There is more hope now than there has been in a long time.'' As for resolutions, however, he has more or less given up on them. ''If I want to do something, I'll do something,'' he said.
Avis Langston, too, is glad to be rid of the 80's, which she associates with ''all those drug problems.'' Of the 90's she said, ''I know this is going to be something different, and I hope it's something good.'' Mrs. Langston, an immigrant from Aruba who lives in Brooklyn and works for Marriott Food Service, also has some hopes that lie closer to home. ''I want to lose 10 pounds, and to do my best for my son, for him to grow up in the right way,'' she said.
Juan Ortega, who works as a security guard for the World Financial Center and lives in Brooklyn with his wife and two sons, is less optimistic. As the decade has progressed, he said, he has seen more grimness in the hundreds of people who cross his path each day. ''Everybody is busy,'' he said. ''They go their own way.'' His life is different. He will spend tonight with his five brothers and four sisters, paying homage to their mother, who died almost two years ago. ''For me it's a special occasion,'' he said. ''We get together and we remember my mother. She was a nice person who helped people.'' There will be food and drinks and talk. ''Some will cry. Some will be quiet,'' he said. ''When you have lost your mother, that is something to remember all your life.''
 
Just Another Work Night
For some people, New Year's is just another work night. Sandy Dehner, who coordinates equipment hookups for Reuters, the news service, has a second job as a waitress, and she'll be working tonight. ''I just want to save money and stop spending so much,'' she said. Ms. Dehner, who is 25, said the 80's was her time to grow up. ''I accomplished all the things I wanted - a job, a car - and now it's time to settle down, get married and have a family,'' she said.
Della Fraites, who has been selling stuffed animals at her daughter's pushcart in the South Street Seaport, said she will spend the evening disassembling the business to meet a midnight deadline. ''That's when our lease runs out,'' she said. ''That's how exciting my New Year's is.''

HEADLINE: WHEAT RIFT SPLITS NIGERIANS AND U.S.

BYLINE: By KENNETH B. NOBLE, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: LAGOS, Nigeria

 BODY:
A bitter trade dispute with the United States over wheat imports is posing a tough challenge for Nigeria's President, Gen. Ibrahim Babangida, and is likely to come up when he visits Washington next month to meet with President Bush.
The dispute arose over Nigeria's decision in 1986 to ban the importing of wheat and other basic food items in an effort to increase domestic food production.
Before the ban, Nigeria spent around $250 million a year on imported wheat, mostly from the United States, making it the sixth-largest market for American wheat. Overall, Nigeria - with more than 100 million people - has usually been the largest market for American goods in black-ruled Africa. 
American officials here in the Nigerian capital have strongly criticized the ban as an unfair trade practice and have warned that the Bush Administration may take retaliatory steps for Nigeria's open refusal to buy American wheat.
''This is going to be the ey issue when Babangida goes to Washington, and there's going to be a lot of effort made to resolve this issue,'' a United States official here said. He added that the Administration is under pressure from Americann farmers' groups to retaliate unless Nigeria soon opens its markets.
 
U.S. Pressure Lacked Subtlety
In the view of Nigerian officials, the dispute has been sharpened by what they consider the impolitic way that American officials here have put pressure on them to end the ban. Nigerian officials were particularly angered by a speech by the former United States Ambassador, Princeton Lyman, who said that the import ban was counterproductive because it encouraged smuggling.
''If Nigeria bans American agricultural products,'' Mr. Lyman said, ''and then smuggles in wheat flour and rice from other sources, the issue becomes much more serious between us.'' He estimated that at least 300,000 tons of smuggled wheat flour and rice are entering the West African country each year.
Citing trade legislation that requires that the Administration report to Congress those countries that discriminate against American imports, Mr. Lyman added, ''Trade sanctions are called for if no redress is possible.''
The Nigerian position has since hardened, and the reasons, many political analysts here say, have less to do with agricultural production than with national pride.
''The Americans miscalculated how important this issue is to us,'' a senior Nigerian diplomat said. ''They don't seem to understand that our primary objective is economic self-sufficiency, and making money for American wheat farmers pales by comparison.''
 
No Edicts for Nigerians
''Nigerians hate more than anything else to have someone come and tell us what to do, or to dictate to us,'' said Akindele Oyebode, a law professor at the University of Lagos. ''That's a great insult.''
In a much-quoted editorial, the official New Nigerian said the ban on wheat imports should be maintained despite the ''threat'' by Ambassador Lyman. ''The fundamental question,'' the editorial argued, is whether Nigeria will be able to ''get rid of the idea of accepting bread as a major consumer item in our basic food.''
Later, the United States Embassy, in an effort to dilute criticism here of American trade policy, issued a statement saying there were no immediate plans to impose trade sanctions. ''There is absolutely no blackmail, subtle or otherwise, intended in the American position,'' the statement said.
In recent weeks, however, in preparation for the President's visit, efforts to resolve the issue have intensified. ''We're at an impasse,'' an American official conceded.
When Nigeria became independent from Britain in 1960, its agricultural products were the prime source of export earnings, and subsistence farming fed many. But the oil boom of the late 1960's and 1970's changed that. It lured millions from the farms and villages to seek riches in the cities. Eventually, oil prices collapsed, but agriculture did not revive.
 
Necessity Breeds Austerity
The growing fragility of Nigeria's economy in the early 1980's prompted the Government to adopt a stringent austerity program. From the beginning, reducing agricultural imports while improving domestic food production was a major element.
So far, according to statistics provided by the Nigerian Government, wheat production has dramatically increased since the import ban - from virtually nothing five years ago to more than 500,000 tons in 1989. During the peak import years, Nigeria bought roughly 1.4 million tons of American wheat a year, in addition to rice, dairy products and sugar.
But Western economists and agricultural experts, in recent interviews, disputed the Government's wheat-production estimates. And a 1989 report by the United States Department of Agriculture called the Nigerian estimates exaggerated and said ''production of over 100,000 metric tons is unlikely.''
''The problem,'' a Western economist said, ''is that the wheat ban is enormously popular here because it seems to be working. And politically, that makes it almost impossible for Babangida to abandon it, lest he appear to be bowing to pressure from the United States.''

HEADLINE: Threatened Northwest Flight Lands Safely

BYLINE: By ERIC WEINER, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: DETROIT, Dec. 30

 BODY:
With fortress-like security thrown up to meet a threatened attack, an almost empty Northwest Airlines jumbo jet from Paris landed here today, uneventfully except for the crush of reporters and television crews assigned to greet the few passengers.
Most of the 130 people originally booked on the plane, a DC-10 that holds 284 passengers, changed their plans after the airline began informing ticket holders on Thursday of a ''security threat'' against the flight.
Flight 51 left Charles de Gaulle Airport this afternoon, delayed two hours because of fog, with only 22 passengers on board, including a public relations representative from Northwest and three reporters. After a nine-hour flight, the plane landed at Detroit's Metro Airport shortly before 5 P.M.
''It went off without a hitch,'' said Robert Gibbons, a company spokesman in Minneapolis. 
Passengers arriving here told of spacious seating, free drinks and a feeling of camaraderie. As they entered the airport they were cornered by reporters who outnumbered family members by at least 2 to 1.
''It was a personal stance for me,'' said Suzanne Chenault of Yosemite, Calif. ''I didn't want to take the easy way out.''
Mr. Gibbons said the airline had given the three cockpit crew members and six flight attendants a chance to switch to another flight, but none did.
Northwest acknowledged the threat and began notifying passengers after the Swedish newspaper Kvallspospen carried accounts of it, Mr. Gibbons said.
 
Action Spurs Debate
Aviation security experts said public disclosure of such threats may become more common, and Northwest's action has spurred debate about the advantages of such warnings.
''Terrorists have this tremendous psychological hold over the American public,'' said Bruce Hoffman, a terrorism expert with the Rand Corporation, a research organization. ''Even by not doing anything, they can cause this panic.''
The airline chose not to cancel the flight but took extra security measures for it and all of its flights between Europe and the United States. Northwest offered to book ticket holders on another flight - even on a competing airline - without any penalty.
Northwest and the Federal Aviation Administration declined to say exactly what extra security measures were taken for the flight.
''It would have been the safest airplane in the world to fly,'' said John Leyden, a spokesman for the aviation agency.
Still, at least one passenger was seen nervously clutching a good-luck charm before boarding the flight in Paris.
Security measures at De Gaulle Airport included bomb-sniffing dogs, the use of sophisticated color X-ray machines and hand-searching to check each piece of luggage. At the airport in Detroit, the plane parked half a mile from the gate and passengers were taken to the terminal by bus.
The British news agency Reuters said the Swedish newspaper, citing security sources, quoted an anonymous caller as saying that the action was planned as revenge for the life sentences given two Palestinians in Sweden last week for bomb attacks in three European cities, including a 1985 bombing of a Northwest office in Copenhagen. Northwest, saying it was acting on the advice of the Federal Bureau of Investigation, would not disclose where the call was received or any other details.
Each year, the airlines receive about 400 anonymous threats, but few are aimed at international flights and even fewer are as specific as the one against Flight 51, said Robert Buckhorn, an F.A.A. spokesman. Airlines have notified ticket holders in the past of bomb threats, but never as publicly or with as much advance notice as Northwest had.
Northwest's move was applauded by families of the victims of the bombing of Pan Am Flight 103 a year ago over Lockerbie, Scotland, in which 270 people died. The families have criticized the airlines and the Government for not warning ticket holders of a threat against the flight.
Two weeks before the crash of the Pan Am flight on Dec. 21, 1988, the United States Embassy in Finland was warned by a telephone caller that a bomb attack might be carried out against a Pan Am flight over Frankfurt. The United States Government then notified airlines, airports and embassies in Europe, but passengers received no word of the threat.
