HEADLINE: H.U.D. Windfall - Subsidies for the Subsidized;
In New York, H.U.D.'s Vouchers Pay for Already Cheap Housing

BYLINE: By MICHAEL WINERIP

 BODY:
The showpiece of the Reagan Administration's housing program was a voucher system, created to give a cash subsidy to poor people so they could choose their own rental housing.
But when the voucher system did not work well in New York City, officials of the Department of Housing and Urban Development, eager to fill their quotas, approved vouchers for about 600 families already living in subsidized housing. Under this double subsidy, the families' already low rents dropped to the point where some are now paying no rent at all.
Most of the 600 families who received the H.U.D. vouchers beginning in 1987 were long-term working-class residents of desirable apartments subsidized by New York State and New York City under the Mitchell-Lama program. Typically, they were paying rents of $250 to $300 before being approved for the H.U.D. vouchers. 
 
Most Pay Less Than $50
An examination of city housing records by The New York Times indicates that two-thirds of the 600 families getting vouchers are paying less than $50 a month in rent as a result; 88 percent are paying less than $100. And 7 percent are paying no rent, just a $38 monthly utility fee.
Through the vouchers, which are good for five years, H.U.D. has been giving almost $2 million a year to 600 New York households that were already subsidized, city records indicate. About 20 percent of the vouchers given out in New York City in 1987 and 1988 went to these families.
At a time when hundreds of thousands of New Yorkers are homeless or living doubled-up with friends or relatives, and when city and state officials are pleading for more Federal housing aid, the sizable double subsidy approved by H.U.D. and city officials has surprised even residents of the buildings where families getting the vouchers live.
''There's a lot of people paying $30 or $40 a month rent now who I know could afford to pay more,'' said Donna Mantin, a teacher who is president of the board of Luna Park, a Mitchell-Lama complex in Brooklyn where about 150 families were issued vouchers. ''This money should go toward other programs and people who could use it more.''
While it is difficult to find anyone who says the double subsidy was the best use of scarce Federal housing dollars, it appears that no laws or H.U.D. rules were broken. But it is clear that a program created to help people find housing ended up being used in New York City to assist people who already had housing.
Starting in 1987, H.U.D. officials nationwide were under tremendous pressure from Washington to make the voucher program succeed. The Reagan Administration had made huge cuts in Federal building programs; the voucher plan was one of the few programs to receive more money. It was tailored to the Administration's free-market philosophy: give poor people a housing stipend that they can use to find an apartment in the location and price range of their choice.
Each of H.U.D's 10 regional offices was given a quota and told to distribute rent stipends as quickly as possible. In fiscal year 1987, the New York regional office was directed to give out 12,000 vouchers.
 
Giving Money Away Proved Difficult
Giving money away sounds easy, but it was a difficult task in New York City, where a typical voucher stipend of $250 a month is far below the true market rents. Eight of every nine families on the New York City public housing waiting list who are offered a voucher return it, unable to use it because rents are so high and vacancy rates so low.
But H.U.D. officials in the New York region were determined to meet their voucher quotas. And they did, partly by approving vouchers for hundreds of people already living in subsidized buildings and partly by using the vast majority of the vouchers outside New York City, in other parts of H.U.D.'s New York regional office, like Puerto Rico and upstate New York.
That vouchers are given to reduce rents so dramatically for people already living in subsidized apartments appeared to surprise several top H.U.D. officials who were told by a reporter. John Dellera, the H.U.D. regional counsel in New York, asked if it was possible that the rents were so low because of a clerical miscalculation.
A H.U.D. official in Washington, hearing examples of rents, said, ''Oh my God, I don't believe it.''
Housing advocates reacted angrily. ''Given the incredible housing need in this city, it's an absurd situation,'' said Steven Banks, director of the New York City Legal Aid Society's Homeless Family Rights Project.
Asked if he knew of anywhere else in the country where vouchers were used in this manner, a H.U.D. spokesman in Washington, William Glavin, said, ''Not that we know of.''
Edmund R. Davis, the deputy regional administrator of H.U.D.'s New York office, acknowledged that the 600 families might have enjoyed ''a windfall.'' Yet these were very poor people, he added, making $6,000 to $12,000 a year, and he said choosing them did not represent a significant misuse of the voucher program. ''It's hardly an earth-shattering issue,'' he said.
Mr. Davis said that if anyone was at fault, it was the New York City Housing Preservation and Development Department, for suggesting these buildings to H.U.D. and for being so slow to use vouchers elsewhere.
The City Housing Commissioner, Abraham Biderman, said the city tried, largely unsuccessfully, to use the vouchers for people who had no housing. The department, which is renovating thousands of abandoned buildings across the city, planned to save the vouchers until those apartments were ready, but that was not fast enough for H.U.D., Mr. Biderman said. He said the Mitchell-Lama buildings were among the few places where the city could use vouchers quickly enough to please H.U.D.
''Would it have been better to make the voucher subsidy less deep and use this money for rehab?'' Mr. Biderman asked. ''Obviously, yes.''
 
H.U.D. Calls $428 A Fair-Market Rent
The voucher program in New York City was aimed at people with very low incomes. To qualify, a family of four can earn a maximum of about $16,000; a single elderly person can earn up to $11,000. To calculate the amount of voucher a recipient is entitled to, the Government first makes an estimate of the local ''fair market rent.'' Then it pays the difference between the fair-market rent and 30 percent of the applicant's income.
The fair-market rent set by H.U.D. for a one-bedroom apartment in New York City in 1987 and 1988 was $428. So if a family's income was $833 a month ($10,000 a year), 30 percent of its income would be $250 a month. The $250 monthly income subtracted from the fair-market rent of $428 would result in a voucher worth $178.
The family then is free to take the $178 voucher and use it for any apartment it can find. If it finds a bargain, it can wind up paying less than the Government standard of 30 percent of its income for rent; if it wants a nicer place, it can pay more.
In New York City, however, there are precious few one-bedroom apartments available for $428 a month that meet H.U.D. quality standards - except in the Mitchell-Lama buildings, with their artificially low rents.
This created a problem for poor people, who kept returning the vouchers unused. It created a problem for H.U.D. officials in New York, who were under pressure to meet voucher quotas set in Washington. And it created a problem for New York City housing officials, who were under pressure from H.U.D. to find some fast use for the vouchers.
''We were trying every way to use vouchers,'' Mr. Biderman said. ''The program just doesn't work in New York City.'' in 1987, Housing Preservation and Development officials came up with the idea of using the vouchers in the Mitchell-Lama buildings. ''We had to use them this way or lose them,'' Mr. Biderman said. ''This way at least we helped people of New York City.''
H.U.D. officials enthusiastically agreed, lending two dozen staff members to the city for several months to calculate which residents would receive the vouchers, a highly unusual move.
Mr. Davis said the H.U.D. staff did most of the certifications because the city was moving too slowly to help find needy people.
 
'People Feel Lucky To Live Here'
Typical of the buildings chosen for vouchers were two in Brooklyn: Lindsay Park in Williamsburg and Luna Park in Coney Island. These are large complexes of 20-story brick buildings put up in the early 1960's with low-interest mortgages and tax abatements from the city and state to make them affordable. Residents tend to be government and office workers or retired people. Virtually none are on welfare.
The apartments are considered highly desirable. The waiting list to get into the 1,587-unit Luna Park complex is eight years, said Mrs. Mantin, the board president. The manager of the Lindsay Park complex, Lou Campbell, said: ''People feel lucky to live here. It's a pretty nice place, really.'' To tour Lindsay Park's seven buildings last week was to see basic, comfortable apartments, immaculately clean hallways and grounds, lobbies decorated for the holidays and six outdoor swimming pools.
It was residents of these buildings who were paying more than 30 percent of their income for rent who were chosen to receive vouchers by city and H.U.D. officials. The housing officials picked Mitchell-Lama buildings that had a higher proportion of poor people.
Before 1987, what H.U.D. would have done in such situations was to issue a certificate to reduce a tenant's rent to 30 percent of his income. If a tenant was making $8,000 a year and paying $270 a month in rent - 40 percent of his income - he would have been issued a certificate for $70, to bring his rent down to $200 a month, 30 percent of his income.
But using the voucher - a tool designed for the free market - in buildings where rents had already been subsidized well below market value created a windfall. Under the voucher program, that same person making $8,000 a year and paying $270 a month for rent would get a voucher for $228 a month. That amount represents the difference between the $428 fair-market rent rate and the $200 that is 30 percent of his income.
Under the voucher system, this person's rent would be reduced to $42, plus a $38 a month utility fee.
 
One-Third Pay $20 or Less in Rent
Through a request filed with the city under the Federal Freedom of Information Act, The Times obtained income and rent information on 113 of the approximately 600 households in the Mitchell-Lama buildings who received vouchers in 1987 and 1988. City officials say they are representative of all 600. The city has about 135,000 Mitchell-Lama units. The residents' identities were not revealed.
All pay a monthly utility fee of $38 for heat and electricity, which is excluded from the calculations. Of the 113 households, a third were paying $20 or less for rent after the voucher and 55 percent were paying $40 or less.
After the voucher, most were paying 10 percent to 15 percent of their income for rent and utilites.
These are some samples from the list:
* A single person in a one-bedroom apartment with an annual income of $5,563, who was paying $258 a month, now pays no rent after the voucher.
* Two people in a one-bedroom apartment with an income of $7,566, who were paying $275, pay $26 after the voucher.
* Two people in a one-bedroom apartment with an income of $11,132, who were paying $245, pay $55 after the voucher.
Even people critical of using vouchers this way emphasize that the recipients in these cases were very-low-income people, who were hardly getting rich off the program. But they say it shows the folly of relying so heavily on one housing program nationwide.
''The voucher program works in Dallas, where you have a high vacancy rate,'' said Robert Hayes, founder of the National Coalition for the Homeless. ''But the way they've used it here reflects a very cynical manipulation.''
''A lot of these people need some subsidy,'' Mrs. Mantin said. ''This just wasn't the way to do it.''
 
Meeting the Quota 'Was an Obsession'
On one point there is wide agreement. Joseph D. Monticciolo, the former administrator of the New York regional office of H.U.D., made it clear that the quota would be met, no matter what, H.U.D. officials said. Throughout 1987, a weeky tally was kept of how many vouchers had been allocated.
''Meeting the voucher goal was an obsession to Mr. Monticciolo,'' said David Burns, H.U.D.'s regional economist in New York. ''The subject used to dominate the weekly meetings with his top staff. He considered this his most important goal and he was going to meet it. It disrupted other work in the office. Many people were diverted.''
Mr. Monticciolo's attorney, Robert Hill Schwartz, did not return repeated phone calls last week. But Mr. Dellera, a H.U.D. spokesman, agreed that there was major pressure in the office and that H.U.D. officials, in turn, pressed the city to use the vouchers quickly.
Officials of several housing authorities in New York State that were issued housing vouchers in the spring of 1987 said they were taken away a few months later because Mr. Monticciolo wrote that the local officials were not moving fast enough to have the vouchers used up by the end of the fiscal year, Sept. 30.
George Lyons, director of the Ellenville Housing Authority, in Ellenville, N.Y., said he was given vouchers in May and had them withdrawn in July, though he felt he could have used them. ''They didn't listen,'' he said. The demand to use the vouchers quickly in 1987 set off a major dispute between H.U.D.'s New York office and the city's Department of Housing Preservation and Development that continues today.
H.U.D. officials say the city dragged its feet on vouchers because it was skeptical of the program and unfamiliar with it. ''You're on the wrong track if you think it's H.U.D.,'' said Mr. Davis of H.U.D. ''H.P.D. has not lifted a finger'' to make the voucher program work, he said.
Mr. Davis noted that over the course of three years, about 2,500 families on the long waiting list of the New York City Housing Authority were able to find apartments using the vouchers. But he acknowledged that those families were a small minority. Eight of nine families that received the vouchers had to return them unused. And Housing Authority officials have criticized the voucher system as unsuitable for New York City.
Whether the city did not try hard enough or the program was ill conceived, New York City families used far less than their share of vouchers than the rest of the H.U.D. New York region. In 1987 and 1988, about 20,000 vouchers were used in the region, which includes New York, New Jersey, Puerto Rico and the Virgin Islands. Fewer than 20 percent of these went to New York City families, although the city's proportionate share of such financing programs in the H.U.D. region is normally twice that, 40 percent.
''Monticciolo put a lot of pressure on the other area offices to make up the shortfall for New York City,'' Mr. Burns said. ''I think the city and state got hurt.''
Mr. Biderman of H.P.D. said the heart of the problem was that Federal funds are really needed to create new affordable housing. Until that happens, he said, vouchers will not have an impact in New York. He pointed out that at the start of the Reagan Administration, the Federal Government was financing ''gut rehabilitation'' of 6,500 units a year in New York City and now is financing a few hundred units a year.
He said the city was slow in using the vouchers because New York officials were hoping to use them in an innovative way. The city's plan was to undertake major renovations of abandoned buildings and save the vouchers to use them as the buildings were opened. But that was nowhere as fast as using them in Mitchell-Lama buildings like Luna Park.
Mrs. Mantin said that when representatives of the Luna Park residents' board started hearing about the unusually low rents, they questioned city housing officials, but were told everything was being done by the rules.
''I guess on paper, it all looks proper,'' she said.

PUB-DATE: December 31, 1989

SECTION: Section 1; Part 1, Page 15, Column 1; Foreign Desk

LENGTH: 1386 words

HEADLINE: Upheaval in the East: Espionage;
It's Still Business as Usual for Spies, Even as the Eastern Bloc Rises Up

BYLINE: By MICHAEL WINES, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Dec. 30

 BODY:
For years, experts have dubbed Czechoslovakia's spy agency the ''two Czech'' service. Agents of the Office for the Protection of State Secrets got one check from Prague, the pun goes, and another from their real bosses at K.G.B. headquarters in Moscow.
The disturbing news from Eastern Europe this winter, American intelligence officials say, is that the punch line has not yet changed.
Despite a democratic revolt that has shaken Communist rule in Czechoslovakia and five other Eastern bloc states, those nations' espionage agencies have not slackened their vigorous efforts to steal Western technology and military secrets, often at Soviet direction, several officials said in interviews.
''We don't see very much indication that any of these countries are diminishing their overseas intelligence activities, with the possible exception of a somewhat greater emphasis on their own interests as opposed to the broader interests of the East bloc,'' a State Department official said. 
 
Infancy of Democratic Revolt
That official and others caution that the democratic revolt is still in its infancy. Eastern bloc spy agencies, they predict, will eventually warm to Western-style government and to inducements, like trade agreements, that will reduce their incentive to spy on the West.
They also agree that the radical changes in the East bloc will eventually cripple the ability of the Soviet Union's primary intelligence agency, the K.G.B., to use its old allies as surrogates in espionage battles between East and West.
''In general, what liaison there was is going to break down further; no question about it,'' said an Administration expert who declined to be identified.
''If I were Kryuchkov I wouldn't be a happy man right now,'' he said. Col. Gen. Vladimir A. Kryuchkov is the K.G.B. chief.
Yet there are few signs that such changes are occurring this winter. On the contrary, several Administration officials and private experts said, the K.G.B. appears in some cases to have stepped up its ''tasking'' of Eastern bloc agencies for specific missions against Western targets.
 
Communists in Control
Of the six nations swept by pressures for democratic change - Bulgaria, Czechoslovakia, Hungary, Poland, Rumania and East Germany - Communists allied with the Soviet Government remain in apparent control of intelligence-related agencies in all but Czechoslovakia and Rumania.
Intelligence experts also noted that there has been but a trickle of defectors from Soviet bloc spy services during the democratic upheaval, although defections usually increase in times of political uncertainty.
Although Central Intelligence Agency officials refused to be interviewed, the Director of Central Intelligence, William H. Webster, said publicly this fall that the warming of East-West relations is stirring an increase in espionage, not a decrease.
In remarks Nov. 29 to the National Press Club, Mr. Webster said it was too early to tell whether Eastern bloc nations would curb their spying on American targets.
''Let us not assume that because we are getting friendly and seeing freedom come up from the streets, that freedom has been endorsed by some of those aggressive intelligence services,'' he said.
 
Well-Founded Concern
Mr. Webster's concern is well-founded, officials say. While the public views espionage as a purely Soviet affair, some of the decade's most damaging spies were recruited and run by the K.G.B.'s East bloc allies.
East German agents managed a ring of spies from 1978 to 1988 inside one of the United States' most sensitive electronic listening posts, atop a wooded hill in West Berlin. The American inquiry into the case has produced one espionage conviction and a guilty plea and is continuing, the Federal Bureau of Investigation said Friday.
Czechoslovak and Polish agents this decade have sought Western military and technological secrets with great success, and Hungarian agents ran a spy network within United States Army installations in Europe that acquired some of NATO's most tightly held war plans.
Much, if not all of that information was sold or given to the Soviets. ''Obviously, these are still countries that had their own interests, but historically the K.G.B. could get access to just about anything they wanted,'' said W. Douglas Gow, the F.B.I.'s new assistant director for counterintelligence.
 
Change Is Unlikely Soon
Mr. Gow and others say they anticipate some easing of the K.G.B.'s grip, but few expect serious change soon. For one thing, they said, the new civilian rulers in some nations - playwrights, coal miners, exiles - are probably too naive or too consumed by economic problems to worry about spying.
''We've often found that changes have taken place in the East bloc countries without any similar changes taking place in those countries' foreign-intelligence-gathering networks,'' said John C. Whitehead, Deputy Secretary of State in the Reagan Administration. ''That's not because the new governments wanted to keep the networks in business, but simply because the new people in office didn't know what was going on in their own services.''
In any case, friends of the Soviet Government appear to control most spying outright through the interior ministries, which generally manage the domestic secret police and espionage.
For example, Poland's Solidarity leadership conceded the Interior Ministry to Communists in what some American officials called a tacit agreement with Mr. Gorbachev to allow a peaceful transfer to democracy.
 
Intelligence in East Berlin
East Germany abolished its Ministry for State Security and its hated secret police, but re-established an intelligence service that will report to Prime Minister Hans Modrow, a Gorbachev favorite.
''No one will be so naive as to think that our country is the only one in the world that can do without intelligence service reconnaissance abroad,'' the East Berlin newspaper National-Zeitung said two weeks ago.
Even in Czechoslovakia, where the Interior Ministry has been moved from Communist control to a troika that includes two leaders of the opposition, American officials say they see no change so far.
Other East bloc nations are likely to feel the same need to spy on the West as long as a vestige of the cold war remains, some experts noted. Zdzislaw M. Rurarz, a former Polish diplomat who defected to the United States in 1981, noted pointedly in an interview that the United States was undoubtedly continuing to spy on the Solidarity-run Government there.
It would be foolish, he said, to expect the Poles not to reciprocate.
 
Two Question Marks
The two question marks are Hungary and Rumania, American officials say. In Rumania, it is unclear whether the Communist or anti-Communist factions of the ruling Council of National Salvation will gain the upper hand, but hatred of Communism runs so deep that many experts doubt that the Communists will prevail.
Hungary's intelligence directorate is Communist-run, but the state has dismantled the Communist Party bureaucracy, leaving it in civilian control. The United States has also warned Hungary that thefts of American technology will kill plans to ease curbs on the legal export of those technologies.
''The Hungarians seem further along than anybody,'' one official said, and have even offered to help prevent the leak of sensitive technologies to hostile countries.
In an apparent bow to American intelligence concerns, Hungary's new Government this fall deported Edward Lee Howard, a turncoat C.I.A. agent who in 1985 helped the K.G.B. destroy much of the agency's Moscow espionage network. The Hungarians have denied deporting Mr. Howard, but American officials confirmed a Los Angeles Times report of the action. 'Net Loss' for the K.G.B. How deeply the K.G.B. will be hurt by the East bloc changes looms as the biggest unanswered question of all.
Roy Godson, head of the Washington-based National Strategy Information Center and a well-known intelligence scholar, called any democratic change ''a net loss'' for Soviet intelligence. But he cautioned against euphoria.
''The Soviets wouldn't have relied on just official cooperation,'' he said. ''It would be surprising if they haven't unilaterally penetrated friendly services with their own agents, too.''
